webTitle: Good and bad

fields.headline: Good and bad
fields.standfirst: Friends of the Earth assesses the various positions of the countries at the Hague, and scrutinises some of the solutions proposed for cutting emissions
fields.trailText: Friends of the Earth assesses the various positions of the countries at the Hague, and scrutinises some of the solutions proposed for cutting emissions.
fields.body:
The EU has adopted a relatively progressive position on most issues. The EU wants to hold the US to the Kyoto agreement, and might therefore make compromises in the Hague.

EU governments may also find their negotiating position weakened by concessions they have made (or may yet make) to fuel tax protesters across the continent.

The USA, Canada, Japan, New Zealand and Australia want to water down the Kyoto treaty. They want other governments to agree to rules that would in fact allow them to increase their emissions of carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels. They hope to make fulfilment of the Kyoto targets as cheap as possible.

The developing countries (G77) are divided on some issues, united on others. China and India are major forces, and the Alliance of Small Island States (Aosis) is trying to get the G77 to stick to strong positions to preserve the Kyoto agreement. Saudi Arabia and other Opec nations want compensation for any potential losses from reduced oil exports.

Sinks

The biosphere and the oceans store and release carbon and are part of the global carbon cycle. However, planting trees rather than reducing emissions from fossil fuels will not save the global climate. The biosphere cannot store all the carbon we could release, which is currently underground in the form of oil, gas and coal. There are huge uncertainties and accounting problems involved with the use of sinks to meet Kyoto targets.

For example, Japan and Canada want rules to allow them not to count increased emissions from cutting down forests, but to include the carbon stored when plantations are grown back on this land.

The USA, Canada and Japan want to use "additional activities" to meet their targets, such as "agroforestry" (which could include the planting of genetically modified tress), "urban greening" and "cropland management". Under the US proposal, the US Kyoto target would effectively be reduced by a quarter.

Friends of the Earth opposed the inclusion of sinks in the Protocol. As they are included now, we argue for accounting rules that will make it impossible for parties to count activities such as normal forest harvesting as climate protection measures.

Flexible mechanisms

Flexible mechanisms were created under the Kyoto agreement to enable industrialised countries to achieve emissions cuts or buy emission "credits" abroad, reducing the need for domestic action.

There are three of these mechanisms: Joint Implementation (JI), the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) and International Emissions Trading (IET).

JI allows projects to reduce emissions in other developed countries (ie deals between Annex 1 countries). The CDM allows for similar projects in developing countries (ie deals between Annex 1 and non-Annex 1 countries). Both those will enable Annex 1 countries to claim emission credits.

IET will allow Annex 1 countries that have achieved emissions reductions over and above those required by their Kyoto target to 'sell' their excess to countries finding it more difficult or expensive to meet their commitments.

The US, Canada and others argue for maximum use of emissions trading. The EU wants a limit to use of the mechanisms, obliging countries to countries meet at least half of their emissions reductions targets through domestic action.

Friends of the Earth wants the majority of reductions to be made at home by the industrialised countries. Annex 1 countries should only be allowed to use the mechanisms for at most one-fifth of their reduction targets.

Joint Implementation (JI)

Here is a typical example of how JI might work. A US company invests in a coal-intensive East European economy, to build a gas-fired power station. Without the US investment, the country would have built a coal-fired power station. Because gas fired stations create less CO2 than coal-fired stations, the new power station would count as a "reduction" in CO2 emissions produced by the US, against its Kyoto target.

It could also be possible for nuclear projects (new reactors or life cycle extensions) to generate carbon credits that could be traded and counted against the Kyoto targets of the investor countries. Nuclear power is not the solution to climate change.

Friends of the Earth wants only clean technologies such as renewables and energy efficiency to qualify as JI projects. Nuclear power in particular must be excluded and the use of sinks projects must be restricted. All projects must ensure public participation and transparency.

Carbon trading

As things stand, OECD countries could buy about 150m tonnes of carbon per year from countries like Russia and the Ukraine. This is because many former communist countries are producing far less CO2 than their Kyoto targets would permit, following the collapse of their economies in the transition period. The US and others want rules which allow unlimited access to such "hot air" trading, with the intention of avoiding domestic action as far as possible.

Supplementarity

The European Union has proposed that a minimum 50% of Kyoto targets should be achieved through domestic action by Annex 1 countries. The US and others are resisting this proposal.

Friends of the Earth and other environmentalists would like to see at least an 80% requirement for domestic action. The economies of the developed countries must be greened if action to fight climate change is to be effective in the long term.

Compliance

It is crucial that Kyoto obligations be enforced. Otherwise the targets will lose all credibility. Japan and Russia are currently opposing binding consequences altogether. The USA and others want "borrowing".

Countries that do not fulfil their obligations would able to deduct the excess emissions from their next commitment period budget, without further sanctions.

The EU suggests a "compliance fund" which would mean that countries have to pay money into a fund which would then be used to either buy credits abroad or to implement real reduction projects.

Solutions

Climate scientists have suggested that atmospheric CO2 concentrations should be kept below 450ppm, or approximately twice pre-industrial concentrations, in order to avoid catastrophic consequences. This will require first stabilisation, and then substantial reduction of global CO2 emissions from current levels.

Friends of the Earth argues that to achieve this, industrialised countries must make deep cuts in their greenhouse gas emissions, of up to 90% by 2050.

Developed countries will need to switch from dependence on fossil fuels to investment in renewable energy sources and energy efficiency measures. Less developed countries must be supported in achieving development through sustainable means.

Useful link

Friends of the Earth

webTitle: Milly's application

fields.headline: Milly's application
fields.trailText: Whether you're interested in me or not I will still travel round the world as my ambition is to see everything everywhere, or at least as close as you can get in a lifetime.
fields.body:
Dear Guardian/Sir/Madam,

There are so many reasons why I'd make a great NetJetter it's hard to know where to begin, so I'll write how I always do, which is all my ideas as I think of them and in no particular order. It makes a better letter anyway.

I have just finished my A levels. I'd always planned to take a gap year after them, and as they went well I definitely will. I don't care if they say exams are getting easier, I still need a year out after them. Whether you're interested in me or not I will still travel round the world as my ambition is to see everything everywhere, or at least as close as you can get in a lifetime. So I already have plans and sort of know what I'm doing, which makes it easier for you - and I've already started saving. Kind of.

When I say I've already planned my gap year I mean that very loosely. You see, the difference between me and other people is that I deliberately have no set plans - I want to take every day as it comes and not be tied to any type of voluntary scheme. I don't want to teach English in foreign countries or conserve forests although I'm sure there are many good reasons to do it.

This is one of the few chances in my life to just travel and enjoy different people and different countries without any pressure. I can be free to do what I want - I'm sure that's a song - and I can share that with everyone who's stuck in boring jobs etc. and maybe encourage them to live their life a bit and get out and see the world.

Now I've got all carried away, you can see why I'd be a good Netjetter. What I'm doing will appeal to all the people out there who would love to do nothing for a year. And there's loads of us. Because I'm going out with not much idea of what I'm going to meet - I've never been out of Europe before - I can write back with all the opportunities and challenges and handy tips I pick up. There have been too many bad stories about backpacking recently so anything other travellers can pick up to help them are really useful, I know. I've been looking into it and there's a lot about voluntary schemes and not enough about people like me. So I'm here to fill the gap!!!!

I know exactly where I want to go:
CANADA > HAWAII > AUSTRALIA (you have to go there) > BALI > SINGAPORE > HONG KONG

That's where I'm going whether I fund it or I get a little help from my friends. (Well, you would be). It's a pretty standard round the world style route, I've been told. But it's still really ecxiting. They do polar bear swims in Vancouver on New Year's Day, did you know? I'll also be travelling with a friend, but if you choose me I'd be doing the first month alone so you'd get both experiences, as in, single girl and girls in a group. That'd be two people's point of view so you get 2 for the price of 1. Bargain. And that way I can be in the photos. Not such a bargain!

Anyway I think I'm near 500 words, or at least I'm starting to ramble so I'll leave you with the thought that I may not exactly be a professional writer but I'm honest and excitable and I'm planning to have a lot of fun and experiences that would interest your readers. Or at least, my mum will read them so that's 1 guaranteed!

I hope this email has kept you glued up until the end.

Yours with a world of hope,
Milly Newman

webTitle: The world as we knew it

fields.headline: The world as we knew it
fields.standfirst: Friends of the Earth explains why climate change occurs, and what will happen if we let it continue unchecked
fields.trailText: Friends of the Earth explains why climate change occurs, and what will happen if we let it continue unchecked
fields.body:
The most important climate summit yet starts in the Hague on Monday November 13. It is expected to last for two weeks. The summit could be the last chance to rescue the historic international agreement signed in Kyoto in 1997, which committed the world's Governments - and developed countries in particular - to making cuts in greenhouse gas emissions.

Meanwhile, severe weather events, which are getting more frequent as man-made climate change takes hold, are killing and destroying property across the planet. Recent months have seen climate disasters in Cambodia, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Switzerland, the UK and the United States. The people of the world are already paying a high price for the failures of their politicians and the greed of large companies.

The science of climate change

Most of the energy that reaches us from the sun in the form of short wave radiation arrives undisturbed at the earth's surface and warms it. Much of this energy is emitted back into space in the form of long wave radiation, but some of this radiation is trapped in the atmosphere by a blanket of water vapour and trace gases called 'greenhouse gases'. Without this natural greenhouse effect, the earth would be about 30°C colder than it is today.

The main naturally occurring greenhouse gases are water vapour, carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N2O). Additional greenhouse gases are released by industrial processes: artificial chemicals called halocarbons (CFCs, HFCs, PFCs) and long-lived gases such as sulphur hexafluoride (SF6).

Carbon dioxide is the most important greenhouse gas generated by mankind, accounting for about two thirds of the human-induced greenhouse effect.

Plants and animals have exchanged carbon dioxide with the atmosphere in a carbon cycle that has remained in balance for the last 10,000 years. However, since the industrial revolution, human activities have disturbed this balance mainly through burning fossil fuels (oil, coal and gas) which produces CO2, the destruction of forests, which releases stored carbon, and the intensive rearing of cattle and high scale plantation of rice, which produces methane.

Carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere have increased by about 30% in the last 200 years, from less than 280 parts per million (ppm) to 368 ppm today.

If we continue to burn fossil fuels at our current rate, atmospheric carbon dioxide will be twice pre-industrial levels by 2030, and three times that figure by 2100.

It's getting warmer

As concentrations of greenhouse gases rise, the earth's atmosphere is warming up.

The global average temperature has risen by almost 0.7°C over the last century, very probably as a result of human activity. This is a rate of warming faster than at any time in 10,000 years!

The 1990s were the warmest decade, and the 1900s the warmest century of the last 1000 years. 1998 was the warmest year globally in the instrumental record.

According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the authoritative group of world scientists which advises governments, global temperature may rise 1-3.5°C by the year 2100. This may not seem a great deal, but should be compared with the rise in temperature since the last ice age of only 3-5°C.

Even if greenhouse gas emissions were stabilised today, atmospheric temperature would continue to rise because of the long life time of greenhouse gases.

Warmer, but not nicer

Climate change is likely to have a significant impact on the global environment.

Precise consequences of global warming for individual countries or regions are difficult to predict, due to the enormous complexity of the global climate system. But in general, the faster the climate changes, the greater will be the risk of damage.

Sea level will rise due to thermal expansion of sea water, and the melting of glaciers and ice caps. A rise in sea level of 15-95 cm is expected by 2100. This will threaten low-lying coastal areas around the globe, and may lead to up to 100 million people being flooded each year, particularly in the countries of southern and South East Asia.

It may also lead to the disappearance of some small island states, such as the Maldives which have an average height of about 1.5m above sea level.

Climatic zones, and thus ecosystems and agricultural zones, will shift towards the poles as temperatures rise. In some cases shifts could be up to 300km per degree Celsius. Forests, deserts, rangelands, and other unmanaged ecosystems will face new climatic stresses. Many ecosystems will decline or fragment, and individual species which are not able to adapt or migrate will become extinct.

Coral reefs are an example of an ecosystem already exhibiting signs of major damage. Severe bleaching of corals worldwide has occurred as a result of warmer surface water temperatures.

Arctic sea ice has thinned dramatically since the 1960s and 70s - nearly 40% in less than 30 years - threatening the variety of species it supports including polar bears .

The Worldwide Fund for Nature predicts that by 2100 up to one third of natural habitats may be destroyed by climate change. We may have already witnessed the first documented example of species extinction due to climate change. As a result of changing rainfall patterns, the golden toad has disappeared from the cloud forests of Costa Rica.

Forests and agriculture

Increased levels of CO2 will initially lead to increased plant growth and expansion of forests in some areas. But climate change may lead to very significant dieback of the forests of the Amazon and Africa.

Patterns of agriculture will need to change as farmers adopt different crops to respond to new growing conditions. Africa in particular is likely to be severely affected by lower cropyields leading to greater risk of famine.

Regional cooling

As average global temperatures rise, some regional temperatures may fall due to changes in ocean circulation. One example is the North Atlantic Ocean circulation. The gulf stream carries warming waters from the Caribbean to the shores of northern Europe. A reduction of these ocean currents could lead to significant cooling.

Changing weather patterns are predicted across the globe. Availability of water is particularly important. Although we don't understand enough about the climate to make specific predictions for small geographical areas, climate models suggest that in areas where water availability is currently low, rainfall will decrease, while wetter areas can expect higher rainfall. Overall this will mean increased likelihood of floods and droughts worldwide.

A warmer globe means more energy in the climate system, fuelling phenomena such as hurricanes, and the cyclical event known as El Niño which affects the climate all around the globe. The frequency of El Niño events appears to be increasing from every 6 years, to 3.5 years and leading to ever more extreme weather events.

The consequences of stronger and more frequent weather events are severe: according to the Red Cross, in 1998 (an El Niño year), there were more refugees from natural disasters than from armed conflict, and the cost of these disasters was put at $65.5bn (about £47.5bn).

Health impacts

Changing regional climates may lead to increase in the spread of disease, especially insect-borne diseases such as malaria, dengue fever, tick-borne encephalitis, and leishmaniasis. Up to 300m more people worldwide could be at risk of the dangerous falciparum malaria, particularly in China and Central Asia.

Some diseases could become more prevalent as a consequence of extreme weather events and the resulting destruction of infrastructure, such as cholera, typhoid, malaria and dengue fever.

Effects on society

Human society will face new risks and pressures. Some regions are likely to experience food shortages. Water resources will be affected as precipitation and evaporation patterns change around the world, and this may lead to conflict as nations compete for limited water supplies. Physical infrastructure will be damaged, particularly by sea-level rise and by extreme weather events. Economic activities, human settlements, and human health will experience many direct and indirect effects. The poor and disadvantaged are the most vulnerable to the negative consequences of climate change.

Friends of the Earth

Arctic sea ice has thinned dramatically since the 1960s and 70s - nearly 40% in less than 30 years - threatening the variety of species it supports including polar bears . The Worldwide Fund for Nature predicts that by 2100 up to one third of natural habitats may be destroyed by climate change. We may have already witnessed the first documented example of species extinction due to climate change. As a result of changing rainfall patterns, the golden toad has disappeared from the cloud forests of Costa Rica. Forests and agriculture Increased levels of CO2 will initially lead to increased plant growth and expansion of forests in some areas. But climate change may lead to very significant dieback of the forests of the Amazon and Africa. Patterns of agriculture will need to change as farmers adopt different crops to respond to new growing conditions. Africa in particular is likely to be severely affected by lower cropyields leading to greater risk of famine. Regional cooling As average global temperatures rise, some regional temperatures may fall due to changes in ocean circulation. One example is the North Atlantic Ocean circulation. The gulf stream carries warming waters from the Caribbean to the shores of northern Europe. A reduction of these ocean currents could lead to significant cooling. Changing weather patterns are predicted across the globe. Availability of water is particularly important. Although we don't understand enough about the climate to make specific predictions for small geographical areas, climate models suggest that in areas where water availability is currently low, rainfall will decrease, while wetter areas can expect higher rainfall. Overall this will mean increased likelihood of floods and droughts worldwide. A warmer globe means more energy in the climate system, fuelling phenomena such as hurricanes, and the cyclical event known as El Niño which affects the climate all around the globe. The frequency of El Niño events appears to be increasing from every 6 years, to 3.5 years and leading to ever more extreme weather events. The consequences of stronger and more frequent weather events are severe: according to the Red Cross, in 1998 (an El Niño year), there were more refugees from natural disasters than from armed conflict, and the cost of these disasters was put at $65.5bn (about £47.5bn). Health impacts Changing regional climates may lead to increase in the spread of disease, especially insect-borne diseases such as malaria, dengue fever, tick-borne encephalitis, and leishmaniasis. Up to 300m more people worldwide could be at risk of the dangerous falciparum malaria, particularly in China and Central Asia. Some diseases could become more prevalent as a consequence of extreme weather events and the resulting destruction of infrastructure, such as cholera, typhoid, malaria and dengue fever. Effects on society Human society will face new risks and pressures. Some regions are likely to experience food shortages. Water resources will be affected as precipitation and evaporation patterns change around the world, and this may lead to conflict as nations compete for limited water supplies. Physical infrastructure will be damaged, particularly by sea-level rise and by extreme weather events. Economic activities, human settlements, and human health will experience many direct and indirect effects. The poor and disadvantaged are the most vulnerable to the negative consequences of climate change. Useful link Friends of the Earth

webTitle: Sam's application

fields.headline: Sam's application
fields.trailText: "I'm a civil servant working in the press office of a major government department with my soul slowly being eaten away. I'm tired of defending some minister for going on a factfinding visit to a far off country when the most travel I get is on the Northern Line. I want to see the world too..."
fields.body:
When I saw your Netjetters advert it was like the light at the end of a tunnel, an escape.

I'm a civil servant working in the press office of a major government department with my soul slowly being eaten away. I spend my day rushing to obey the every whim of assorted politicians and dealing with journalists asking silly questions (not from the Guardian of course - they are always a delight to talk to). I'm tired of defending some minister for going on a factfinding visit to a far off country when the most travel I get is on the Northern Line. I want to see the world too.

Mind you, I'm not very adept at travelling. The longest I have been away is a few weeks in Europe just before university. My photos from that summer remind me of hot, tiring journeys, noise, confusion and living off cheese baguettes. But despite the lack of sleep, the hunger and the ground-opening teenage embarrassment that comes from having a group of Spanish girls giggling at your accent, I thought it was great. I loved arriving in a new place by train and stepping out in the early morning light to explore. I loved how everything was different and strange; how simple things like ordering a coffee would turn into a frenzy of arm-waving and arguments. And I loved talking to new people who always seemed pleased to meet me and keen to show me their country - apart from that ticket collector in Rome who was very rude.

Where would I go? I'd go to Africa to live in a treehouse above roaring lions and ponderous elephants. I'd go to Vietnam to travel down a slow, wide river in a small boat surrounded by chattering rainforests. I'd go to the Middle East to be woken up by the call to prayer echoing across the city. I'd go to the Andes to snowboard on glaciers. I'd go to North America to travel by train through mountains and by lakes. I'd go to all these places but I know the most fun would come in the places I never planned to be in.

And you say I get to tell everyone what a great time I'm having? Well, I would try to inspire everyone who is stuck in a job which frustrates them but that they cannot see a way out of. I would show them the amazing places they could be.

I had enough trouble getting around Europe in six weeks so I can't imagine why I want to go round the world in six months. I know it would be wonderful and awful, exciting and dull and I know it would change me completely. So please pick me.

I'm not too sure how I will get on without my civil service umbrella - but then I've heard it doesn't rain so much abroad.

Lots of love

Sam

webTitle: Aussies get in a tangle over 'racist' nicknames

fields.headline: Aussies get in a tangle over 'racist' nicknames
fields.standfirst: Across the country, they love their epithets. But you better be white if you decide to call someone a "nigger", even if it's yourself, as Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: Across the country, they love their epithets. But you better be white if you decide to call someone a "nigger", even if it's yourself, as Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
After "sorry", a word the Australian prime minister John Howard still refuses to utter to the country's Aborigines, the most contentious word in Australia at the moment is probably "nigger".

A tale of two nicknames unfolded last week. As a white judge ruled that it was okay for whites to call another white man "nigger", a black activist was under fire from whites for naming himself the politicians' "pet nigger".

On Friday, a federal court judge said that a Queensland sports ground, with a stand that was named after local rugby player ES "Nigger" Brown in the 1960s, did not contravene Australia's racial discrimination laws.

The trustees of Toowooba's Athletic Oval said that the stand commemorated Edwin "Nigger" Brown, the town's first international rugby league player, who toured Britain in the 1920s.

"Nigger" Brown, who died in 1972, was white, not Aborigine. Local whites said he had earned his "ironic" nickname because of his extremely fair complexion and incongruous surname.

The judge accepted that the use of "nigger" could be racist, but ruled that it was not in this context, striking out a claim by a local Aborigine, Stephen Hagan, that the sign was offensive.

Implying that no stone mason could be racist, the judge noted that even Mr Brown's gravestone bore the words Edward Stanley "Nigger" Brown.

Meanwhile, several thousand kilometres north west of Toowoomba, in the arid north of Australia's "top end", another man with a contentious nickname, Tracker Tilmouth, stirred up anger in the Northern Territory branch of the Labour party.

Mr Tilmouth was nicknamed "Tracker" years ago by a fellow Aboriginal politician, because his initials, LBT, spelt out "little black Tracker".

It was a joke: since European settlement, whites have exploited Aborigines for their hunting skills, forcing them to track down everything from stray bullocks to escaped prisoners.

Now Tracker was truly domesticated - more like Labour's "pet nigger", he told a local newspaper. "I'm allowed to mow the lawns, but I'm not allowed on the veranda," he explained, criticising Labour for marginalising its Aboriginal members, choosing non-Aboriginal candidates and failing to act in the interests of Aborigines.

He warned that, in future elections, the Labour party could not continue to rely on the black vote in the region.

Local Labour politicians were furious. "In today's Australia, the only Aboriginal people treated, to use Tracker's most unfortunate expression, as pet niggers, are people who allow themselves to be treated like that," said former Northern Territory senator Bob Collins.

"I just put it down to Tracker and his colourful language," said Northern Territory Labour leader Clare Martin dismissively.

Political friends of Mr Tilmouth suggest his frustration at the lack of headway Aborigines are making in Australia's white-dominated political institutions simply got the better of him.

He was widely tipped to become a Labour senator three years ago, but was opposed by factions in the NT Labour party. One of those who was reported to have blocked his nomination was Mr Collins.

Aborigines make up a third of the Northern Territory's population. Two of Labour's seven politicians in the 25-member legislative assembly are Aboriginal, but the party is stuck in permanent opposition and there are no other Aboriginal members in the assembly.

The state, governed by the conservative Country Liberal party, is famous for its mandatory sentencing laws, which lead to the "zero tolerance" jailing of many Aborigines for minor offences.

For instance, last week, an Aboriginal man was jailed for 14 days in the Northern Territory for stealing a six-pack of beer while drunk two-and-a-half years ago.

Nationally, there are more than 400,000 Aborigines in Australia, just over 2% of the country's population.

But none of the current federal government or the Labour opposition are Aboriginal. Black judges are also practically unheard of.

So the name game goes on. "You look at it in a couple of contexts," said one local Aborigine, Wally McCarthy, during the long-running Toowoomba sports ground saga.

"We use 'nigger' a lot. You know, we've got black people that we call 'nigger'... [but] I'm 65 and I'll fight if somebody calls me 'nigger'."

However, the absence of Aborigines at the apex of Australian society underlines that it is more commonly white judges and white politicians who determine when "nigger" is nice and when it is nasty.

webTitle: ITC rebukes Channel 4

fields.headline: Foul-mouthed technicians earn Channel 4 reprimand
fields.trailText: 8am: Foul-mouthed Channel 4 technicians were criticised by the ITC after they were caught swearing at this year's Party in the Park. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Foul-mouthed Channel 4 technicians have earned the channel a slapped wrist from TV watchdogs after they were caught swearing during the broadcast of this year's Party in the Park.

Five viewers complained to the Independent Television Commission about two uses of four-letter words during Channel 4's T4 coverage of the Capital Radio event, which went out at 12.30pm.

Viewers were treated to shouted instructions next to an open mike during the live broadcast.

Channel 4 protested that the event had a "previously unblemished" record for strong language and said they had taken steps to prevent the accidental broadcasting of bad language.

Nevertheless the ITC found Channel 4 in breach of section 1.4 of its programme code, which bans "profanity" before the 9pm watershed.

MTV got itself into hot water after Iggy Pop and Boyzone's Shane Lynch uttered a string of expletives on its annual MTV Music Awards, some of which went out before the watershed.

MTV said that it was impossible to prevent bad language altogether.

Channel 5's raunchy show, X Certificate, also came under fire for the explicit nature of its clips.

The broadcaster argued that it was a late-night show and that the material shown was available in video shops. But the ITC still found some scenes offensive.

The ITC's findings come in the wake of the resignation of Lord Holme, chief executive of the other broadcasting watchdog, the Broadcasting Standards Commission, following News of the World revelations about his private life.

webTitle: In brief, 6pm: Sheen frets about Bush Jr and the bottle

fields.headline: Sheen frets about Bush Jr and the bottle
fields.trailText: Plus: Ron Howard's a tough nepotist; celebrity restaurant markets reels as Don Johnson and Danny Glover enter the fray; and cyber-Scooby promised for new film
fields.body:
 Concerned Martin Sheen told a group at a Californian treatment centre that George W Bush is a "white-knuckle drunk" and he was worried that that the presidential candidate never received counselling for his arrest in 1976 for drunken driving, reports Associated Press. "He's still in denial about it," said Sheen, a recovering substance abuser himself, "You have got to be in a program. I did not make up the rules about that". Throughout his campaign, Bush had deflected questions about the incident admitting he made mistakes in his youth and claiming he gave up alcohol when he was 40.

 Tough dad and film director Ron Howard has admitted he feels guilty about only letting three out of his four children appear in the latest Jim Carrey feature, How the Grinch Stole Chrismas. He refused to let one of his daughters appear in the film, based on the children's books by Doctor Seuss, because her school grades were not up to scratch. He says: "Those were the rules there were tears several nights but I made it up to her by letting her sing in the chorus on the soundtrack." The former Happy Days star also created roles for his dad, his brother and his wife in the film, which is released here on December 1.

 It seems you're nobody in Hollywood these days unless you own a restaurant. Don Johnson and Danny Glover have both opened eateries recently: Johnson's is a Vietnamese restaurant called Ana Mandare in San Francisco and Glover's a fast food joint called Hollywood Fries in Los Angeles. It is also rumoured Kevin Costner and Robert Wagner are to go into the catering business together, but biggest of all is the golf-themed restaurant Cameron Diaz, Gloria Estefan and Jennifer Lopez are opening in Atlanta, Georgia later this month.

 Scooby Doo will be completely computer-generated in the forthcoming adaptation of the loopy 60s kids' cartoon, according to Ain't It Cool. Director Raja Gosnell apparently confirmed in a recent panel meeting that the easily startled canine will join Roger Rabbit, Jar-Jar Binks, Rocky and Bullwinkle in the illustrious ranks of stupid-voiced animated animals in live-action films.

webTitle: Fight for two nations in one city

fields.headline: Fight for two nations in one city
fields.trailText: Friends of the late Donald Dewar like to tell how he would go to the edge of his Glasgow constituency, Anniesland, to remind himself what he stood for. On one side lay Bearsden, a desirable suburb. On the other lay Drumchapel, a bleak housing estate, that formed the main part of his seat.
fields.body:
Friends of the late Donald Dewar like to tell how he would go to the edge of his Glasgow constituency, Anniesland, to remind himself what he stood for. On one side lay Bearsden, a desirable suburb. On the other lay Drumchapel, a bleak housing estate, that formed the main part of his seat.

Two nations in one city; health, education and opportunity determined by a separation of a few hundred yards of park. It was a divide that drove Mr Dewar, and will play a large role in deciding who succeeds him in Anniesland.

The byelection on November 23 will be a double-header because Mr Dewar held seats at both Westminster and in the Scottish parliament. On paper it should be straightforward. He had a 15,000 majority for Westminster and an 11,000 majority for Holyrood, and his standing in the constituency was immense. In the old days, when it was called Garscadden, it was said you did not count Labour votes, you weighed them.

"Nothing is guaranteed," said John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde University. "You can't assume people will vote Labour out of affection for Donald Dewar. He had a personal vote - so in a sense that makes it less safe for Labour, because that will disappear. People will vote on the candidates in front of them and what they think of the issues that affect them and the constituency."

Anniesland occupies the north-west corner of Glasgow. It has upmarket enclaves, Kelvinside and Jordanhill, but is typified by council estates and established working class neighbourhoods. It has the second highest proportion of over-55s in Scotland, and has come close to the top in UK-wide surveys of poverty and ill-health. Analysts say the issues will be as they have always been: jobs, pensions, housing, social justice.

"Anniesland raises the whole question of whether or not Labour can reconnect with some of its core supporters," said Mr Curtice. "The party will want to stem the decline in its vote."

It is an awkward fight for Labour, and the party's campaign has played heavily on the theme of following in Mr Dewar's footsteps. On Friday Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, flew up from London to chat with pensioners, play carpet bowls, and eat in the supermarket cafe where Mr Dewar dined.

Labour's Westminster candidate is his former election agent, John Robertson; the Holyrood hopeful is Bill Butler, a Glasgow councillor and left-winger whose wife, Patricia Ferguson, is MSP for the neighbouring constituency of Glasgow Maryhill and deputy presiding officer at Holyrood.

Mr Butler, 44, has faced awkward questions as to the authenticity of his leftist credentials after his support for the proposed transfer of council homes to housing associations, widely opposed among Glasgow housing groups.

"The Labour party is a democratic party. I will have my say, we will draw up a political position, and then I will go out there and fight for party policy," he says. "I think those categories of old and new Labour are slightly passé. I see myself as middle-aged Labour."

He rejects predictions of a harder fight for Labour, which has taken a pounding in Scottish polls.

"I don't see either of these fights as easy. We are confident but not complacent. We are going to fight for every vote. We are fighting on social justice, the bread-and-butter issues that Donald would have wanted. And Donald would have said you have got to get on with it."

The Scottish National Party has lost no time in doing so, and poll pundits say that, despite the odds, Anniesland is within its grasp - requiring a 22% swing to take the Westminster seat and a 19.5% swing for the Holyrood seat, feats that it has managed elsewhere. In Hamilton South the SNP nearly took George Robertson's seat with a 22.5% swing.

"Very big swings are required, but the SNP has shown itself capable of doing that in a byelection," said Malcolm Dickson, a Glasgow polling analyst. "They have also shown they can be a very effective campaigning machine. No one should imagine it's cut and dried."

SNP officials say they are confident they can deliver an upset. "Labour has let Anniesland down, both from Westminster and Holyrood," said campaign officer Calum Smith. "Look at statistics regarding health, and the concern over the housing stock transfer. There is a feeling of alienation here - we can address that."

Tom Chalmers, the SNP's Holyrood candidate and a local lawyer, said they had been encouraged by the response of constituents and sensed a real desire for a change.

In the constituency itself, however, there seems little heart for an all-out political fight in a byelection that no one wanted. At the Drumchapel disabled action group, a body with close links to Mr Dewar, chairman Andrew McNaught worried that Anniesland would never find another politician to match him.

"It may be a Labour stronghold, but they are going to have to do a lot of work to try to convince the electorate that these are the men to take over Donald's mantle," he said. "I don't think they will have the rapport with the electorate that Donald had. He came here a lot, and he used to say he didn't feel that our opportunities should be any less because of where we lived. You felt he meant it. You felt he was one of us."
1997 general election result
Donald Dewar (below) Lab 20,951 William Wilson SNP 5,797 Andrew Brocklehurst C 3,881 Christopher McGinty LD 2,453 Labour majority 15,154 But past loyalty and respect for the dead do not win ballots. The former Labour leader, John Smith, left a 15,700 majority in Monklands East when he died, and Labour barely held it with a 1,600 lead.

Labour's Westminster candidate is his former election agent, John Robertson; the Holyrood hopeful is Bill Butler, a Glasgow councillor and left-winger whose wife, Patricia Ferguson, is MSP for the neighbouring constituency of Glasgow Maryhill and deputy presiding officer at Holyrood. Mr Butler, 44, has faced awkward questions as to the authenticity of his leftist credentials after his support for the proposed transfer of council homes to housing associations, widely opposed among Glasgow housing groups. "The Labour party is a democratic party. I will have my say, we will draw up a political position, and then I will go out there and fight for party policy," he says. "I think those categories of old and new Labour are slightly passé. I see myself as middle-aged Labour." He rejects predictions of a harder fight for Labour, which has taken a pounding in Scottish polls. "I don't see either of these fights as easy. We are confident but not complacent. We are going to fight for every vote. We are fighting on social justice, the bread-and-butter issues that Donald would have wanted. And Donald would have said you have got to get on with it." The Scottish National Party has lost no time in doing so, and poll pundits say that, despite the odds, Anniesland is within its grasp - requiring a 22% swing to take the Westminster seat and a 19.5% swing for the Holyrood seat, feats that it has managed elsewhere. In Hamilton South the SNP nearly took George Robertson's seat with a 22.5% swing. "Very big swings are required, but the SNP has shown itself capable of doing that in a byelection," said Malcolm Dickson, a Glasgow polling analyst. "They have also shown they can be a very effective campaigning machine. No one should imagine it's cut and dried." SNP officials say they are confident they can deliver an upset. "Labour has let Anniesland down, both from Westminster and Holyrood," said campaign officer Calum Smith. "Look at statistics regarding health, and the concern over the housing stock transfer. There is a feeling of alienation here - we can address that." Tom Chalmers, the SNP's Holyrood candidate and a local lawyer, said they had been encouraged by the response of constituents and sensed a real desire for a change. In the constituency itself, however, there seems little heart for an all-out political fight in a byelection that no one wanted. At the Drumchapel disabled action group, a body with close links to Mr Dewar, chairman Andrew McNaught worried that Anniesland would never find another politician to match him. "It may be a Labour stronghold, but they are going to have to do a lot of work to try to convince the electorate that these are the men to take over Donald's mantle," he said. "I don't think they will have the rapport with the electorate that Donald had. He came here a lot, and he used to say he didn't feel that our opportunities should be any less because of where we lived. You felt he meant it. You felt he was one of us." 1997 general election result Donald Dewar (below) Lab 20,951 William Wilson SNP 5,797 Andrew Brocklehurst C 3,881 Christopher McGinty LD 2,453 Labour majority 15,154 But past loyalty and respect for the dead do not win ballots. The former Labour leader, John Smith, left a 15,700 majority in Monklands East when he died, and Labour barely held it with a 1,600 lead.

webTitle: Malesani seizes the day

fields.headline: Malesani seizes the day
fields.trailText: Two weeks ago, Alberto Malesani was a dead man walking. His big-name Parma side - Buffon, Thuram, Cannavaro et al - were clamped to the lower half of Serie A, without a win in their opening three games, and Malesani's bloodshot eyes betrayed the pressure he was facing. "In the last days I haven't slept very well," he wearily explained. "But this doesn't mean that I'm going to surrender. I want to stay here."
fields.body:
Two weeks ago, Alberto Malesani was a dead man walking. His big-name Parma side - Buffon, Thuram, Cannavaro et al - were clamped to the lower half of Serie A, without a win in their opening three games, and Malesani's bloodshot eyes betrayed the pressure he was facing. "In the last days I haven't slept very well," he wearily explained. "But this doesn't mean that I'm going to surrender. I want to stay here."

After successive wins against Milan and Bari, Malesani was entitled to feel more relaxed about his situation. The vultures had stopped circling. He was safe. And then on Saturday he nearly died. The Parma coach was on the way back from training when he lost control of his car on the motorway. In the resulting crash, he fractured his collar bone and had to be airlifted to hospital. But not even a close encounter with the grim reaper could stop the indefatigable Malesani. "I stared death in the face but tomorrow I'll be back on the bench," he defiantly told reporters from hospital. And so he was.

And Parma were able to display the same stubborn qualities as their coach, as they edged past Serie A leaders Udinese with two goals in the last six minutes.

Malesani's side, inspired by Portuguese winger Sergio Conceicao, were dominant throughout. The only problem was they couldn't score. In form Patrick Mbomba missed chance after chance, as did - perhaps less surprisingly - Savo Milosevic. But just as in their previous two games, Parma found a way to win right at the death.

Sabri Lamouchi broke the stalemate six minutes from time, driving his shot home off the inside of the post. And then in injury time, French playmaker Johan Micoud capped an excellent display with a 25-yard curler, leaving Malesani ecstatic at the 2-0 victory. "When we play like this I think we can win against every team," he claimed. "We dominated the whole game and I knew that sooner or later we were going to score, it was just a matter of time."

Udinese's defeat opened up the way for Roma to return to the top of Serie A, and Fabio Capello's side took full advantage with a 2-1 win against lowly Reggina.

Roma were without Gabriel Batistuta, and found Reggina keeper Massimo Taibi in inspired form (no, really), but even so the result was never really in doubt, even when Erjohn Bogdani equalised Francesco Totti's opener early in the second half. The Lupi were simply too strong, and, despite Taibi's best efforts, they scored the winner through Montella after 72 minutes.

Afterwards, Reggina's Franco Colomba had nothing but praise for Roma. "I think we lost to a good team," his gracious assessment ran. Capello, meanwhile, was typically coy praising Montella as a "good penalty box player," but refusing to say why he has preferred playing Marco Delvecchio alongside Batistuta. "I try to play the best elements available at any given time," he stated, his poker face giving nothing away.

Elsewhere, lowly Lecce - famous for the garishness of their MCC tie-esque shirts as much as the quality of their football - displayed gladiatorial levels of courage to beat Internazionale in the San Siro for the first time in their history.

Things started badly for Lecce when they conceded a penalty after ten minutes, but keeper Antonio Chimenti made a brilliant save to thwart Laurent Blanc. And so the pattern of the match was established: Inter shoot, Chimenti saves - the only exception being in the 21st minute when Davor Vugrinec put Lecce ahead.

Incredibly the scored stayed at 1-0, even though Lecce were reduced to ten men just before half-time when Alberto Malusci was sent off for hacking down Hakan Sukur. In the second half Inter even tried a four pronged attack of Vieri, Keane - reportedly about to join Reggina on loan for a year - Sukur and Recoba but they still couldn't find a way through.

"Today I stopped everything. It was my day," explained Lecce keeper Chimenti afterwards. "But it's all the team that won. We were down to ten men and we gave our best shot. Let's enjoy this result."

On Saturday the big game between Juventus and Lazio at the Stadio Delle Alpi fizzled out to a 1-1 draw, after Marcelo Salas's 25-yard scorcher cancelled out Igor Tudor's opener for Juve. But unfortunately the match will be remembered more for events off the pitch.

Sadly, the Lazio fans are at it again - directing their famous racist abuse at Edgar Davids. And this time, after the taunting came violence. During the game TV cameras showed a man being kicked unconscious for several minutes before the police finally decided to act. An omen for England's friendly against Italy - also at the Stadio Delle Alpi - on Wednesday night perhaps?

webTitle: Barca in crisis after another home defeat

fields.headline: Barca in crisis after another home defeat
fields.trailText: Vicente del Bosque must be laughing his moustachioed head off. Secretly, of course - after all, he wouldn't want anyone to see him looking happy. But laugh he will. After three defeats on the trot, all the talk last week was of Real Madrid in crisis. This week it's Barça's turn.
fields.body:
Vicente del Bosque must be laughing his moustachioed head off. Secretly, of course - after all, he wouldn't want anyone to see him looking happy. But laugh he will. After three defeats on the trot, all the talk last week was of Real Madrid in crisis. This week it's Barça's turn.

After crashing out of the Champions League in midweek, the Catalans plunged new depths with a 2-1 home defeat against Villarreal in a game that saw 13 yellow cards (but miraculously no red ones). Barça were 1-0 down after just 32 seconds - none of their players had even touched the ball when Víctor beat Arnau with embarrassing ease to open the scoring. The home side equalised through Cocu, but were made to pay for a whole host of missed opportunities when Víctor clinched Villarreal's victory minutes into the second half.

The defeat leaves Barcelona outside the Uefa Cup places and manager Lorenzo Serra Ferrer deep in trouble. The Mallorcan has a problem - the same problem that Robson and Van Gaal had, in fact - he's not Johan Cruyff. But at least Robson and Van Gaal managed to win things. Serra Ferrer, on the other hand, has done little to suggest that he's going to bring any nice shiny trophies to the Catalan capital. Actually, maybe he has. Maybe it's all part of a master plan - the Uefa Cup has to be easier to win than the Champions League, after all.

The manager can't be blamed for losing Luis Figo, of course, and most of the culés were happy enough when he dismantled Van Gaal's Ajax team - and delighted when Jari Littmanen disappeared from the starting line-up.

Serra Ferrer also successfully broke up the De Boer brothers at last, selling Dire De Boer to Rangers - where, amazingly, he passed the medical - and keeping Decent De Boer at the Nou Camp. But his summer signings haven't impressed. Comedy Keeper Dutruel and Marc Overmars have been especially unpopular. Meanwhile, Gerard, and Alfonso - who seems to have left his white scoring boots in Bruges - have spent most of the season on the bench. A number of players have already expressed their doubts about Serra Ferrer's system. And who wouldn't with Manu Petit playing at left back?

Barça president Joan Gaspart is openly looking for a manager for next season, but it won't be a surprise to see Serra Ferrer packing his bags sooner rather than later.

There is nothing like disaster at Barça to cheer up the madridistas - throw in a 5-1 victory and delirium sets in. To add the finishing touch, arch-centralist and Barça-hater, Fernando Hierro was the main man with two goals. And it could have been even better, too, had the captain not missed a last minute penalty after Álvaro had brought down McManaman. Guti, the latest addition to Camacho's national squad, Savio and Raúl completed the scoring.

Amid the delight, spare a thought for the Mayor of Las Palmas, José Manuel Soria López. It was all rather too much for him to take and he had to be rushed to hospital after the game - although he's since been given the all clear.

Deportivo La Coruña and Valencia lead the table, both on 20 points. Depor saw off Zaragoza 2-0, with two goals either side of half time from Diego Tristán. Tristán lobbed Zaragoza keeper Juanmi for the first, before completing the scoring in the second half with an excellent finish after a fine Depor move.

Valencia didn't enjoy life quite so much this weekend and had to rely on a last minute goal from Diego Alonso to secure a 2-2 draw against Rayo at the Mestalla. Rayo had taken the lead with two fabulous goals. The first was a classic 50-yard lob from Elvir Bolic that made James Beattie's effort at the weekend look like what it was - an aimless hoof that got lucky.

Midfielder Míchel scored the second with another (not quite so) great strike in the 52nd minute. It was the brilliant Mendieta - of course - who led Valencia's comeback with a goal ten minutes later, before John Carew set up Diego Alonso for the equaliser right on time.

Things are looking bleak at the bottom of the table for Real Sociedad, who lost 1-0 against Oviedo, thanks to another goal from local hero Oli. No disgrace there - Radi Antic's side, who are unbeaten in the New - and very impressive - Carlos Tartiere, boast the best home record in the division. If only their away form was as good.

Just above Real Sociedad are Racing and Osasuna who, true to form, played out a 0-0 draw yesterday. Above them lie Athletic (who beat Celta 2-1), Málaga and Espanyol (who between them produced another 0-0 bore), and Valladolid who miraculously avoided yet another 1-1 draw with a winner 17 minutes from time against high-flying Alavés.

Never ones to shy away from publicity, Spanish referees are back in the news. From January the Hijos de Puta will be sponsored by digital television company QuieroTV and will wear the company's logo on their shirts. Francesc Fernández Ontineros, secretary general of Media Park, the company that helped broker the deal, claimed that this was a "step forward on the road to the professionalisation of referees". Yeah, right. That's what it is. It surely won't be long till QuieroTV offers its viewers all sorts of wonderful new angles from its revolutionary RefCam.

Rumours that SpecSavers are lining up a similar deal in the Premiership are yet to be confirmed. Boom boom.

webTitle: Sue's application

fields.headline: Sue's application
fields.trailText: "My just-graduated son is also applying to be a Netjetter but I say to him and all the young: sod off. Let him watch Big Brother and read The Beach. He will have other chances..."
fields.body:
I want to be a Netjetter.

I am fifty, fairly fit and fed-up. I am overworked, underpaid (public sector - worthy work but worthless pay) and impoverished by student offspring. I am ready to receive my reward in heaven - travelling.

I have long been consumed with the desire to travel. Pre-divorce, it was camping and car-sick children, with an occasional trip to France. It is one of life's small mysteries as to why all teachers are such Francophiles. In seven post-divorce years I have only been able to manage three holidays: a first-time skiing trip to Italy - experiencing an equal measure of terror and exhilaration; a walking trip in Romania - feeling a curious mixture of envy and guilt at the simple but harsh peasant life; and a cheap week in Kefalonia where the beauty of the island took my breath away every single day. I am currently saving for a trip to Nepal. At this rate I will have to live to the age of 150 to make a small dent on where I want to go.

My just-graduated son is also applying to be a Netjetter but I say to him and all the young: sod off. Let him watch Big Brother and read The Beach [not bother with the film]. He will have other chances. Which of us would be the most excited by the adventure, the most awe-struck by of the wonders of this planet, the most appreciative of the diversity of its cultures? I would consider it an honour to represent the Shirley Valentines and Bridget Joneses of this world. I would try my hardest to live up to all the dreams of middleagedwomankind - we are a feisty lot!

Where do I want to go? EVERYWHERE and ANYWHERE - definitely every continent. I do not know if a detailed itinerary is required. I can't be bothered to work that out now. It is too exciting just to think about the whole concept. I will just throw out a few places high on my wish list: Prague, Krakow, St Petersburg, on to China, Nepal, into India, join the backpackers in South-East Asia, pop to Australia and New Zealand, across to South America, any part will do but must include Peru, up to the Caribbean, I suppose I must include the States, if only to test out my long-held prejudices, Canada if time... I have just looked at an atlas and realised I have missed out Africa! I am sure I can fit it in somewhere.The beauty of six months and a world-wide ticket would be the freedom to be side-tracked, to be guided by other travellers and Guardian Unlimited readers, to go where the nose or the eyes lead. My heart is beating so fast just thinking about it.

I may not have a job to come back to. I would certainly have a lot of debts. It would be well-worth it! I could live off the memories for the same amount of time it would take me to pay off the debts - probably the rest of my life. My family [apart from my son] and colleagues think I am mad to even apply - I probably am... but I can dream.

I want to be a Netjetter.

webTitle: Confused by the acronyms?

fields.headline: Confused by the acronyms?
fields.standfirst: From Aosis to Opec, here's a glossary of terms, supplied by the RSPB
fields.trailText: From Aosis to Opec, here's a glossary of terms, supplied by the RSPB.
fields.body:
Aosis
The Alliance of Small Island States - these include the islands of the Pacific, Atlantic and Indian oceans, such as Samoa and almost all Caribbean nations

Annex 1 Countries
This refers to Annex 1 of the Climate Convention. These are the developed industrial countries, mostly the OECD and countries with economies in transition

Annex B Countries
The developed countries in Annex B of the Kyoto Protocol. Annex B specifies their targets

Anthropogenic
Human-induced (as in anthropogenic impacts)

Assigned Amounts
A country's emissions 'budget' - the maximum greenhouse gases a country can emit from 2008-2012. It is based on their emissions in a baseline year, usually 1990, and their targets

Banking
Banking in the sense of 'banking' current emissions reductions against future emissions

Borrowing
Usually in the context of non-compliance, where countries might borrow from future Assigned Amounts if they were not to stay within their current targets

Basket
Refers to a mix of greenhouse gases which are lumped together and counted as equivalent to carbon dioxide emissions. The basket of gases in the Protocol are carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons and sulphur hexafluoride.

Bubble
The system whereby several countries can meet a reduction target jointly, while having different individual targets. The EC countries are currently the sole example. Also known as burden sharing.

Byrd-Hagel Resolution
A decision adopted by the US Senate, that agreed, among other things, it would not ratify the Kyoto Protocol unless it involved 'meaningful' participation by developing countries.

Carbon Sequestration
Simply, carbon storage

Commitment Period
The commitment period is the time period in which countries must meet their assigned amounts. The first commitment period set out in the Kyoto Protocol is 2008-2012

CDM
Clean Development Mechanism - this is one of three 'flexible mechanisms' that are included in the Kyoto Protocol. The CDM allows emissions reductions projects in developing countries to be offset against emissions in Annex 1 countries

Compliance
Means meeting one's obligations set out in a treaty or other legal instrument

COP
The Conference of the Parties. This is the supreme governing body the Convention. Parties are the Governments of countries that have ratified the Convention

Differentiation
The name given to the fact that industrialised countries have adopted different targets for the first commitment period in the Kyoto protocol. The average target is 5.2% reductions although the targets of individual countries range from 8% for the EU to 10% for Iceland

Emissions Permits
Also known as tradeable permits. These would be the currency used in the Kyoto Protocol's cap and trade scheme. They will be in units of tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent.

Emissions Trading
Emissions trading is a system in which participants take on an emissions limitation target and are then allowed to exchange emissions between themselves. A participant meeting its target with emissions reductions to spare would sell them to another that would be likely to miss its target. Under the Kyoto Protocol, the participants are countries but a Kyoto based scheme would probably, in practice, involve trading between firms with responsibility for their actions being taken by Governments

CERs
Certified Emissions Reductions - the reductions created by CDM projects. They will be offset against the donor developing country's emissions targets

Flexibility
The word flexibility is derived from the expression that countries should have flexibility in how they achieve their emissions reductions. It almost invariably means offsetting emissions abroad

Group of 77 - the negotiating block of all the developing countries, the G77 has widely differing interests which often make it hard to reach internal consensus. China is always added as a separate member of the G77 (eg G77 and China) but in practice it is an integral member of it

The Kyoto protocol currently makes provision for Annex 1 countries to take into account afforestation, reforestation and deforestation - ARD - as well as other land use change in their commitment, known as land use, land use change and forestry

webTitle: Aids victims get Hollywood boost

fields.headline: Aids victims get Hollywood boost
fields.trailText: A number of top Hollywood stars are donating props and costumes from well-known films for an auction of film memorabilia to raise money for an Aids charity
fields.body:
A number of top Hollywood stars are donating props and costumes from well-known films for an auction of film memorabilia to raise money for an Aids charity.

Liam Neeson, who is spearheading the Movie Action for Children event, is donating the lightsabre he used in the Star Wars prequel The Phantom Menace, reports Ananova.

This alone is expected to raise a significant amount of money from Star Wars devotees, as it's the first time George Lucas has allowed anything from the Star Wars films to be auctioned off. "Needless to say the lithium crystals aren't here so it doesn't switch on," said Neeson, but, "it really is a collector's item so we're expecting to get a lot of money for it."

Leeson has contacted some of his Hollywood buddies, asking them to donate items which are hoped will raise large amounts for the charity, which pays for drugs that stop prevent HIV-positive mothers from passing on the virus to their babies.

Among the items are Julia Roberts's wedding dress from The Runaway Bride, Mel Gibson's sword from Braveheart and Robert De Niro's outfit from US box office hit Meet the Parents. "My colleagues in the movie industry have reacted in an extraordinary way to the challenge," said Leeson, who is also donating the original script from Schindler's list complete with smudgy coffee marks and cigarette ash.

The auction will go ahead at Sotheby's in New York on March 6.

webTitle: Applause for social care institute may not last

fields.headline: Applause for social care institute may not last
fields.standfirst: The creation of a social care institute for excellence has been greeted with approval all round. But the fledgling organisation may find its first steps less well received
fields.trailText: The creation of a social care institute for excellence has been greeted with approval all round. But the fledgling organisation may find its first steps less well received, writes Linda Steele.
fields.body:
Another acronym has emerged blinking into the social care world. Scie (pronounced "sky"), which stands for the social care institute for excellence, is the offspring of a government determined to populate public services with measurable, high quality initiatives driven by what works.

Scie's conception was greeted with all-round approval. Its aims will be to provide evidence of good practice, and to ensure that the lessons of its research are carried into national social care standards, training and work on the ground.

But the fledgling organisation, when it comes into being, may find its first steps less well received, if the experience of its older sibling, the national institute for clinical excellence (Nice) is anything to go by. Dark mutterings about rationing were heard (largely from the direction of pharmaceutical companies) when Nice refused to back the flu drug Relenza. Its approval of taxane cancer drugs met with sighs of relief from sufferers, while multiple sclerosis campaigners have been angered by an anticipated rejection of beta interferon.

Constructive argument
Of course, Nice is a different creature, charged with advising the NHS on cost-effectiveness and good practice in treating disease. But, in a field that has seen such dubious methods as pindown and rows over recovered memory syndrome, are Scie's ruminations on good practice likely to be any less controversial?

"Even if you put the best experts together on adoption, we'd still disagree on what is the best intervention," says June Thoburn, social work professor at the University of East Anglia.

Of course, Scie might encourage constructive argument. Jennifer Bernard, chief executive of the Central Council for Education and Training in Social Work, says: "Scie will not be without contention - for example, do children do better in same-race families? But we need to have these debates and see where research needs to be done."

Being able to point to a body of evidence should allow social work to improve its poor public image as well as its practice. "We could say: 'It's not about being woolly liberals or politically correct - this is based on research'," adds Bernard.

Thoburn argues that these fundamental disagreements make Nice a poor model for Scie. "It's not like kidneys - the notion of coming out with medicines you can prescribe is just not on. Within social care, there isn't agreement because it's about deciding what's right for the individual," she says.

Perhaps proving Thoburn's point about the lack of agreement, Martin Knapp, professor of social work at the London School of Economics, argues that: "There's no less individuality in healthcare. In fact, there are parallels between the decisions that social workers and GPs take." Knapp argues that the main difference - and here, he and Thoburn would concur - is that GPs have (and social workers should have) a body of good, easily accessible research to turn to.

Inclusivity
Nice has a standing committee that asks for evidence, and sometimes commissions expert research. Thoburn argues that Scie should have a skeleton secretariat under a respected research director. It should commission experts to analyse research according to the area of practice under scrutiny.

Whatever shape it takes, Scie will have to be inclusive. Unlike their health counterparts, field social workers tend not to undertake research. To avoid becoming an academic institution trying in vain to spread the good practice word, Sice will need to find a way to involve social care staff and academic researchers in its deliberations, as well as service providers, users and carers, and the various regulatory bodies that are springing up. Daphne Statham, director of the National Institute for Social Work, which hopes to get the job of running Scie, speaks of "a co-ordination partnership".

A straw poll suggests that the sector would prefer an independent but fully funded Scie. And when it comes to funding, there's another issue. Many social services workers do not have internet access at work, so they won't be able to access Scie's guidance. A big investment in information technology is needed if the government's new baby is to fulfil the promise of making "maximum use of electronic means to publicise and exchange information" and promoting evidence-based social care.

webTitle: No place to go

fields.headline: No place to go
fields.standfirst: Dr Ute Collier, Head of Climate Change at WWF-UK, writes of the threat global warming poses to wildlife
fields.trailText: Dr Ute Collier, Head of Climate Change at WWF-UK, writes of the threat global warming poses to wildlife
fields.body:
From the Arctic to Antarctica, the reality of climate change is becoming ever more apparent as sea ice melts, glaciers retreat and droughts, floods and storms become more frequent.

These changes are not only impacting on people but also on wildlife globally. Polar bears are finding it harder to hunt on the receding ice and Peary caribous are suffering due to a lack of winter fodder. The golden toad of Costa Rica is believed to be the first species to have become extinct due to climate change, as rainfall patterns and humidity levels have changed in the cloud forests.

And this is only the first stage of much larger changes to come - unless we implement ambitious programmes to cut our emissions from fossil fuel combustion.

Unprecedented rate of change

While average temperatures have risen at a rate of around 0.6° C over the last century, the Arctic and Antarctic have seen much higher increases. A 6° C warming over the last decade in the Arctic has been accompanied by 40% decrease in the thickness of the Arctic sea ice. These changes threaten species that depend on the ice for hunting and rearing their young such as polar bears and walruses.

Elsewhere, rising sea temperatures are posing a new threat to already over-fished stocks of cod and have resulted in a severe bleaching of large areas of coral reefs.

While the climate has changed in the past, change is now happening at a much faster rate, making it difficult for all but the most mobile species, such as birds, to move and adapt. Add habitat destruction and urban sprawl, intensive agriculture and other developments and many plants, birds and mammals will simply have nowhere to go.

A recent report by WWF on climate change and wildlife* has highlighted the impacts climate change may have. The accelerating rates of warming we can expect in coming decades are likely to put large numbers of species at risk.

In particular in the higher latitudes of the northern hemisphere, where the warming will be greatest, it is questionable whether they will find suitable habitats elsewhere. Plants may need to move 10 times faster than they did at the end of the last ice age.

The worst affected countries are likely to be Canada and Russia, which could lose more than half their current habitats, with an associated species loss of up to 20% in some areas. For example, as the Arctic tundra is replaced by forest, millions of geese, ducks and wading birds are likely to lose their summer breeding habitat.

High migration rates will particularly threaten rare, isolated or slow-moving species. The winners in the climate change race will be weeds, pests and generalists that can move, reproduce or adapt fast.

While rabbits are unlikely to be threatened, species at risk include the rare Gelada baboon in Ethiopia, the mountain pygmy possum of Australia, the monarch butterfly at its Mexican wintering grounds, and the spoon-billed sandpiper at its breeding sites in Russia's arctic far east.

UK impacts

In the UK, the impacts of climate change on wildlife initially look positive. Swallows now arrive much earlier in the spring and leave later in the autumn and Little Egrets breed on the South Coast. The rare Dartford warbler is at record levels.

However, the irony is that further climate change may eventually destroy the heathland habitats on which this and other rare species depend. There are very few opportunities to re-create lowland heath away from its current stronghold in southern England.

Most at threat are mountain habitats. For example, in the Cairngorms in Scotland, dotterels, ptarmigans and mountain hares are likely to disappear. Elsewhere, rare, isolated species such as the Arctic char (found in Cumbrian lakes) and the Snowdon lily may not survive. The prime birding sites (mudflats and saltmarshes) in East Anglia are under threat from sea-level rise.

But something can still be done

Some species will be able to adapt and move northwards but we need to make sure that they have places to go to and are not stopped by roads or fields of wheat. A good network of protected areas is crucial but we have to accept that we cannot preserve what we have now in perpetuity.

Some change is inevitable; the challenge now is to reduce emissions to avoid the worst case scenario of vast species and habitat loss.

* Malcolm, J and Markham, A (2000). Global warming and terrestrial biodiversity decline: A report for WWF

webTitle: Third Division  Round-up

fields.headline: Third Division  Round-up
fields.trailText: Chesterfield will hold a press conference today amid growing concern that their on-field success may be harmed by off-the-pitch disaster.
fields.body:
Chesterfield will hold a press conference today amid growing concern that their on-field success may be harmed by off-the-pitch disaster.

Chester have yet to receive the first instalment of Luke Beckett's transfer fee, a sum of £75,000. The league leaders must pay within three days or the FA, which has already charged them, will punish them with a fine - or even a points deduction.

Beckett underlined his value on Saturday by scoring his eighth goal of the season to secure a 1-0 victory over Hull .

The fact no other top-seven side won did little to lift the mood, and the match was stopped for four minutes because of crowd trouble.

Of the bottom sides, only Torquay lost. They were beaten by York , who sealed a 3-2 victory in the 88th minute. But the biggest upset of the day came at Brunton Park, where Carlisle , bottom of the league and without a win in 13 matches, beat Southend , who had gone 13 games without defeat.

Ian Stevens and Scott Dobie gave Carlisle a 2-0 half-time lead and, though David Lee pulled a goal back in the 86th minute, Dobie's late second sealed an unlikely but comfortable victory.

webTitle: Second Division Round-up

fields.headline: Second Division Round-up
fields.trailText: The Wigan manager Bruce Rioch played down his side's chances of promotion after they went top with a 2-1 home win over Cambridge .
fields.body:
The Wigan manager Bruce Rioch played down his side's chances of promotion after they went top with a 2-1 home win over Cambridge .

"We didn't play well in the first half; our passing was not up to standard," he said. "We know we can do better and we will have to stay at the top."

A Neil Mustoe goal gave United the lead in the first half, but Neil Roberts equalised 15 minutes from time and an own goal from Paul Wanless four minutes before the end secured the points. Wigan are now two points clear of Walsall, who managed only a 0-0 draw at Bristol Rovers .

The performance of the day came at Bournemouth , where the on-loan 18-year-old West Ham striker Jermaine Defoe showed skill and style in abundance as his team beat Northampton 3-0. He dominated proceedings, netting twice and showing that in his case you can believe the hype.

Another side on the up are Rotherham , now unbeaten in seven games. They ended Brentford's eight-match unbeaten run as they cruised to a 3-0 away victory. The Brentford manager Ron Noades was furious with his side's anaemic performance. "Every time we get near the play-off situation we blow it," he said. "The players have really let me down."

The Luton manager Ricky Hill was also feeling the heat. His side crashed to their sixth home defeat, 3-0 at home to Bristol City, leaving disgruntled fans calling for him to go. "Our defence went to sleep, our midfield was half-asleep, all their goals came from our mistakes," said a weary Hill, adding that he would not quit.

The Greater Manchester rivals Bury and Oldham met with contrasting fates. Oldham, showing signs of a revival, beat Stoke 1-0 thanks to a Lee Duxbury goal. Bury, who started the season strongly, are without a win in seven games after losing 2-1 to Wycombe.

fields.trailText: More than 200 Huddersfield fans demonstrated against the club's owner Barry Rubery and demanded the return of their former manager Peter Jackson after a 2-0 home defeat to West Brom which left them five points adrift and without a goal since October 6.
fields.body:
More than 200 Huddersfield fans demonstrated against the club's owner Barry Rubery and demanded the return of their former manager Peter Jackson after a 2-0 home defeat to West Brom which left them five points adrift and without a goal since October 6.

Terry Fisher, Huddersfield's associated director, said: "I completely understand the frustrations but I don't think demonstrations outside the boardroom are the way forward. I'm sure Barry Rubery is very confident he can turn things round."

Bolton are third, behind Fulham and Watford, after their 2-0 home win over Barnsley, but Sam Allardyce, the Wanderers manager, appealed for more vocal support. "I was a bit disappointed with the lack of atmosphere," he said. "We need to get more in the stadium to lift the lads."

The Burnley manager Stan Ternent's priority remains avoiding relegation even though his side's 2-0 win at home to Sheffield United lifted them to fourth. "Our first aim is to ensure First Division status and that could take seven more wins," he said. Andy Payton got both goals, the first coming from the spot after a handball by Wayne Quinn.

Wolves are considering suing their former striker Dougie Freedman if video evidence suggests he deliberately stamped on Ludovic Pollet, who was carried off during Crystal Palace's 3-1 win at Molineux with a facial gash which required four stitches. "If a deliberate action caused the injury then obviously this is a matter we will have to discuss further," said Colin Lee, the Wolves manager, who was also left to contemplate a demonstration of irate fans outside the ground.

Blackburn's six-match winning streak ended with a 2-2 draw at Portsmouth and Sheffield Wednesday's revival continued with a 3-2 win over Norwich.
