webTitle: Oftel orders BT to offer flat-rate charge

fields.headline: Oftel orders BT to offer flat-rate charge
fields.standfirst: Nov 13: BT sells stake in Swiss company
fields.trailText:
Telecoms watchdog Oftel has sparked a revolution in internet access by ordering BT to introduce UK-wide flat-rate charges, writes Dan Milmo.
Nov 13: BT sells stake in Swiss company
fields.body:
Telecoms watchdog Oftel has sparked a revolution in internet access by ordering BT to introduce UK-wide flat-rate charges.

BT has to implement a new unmetered access service by February 2001, in a move welcomed by internet companies itching to boost their subscriber figures and still reeling from a series of flat-rate access fiascos.

AltaVista UK, WorldOnline and LineOne were among the internet companies left with egg on their faces after pulling their flat-rate services because BT surcharges made them too expensive.

A spokesperson for AOL UK, said: "We are delighted. This is a very positive move for consumers and the industry."

BT gave the move a cautious welcome, having argued against unmetered access due to concerns about overloading the network.

"We have never been against unmetered access in principle. If the conditions are right there is no problem, but it depends on the network being ready and the price being right," said a BT spokesperson.

The new guidelines state that BT must give operators a cut-price rate for internet access from a customer's home to a rival operator's network.

Oftel adds that BT will have to counter concerns about an over-stretched network by creating extra space for the traffic, though it will share the cost with other operators.

It is expected that scheme will have a positive knock-on effect for consumers, bringing internet access down to £10 a month. AOL UK's flat-rate package charges customers £14.99 per month under the Friaco pricing framework.

The scheme will end BT's practice of charging competitors by the second for all internet connections running through its network.

webTitle: Florida votes deadline blow for Gore

fields.headline: Florida votes deadline blow for Gore
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election
fields.trailText: Al Gore's hopes of winning the US presidency today suffered a setback when Florida's Republican secretary of state ruled that all recounts must be completed and certified by tomorrow.
fields.body:
Al Gore's hopes of winning the US presidency today suffered a setback when Florida's Republican secretary of state ruled that all recounts must be completed and certified by tomorrow.

The tight deadline imposed by Katherine Harris has left officials unsure whether they will be able to complete hand recounts of the poll in parts of the state.

One of the four Florida counties, Volusia, has begun recounting 184,000 votes and a second, Palm Beach, was scheduled to start hand counting 430,000 votes today.

State officials warned that counties that do not certify their vote by the deadline "shall be ignored".

The move comes after samples of the recount over the weekend suggested that Mr Gore could yet move ahead of his rival George W Bush in the vital election. The winner will almost certainly take the White House.

Mr Bush has begun legal action to block the hand recounts, arguing that for them to take place only in four mainly-Democratic Florida counties would discriminate against him. A decision on this is expected later today, but even without it Ms Harris's decision to impose a deadline may ensure the Republicans take the state.

Former US secretary of state Warren Christopher, representing Mr Gore in Florida, said he regretted her decision and it would be challenged very soon in the courts. He described her actions as "abitrary and unreasonable".

The Florida secretary of state is a Republican who campaigned for Mr Bush. She added that overseas absentee ballots, which must be received by Friday, would be counted and certified by each county no later than Saturday morning. She said this would allow the presidential election in Florida to be officially certified by Saturday afternoon barring any court intervention.

webTitle: True North exec poached by Omnicon

fields.headline: True North exec poached by Omnicon
fields.trailText: Monday 5pm: True North has lost one of its most senior staff to Omnicon, only weeks after losing the DaimlerChrysler account to the US advertising group. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
True North has lost one of its most senior players, only weeks after losing its biggest piece of business.

US advertising group Omnicom, which took control of the multi-million pound DaimlerChrysler account from True North earlier this month, has now poached one of the agency's most senior employees to run the account.

Mike Vogel, president of True North-owned FCB Worldwide's Detroit office, becomes the new chairman and chief executive of PentaMark Worldwide, the Omnicom agency being set up specifically to run the Chrysler account.

The loss of the business is a massive blow to True North, and the departure of senior staff may well hinder the group's chances of acquiring a replacement car account.

True North chairman and chief executive David Bell said that there may be job cuts as a result of the account loss. He has pledged to find other business to make up the massive loss in revenue from the Chrysler business.

The review saw the two networks pitch head-to-head for the business, which they shared.

The loss of the account has now rekindled speculation that True North may face a takeover bid, possibly from the Interpublic Group of Companies or Publicis, or a merger with Cordiant.

webTitle: Opinion: Global warming treaty must not become a 'cheat's charter'

fields.headline: Global warming treaty must not become a 'cheat's charter'
fields.standfirst: The climate crisis will worsen unless the Hague conference makes the Kyoto agreement watertight, warns Stephanie Tunmore, climate campaigner for Greenpeace
fields.trailText: Opinion: The climate crisis will worsen unless the Hague conference makes the Kyoto agreement watertight, warns Stephanie Tunmore, climate campaigner for Greenpeace.
fields.body:
The international climate negotiations resume in the Hague from 13th -24th November and governments will have to take decisions on crucial issues. How these issues are decided will determine whether the Kyoto Protocol becomes a first step towards climate protection or a 'Cheat's Charter' that will allow industrialised countries to increase rather than reduce emissions.

Since Kyoto in 1997, when 38 industrialised countries agreed to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions by an overall 5.2%, the talks have made very little progress. The meeting in the Hague is the culmination of three years of wrangling and, in theory, is where cards must be laid on the table and agreement reached about how the developed world will achieve their individual targets.

But as the prospect of legally binding targets gets nearer, concerted efforts are being made to insert loopholes into the Kyoto Protocol. If accepted these loopholes could result in an environmentally ineffective treaty that could actually legitimise an increase in CO2 emissions.

Fossil fuels are at the core of the current climate crisis. Burning oil, coal and gas for energy releases carbon dioxide (CO2) into the atmosphere, creating a thick 'blanket' of gases around the earth and trapping the sun's heat. As global temperatures rise, the planet's climate system is being thrown into disarray.

In theory, the solution is quite simple. Substantially reduce the use of fossil fuels by replacing them rapidly with clean renewable energy sources.One of the loopholes being suggested by a number of industrialised countries is counting the amount of CO2 stored in carbon 'sinks' - especially forests - against their fossil fuel emissions. This would effectively allow them to carry on business as usual and still nominally achieve their targets.

The danger inherent in this approach is that forests and other vegetation only store CO2 temporarily and it can be released back into the atmosphere rapidly at any time.

Through photosynthesis, trees take CO2 out of the atmosphere and store it as wood carbon. Carbon is also stored in plants on the forest floor, in leaf and forest debris and in forest soils. But much of this carbon is constantly moving.

Young trees absorb large amounts of CO2 as they grow but a mature forest can reach an 'equilibrium' where it emits as much as it takes up. Branches and leaves fall to the forest floor and release CO2 as they decay and drought and wildfires can cause a forest to die and release so much CO2 back into the atmosphere that it becomes a 'source' rather than a sink. Drought and wildfires are expected to increase as a result of climate change.

This makes accounting for the amount of carbon stored in forests difficult and imprecise.

By contrast, subterranean carbon buried underground in the form of fossil fuels is locked out of the atmosphere and leaving it underground guarantees that it will not be a burden on the atmosphere.

Under Kyoto Protocol rules, every tonne of CO2 stored in forests would allow a corresponding tonne of fossil fuel CO2 to be released into the atmosphere.Given the difficulties of calculating the exact uptake of CO2 by forests and the impermanent nature of the storage, these proposals could result in emissions to the atmosphere increasing substantially rather than reducing.

The only way that a tonne of carbon stored in forests could have the same impact on the atmosphere as a tonne of 'avoided' fossil fuel carbon is if the forest carbon is permanent. None of the stored carbon could ever be allowed back into the atmosphere, so the forest could not be allowed to decay, burn down or be harvested. If the trees are harvested, the resulting paper or wood products would have to be tracked in perpetuity to make sure they were never destroyed.

There would also need to be certainty that the CO2 stored in the forest is additional. A lot of forest management practices would happen anyway because they are 'good practice' but it is now being proposed that many of these should be eligible for emissions credits. If this is allowed it will be difficult to differentiate between what would have happened anyway and what is truly additional.

The recent floods in the UK have delivered a timely reminder of what we can expect in the future if we fail to address climate change and it is to be hoped that politicians gathering in the Hague will pay attention.

We have to urgently reduce the amount of CO2 we are putting into the sky if we are to avoid the worst impacts of climate change. The only way to do that is through domestic action to phase out fossil fuels and switch to clean renewable energy sources. Creative 'carbon accounting' with sinks might be a clever trick but it won't save the climate.

webTitle: Nuisance,  Nutrition, and  Nu ground

fields.headline: Nuisance,  Nutrition, and  Nu ground
fields.trailText: WOUND WITH A VIEW
fields.body:
WOUND WITH A VIEW

The England squad is like a night out with Billie Piper - people are falling down all over the place. This morning saw loveable young thug Alan Smith drop out due to "tiredness" and Manchester United's Wes Brown withdraw with seafood poisoning, oh alright then, a knee injury. This afternoon brought even worse news for Peter Taylor, as Paul Scholes and Michael Owen won't be playing either. Fortunately, Paul Ince should still be waiting on standby (he's heard it's a high stakes game).

Owen only did a spot of light training this morning, but that was still enough to exacerbate a back injury which will stop him from travelling. Scholes managed a full session, but will not risk the thigh he strained during United's 2-1 win over Boro on Saturday. Gareth Southgate will be fit, however, having failed to be inconvenienced by a cheek injury. "I think it will be very difficult to stop Gareth going anywhere," said John Gregory, who has managed to stop him from leaving Villa Park for ages.

One piece of good news - unless you possess a copy of No Surrender to the IRA on 7-inch - is that Svennis looks likely to take part-time charge of England for the two World Cup qualifying matches next March. Lazio had sounded frosty about letting their coach do two jobs at once, but club vice-president Dino Zoff said today: "We want to do everything we can to help the English Football Association. It will be difficult because of his commitment to Lazio, but Mr Eriksson is very keen to get involved for the games and we want to help him." Astonishing! Please excuse the Fiver while we faint in the toilets.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

McFIVER'S RESTAURANT

Hungry for burgers? Then come to McFiver's - the home of football-related fast food where the surfaces are wiped clean nearly every day! Once you've sunk your teeth into one of our meaty baps, we guarantee you'll be hooked. Take the Big Merse, for example. It's a 100% ham topped with plenty of cheese, and every one comes served with a liberal helping of chippy comment.

So take a bite and let the unctuous flavour of 'urging Aston Villa to buy some more players to make sure of a place in Europe' ooze out. "People like McDonald's are at the top of their sphere, selling more fast food than anyone else. But they still pump more and more money into advertising because they want to stay top dogs. Villa have to adopt the same philosophy in terms of football."

Also, if you buy a Big Merse as part of a Smiles Meal, you'll get a free plastic talking dinosaur which insists that Villa should settle for nothing less than Big Cup football. "This is a better team than when I came here two years ago. You have to be realistic and say that Manchester United and Arsenal are a long way clear. But the top three is realistic for us if we strengthen. That's what I believe otherwise there would be no point coming into training every day." Mmm, that sure tastes booze-renouncin' good!!!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It happened in slow motion. But now I've this kind of lease of life like, isn't it good to be alive!" - Parma coach Alberto Malesani in reflective mood upon being airlifted to hospital after fracturing his collar bone in a near-fatal car crash.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HOUSE MEETING

As far as the Fiver is concerned, Liverpool's dock area has never been the same since Richard and Judy migrated south. Yes, it's a far livelier place, with lots of interesting things to do and far fewer plebs in matching macs squashing their faces against a window in the hope of getting on TV. And this Saturday, Everton fans will vote on whether to improve the area even further by ditching the venerable Goodison Park and building a new 50,000-plus ground on the King's Dock.

While club officials look set to reject calls for an American-style vote, whereby voters punch a hole in Peter Johnson, there is a lot of anticipation ahead of the weekend. Although the Everton faithful were polled on leaving Goodison Park in 1997, this is the first time they've been offered an actual alternative to the current ground. However, rumours that fans will be able to vote on the inclusion of in-ground escalators and snack machines at the end of every row remain just that.

For chief Toffee Bill Kenwright, there is a lot riding on this vote. The theatrical impresario (you should see his Chichester Festival Hall) is currently facing down rumours of continuing financial difficulty at the club, and talk that Walter Smith might resign as manager - fears today refuted by Smith himself. He is also trying to revive a foundering £26m investment deal with NTL, for whom the promise of a new stadium could be crucial. So it's a big vote and no mistake. Let's hope it goes well or they may get a new 70,000-seater Pat Buchanan.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Internazionale striker Robbie Keane is set to move to Reggina on loan until the end of the season, according to reports in Italy.

Celtic have denied making a bid for Leicester midfielder Neil Lennon. "Somebody said I had put in a £7m offer but that is nonsense," said manager Martin O'Neill. "I will keep speculation for another time."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Derby have signed Scotland defender Brian O'Neil in a swap deal which takes Stefan Schnoor to Wolfsburg. Meanwhile, Taribo West also joined the Rams today on a three-month loan from Internazionale after securing a work permit.

Kaiserslautern have signed Tottenham Hotspur winger Jose Dominguez for an unspecified fee.

Middlesbrough defender Gianluca Festa has handed in a transfer request after dropping behind Ugo Ehiogu, Gary Pallister, Colin Cooper, Steve Vickers and Dean Gordon in the Riverside pecking order.

Patrik Berger has undergone knee surgery in the US and the operation has been declared a success. The Liverpool midfielder could be back in action by March.

Former AIK Stockholm boss Stuart Baxter has claimed Hearts are considering him for the vacant manager's job at Tynecastle. "All I know right now is that they Hearts have shown an interest, nothing more," said Baxter. But chief executive Chris Robinson has denied the claim: "The club have not spoken to or approached anyone but Stuart Baxter has come forward of his volition."

Napoli, bottom of Serie A, have sacked coach Zdenek Zeman after five months in charge. The chain-smoking Czech will be replaced by Emiliano Mondonico, formerly coach of Torino.

John Sheran has taken over as Montrose manager on a permanent basis. Sheran had been caretaker boss since Kevin Drinkell's departure last month.

Ian McPhee has left his post as manager of Forfar by mutual consent.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Uefa Big Cup Weekly (11.30pm) The upper classes at play.

Nationwide Football League Extra (12.35am) As wide as a nation or your money back.

Channel 5: Dutch Football (4.30am) Roll up and watch them pass it around.

Sky Sports 1: World Football Show (7.30pm, 12midnight) All around the world: this show's editorial policy or over-produced Oasis single? You decide.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2.30am) As the Fiver searched for McCaff using a popular 'interweb' search engine, we chanced upon 'Mrs McCaffrey and Mrs Howard's Class Journal'. Unsurprisingly, it is far more interesting than the boy McCaff could ever be. "On April 11 we got six duck eggs to hatch. As of today we only have two surviving eggs. On May 3 we watched a video of the ducks that were hatched last year. They were called River, Bender and Lucky."

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11pm SS1, 2am) Hold on! That can't be Forest near the top of the table, can it?

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm) ...better than he commentated, we hope.

British Eurosport: Eurogoals (5.40pm, 9.40pm) The best European goals round-up you never ever watch.

"People like McDonald's are at the top of their sphere, selling more fast food than anyone else. But they still pump more and more money into advertising because they want to stay top dogs. Villa have to adopt the same philosophy in terms of football." Also, if you buy a Big Merse as part of a Smiles Meal, you'll get a free plastic talking dinosaur which insists that Villa should settle for nothing less than Big Cup football. "This is a better team than when I came here two years ago. You have to be realistic and say that Manchester United and Arsenal are a long way clear. But the top three is realistic for us if we strengthen. That's what I believe otherwise there would be no point coming into training every day." Mmm, that sure tastes booze-renouncin' good!!! * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "It happened in slow motion. But now I've this kind of lease of life like, isn't it good to be alive!" - Parma coach Alberto Malesani in reflective mood upon being airlifted to hospital after fracturing his collar bone in a near-fatal car crash. * * * * * * * * * * * * * HOUSE MEETING As far as the Fiver is concerned, Liverpool's dock area has never been the same since Richard and Judy migrated south. Yes, it's a far livelier place, with lots of interesting things to do and far fewer plebs in matching macs squashing their faces against a window in the hope of getting on TV. And this Saturday, Everton fans will vote on whether to improve the area even further by ditching the venerable Goodison Park and building a new 50,000-plus ground on the King's Dock. While club officials look set to reject calls for an American-style vote, whereby voters punch a hole in Peter Johnson, there is a lot of anticipation ahead of the weekend. Although the Everton faithful were polled on leaving Goodison Park in 1997, this is the first time they've been offered an actual alternative to the current ground. However, rumours that fans will be able to vote on the inclusion of in-ground escalators and snack machines at the end of every row remain just that. For chief Toffee Bill Kenwright, there is a lot riding on this vote. The theatrical impresario (you should see his Chichester Festival Hall) is currently facing down rumours of continuing financial difficulty at the club, and talk that Walter Smith might resign as manager - fears today refuted by Smith himself. He is also trying to revive a foundering £26m investment deal with NTL, for whom the promise of a new stadium could be crucial. So it's a big vote and no mistake. Let's hope it goes well or they may get a new 70,000-seater Pat Buchanan. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Internazionale striker Robbie Keane is set to move to Reggina on loan until the end of the season, according to reports in Italy. Celtic have denied making a bid for Leicester midfielder Neil Lennon. "Somebody said I had put in a £7m offer but that is nonsense," said manager Martin O'Neill. "I will keep speculation for another time." * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Derby have signed Scotland defender Brian O'Neil in a swap deal which takes Stefan Schnoor to Wolfsburg. Meanwhile, Taribo West also joined the Rams today on a three-month loan from Internazionale after securing a work permit. Kaiserslautern have signed Tottenham Hotspur winger Jose Dominguez for an unspecified fee. Middlesbrough defender Gianluca Festa has handed in a transfer request after dropping behind Ugo Ehiogu, Gary Pallister, Colin Cooper, Steve Vickers and Dean Gordon in the Riverside pecking order. Patrik Berger has undergone knee surgery in the US and the operation has been declared a success. The Liverpool midfielder could be back in action by March. Former AIK Stockholm boss Stuart Baxter has claimed Hearts are considering him for the vacant manager's job at Tynecastle. "All I know right now is that they Hearts have shown an interest, nothing more," said Baxter. But chief executive Chris Robinson has denied the claim: "The club have not spoken to or approached anyone but Stuart Baxter has come forward of his volition." Napoli, bottom of Serie A, have sacked coach Zdenek Zeman after five months in charge. The chain-smoking Czech will be replaced by Emiliano Mondonico, formerly coach of Torino. John Sheran has taken over as Montrose manager on a permanent basis. Sheran had been caretaker boss since Kevin Drinkell's departure last month. Ian McPhee has left his post as manager of Forfar by mutual consent. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: Uefa Big Cup Weekly (11.30pm) The upper classes at play. Nationwide Football League Extra (12.35am) As wide as a nation or your money back. Channel 5: Dutch Football (4.30am) Roll up and watch them pass it around. Sky Sports 1: World Football Show (7.30pm, 12midnight) All around the world: this show's editorial policy or over-produced Oasis single? You decide. You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2.30am) As the Fiver searched for McCaff using a popular 'interweb' search engine, we chanced upon 'Mrs McCaffrey and Mrs Howard's Class Journal'. Unsurprisingly, it is far more interesting than the boy McCaff could ever be. "On April 11 we got six duck eggs to hatch. As of today we only have two surviving eggs. On May 3 we watched a video of the ducks that were hatched last year. They were called River, Bender and Lucky." Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11pm SS1, 2am) Hold on! That can't be Forest near the top of the table, can it? Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm) ...better than he commentated, we hope. British Eurosport: Eurogoals (5.40pm, 9.40pm) The best European goals round-up you never ever watch.

webTitle: November 12 ratings

fields.headline: Reality bites as Frostrup's Panorama falls short
fields.trailText: 2.15pm The honey-voiced Mariella Frostrup's Panorama debut last night failed to take audience figures over 3m, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Even the addition of the honey-voiced, honey-blonde Mariella Frostrup to Panorama last night failed to take audience figures over the 3m watermark.

Ms Frostrup's presence and her subject matter - reality TV shows - simply did not curry favour with Panorama's heartland viewers, many of whom defected either to ITV for the first programme in the third series of Cold Feet or to Channel 4's movie, the English Patient.

The Sunday night special attracted 2.7m viewers, 13% of audience share and the second lowest figure since the programme was moved from Monday night five weeks ago.

And although a BBC News spokeswoman stressed that viewing figures were in line with what Panorama's been getting since the programme was shifted, the experiment is not likely to have been seen as a success.

Using a celebrity presenter to front the programme was always a risk and viewing figures suggest that the further the programme veers from its old-school, hard current affairs format, the more viewers it loses.

The last ever programme in the Monday slot, the acclaimed Who Bombed Omagh? fronted by John Ware, attracted 4.2m viewers, substantially more than last night's programme.

The following week's special on child labour in third world factories run by big brands such as Nike and Gap pulled in 3.2m, a significant drop from the hard-hitting investigation into the worst ever IRA atrocity, but still head and shoulders above the reality show special.

Could it be that audiences have finally had enough of Big Brother? Going up against a double-bill of Cold Feet was never going to be easy.

The popular thirty-something saga attracted 8m and a 36% share at 9pm, while the English Patient on Channel 4 roped in 3.1m, 16% of share.

Panorama did, however, beat Channel 5's Earthquake in New York, which got 2m viewers, 9% of share.

In an otherwise uneventful weekend, Friday's Have I Got News For You (BBC1) suffered from the absence of Germaine Greer, who graced the programme with the presence the previous Friday.

Ratings fell from 6.2m (27% of share) to 5.4m this week.

Whether it was the US elections deadlock or the Austrian disaster (or just appalling weather), ITV pulled in a second week of strong news viewing figures with 8.5m on Saturday, up from 7.4m the previous week.

fields.headline: Read our inbox
fields.standfirst: Shakespeare, poor scansion and the trials of teaching in London are among the topics of this week's correspondence
fields.trailText: Shakespeare, poor scansion and the trials of teaching in London are among the topics of this week's correspondence
fields.body:
A certain Peter Levitt of Huntingdon has sent us a poem concerning the already-missed Ofsted chief. " I came over all a-quiver last week and I have just come round and to my delight I realise that Mr W has gone. I waxed lyrical." Prepare yourselves:

Remember, remember the first of November,
Tory Telegraph plot
I see no reasons
Why Woodhead's malfeasance
Should ever be forgot
... or forgiven for that matter!

"I know, it doesn't scan and the rhymes are poor - but I feel so much better!" he concludes. We can only hope that Peter isn't planning a poetry-writing session in the literacy hour.

"Thank goodness Chris Woodhead has gone," concurs Richard Neale, chairman of an ATL committee. "However, the real question is what happens to Ofsted now? It must be seen to be an independent body by everybody involved in education. Inspections are part of the education system, but the Ofsted models need a total remodelling so that all involved know that something positive comes out of each inspection. The naming and shaming aspect of Ofsted has become part of its culture and Chris Woodhead played on that to his full advantage.That is why so many are pleased to see him go."

Rod Woodhouse is unhappy with last week's pre-budget announcement. "Yet again Gordon Brown has promised headteachers that "the cheque's in the post". When will David Blunkett tell him that it doesn't quite work like that? The government has no mechanism, practical or legal, to send funds direct to schools. ALL monies from central government have to go via each LEA. They cannot be bypassed. The government, thank God, can ensure that nothing is siphoned off, however it is up to individual LEAs as to when schools are allocated such monies. Could they be sitting on the interest?"

Another correspondent points out that London teachers are getting poorer, thanks to a cut in the value of the London Weighting. "The London Allowance is totally inadequate in the face of the spiralling costs of living and working in the capital. The government has invented a second level of recruitment and retention allowance of £1,782, but most schools do not have the budget to fund this for all teachers and so are awarding it to none of their staff," she adds, suggesting that the recent £6000 London Allowance to Metropolitan police officers "sets a reasonable benchmark."

Our piece on the difficulties faced by female Asian university students prompted one reader to point out that Hindu and Islamic communities can take very different views of the subject.

Literacy co-ordinator Caroline Bannister takes issue with a report in the Guardian's Are we Dumbing Down? special. Hollywood films are not the only way that pupils experience Shakespeare, she says, but points out that an initial screening of a film or animation is a good way to stimulate children's interest. Her own Year Six group began by watching Leon Garfield's 'Animated Tales: Macbeth', then saw a children's production of the play at a Wimbledon theatre. and were 'spellbound'. "As I began teaching about the play in my literacy hour today, by comparing the treatment of the Witches in the original Elizabethan text and both productions seen, it was immediately evident that the children could read and understand the play text as well as draw on the Animated Tale and the Theatre Production versions with great enthusiasm and knowledge," she writes.

You can email us at editor@educationunlimited.co.uk. Please let us know if you would prefer to remain anonymous. Contributions may be edited. Or post a message at the EducationUnlimited talkboards.

webTitle: ITV should have shown Morse first, says creator

fields.headline: ITV should have shown Morse first, says creator
fields.standfirst:
ITV defends Morse screening
ITV blunder kills Morse down under
Review: How Morse met his maker
Seven Network
Inspector Morse: The Remorseful Day
fields.trailText:
4.15pm update: Inspector Morse creator Colin Dexter has said he was astonished that the final episode of the long-running drama was not premiered on ITV. By Lisa O'Carroll.
ITV defends Morse screening
ITV blunder kills Morse down under
Review: How Morse met his maker
fields.body:
Inspector Morse's creator, author Colin Dexter, today said he was astonished and disappointed that the adaptation of his final work was not premiered on ITV.

"I am extremely surprised. I know nothing about it being shown in Australia," he said.

"Everyone here felt Wednesday was the first showing. Carlton are obviously relaxed about it, but I don't think anybody else would have been happy about this.

"Most people would have felt that the first public showing of the last Morse should have taken place, as directed and commissioned by the ITV network, on ITV.

When told that Carlton was justifying Australia's worldwide premiere by pointing out that Sydney was 14,000 miles away, Mr Dexter said: "I suppose it is true that it won't spoil it for viewers here, but I don't know if any amount of distance can justify letting another country show it first."

Mr Dexter, who decided to kill off Inspector Morse in his final book, The Remorseful Day, has enjoyed a close working relationship with ITV over the past 13 years.

He wrote at total of 13 Morse books, all of which have been adapted for ITV.

webTitle: ITV bosses defend Australian screening of Morse

fields.headline: ITV bosses defend screening Morse down under
fields.standfirst:
ITV blunder kills Morse down under
Review: How Morse met his maker
Seven Network
Inspector Morse: The Remorseful Day
fields.trailText:
3.30pm update: ITV chiefs have defended last night's Australian screening of the final episode of Inspector Morse, three days before it is due to go out in the UK, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
ITV blunder kills Morse down under
Review: How Morse met his maker
Seven Network
Inspector Morse: The Remorseful Day
fields.body:
It has been years in the planning and when it finally goes on air this Wednesday it is guaranteed an audience of more than 10m. Such is its popularity the repeats over the next 10 years will do equally as well.

But today ITV chiefs were strangely unfazed when they learned that the screening of the last ever episode of Inspector Morse, one of their biggest drama series, this week will not be a world premiere.

They spent £2m on the episode, The Remorseful Day, but today said it didn't matter that the show had already gone out elsewhere, albeit thousands of miles away in Australia.

"This is not unusual. Monsignor Reynard was seen in Australia before it was seen here," said a spokesman for Carlton about actor John Thaw's last programme before Inspector Morse.

"I know this because John mentioned that his brother, who lives in Australia, saw it there before it went out here."

The programme was made by Carlton and sold to Australia's Seven Network by their international sales team. It aired in the country last night.

The spokesman added: "We ran this past the network centre when we sold it and they said it was OK. The fact that this happened 14,000 miles away means that viewers will not be missing out. 99.99% of viewers will get pleasure out of this on Wednesday.

"If it had been somewhere like Belgium or Ireland we wouldn't have allowed it be broadcast before the UK because it might have spoiled it for viewers."

webTitle: Press concerns grow over US constitutional crisis

fields.headline: Press concerns grow over US constitutional crisis
fields.standfirst: Commentators fear that the current stalemate could give way to even more confusion over the US presidency, reports Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Commentators fear that the current stalemate could give way to even more confusion over the US presidency, reports Derek Brown.
fields.body:
After the excitement of last week, a certain weariness is creeping into the coverage of the US election saga. There is also growing alarm that the stalemate could develop into a full-blown constitutional crisis, and widespread predictions that whatever the outcome, the next president will be enfeebled by his clouded mandate.

From the heart of the action, the Palm Beach Post reports optimistically that the final outcome of the extraordinary contest could be known this week: " The road to the White House may have taken a decisive turn here early Sunday when a fatigued and divided Palm Beach County Elections Canvassing Board ordered a hand recount of the county's 462,657 presidential ballots. With Republican George W. Bush hanging on to an unofficial 288-vote lead in the race for Florida's 25 decisive electoral votes, the prospect of scouring the Democratic-leaning county's ballots for a fourth time was slammed by Republicans on the Sunday talk show circuit and will be challenged today at 9.30am in a federal court in Miami."

Dave McNeely, in a syndicated column for the Abilene Reporter-News, has no doubt about the key factor in the presidential race: "If Texas Gov. George W. Bush wins the presidential race, he would be well-advised to invite Ralph Nader to the inauguration. Because if Bush becomes president, it will have been because Nader was the Green Party's presidential candidate.

"While Nader received just 3 percent of the national vote and only 2 percent in Florida, most of the 96,000-plus votes Nader got in Florida would have gone to Democrat Al Gore. Whichever candidate wins Florida wins the presidency."

The Boston Globe faces up to an uncomfortable truth: "The scrutiny being applied to the 2000 presidential vote reveals an uncomfortable truth about American elections known to anyone who has ever volunteered as a poll worker in a campaign. Every year, in every county, elections are held that are fraught with error, confusion, jammed machines, lost or discarded ballots and disenfranchised voters.

The spotlight threatens to cause a contagion of recounts. The secretary of state, William Galvin, ordered a recount in all Boston precincts last week, concerned that thousands of votes on the eight ballot questions may have been ignored. In New Mexico a partial recount of the presidential vote is under way, and supporters of both Governor George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore are keeping an eye on Iowa, where any recount request must be made by Thursday."

The Chicago Sun Times asks the unthinkable question: what if ballot officials in Florida are unable to say whether Mr Gore or Mr Bush won? The paper lists a number of decidedly recondite possibilities. It says the decision could revert to the US congress, which could vote to install President Gore, President Bush, President Joe Lieberman, President Dick Cheney, or even President Denny Hastert (the speaker of the House of Representatives).

The New York Times chides Mr Bush for his latest court moves to block a new manual count in Florida's Palm Beach county: "The potential for new trouble was introduced by Governor George W. Bush, who moved in federal court to block the manual counting of ballots in Florida. It was a puzzling step from someone who earlier had rightly deplored the tendency toward litigation among Democrats. The obvious way out of the current mess is for the forces of Mr Bush and Vice President Al Gore to drop their actual and threatened lawsuits challenging the validity of the ballots and the vote counting in Florida and other states. If counting and recounting proceed unimpeded, we can know who the next president is by the end of the week."

The Dallas Morning News has a thoughtful editorial on the deep divisions in the nation. It urges both candidates to follow the advice of an earlier president facing even deeper divisions: Abraham Lincoln told his fellow Republicans in 1858, when the nation was fiercely split between pro-slavery and abolition, that "a house divided cannot stand."

The article goes on: "No matter who eventually wins the White House, he must move boldly to heal the fractures that will only weaken our body if left untended. Like Mr. Lincoln, George W. Bush or Al Gore will need to reach deep within themselves to find the language that heals our wounds. They also must match their words with strong moves that signify to those who opposed their election that they intend to earn the trust of all the people. This election's closeness will require the next president to put aside the more divisive parts of his agenda at first and concentrate on issues that stand a reasonable chance of securing passage."

webTitle: Morse finale broadcast in Australia

fields.headline: ITV blunder sees Morse finale revealed down under
fields.standfirst:
Review: how Morse met his maker
Seven Network website
Inspector Morse: The Remorseful Day
fields.trailText: 11.15am: As Morse mania builds to a crescendo in Britain, Australians already know the dramatic denouement of the last ever episode after it was aired on Seven Network last night. By Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
We have been told it is the final ever Morse and the nation is on tenterhooks.

But in an extraordinary bungle revealed today, millions of viewers have already seen the inspector's last gasp.

As Morse mania builds to a crescendo in Britain, Australians already know the dramatic denouement of the last ever episode after it was aired on the country's Seven Network last night.

The Remorseful Day, made and distributed by Carlton, was billed as a movie premiere on the national free-to-air channel owned by Australian media mogul Kerry Stokes.

But the channel, which consistently comes second in the Australian ratings to Kerry Packer's Channel Nine, did not trumpet the showing of Morse as a world first.

ITV, which kept the British date of the eagerly anticipated adaptation of Colin Dexter's final Morse novel under wraps for months, is running Inspector Morse's final two hours on Wednesday evening.

Last night the pulling power of John Thaw, who plays the Oxford-based chief inspector, and his sidekick Lewis (Kevin Whately), was pitched against Samuel L Jackson and Kevin Spacey, as Channel Nine premiered The Negotiator.

No ratings for the battle have been released yet.

Inspector Morse's grouchy countenance is a familiar face to Australian viewers, to whom Morse has regularly been syndicated. The inspector even visited the country in one feature-length episode.

Last year, Carlton successfully sold Inspector Morse to the Bravo Network's film and arts channels, which covers the whole of south America.

British television series are regularly syndicated to Australia. The Royle Family, The Bill, and Ibiza Uncovered have been recent hits with public service broadcaster ABC buying the most UK programmes.

In February, the Seven Network and Granada Group jointly established Australia's largest independent television production company.

The new outfit, in which both firms have a 50% stake, is producing programmes for the Australian broadcasting market, while increasing the access of both companies to each other's distribution markets.

webTitle: The Gleaners and I

fields.headline: The Gleaners and I
fields.standfirst:
The Gleaners and I
London film festival ***
fields.trailText: The term "gleaners" refers to a now-defunct strand of mainly female agricultural workers who flourished in feudal France. The "I", in this case, is film-maker Agnes Varda, apparently still going strong in her eighth decade. Marry the two and you have a likably mercurial documentary, shot on a flyweight digital camera in the first person, Nanni Moretti-style.
fields.body:
The term "gleaners" refers to a now-defunct strand of mainly female agricultural workers who flourished in feudal France. The "I", in this case, is film-maker Agnes Varda, apparently still going strong in her eighth decade. Marry the two and you have a likably mercurial documentary, shot on a flyweight digital camera in the first person, Nanni Moretti-style.

Taking her lead from impressionist paintings and dictionary definitions ("to glean is to gather after the harvest"), Varda sets out to trace how the gleaner's art has adapted to today's mechanised world. Her odyssey leads her through a France that is tipping towards winter and spotlights a thriving scavenger culture on the fringes of mainstream society. Gleaning, she finds, has become an eclectic feast of late. True, the unemployed rustics who forage through a discarded potato mountain appear the most obvious descendants of the peasants of old. But the boho artist who collects his materials from the roadside is, in a sense, a gleaner too. As are the illicit fishermen plucking sandy oysters out of the retreating tide, or the crusty town kids charged with rifling the dustbins at their local Intermarche.

In younger, ruder hands, The Gleaners and I would surely have wound up a far more abrasive affair, touching as it does on the charged issue of direct action among a disenfranchised underclass. Except that Varda shies decorously away from obvious political conclusions. Instead, her line of inquiry is gentle, curious, her role more that of a browser than a director. The tack pays off in a film that is at once airily free-form and oddly profound.

In shooting her documentary, Varda spent six months with France's modern-day gleaners; these millennial Wombles feeding from society's over-spill. She comes away with a digital scrapbook of beguiling social vignettes. That and a pair of high-backed chairs for her sitting room at home.

 At the National Film Theatre, London SE1, today. Box office: 020-7928 3232.

webTitle: Fundraiser boosts arthritis research

fields.headline: Fundraiser boosts arthritis research
fields.trailText: Arthritis researchers at Imperial College, London are to benefit from a £32,000 grant single handedly raised by an arthritis sufferer, who has spent 21 years collecting money outside Sainsbury's stores.
fields.body:
Arthritis researchers at Imperial College, London are to benefit from a £32,000 grant single handedly raised by an arthritis sufferer, who has spent 21 years collecting money outside Sainsbury's stores.

David Paterson, who had pioneering surgery in 1986 to alleviate a crippling arthritic condition, will tomorrow present a cheque to Professor Andrew Amis, head of the computer-aided systems engineering group in the Imperial's mechanical engineering department.

Paterson has spent more than 147,000 hours and covered nearly half a million miles collecting for the Arthritis Research Campaign outside Sainsbury's, Savacentre and Homebase stores across the UK. He has raised a total of £498,000 for the ARC so far.

The £32,000 cheque will be used by the Imperial group to support a research student. The group are trying to help surgeons improve operating techniques on patients with knee problems. The Arthritis Research Campaign exists solely to find the cause of and cure for arthritis and all other forms of rheumatic disease.

For further information see: http://www.arc.org.uk, and http://www.ic.ac.uk

webTitle: Explained: global warming

fields.headline: Global warming
fields.standfirst:
Representatives of 180 countries have gathered in the Dutch town of the Hague for a key two-week meeting on climate change. What is the aim of the gathering - and what is it likely to achieve in practice? Joanna Griffiths and Julian Glover explain.

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Representatives of 180 countries have gathered in the Dutch town of the Hague for a key two-week meeting on climate change. What is the aim of the gathering - and what is it likely to achieve in practice? Joanna Griffiths and Julian Glover explain.
fields.body:
What is happening in the Hague?
A massive international conference (its formal title is the 6th Conference of the Parties, or COP6) has begun. It aims to establish the ways in which the international community can combat climate change - and then hold them to their promises.

Haven't there been conferences before?
Yes - lots. This latest gathering is the culmination of a decade of international negotiations. In 1992 at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) was opened for signature. This expressed concern about the effects of climate change (such as the movement of agricultural zones, the melting of polar ice caps and rising sea levels). And in 1997, governments established the Kyoto protocol, ratification of which would set up targets for reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

What are the targets?
Developed countries agreed to cut their collective greenhouse emissions by an average of 5.2% below 1990 levels over the years 2008-2012. Different countries adopted different targets: the EU committed to a cut of 8%, the US to 7% and Japan to 6%. Russia and the Ukraine agreed to stabilise at 1990 levels.

So what is new about the Hague meeting?
It is a make-or-break gathering at which countries will accept or refuse the terms of the Kyoto protocol. In order for the protocol to come into practice, it must be ratified by 55 parties to the convention. Some of them must be developed industrial countries, which account for 55% of the carbon dioxide emissions.

Why does this matter?
Because the world's climate appears to be changing. During the closing years of the last century, record temperatures and a run of extreme weather caused havoc around the world. Scientists at the UK meteorological office say that average temperatures have risen by about 0.6C since 1860 (when global records began). Six of the warmest years on record occurred during the 90s, with 1998 the warmest year since records began and 1999 not far behind.

So what are the causes of climate change?
Some of the changes are probably part of the earth's natural climatic cycles, but most scientists agree that man has had a big impact. The intergovernmental panel on climate change says that rising temperatures are "unlikely to be entirely natural in origin".

How does it occur?
Energy that comes from the sun in the form of short-wave radiation reaches the earth's surface undisturbed and warms it. Most of this energy is emitted back into space in the form of long-wave radiation, but some of this radiation is trapped in the atmosphere by a blanket of water vapour and trace gases called greenhouse gases. The main naturally occurring greenhouse gases are: water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N20). Additional greenhouse gases are created by industrial processes: they are artificial chemicals called halocarbons (CFCs, HFCs and PFCs) and long-lived gases such as sulphur hexafluoride (SF6).

But how has man upset the process?
Plants and animals have exchanged carbon dioxide with the atmosphere in a carbon cycle that has remained in balance for the last 10,000 years. Since the industrial revolution, humans have disturbed this balance - by burning fossil fuels (such as oil, coal, and gas), by destroying forests, releasing stored carbon; and by agricultural practices such as the intensive rearing of cattle and high-scale plantation of rice (which produces methane).

What's the evidence?
Carbon dioxide is the most important man-made greenhouse gas, accounting for about two-thirds of the human-derived greenhouse effect. Carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere have increased by about 30% in the last 200 years, from less than 280 parts per million (ppm) to 368 ppm today. The lobby group Friends of the Earth forecast that if we continue to burn fossil fuels at our current rate, atmospheric carbon dioxide will be at twice pre-industrial levels by 2030, and three times that figure by 2100.

What are the effects of climate change?
One prediction suggests that if current trends persist, air temperatures could rise by 1-3.5C by 2100. Recent research published in the magazine Nature has suggested this rise could be more like 6C in the next century. As the world warms, the average sea level is expected to rise - by between 15cm and 95cm by 2100 relative to 1990 - as a result of thermal expansion of the oceans and melting of the glaciers and ice sheets. The 90s were not only the warmest decade of the 20th century, but also of the millennium. In addition to this trend of high temperatures, we can expect intense precipitation, long dry spells, frequent hurricanes and extremely high temperatures sometimes.

What is the worst-case scenario?
The worst-case scenario forecast by scientists is the "runaway greenhouse effect" in which all the factors that cause global warming would eventually override the factors which work against it. Forests, for example, are thought to counter carbon dioxide emissions, because plants absorb carbon dioxide. So one of the suggested solutions to climate change is to plant vast forests.

Recent research published in Nature, however, suggests that planting forests on areas which were formerly covered with ice would darken the earth's surface, making it absorb more of the sun's radiation. Further research from Nature suggests that forests will only absorb carbon up to a point, after which plants will become saturated, and will begin to emit it.

There are also fears that if the Arctic tundra begins to melt, then organic matter stored in the ice will be oxidised. This could release huge amounts of carbon dioxide and methane. The melting of the Arctic ice cap would also reduce the amount of solar radiation the planet reflects, allowing more heat to be trapped.

So will countries agree to the Kyoto protocol?
It is far from clear that they will. Many campaigning groups are concerned about a technical detail in the Kyoto protocol, which allows countries to offset their domestic emissions. In short, it allows a participant meeting its emissions reduction target to trade their surplus with another country. This could be by richer countries to avoid making significant cuts to their emissions. The Hague meeting will decide how much countries will be able to use these mechanisms to avoid actual cuts in domestic emissions.

Who is involved in this?
The USA, Canada, Japan, New Zealand and Australia want to reduce the impact on their economies of the Kyoto agreement. They want most of their emissions targets to be fulfilled by these emissions-trading mechanisms. The EU has been keener to make real cuts in emissions. But many EU governments, including the UK, want the US to ratify the Kyoto agreement, so may be forced to make concessions. Meanwhile, the developing countries are divided on some issues and in agreement on others. The key forces are China and India. Saudi Arabia and other Opec countries are asking for compensation for lost revenues from the export of oil.

webTitle: Concerns over gaps in education research

fields.headline: Concerns over gaps in education research
fields.trailText: Academics have raised fresh concerns over the lack of expertise in key research topics aimed at improving teaching in schools and universities.
fields.body:
Academics have raised fresh concerns over the lack of expertise in key research topics aimed at improving teaching in schools and universities.

The concerns have emerged following the launch of £7.5m worth of research projects as part of the largest educational research programme seen in the UK, with funding of £12.5m over five years.

The former chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, enraged academics last year when he suggested that much of the £70m national education research effort was not worth funding.

Researchers coordinating the programme have listed a number of areas in which they were unable to commission projects due to the lack of high-quality applications from academics. These include important topics such as post-compulsory education, workplace learning, lifelong learning, languages and arts in schools and special needs education.

The £12.5m teaching and learning programme, commissioned by the Economic and Social Research Council, aims to support research that will improve the achievement of learners at all ages and stages of education.

A review of UK educational research for the programme has revealed that "expertise is widely and unevenly distributed."

John Kanefsky, assistant director of the programme, said that some researchers lack the skills necessary to conduct large-scale, quantitative research and experimental studies.

The teaching and learning programme aims to improve research capacity in the area with a series of training and networking programmes.

Nine major research projects were launched at a conference last week. These include projects aiming to increase the attainment of primary school pupils through better home-school cooperation, identify ways in which teachers help pupils to learn more effectively, and improve teaching environments in university undergraduate courses.

Details of the projects can be found on the programme's website: http://www.ex.ac.uk/ESRC-TLRP/

webTitle: How to put the word to rights

fields.headline: How to put the word to rights
fields.standfirst: Journalists who write for the web are being forced into the courts to defend their copyright. Now, says Sean Dodson, one man thinks he has the solution, a site that markets articles to editors
fields.trailText: Journalists who write for the web are being forced into the courts to defend their copyright. Now, one man thinks he has the solution, a site that markets articles to editors. By Sean Dodson.
fields.body:
Journalists are not used to taking up cudgels for copyright. But now a number of recent high-profile disputes over the issue have begun to make many of them sit up and start fighting for their rights on the web.

Last month, leading online journal Salon.com sent out contracts to its freelance writers. For most, this was the first contract the publication had ever sent them. The contracts asked the writers to give up resale rights to their published work in exchange for 25% of the resale fee.

Salon managing editor Scott Rosenberg told the Village Voice the contracts were an "honest attempt to secure resale rights individually - we make no claims to have the rights until a writer signs - and to compensate writers for those rights."

Not true, say a number of writers, including San Francisco-based Sam Witt and Sean Durkin and Media-week (US) columnist Catherine Seipp, who claim Salon is selling work on which they still own copyright. And what's more, with Salon's stock dropping below $1 (70p), many US pundits saw the contracts as nothing more than a transparent rights grab.

The dispute followed a number of high-profile cases in the US and UK over freelance rights. Steve Brill, the self-appointed watchdog of the US media and one-time editor of Brill's Content, got into trouble when he launched his massive e-publishers, Contentville.com in June. He angered hundreds of writers when he began selling work on which they held copyright direct to the public without their consent.

Then, in September, the Authors Guild, the largest advocacy and trade group representing writers in the US, filed a lawsuit in New York against five corporations - including Dow Jones Interactive, Reuters and Reed Elsevier - accusing them of years of systematic copyright infringement of thousands of freelance writers' articles. And next month the National Writers Union will appeal to the Supreme Court in a case against the New York Times.

Back in the UK, Serena Mackesy, a former contributor to the Independent and best-selling author of The Temp, found sections of her novel for sale on US search engine Northern Light. Mackesy had originally written The Temp as a column in the Independent. She retained copyright and went on to sell it as a novel to Random House. After publication, she found a significant number of the original columns that were first published in the Independent - and which comprise the majority of the novel - for sale on Northern Light for $3.95 a pop.

Even after the discrepancy was pointed out, Northern Light repeatedly refused to take the offending material off its site, saying that it had bought the material from the Independent in good faith. After a flurry of solicitors' letters and a number of transatlantic phone calls, the offending sections of The Temp were finally removed.

One US writer thinks that the problem of electronic rights could be solved not in the courts, but on the web. Last month, David Wallis, seven years a contributor to the New York Times (and incidentally one of Steve Brill's most vocal critics) launched Featurewell.com. The site is an electronic marketplace that enables editors to read and then purchase the rights to publish articles by what it claims are the world's finest journalists. The site is effectively an online agency for writers. There is no subscription fee, editors pay for the rights to publish stories on an à la carte basis.

Wallis, who has written for most of the UK broadsheets, says he got the idea for Featurewell after managing to be the only print journalist to interview Manuel Noriega while he was in prison in 1998. Wallis sold the same article 21 times and made more than $20,000.

"As the internet took hold, I noticed how contracts that I and other writers would receive had become more stringent," says Wallis. "I thought we could turn the tables and efficiently market our work and maybe also motivate writers to cross out clauses in their contracts."

Traditionally, the rights to the article revert back to the writer after a gap of between one and 90 days. The paper or magazine can work directly on reselling the writer's work and, if successful, the writer will, more than likely, receive 50% of "spot sales". However, most publications work through a third party - the large syndication houses. Then the third party takes 50% and the remainder is split evenly between the writer and the publication, leaving the writer with 25% of the sale.

Featurewell is offering writers 60% of resale and the writer retains copyright on all material sold. Of the 40% that is left, Wallis claims to split this with the publication in which the piece first appeared. This, says Wallis, gives Featurewell the cachet of being associated with top publications and clean copy that requires no further editing.

"First of all I believe it is good business to treat writers well and fairly and I think if it is left to corporations to decide, then the writer will always be the one to get the short end of the stick," argues Wallis. "So I thought it would be good business and politically satisfying to start a company that paid more to writers and allowed editors to shop around."

Wallis insists that there is a market out there - and cites his own career as a prime example. "I've probably earned a third of my living over the past few years solely on foreign sales of pieces I've already written," he says. He claims he makes $60,000 a year on average. His list of writers is impressive: Pulitzer Prize winner Justin Kaplan, Claudia Dreifus of the New York Times and a number of expatriate Brits, namely Alex Kershaw of the New York Times and the freelancer Tessa Souter. Now Wallis wants to appeal to UK writers and editors, too, and has signed a deal with British translation company Pretorious to offer foreign language editions. And soon he hopes to offer original content as well.

In the first month of operation, Featurewell has sold more than $5,000 worth of articles - about a dozen pieces. Not much, but Wallis says that this was all through word of mouth, and calls it "a really encouraging start". But will there be a market? After all, if so many writers are being asked to sign away their electronic rights (or have already done so), who will be left to write for Featurewell? Wallis says that we are beginning to see a backlash against stringent contracts. "The more publications try to issue these contracts, the more [writers] will rebel, the more content I will be able to get my hands on."

Last but not least is the issue of money. "Writers are remarkable," he says. "On the one hand they are some of the most literate people in the world, but on the other they barely read their contracts. And at the end of the day we are underpaid. But now with publishers wanting to restrict us from reselling our work and with freelance fees frozen in time as if inflation did not exist - well frankly that is not fair."
fields.bodyText: Journalists are not used to taking up cudgels for copyright. But now a number of recent high-profile disputes over the issue have begun to make many of them sit up and start fighting for their rights on the web. Last month, leading online journal Salon.com sent out contracts to its freelance writers. For most, this was the first contract the publication had ever sent them. The contracts asked the writers to give up resale rights to their published work in exchange for 25% of the resale fee. Salon managing editor Scott Rosenberg told the Village Voice the contracts were an "honest attempt to secure resale rights individually - we make no claims to have the rights until a writer signs - and to compensate writers for those rights." Not true, say a number of writers, including San Francisco-based Sam Witt and Sean Durkin and Media-week (US) columnist Catherine Seipp, who claim Salon is selling work on which they still own copyright. And what's more, with Salon's stock dropping below $1 (70p), many US pundits saw the contracts as nothing more than a transparent rights grab. The dispute followed a number of high-profile cases in the US and UK over freelance rights. Steve Brill, the self-appointed watchdog of the US media and one-time editor of Brill's Content, got into trouble when he launched his massive e-publishers, Contentville.com in June. He angered hundreds of writers when he began selling work on which they held copyright direct to the public without their consent. Then, in September, the Authors Guild, the largest advocacy and trade group representing writers in the US, filed a lawsuit in New York against five corporations - including Dow Jones Interactive, Reuters and Reed Elsevier - accusing them of years of systematic copyright infringement of thousands of freelance writers' articles. And next month the National Writers Union will appeal to the Supreme Court in a case against the New York Times. Back in the UK, Serena Mackesy, a former contributor to the Independent and best-selling author of The Temp, found sections of her novel for sale on US search engine Northern Light. Mackesy had originally written The Temp as a column in the Independent. She retained copyright and went on to sell it as a novel to Random House. After publication, she found a significant number of the original columns that were first published in the Independent - and which comprise the majority of the novel - for sale on Northern Light for $3.95 a pop. Even after the discrepancy was pointed out, Northern Light repeatedly refused to take the offending material off its site, saying that it had bought the material from the Independent in good faith. After a flurry of solicitors' letters and a number of transatlantic phone calls, the offending sections of The Temp were finally removed. One US writer thinks that the problem of electronic rights could be solved not in the courts, but on the web. Last month, David Wallis, seven years a contributor to the New York Times (and incidentally one of Steve Brill's most vocal critics) launched Featurewell.com. The site is an electronic marketplace that enables editors to read and then purchase the rights to publish articles by what it claims are the world's finest journalists. The site is effectively an online agency for writers. There is no subscription fee, editors pay for the rights to publish stories on an à la carte basis. Wallis, who has written for most of the UK broadsheets, says he got the idea for Featurewell after managing to be the only print journalist to interview Manuel Noriega while he was in prison in 1998. Wallis sold the same article 21 times and made more than $20,000. "As the internet took hold, I noticed how contracts that I and other writers would receive had become more stringent," says Wallis. "I thought we could turn the tables and efficiently market our work and maybe also motivate writers to cross out clauses in their contracts." Traditionally, the rights to the article revert back to the writer after a gap of between one and 90 days. The paper or magazine can work directly on reselling the writer's work and, if successful, the writer will, more than likely, receive 50% of "spot sales". However, most publications work through a third party - the large syndication houses. Then the third party takes 50% and the remainder is split evenly between the writer and the publication, leaving the writer with 25% of the sale. Featurewell is offering writers 60% of resale and the writer retains copyright on all material sold. Of the 40% that is left, Wallis claims to split this with the publication in which the piece first appeared. This, says Wallis, gives Featurewell the cachet of being associated with top publications and clean copy that requires no further editing. "First of all I believe it is good business to treat writers well and fairly and I think if it is left to corporations to decide, then the writer will always be the one to get the short end of the stick," argues Wallis. "So I thought it would be good business and politically satisfying to start a company that paid more to writers and allowed editors to shop around." His list of writers is impressive: Pulitzer Prize winner Justin Kaplan, Claudia Dreifus of the New York Times and a number of expatriate Brits, namely Alex Kershaw of the New York Times and the freelancer Tessa Souter. Now Wallis wants to appeal to UK writers and editors, too, and has signed a deal with British translation company Pretorious to offer foreign language editions. And soon he hopes to offer original content as well. In the first month of operation, Featurewell has sold more than $5,000 worth of articles - about a dozen pieces. Not much, but Wallis says that this was all through word of mouth, and calls it "a really encouraging start". But will there be a market? After all, if so many writers are being asked to sign away their electronic rights (or have already done so), who will be left to write for Featurewell? Wallis says that we are beginning to see a backlash against stringent contracts. "The more publications try to issue these contracts, the more [writers] will rebel, the more content I will be able to get my hands on." Last but not least is the issue of money. "Writers are remarkable," he says. "On the one hand they are some of the most literate people in the world, but on the other they barely read their contracts. And at the end of the day we are underpaid. But now with publishers wanting to restrict us from reselling our work and with freelance fees frozen in time as if inflation did not exist - well frankly that is not fair."

webTitle: Scholes and Owen out of Italy friendly

fields.headline: Scholes and Owen out of Italy friendly
fields.trailText: Michael Owen and Paul Scholes have been forced to withdraw from the England squad to face Italy on Wednesday night after suffering minor injuries.
fields.body:
Michael Owen and Paul Scholes have been forced to withdraw from the England squad to face Italy on Wednesday night after suffering minor injuries.

Owen took part in a light training session this morning but had to pull out with a back injury, while Scholes performed a full session but was then deemed to have a thigh strain too serious for him to travel.

With Wes Brown and Alan Smith already having pulled out, caretaker coach Peter Taylor has been left with 22 players for Wednesday night's game in Turin. However Gareth Southgate is expected to recover from a facial injury suffered last weekend.

The absences of Owen and Scholes will be keenly felt, especially as they were two of the few players with any real amount of international experience behind them in the squad. Taylor is now expected to choose between Robbie Fowler and Kevin Phillips to partner Emile Heskey up front.

webTitle: First bodies removed from Austrian train fire

fields.headline: First bodies removed from Austrian train fire
fields.standfirst: More about the Kitzsteinhorn fire
fields.trailText: Recovery teams in Austria today removed the first of some 159 bodies from the scene of Saturday's Alpine train fire, as the Foreign Office confirmed that a British ski instructor, Kevin Challis, was among those who died.
fields.body:
Recovery teams in Austria today removed the first of some 159 bodies from the scene of Saturday's Alpine train fire, as the Foreign Office confirmed that a British ski instructor, Kevin Challis, was among those who died.

Twenty nine bodies will be flown to the provincial capital, Salzburg, for DNA tests. The force of the blaze means that identification by traditional means is unlikely to be possible.

The deaths occurred when a train carriage on a funicular railway caught fire in a tunnel at Kitzsteinhorn as it was taking skiers and snowboarders to the slopes.

With tunnel finally free of smoke yesterday afternoon, rescuers from the Austrian army and fire service were finally able to enter the tunnel from the top end to avoid any risk of the burnt-out carriage slipping downhill.

What they found exposed them to what Salzburg provincial governor Franz Schausberger called "a heavy psychological toll". "It must be said that the salvage operation is extremely difficult," he said. "The victims are next to, in and under the train." . About 110 recovery workers were at the site today and planned to continue their efforts round the clock. But Franz Lang, chief of Salzburg's criminal police, said that the teams would have to be constantly changed because of the nature of the work.

Mr Challis, the British man who died in the fire, was a ski instructor who lived in Austria and had an Austrian wife. He is thought to have escaped the blazing train but been engulfed by flames and toxic fumes as he fled up the tunnel, his widow said today.

Mr Challis's eight-year-old daughter Siobhan had already gone up the mountain on the train and was waiting for her father at the top when disaster struck, Christl Challis said.

Mrs Challis said her husband's family were travelling to Austria to be with her from his home town of Bridport, Dorset.

Although uncertainty persists about the total number of people who boarded the train on Saturday morning, it was designed to carry 180 people and is believed to have been full. The dead, many of them young skiers, included the German freestyle world champion skier, Sandra Schmitt, and her parents. The death toll includes 52 Austrians; 42 Germans; 10 Japanese; eight Americans and three Slovenes. The authorities had names but no nationalities for more than 44 other missing people.

"We're reckoning with a number of victims somewhere under 175," Mr Lang said.

Mr Lang said that large parts of the car had melted, making it difficult to separate the bodies from the car itself. "We will need some time for this work," he said

Many of the bodies are charred beyond recognition and authorities believe it could be weeks before they are identified.

Officials said 18 people - 12 of whom saved themselves from the cable car after they broke its window with a ski and six who had been waiting at the top of the tunnel - survived the disaster. One of the survivors was in serious condition with lung damage.

The others were released from hospital yesterday. One survivor, Gerhard Hanetseder from the town Gallspach in Upper Austria, told Austrian radio that smoke entered carriage soon after it began its ascent. He noticed the fire after the train entered the tunnel. "Then panic spread. We tried desperately to get the doors open. The panic got ever worse. In the meantime the entire cabin was on fire," he said. "By chance, a few of the passengers, using ski boots or ski poles or other implements tried to smash the Plexiglas windows.

"I saw in the last minute someone jump out and then I tried to grab my daughter, I gave her a push. And then I also somehow got out."

Those missing were presumed killed by flames and acrid smoke inside the car or in the tunnel while trying to escape. The cause of the fire remained unclear.
