webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week thirteen, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week thirteen, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Patrick Murray dissects the latest bets
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):, Scott Murray = £165.21, Sean Ingle = £108.86, Paul MacInnes = £56.46, Football Unlimited punters collective = £47.77
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):, Scott Murray = £165.21, Sean Ingle = £108.86, Paul MacInnes = £56.46, Football Unlimited punters collective = £47.77

Scott Murray:
Preston v Crewe: no goalscorer £5 @ 10/1. Bet lost.

Can it really be true? A Scott Murray speculative 10/1 punt doesn't come off! Has the world gone mad? I'm so used to congratulating Mr M on landing yet another long-odds winner I really don't know what to say when faced with failure.

One good thing, at least, is that Scott is now backing no goalscorer rather than no goals. I seem to remember that wasn't the case a few weeks ago so at least I have achieved something in the brief time allowed to me to warp young minds.

What is slightly worrying though is the frequency with which Mr M seems to choose live games to bet on. I will give him the benefit of the doubt on this occasion, after all few things are more boring than cheering on no goals in a live game. But it is all too easy to fall into the trap of having an 'interest bet', giving yourself a financial interest to spice up what might otherwise be a fairly uninteresting game. Does anyone out there recognise themselves in that description?

Of course most of us do it, and I'm not saying there is no place in life for interest bets - far from it in fact, betting should be fun. But if you want to be a disciplined and winning gambler then these types of bets must be avoided.

But enough, this is doubtless a mere hiccup in the unstoppable march towards the £200 mark by the inestimable Mr M. He's done nothing wrong, but one can't expect every 10/1 shot to come off.

Sean Ingle:
£5 double: Bradford v Everton 0 or 1 Goals @ 2/1 and Valladolid to draw with Alaves @ 2/1. Bet lost.

He is the bane of my life is Mr Ingle. Well maybe not THE bane, I reckon that title can safely go to my forever-nearly-finished-but-never-actually-finished PhD, but he certainly qualifies as a bane. And he knows it. And he does it on purpose I'm sure.

This week's Ingle bet is, predictably enough, another two fingers up to all I hold dear. A double consisting of 0 or 1 goals and a draw, three offences for the price of one. Now that is value.

I don't have a major problem with betting on 0 or 1 goals, but if you believe a game will be low scoring then generally no goalscorer represents better value at three or four times the price. In this case it would have turned a winner into a loser but would it have done so four times out of five?

Similarly I don't have a major problem with backing the draw but I have to think it is far easier to pick a underrated or overrated team than it is to find an underrated draw.

My real objection - surprise surprise I hear regular readers of this column say - is to the double. Greed is a terrible thing. Impatience is a terrible thing. Both are expensive things. Once again Mr Ingle costs himself money by his inability to see the wisdom in slow, steady accumulation over gung-ho I-want-it-all-and-I-want-it-now tactics.

I can hardly wait for next Friday and the suitably biting riposte from Mr I.

Laith Amiry,
who writes for Weekend Football, a betting prediction site: £10 treble -Ipswich to beat Charlton @ evens, Sunderland to beat Southampton @ 4/7, and Chelsea to beat Leeds @ 4/5. Bet lost.

This is all very cogent and well argued but I don't see much talk of value here. Reading between the lines I fear Mr Amiry is on the lookout for winners rather than profit (see virtually everything I've written in my columns before if you don't know where I'm coming from here).

The chances of finding three value bets in the Premiership of a weekend would seem to me to be pretty slim. This is what the football the bookies know best, and as they have a 12% overround margin in their favour, is it very likely they will get the odds so badly wrong as to overcome that margin in three separate cases.

Of trebles the less said the better I'm sure you'll all agree. Of favourite backing ditto. Not my idea of the way forward as regular readers will know. So the poor old FUPC now has even less money than the inestimable Mr MacInnes thanks to his underhand tactics of taking a holiday and thus avoiding the inevitable losing punt. Hopefully he will be back next week with more amusing tales of expensive last minute equalisers. As will I, dear punter, as will I.

webTitle: Railtrack rewards shareholders as profits slump

fields.headline: Railtrack rewards shareholders as profits slump
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Railtrack is to pay its shareholders higher dividends rather than invest the money on improving Britain's railways - despite interim results out today showing a slump in profits.
fields.body:
Railtrack is to pay its shareholders higher dividends rather than invest the money on improving Britain's railways - despite interim results out today showing a slump in profits.

The interim results showed that the company's pre-tax profits had fallen by almost a third from April to September.

But the £175m profit, which the company is using to fund a 5% rise in its shareholders' dividend, does not include the period after the Hatfield train crash. Railtrack's profits are expected to fall further when a £250m bill for the emergency repair work and subsequent delays are added to its balance sheet.

The decision to raise the dividend means the company will have less money to reinvest in the UK's rail network.

Mick Rix, general secretary of the train drivers' union Aslef, said it was "extraordinary" that the Railtrack board should reward its shareholders while "presiding over a shambles unprecedented in the railway industry".

Railtrack has apologised for delays due to speed restrictions and engineering work and announced it would be offering a compensation package.

This weekend it was reported that the train operators, which are losing around £2m a day in revenues, are demanding up to £200m in compensation. It is believed that some are even considering withholding their track access payments, worth around £2.2bn each year, until Railtrack pays.

Under the rules of its operating licence, Railtrack must pay compensation if the network is not open to normal levels of traffic or if it is disturbed because of engineering work.

City analysts expect Railtrack to take a special provision in the first half of the year to cover the costs of the repair work. "Given all the operational problems this year - in the shape of the worsening delays and the Hatfield crash - it seems likely that substantial provisions will be made to cover short-term maintenance expenses. Consequently we expect the current year's results to be significantly below last year's," Deutsche Bank transport analyst Richard Hannah said.

webTitle: M&S considers removing brand name from around 50 stores

fields.headline: M&S considers dropping brand name in up to 50 stores
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Marks & Spencer has confirmed it is considering ditching its brand name in as many as 50 underperforming stores. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer has confirmed it is considering ditching its brand name in as many as 50 underperforming stores.

The company has decided not to close the poorly performing stores because it is worried about the negative publicity this would cause.

Instead, it is considering creating a more downmarket second-string brand and renaming the stores. According to weekend newspaper reports M&S chairman Luc Vandevelde is targeting the customers of C&A, the low-cost clothing chain that closes in January.

A M&S spokesman said: "Nothing is sacrosanct with regard to restoring the profitability of this business. We're very determined to get back on track but we've made no decisions and we are not in a position to discuss whether we will change the name yet."

M&S has already dropped the long-running St Michael tag and the company recently made its first foray into unbranded stores. Last month M&S launched a chain of lingerie stores under the brand msl, marking the first time the retailer had opened a store without the Marks & Spencer name above the door.

webTitle: Inspector Morse review

fields.headline: How Morse met his maker
fields.standfirst:
Our man down under, Patrick Barkham, is one of millions who have already seen Inspector Morse's final outing. Here Mediaguardian.co.uk scoops the nation with the first genuine review.
ITV blunder kills Morse down under
Seven Network website
Inspector Morse: The Remorseful Day
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: Our man down under, Patrick Barkham, is one of the millions who have already seen Inspector Morse's final outing. Here Mediaguardian.co.uk scoops the nation with the first genuine review.
ITV blunder kills Morse down under.
fields.body:
Every Morse fan knows this is the end for the chief inspector, so no reviewer can spoil it. Happily, the makers of the last ever episode of Inspector Morse don't ruin things either. The Remorseful Day is a back-to-basics Morse rather than a "best of" Morse.

Episodes of Morse were always two hours spent in television's slow lane, with lots of lingering shots of Oxford's dreaming spires and John Thaw's face, fascinatingly wrinkled in short-temper.

There is plenty more here as, true to the series' first principles, the finale features an impossibly high murder count filmed at a splendidly languid pace, allowing the drama of Morse's demise to build and build.

This is a wintry Morse, perfect for a Wednesday evening in November and the gloomy tone of Morse's last case.

It is set not in an Oxford college, but centred around Morse's favourite location - the country pub. Despite doctors telling him not to, the chief inspector drinks as much real ale in this episode as any of the best from the mid-eighties, where he would be seen roaring off in his dark red Jaguar shortly afterward downing three pints of some dark brown brew.

Morse starts his final outing ill and listless. All his customary exasperation seems exhausted. Two months from retirement, the inspector is cultivating a rather hopeless new bird-watching hobby. After a couple of murders, he perks up, especially when he successfully hijacks Lewis's investigations.

It is an appropriately old-fashioned intrigue. The picturesque Oxford village life it depicts is simmering with tensions of class and sex. A woman who is partial to a bit of "kinky rumpy-pumpy", as Lewis puts it, is bumped off. Everyone is drawn in: from a grey-haired PR smoothie to a bored village youth, who circles around the village on his BMX bike smoking dope. There is also a splendid turn by former Eldorado star Jesse Birdsall as a local builder with an eye for the ladies.

Morse's death, when it comes, is not as Hollywood as Morse's makers appeared to threaten after they said they had drawn out the low-key end penned by Morse's creator Colin Dexter. The chief inspector's fatal heart attack occurs in a hugely appropriate setting, against the dramatic soaring of some of his favourite choral music.

There is the inevitable gloomy hospital scene where much, as befits the irritable inspector, is left unsaid. It's devastating, but not an anti-climax. Like a Shakespearian tragedy, it is a sidekick who has the final word, closing the last chapter on the stuff of legend. At the end, all eyes (and not many dry ones) are on Lewis.

webTitle: Pressure grows on Amazon

fields.headline: Amazon feels the heat
fields.trailText: 8am: Doubts are growing over the financial future of online retailer and internet legend Amazon.com, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Doubts are growing over the financial future of online retailer and internet legend Amazon.com.

The company's balance sheet has been under intense scrutiny over the past few months, and the pressure has increased thanks to a series of ill-fated investments.

Online pet products retailer Pets.com folded last week, taking $60m of Amazon money with it. The US site shut down after running out of funding, leaving 255 people out of a job.

Pets.com and its remaining assets are up for sale, but no buyers have come forward.

Analysts have referred to Amazon's "fuzzy math" on similar deals with companies such as Drugstore.com and Living.com, which has now collapsed.

The Drugstore deal will see Amazon receive $105m (£74m) from the online pharmacist over the next three years. The arrangement has been derided because the first payment of $35m (£24.6m) was in Drugstore shares, which have been steadily falling in value.

Concerns have been raised that Amazon does not properly spell out whether or not it is being paid in stock as well as cash.

The revelations about Amazon's risky investments are alleged to be the reason behind the US Securities & Exchange Commission's informal investigation into the company.

Amazon has also become embroiled in a war of words with US analysts who once made it the darling of the stock market. One executive described a Lehman Brothers report that cut $253m (£178m) from Amazon's cash reserves as "silly."

The rows have overshadowed Amazon's latest results, which showed an 80% rise in sales and a sharp fall in losses.

But Amazon's once highly-rated shares have fallen since June, and investors will eagerly await the results from the traditionally busy Christmas period.

Positive results could signal a spell of relief for pressurised tech stocks, but figures which are anything short of impressive are likely to result in another stock market panic.

webTitle: Scotsman announces largest sales increase of any British paper

fields.headline: Scotsman announces record sales increase
fields.trailText: 2pm: The Scotsman has recorded the largest sales increase of any British newspaper. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Scotsman has recorded the largest sales increase of any British newspaper, increasing its sales by 30% compared to the same period last year.

The Scotsman announced a rise of over 30% to 101,756 from the same period last year when it was selling 77,712 copies.

The sales increase has held firm through October, which saw the paper's owners, Press Holdings, double the cover price to 30p.

The paper is now out-selling any of the English national papers in Scotland, and Press Holdings claims that is it also beating its rival the Glasgow Herald.

Although the Herald - which is classed as a regional paper - does not announce monthly sales figures, Press Holdings says "trade estimates" indicate that the Herald's figures have fallen to 92,500, a claim not denied by the paper's publisher SMG.

In its heyday in the 70s, the Herald sold over 120,000 copies.

webTitle: Baby scandal hospital stored 400 foetuses

fields.headline: Baby scandal hospital stored 400 foetuses
fields.standfirst: <A HREF="http://www.guardian.co.uk/nhs/"Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Up to 400 foetuses have been kept at Alder Hey hospital, a spokesman confirmed today.
fields.body:
Up to 400 foetuses have been kept at Alder Hey hospital, a spokesman confirmed today.

The hospital, in Liverpool, is already under investigation over the storing of organs from 800 babies. The retained foetuses were included in the external inquiry, the spokesman said.

He said that parents' groups had been informed of the collection of foetuses last December and added that talks were going on to decide what should be done with them.

The foetuses were sent to the Liverpool hospital by other hospitals in the city. Most were from stillbirths and terminations.

They were collected by Professor Dick Van Velzen, the pathologist at the centre of the organ retention scandal at the hospital. He has also carried out pathology work for other hospitals.

Prof Velzen worked at the hospital between 1988 and 1995 and the foetuses date back to that time. Some have been used for research at Liverpool University.

"It's quite a different issue from the retention of organs from children who died at Alder Hey but it is also something we have been completely open about," the hospital spokesman said. "Where families have approached us we have rigorously sought to give them the fullest information about any organs of their children that are held by the hospital and we have done that for foetuses too."

Ed Bradley, spokesman for parents' group Pity2, said he was "horrified" at the store of foetuses. "Alder Hey knew about this and should have made this known months ago," he said.

"Some of these foetuses are from stillbirths and miscarriages which means they were wanted and I am sure aparents would have had no idea they would end up in a hospital store. Although our campaign relates to the removal of organs, we would sympathise with anyone affected by this and I am sure Alder Hey's phone lines will be jammed today with worried parents."

webTitle: Inland Revenue hires first marketing director

fields.headline: Taxing times for Schoolar
fields.trailText: 2pm: The Inland Revenue has hired its first-ever marketing director as it embarks on a major communications drive designed to overturn its poor reputation. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Inland Revenue, that most hated of government departments, has hired its first-ever marketing director as it embarks on a major communications drive designed to overturn its poor reputation.

Ian Schoolar, one of the marketing industry's best-known executives, joins from Nat West Bank, where he is head of brand communications.

He takes on the difficult task of making the Inland Revenue more user-friendly and will oversee all of the Revenue's communications work including advertising, PR, leaflets and forms and internal communications.

Revenue chairman Nick Montagu said: "The nature of the Revenue has changed profoundly in the last few years and it is important that we increase our understanding of our customers and their needs.

"The Revenue is becoming an enabling department, not just a regulating one, and Ian's role in carrying forward that transition is a vital one."

webTitle: How to get ahead in fundraising

fields.headline: How to get ahead in fundraising
fields.standfirst: Charity fundraisers are increasingly in demand, but there's no single way to enter the profession, writes Liza Ramrayka
fields.trailText: Charity fundraisers are increasingly in demand, but there's no single way to enter the profession, writes Liza Ramrayka
fields.body:
Collection tins and sponsored events may be the public face of charity fundraising, but a huge variety of skills and experiences lie behind this £13bn-a-year industry. Today's charity fundraisers are as likely to deal with blue-chip companies as with blue-rinse charity-shop volunteers. The results can be hugely rewarding, both in terms of meeting financial targets and in working for a good cause.

Charities raise funds from a number of sources. Donations from the public usually account for a large proportion of income, while other sources include grants from trusts or foundations, National Lottery funding and donations from companies. Most charities now rely on a range of fundraising techniques to bring in the cash. These include direct mail, events, face-to-face dialogue and, more recently, internet fundraising.

Fundraisers fall into two categories - specialists and generalists. A large charity will usually have fundraisers who specialise in a different technique. A small charity will employ fewer fundraisers, but will choose people with more general experience.

Salaries now rival those in the commercial sector, although regional charities may not be able to match their London equivalents. A fundraising assistant can expect to earn at least £15,000; a director of fundraising or marketing can command around £50,000, and as much as £70,000 in some cases. According to Charity Rewards, an annual survey of salaries in the charity sector, fundraisers are becoming increasingly scarce as demand for them rises in line with charities' desire to diversify and increase their income.

There is no single way of becoming a charity fundraiser. A graduate with experience of organising events at college could join a charity as an events co-ordinator. A marketing director in the commercial sector could make the switch to the voluntary sector as a director of fundraising.

Ideally, you will have some experience of marketing, public relations or promotions work. A fundraiser's tasks will depend on the charity and field, but could include presenting sponsorship proposals to corporate donors, designing fundraising initiatives for schools or employee groups, liaising with regional fundraisers, and completing grant application forms. "There are opportunities at almost every level and multiple routes to getting in," says Janet Cummins, chief executive of specialist recruitment company Charity and Fundraising Appointments.

Nine years ago, Jane Harris was working in public relations for a holiday tour operator, taking travel agents around Spain. Today, she's the corporate support manager for YHA, the hostels and education charity, with responsibility for building relationships with the business sector. After leaving PR, Harris spent seven months volunteering for the Samaritans and also helped with street collections for a local disability charity. This experience led to her first charity-sector job, as fundraising assistant at Victim Support. "I think that they were quite impressed that I had volunteered, as it showed I was interested in the sector," she says.

As well as interest and commitment, a potential fundraiser should also demonstrate persistence and powers of persuasion. "You get an awful lot of 'no's' on the way to the 'yes's'," says Cummins. "The ability to think creatively and laterally is also important, as are good interpersonal skills."

Cummins stresses that professional development is essential once you're in post. "Fundraising is not just about local people running coffee mornings. You need to know about the law, managing volunteers and working with trustees." For those with little or no fundraising training, there are courses available to suit different needs, times and budgets. Providers include the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers, the Open University and the Directory of Social Change.

Ian Ventham, head of fundraising and marketing at the Royal National Lifeboat Institute, says the sector has grown up over the last 15 years. "Fundraising has become more sophisticated and fundraisers more professional," he says. Ventham, whose experience includes stints at Help the Aged and the NSPCC, adds that demands on fundraisers are constantly changing. "Different donors have different needs, at different stages of their lives. The fundraiser's job is to understand and meet those needs."

Case study
Liz Monks, 31 - deputy director, Shelter
"My background is in marketing. I worked for five years for a small financial services company, handling their trade PR and business-to-business work. I was volunteering at the Terence Higgins Trust (THT) at the time, and started to look at jobs going there because I really believed in what they were doing.

"In 1995, a job came up as corporate and community fundraiser, which I applied for and got. The job involved organising all the charity's big events, so it was very good experience. After three years, I wanted another challenge. You think you go into charity fundraising selflessly but, in reality, you continue to want challenges. So, in 1998, I took a job as head of corporate and community fundraising at the Royal National Institute for Deaf People (RNID). It was completely different to THT - it was a 90-year-old charity and the cause was not perceived as sexy in fundraising terms. I found my commercial experience quite valuable there and RNID was made charity of the year by several companies, including WH Smith and Virgin.

"In July this year, I came to work at Shelter as deputy director of fundraising. It's a very interesting cause and, to be honest, you have to believe in it. When you're in front of funders, you have to be able to feel passionate about what you're pitching to them. Another reason for coming here was to work with my old boss from RNID, as we complement each other's skills very well.

"When I first came into the sector, I took a huge pay cut but I'm now probably earning what I would if I'd stayed in the commercial sector. You can achieve things at quite a young age in this sector and it's a seller's market right now. Fundraising gives you the ability to change people's lives. How often can you say that about the business sector?"

Five tips for fundraisers
 If you're currently working in the commercial sector, become a volunteer. "Think of a cause close to your heart and offer your services," says Cummins. "Even if it's not on the fundraising side, it will be valuable experience and will help you to understand the charity sector's culture."
 Know your strengths - and your weaknesses. If you don't like juggling too many balls, specialise in one area of fundraising. If you enjoy the challenge, pick a job that requires general experience.
 Don't be afraid to ask for advice and support. In many organisations, you may be the only person doing that job, so it's important to meet other fundraisers and discuss ideas.
 Keep learning. "Fundraising is a wide and complicated subject. Different areas require different knowledge," says Cummins.
 Network, network, network. "Fundraising is all about friend-raising," says Cummins. "You have to build and maintain relationships."

webTitle: Cook warns against EU scare stories

fields.headline: Cook warns against EU scare stories
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, launched the government's latest European offensive today with an attack on Eurosceptics who, he said, are "betraying our nation".
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, launched the government's latest European offensive today with an attack on Eurosceptics who, he said, are "betraying our nation".

Speaking to the Centre for European Reform, Mr Cook said that true patriotism meant fighting for Britain to have a leading place in Europe. "It is a betrayal of our nation and our future constantly to obstruct every fresh opportunity for cooperation in Europe," he said.

Later today the prime minister, Tony Blair, will tell City bankers that ''active and constructive engagement" with the EU is vital to ensure Britain's prosperity and international clout.

The government is making a concerted attempt to take the European battle to its opponents in the Tory party and the press, who ministers accuse of peddling myths to scare voters away from Europe.

webTitle: BT sells £460m stake in Swiss phone company

fields.headline: BT sells £460m stake in Swiss phone company
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: BT has sold its stake in Swiss phone company Sunrise for £460m in a bid to reduce its £30bn debt mountain, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
British Telecommunications has started to lighten its load for the rough ride ahead with the sale of its stake in Swiss phone company Sunrise.

The £460m sale comes as BT battles to reduce its £30bn debt mountain with a series of sales and flotations, against a background of mounting investor disgruntlement at the company's performance.

BT will make a £390m profit on its 34% stake, which is being sold to fellow Sunrise shareholder TeleDanmark.

"This is a case of the right deal at the right time," said a BT spokesperson.

Meanwhile, BT's role in French phone operator Cegetel is in doubt following a row with co-shareholder Vivendi and chief executive Peter Bonfield's refusal to rule out a sale.

Vivendi has called for BT to clarify its position with Cegetel, following BT's attempts to close down Vivendi's Vizzavi wireless internet portal.

BT believes the portal could damage Cegetel's mobile phone subsidiary, and is angry at being left out of the venture.

Mr Bonfield added fuel to the fire in a newspaper interview, saying BT was unlikely to gain full control of the company, leaving the possibility of a sale that could raise £8bn.

webTitle: Online shopping spend triples in 12 months

fields.headline: Online shopping spend trebles in 12 months
fields.trailText: 1pm: More people are shopping on the internet, despite the negative publicity still casting a shadow over e-commerce. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Shopping over the internet is growing, despite the negative publicity still casting a shadow over the notion of e-commerce.

The latest Internet Monitor from research firm BMRB shows that more often than not, the negativity is being cancelled out by the online experience.

Any worries consumers may feel are dispelled once they have ventured online, with most expressing satisfaction with the service they received.

According to the survey, over two-thirds - 68% - of online shoppers rate their last e-commerce experience as 'very good', and top line figures show that practically everyone - 97% - rates their last experience of online shopping as satisfactory or better.

Overall, the total level of online spend has tripled in the past 12 months and grown by more than 13 times in the last two years.

In the six months to August this year, British consumers spent a whopping £2.5bn online, compared with £0.85bn for the same period last year.

The rise has been fuelled by the fact that 42% of Britain's 14m internet users are now shopping online, and average monthly online spends are up to £403 from £105.

At the same time, online banking is soaring, with more than 3m UK consumers doing their banking online. Among these, Egg is the leading internet bank with 7% of online bankers.

The survey's results coincides with a positive step forward for online shoppers - the European distance contract legislation, which enforces a seven-day cooling off period allowing online shoppers to return goods with a full refund, comes into effect in the UK this week.

webTitle: Full text: Robin Cook's speech in Europe

fields.headline: Cook: 'We need to develop a positive storyline about Europe'
fields.standfirst:
Speech by the foreign secretary Robin Cook to the centre for European reform

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText:
The sort of Europe I want to see in 2010 is a Europe with which everyone in this country can be
                                    comfortable. A wider Europe. A prosperous Europe. A safer Europe. A stable Europe. And a strong
                                    Europe.
fields.body:
The sort of Europe I want to see in 2010 is a Europe with which everyone in this country can be comfortable. A wider Europe. A prosperous Europe. A safer Europe. A stable Europe. And a strong Europe.

A wider Europe because by 2010 we shall be well on the way to reuniting Europe. With up to a dozen new member states, the EU will have become the whole of the Continent, from the Arctic to the Mediterranean and from the Black Sea to the Atlantic. The Eurosceptics should reflect on why they want us to get off the bus when so many are queuing to get on.

And the British people need a prosperous Europe. We are already part of the worldÕs biggest Single Market. Three million British jobs now depend on our trade with the rest of the EU. One million jobs have been created in this country since we joined the Social Chapter in 1997. By 2010 we want more. The economic reform agenda which we developed at Lisbon will turn the EU into the worldÕs leading knowledge-based economy. We can meet this objective, and create more jobs, by modernising and renewing the European social model which has always valued labour as a resource worth investing in, not just as a factor of production. Higher growth, greater prosperity and more jobs throughout Europe are all in BritainÕs national interest.

I am not going to give the journalists their headlines for tomorrow morning by saying now whether I think Britain will be part of the Euro by then. It is astonishing how many acres of newsprint ministers can receive on the Euro by stating the obvious. Our policy is well-known, and we will continue to make the case for British membership. So let me put it this way: If the Euro is successful, if the economic tests have been met following our assessment early in the next Parliament, we will recommend entry to the British people in a referendum. And if the economic case is strong, I believe the British people will support entry.

A safer Europe because that is the best way to build a safer Britain. In 2010 I want a Britain safer from cross-border criminals, terrorists, drug dealers and people traffickers. Crime knows no boundaries and the fight against crime should know no boundaries. That is why we are already working with our neighbours in the EU to make Europe an area of freedom, security and justice. The more countries of Europe join the EU, the safer we will be. British people want to know that there is no hiding place for criminals or the proceeds of their crimes anywhere in Europe.

And I want to see a Europe of strength in the world. It is a delusion to imagine that Britain is stronger if it is isolated. The best way to project British values and British interests is by doing so in partnership with those who share our values: democracy, human rights, justice and freedom.

The British people gain because Britain and the rest of Europe speak with a single voice in international negotiations on trade and the environment. In the WTO, Britain on its own would be a significant influence, but our message and interests might be drowned out among competing European voices. By pooling our interests with those of our European partners, we are transformed into one of the two key actors in global trade negotiations. The same is true in the environment, where the EU is a model for the world of how to combine prosperity and opportunity with a healthy environment, and, because of that, an increasingly powerful voice in global environmental debates. BritainÕs voice will be heard more clearly in the world because our interests are backed by a Union of 15 or 25 countries which share our outlook.

And each of these countries will be a member of a Europe of stability. The European Security Initiative reinforces our ability to respond to crises where NATO is not engaged. By 2010 we could see a joint EU operation bringing order in place of instability, safeguarding BritainÕs national interests and enhancing respect for BritainÕs military skills.

This prospect of Europe in 2010 is an exciting vision. And Britain will reap the full benefits Ð security, prosperity and strength. Which makes it hard to fathom why so much of the discussion about Europe here Ð whether in the media, Parliament or political debates around the country Ð is dominated by fear and anxiety, not excitement.

What sort of EU do parts of the British media foresee in 2010? An EU in which jackbooted Eurocops roam the streets of Britain, arresting anyone eating bent bananas or drinking beer in pints. A Europe where lollipop ladies are harmonised, where darts are banned from British pubs and where rubber ducks are banned from the great British bathtub. All of which, and more, have passed recently through the pages of our press.

Euromyths provide great fun for journalists. The media has a mission to entertain. And some of them rise magnificently to that goal. But they are failing in their other mission Ð to inform. That is the conclusion we must draw from a recent Eurobarometer survey which showed that just two per cent of the British people believe what they hear about Europe in the media. Those of us who want the public to have a proper understanding of the benefits we derive from our membership of the EU have a strong interest in turning the tide of EU reporting. From now on the Government will be rebutting all such stories vigorously and promptly. You will be hearing the catchphrase ÔFacts, not MythsÕ, until that is the way the EU is reported.

Turning the tide of the national debate about Europe is about more than correcting error. We need to develop a positive storyline about Europe. This is not something the Government can or should be doing on its own. There are many national publications, and many journalists working for them, who do not share the ideological Euroscepticism of the Daily Mail. But, with the exception of the Financial Times, no newspaper in this country has a consistently objective narrative about Europe.

The biggest Euromyth of all is the myth of the superstate. There will not be a superstate because the British people would never allow it. And neither would the French people, the German people, the Italian people or the people of Poland, Hungary, Latvia or the other countries now queuing up to join the EU because they know it will make them stronger.

Last week Romano Prodi made an important speech in this country, in which he exploded the myth of the European superstate, and stressed the primacy of national identities in Europe. He praised what Tony Blair had said about the future of Europe last month in Warsaw. But how was he reported the following morning? ÔBritain rejected calls yesterday from Romano Prodi to abandon its veto on key areas of policy.Õ

Note how this opening line presents President ProdiÕs speech, in which he agreed with the British Prime Minister, as a challenge to the Prime Minister. Note how Britain is being portrayed on the defensive Ð rejecting pressure on it from Europe. Note how it is assumed that any reduction in unanimous decision making is a threat to the British national interest. And note also that this intro is not culled from the Daily Mail, where it belongs, but from The Guardian.

How can we hope to convince the public of the case for Europe, if even those papers who profess to support Europe, consistently present it to their readers as a threat?

We need the sensible, mainstream press to stop dancing to the Eurosceptic tune. The pro-European papers should be saying why they believe our place is in Europe, not why others believe our place is outside. Those who believe BritainÕs interests are best served by strengthening our influence in Europe should come out of the closet. They have nothing to be ashamed of. Pro-Europeanism is a respectable cause. It has a distinguished history in British political thought, and contains a more reasoned vision of the future than the isolationism which would betray our national interests.

It is patriotism, it is national self-interest, to argue for BritainÕs full engagement as a leading partner in Europe. It is a betrayal of our nation and our future constantly to obstruct every fresh opportunity for cooperation in Europe. On Thursday, I shall be expanding the long-term positive case for engagement in Europe and the British principles which underpin it. But before we get to the horizon we must first traverse the foreground. Today I want to present the good news story that an objective press should be preparing to report from Nice next month.

Many of them are already tipping their pens with doom and fear. But we should be looking forward to Nice with positive anticipation. It is the next important step towards building the sort of Europe we want to see by 2010.

The Nice Summit is good news because it will produce two things Britain supports: Reform and Enlargement. Nice is about clearing the way for the accession of the first new member states. It is about reuniting Europe and releasing the benefits of prosperity, stability and strength for EuropeÕs new democracies in the East. But admitting them to the EU is not just an exercise in altruism. Britain is a champion of EU enlargement also because of a hard-headed calculation of the benefits it will bring to the British people. More allies in the fight against our joint enemies Ð cross-border crime, pollution, drugs, poverty and unemployment. More jobs because our companies will be operating in a domestic Single Market of half a billion consumers. More clout in an increasingly multilateral and globalised world because a whole continent will be batting for our interests.

The Nice Summit is good news because it will reinforce the place of human rights in our political culture. The Charter of Rights will be a political declaration, not a binding document. It will set down, for the first time in one place, the rights to which the EUÕs residents are already entitled. The political rights enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights, and the economic and social rights contained in the EU Treaties and the member statesÕ own national laws and practices.

The Eurosceptics donÕt like the Charter. What is it they so dislike? The Charter will help people know their rights. Who could object to that? It will guide the EU institutions on what they need to do to respect those rights. Surely that canÕt be the problem. It wonÕt damage business Ð the CBI have welcomed it. Nor will it become legally binding unless we agree. I can only conclude that those who dislike the Charter dislike the rights within it Ð the right to be presumed innocent until proved guilty, the right to dignity, the right to freedom of expression. Only in the perverse logic of Euroscepticism could rights be considered a threat to Britain and the interests of the British people.

The Nice Summit is good news because it will make Britain stronger. Our negotiating objective is to get more votes in the Council of Ministers and increase our relative weight for the first time since we joined in 1973. Nice will make sure BritainÕs influence is felt still more strongly in a wider Europe.

The Nice Summit is good news because it means we can go on building an EU which works for us. Some in Britain think we should have a veto on everything. But they forget that if we have a veto, so does everyone else. I donÕt want everyone to have a veto on our initiatives. In the last two years there were 85 votes on QMV in the Council. Britain was outvoted just five times. We have been rather successful in making majority voting work for BritainÕs interests.

That means there were 80 occasions when other countries could have used a veto to stop outcomes we wanted. Measures like the e-commerce rule which several countries opposed but which we got through in the interests of British business. Or the right of British chocolate makers to sell their products throughout the EU. And a ban on driftnets which has saved countless dolphins and turtles from death was passed under our Presidency despite opposition from three other countries.

We are supporting more QMV at Nice where it will make the EU work better in our interests. We donÕt want countries to be able to veto improvements to the way the European Court of Justice speeds up its work, or to veto much-needed reforms to streamline the CommissionÕs accounting procedures. But we will retain consensus in areas which are essential to our national identity like tax, social security, border controls, defence or treaty amendment.

That does not mean Nice is the last word on the EUÕs institutional shape. There is still a democratic deficit in the institutions. Paradoxically, this is partly because of the very strength and vigour of the national democracies which make up the EU. The parliaments and governments of the nation states are where the will of the people finds its most expressive voice. If we want to find ways of making sure that EuropeÕs priorities in 2010 are the peopleÕs priorities, we can do so by leveraging the strength of EuropeÕs national democracies for our collective interests.

Tony Blair, in his speech last month in Warsaw, floated some ways of doing this. Representatives of national parliaments could sit in a second chamber of the European Parliament. This chamber would harness the strength of EuropeÕs national democracies. It would not legislate, but preserve the balance between what the Union does and what the member states do.

Britain has always been an outward-looking nation. It would be extraordinary if we were now to allow isolationists to throw the opportunity of Europe away. I want to re-cast the debate about Europe in this country. A debate based on facts, not myths. I want to bury the myth of a superstate Ð national identities are too strong. I want to bury the myth that Brussels is Them. Brussels is us.

I want to bury the myth that Britain can only win when Europe loses, or vice versa. In the EU we can all be winners.

It is a delusion of the Eurosceptics that a stronger Europe necessarily means a weaker Britain. On the contrary the stronger Europe is in the world the stronger will be Britain. A weak Europe means a weak Britain.

Where Britain will be in 2010 depends on who wins the debate on Europe today. If the debate is won by the Eurosceptics, 2010 will find Britain isolated and weaker. A Britain at best marginalised in the key decisions of its neighbours. A Britain at worst outside the biggest trading bloc in the world.

If the debate is won by those who believe in Britain in Europe, 2010 will find a more confident Britain. A Britain playing a leading part in the worldÕs largest union of nation states, delivering the economic opportunity, the clean environment, the safe streets, and the regional peace that the British people want.

Those are the alternative futures for Britain that hang on the present European debate. I know which future I want for Britain. And I know that many in the press want that future too. It is time that all of us who share that vision of our future made sure that the British people can hear the positive reasons why they should choose a stronger Britain in a wider Europe.

Only in the perverse logic of Euroscepticism could rights be considered a threat to Britain and the interests of the British people. The Nice Summit is good news because it will make Britain stronger. Our negotiating objective is to get more votes in the Council of Ministers and increase our relative weight for the first time since we joined in 1973. Nice will make sure BritainÕs influence is felt still more strongly in a wider Europe. The Nice Summit is good news because it means we can go on building an EU which works for us. Some in Britain think we should have a veto on everything. But they forget that if we have a veto, so does everyone else. I donÕt want everyone to have a veto on our initiatives. In the last two years there were 85 votes on QMV in the Council. Britain was outvoted just five times. We have been rather successful in making majority voting work for BritainÕs interests. That means there were 80 occasions when other countries could have used a veto to stop outcomes we wanted. Measures like the e-commerce rule which several countries opposed but which we got through in the interests of British business. Or the right of British chocolate makers to sell their products throughout the EU. And a ban on driftnets which has saved countless dolphins and turtles from death was passed under our Presidency despite opposition from three other countries. We are supporting more QMV at Nice where it will make the EU work better in our interests. We donÕt want countries to be able to veto improvements to the way the European Court of Justice speeds up its work, or to veto much-needed reforms to streamline the CommissionÕs accounting procedures. But we will retain consensus in areas which are essential to our national identity like tax, social security, border controls, defence or treaty amendment. That does not mean Nice is the last word on the EUÕs institutional shape. There is still a democratic deficit in the institutions. Paradoxically, this is partly because of the very strength and vigour of the national democracies which make up the EU. The parliaments and governments of the nation states are where the will of the people finds its most expressive voice. If we want to find ways of making sure that EuropeÕs priorities in 2010 are the peopleÕs priorities, we can do so by leveraging the strength of EuropeÕs national democracies for our collective interests. Tony Blair, in his speech last month in Warsaw, floated some ways of doing this. Representatives of national parliaments could sit in a second chamber of the European Parliament. This chamber would harness the strength of EuropeÕs national democracies. It would not legislate, but preserve the balance between what the Union does and what the member states do. Britain has always been an outward-looking nation. It would be extraordinary if we were now to allow isolationists to throw the opportunity of Europe away. I want to re-cast the debate about Europe in this country. A debate based on facts, not myths. I want to bury the myth of a superstate Ð national identities are too strong. I want to bury the myth that Brussels is Them. Brussels is us. I want to bury the myth that Britain can only win when Europe loses, or vice versa. In the EU we can all be winners. It is a delusion of the Eurosceptics that a stronger Europe necessarily means a weaker Britain. On the contrary the stronger Europe is in the world the stronger will be Britain. A weak Europe means a weak Britain. Where Britain will be in 2010 depends on who wins the debate on Europe today. If the debate is won by the Eurosceptics, 2010 will find Britain isolated and weaker. A Britain at best marginalised in the key decisions of its neighbours. A Britain at worst outside the biggest trading bloc in the world. If the debate is won by those who believe in Britain in Europe, 2010 will find a more confident Britain. A Britain playing a leading part in the worldÕs largest union of nation states, delivering the economic opportunity, the clean environment, the safe streets, and the regional peace that the British people want. Those are the alternative futures for Britain that hang on the present European debate. I know which future I want for Britain. And I know that many in the press want that future too. It is time that all of us who share that vision of our future made sure that the British people can hear the positive reasons why they should choose a stronger Britain in a wider Europe.

webTitle: O'Neil joins Derby as Schnoor heads home

fields.headline: O'Neil joins Derby as Schnoor heads home
fields.trailText: Scotland defender Brian O'Neil today joined Derby in a swap deal which saw Stefan Schnoor return to Germany with Wolfsburg.
fields.body:
Scotland defender Brian O'Neil today joined Derby in a swap deal which saw Stefan Schnoor return to Germany with Wolfsburg.

O'Neil passed a medical this morning before signing a deal which will commit him to the Rams until June 2003.

Later today the 28-year-old centre-half will join the rest of the Scotland squad as they prepare for their international friendly against Australia on Wednesday.

O'Neil, who will wear the number three shirt, spent two years at Wolfsburg after spells at Aberdeen, Nottingham Forest and Celtic.

He is expected to make his debut for Derby on Saturday against fellow strugglers Bradford at Pride Park.

Schnoor said: "For everybody this is good business. Derby are signing an experienced defender and a return to Germany suits my family.

"The swap is perfect especially as Brian wants to get back to Britain, although I've enjoyed my time here.

"For me it was a great experience and there are positive signs now at the club. Derby could finish between sixth and 10th."

webTitle: Sky boosts efforts to become ITV news supplier

fields.headline: Sky boosts efforts to become ITV news supplier
fields.trailText: 11.30am: BSkyB has stepped up its efforts to wrest the lucrative contract for ITV news supply from ITN, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
BSkyB has stepped up its efforts to wrest the lucrative contract for ITV news supply from ITN.

It is said to be in talks about a joint venture, possibly with Scottish TV, to try and get around strict rules which up to now have prohibited it from bidding.

Sky News chief Nick Pollard met ITV chiefs last Thursday to discuss a possible deal for the flagship lunchtime, teatime and evening bulletins.

The station, which has been running for 11 years, has tried to win contracts with ITV in the past but was not deemed a suitable supplier by TV watchdog the Independent Television Commission.

Sky is still regarded an unsuitable bidder, but Mr Pollard is pressing ahead in the hope he can win status as an official ITC "nominated news supplier".

At the moment it is disqualified from bidding because Rupert Murdoch's stake in the company is too big.

However Sky bosses are said to be in talks about a joint venture, possibly with Scottish and Ulster TV and Channel TV on the Channel Islands.

Sources say last week's talks were with ITV news controller Steve Anderson and commercial director John Hardie.

"Sky would not go this far, if they didn't think there was a way forward. They are trying to find a way around the brick wall, rather than rush headlong into it," said one source.

Earlier this summer Mr Pollard wrote to the ITC seeking approval as a "nominated news provider", a prerequisite to pitch for the ITV news contract.

Today the ITC said it had written to Sky reiterating the fact that it was barred from being an ITV supplier because of Rupert Murdoch's dominant share in the company.

Under the rules, shareholdings in the company supplying ITV with its news must be limited to 20%. Mr Murdoch owns 37.5% of Sky, automatically disqualifying the station from supplying ITV.

This legal snag would be removed if Sky set up a joint venture with another company.

webTitle: See Naples and cry

fields.headline: See Naples and cry
fields.trailText: Sophia Loren cried with happiness when she returned yesterday after a 15-year absence to Pozzuoli, the poor Neapolitan district she once called home
fields.body:
Sophia Loren cried with happiness when she returned yesterday to the poor Neapolitan district she once called home.

The actress, venerated in her native Italy as a symbol of femininity, was cheered by old friends and neighbours as she explored Pozzuoli, the Naples suburb where she grew up.

A 15-year absence prompted officials in May to remove her right to vote, leaving the 66-year-old actress distraught. Despite a childhood of poverty, allied bombing raids and taunts over her illegitimacy, the district was in her soul, she said.

"Am I all emotional? Sure, I have to say that I cried, and I cried with joy. Every step of the stairs, every little mark on the wall reminds me of something."

Now a resident of California and Switzerland, she came back to Procida, a tiny fishing island in the Bay of Naples, to star in a film directed by Lina Wertmuller.

"Sophia, you're very beautiful," shouted an admirer, as she entered the flat where she once shared two bedrooms with seven others. Loren hugged her aunt, Dora Villani, and her sister, Maria Scicolone, mother of Alessandra Mussolini, the politician granddaughter of Benito Mussolini.

At the age of 14 she won a local beauty contest and a year later went to Rome to find fame, fortune and marriage with the producer Carlo Ponti.

webTitle: Unions attack tests for brightest pupils

fields.headline: Unions attack tests for brightest pupils
fields.standfirst:
Government launches computer-based exams for talented nine-year-olds amid concern that children are under too much stress
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Computer-based tests designed to stretch the country's most talented nine and 13-year-olds will be launched on the internet today, as part of a government drive to raise school standards and enable international comparison.
fields.body:
Computer-based tests designed to stretch the country's most talented nine and 13-year-olds will be launched on the internet today, as part of a government drive to raise school standards and enable international comparison.

But the move will infuriate teaching unions, who claim it confirms the government's obsession with testing and will put bright youngsters under unnecessary stress at the expense of a rounded education.

The World Class Tests, devised as part of a programme to boost education standards in inner-city areas, are scheduled for introduction at the start of the 2001 academic year. Schools are being invited to put forward their brightest pupils to do the tests as part of the pilot scheme.

The tests, which have been developed by the government's examination adviser, the qualifications and curriculum authority (QCA), can be taken on-screen in an interactive computer format using high quality graphics or using pencil and paper. They cover mathematics and problem solving, but are designed to be more challenging than conventional subject tests.

The maths tests, for example, aim to encourage deeper thought about topics that children will have covered in normal lessons. Similarly, the problem solving tests will incorporate questions covering maths, science and technology, but will be at a level that a child would not normally have encountered in the classroom.

The brightest children would be able to do about six questions in 30 minutes.

Parents, as well as teachers, will be encouraged to put forward their youngsters for the tests, and schools will be able to access the answers as well as the questions on the QCA's website. All schools and libraries are this week being sent an explanatory leaflet setting out the details of the tests and how they can access them.

The QCA said that children who were likely to do well in the tests were those who were "determined, diligent and interested in uncovering patterns". They are also set to be extended to 18-year-olds as part of the new-style A-level programme.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, has invited several countries, including the US, Australia and Singapore, to become partners in the tests, which will allow international "benchmarking" to take place. Following a meeting between Mr Blunkett and the US education secretary, Richard Riley, in June, international trials of the tests will begin in some US schools early next year.

David Hargreaves, chief executive of the QCA, said: "These tests are an exciting development. Innovation in the content of the tests and the way they are presented to pupils will be the key to their success. The tests are challenging but will be available to any child when parents or teachers think they are ready."

But John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "World class tests at nine and 13 are a further example of the government's obsession with testing at the expense of true education. The brightest children are already placed under sufficient stress by the examination system in this country.

"Like the A* grade at GCSE, these tests will add to the stress levels of academically able children. School leaders will be concerned that parents will put pressure on schools for their children to sit the tests, even when this may be inappropriate."

Mr Dunford said the best way to stimulate bright youngsters' intellectual curiosity was to introduce them to an extended curriculum of greater breadth and depth.

A research programme to be published shortly by the SHA, in conjunction with the Professional Association of Teachers, is said to confirm initial findings that youngsters in England are being "tested to destruction" throughout their school careers.

webTitle: The first month of ratings for the BBC's Ten O'Clock News

fields.headline: BBC and ITV go head to head in news ratings war
fields.standfirst: One month after the BBC moved its Nine O'Clock News to 10pm, how are the BBC's ratings faring in comparison with its ITV rival's?
fields.trailText: Jason Deans and Lisa O'Carroll examine how the BBC's ratings have fared one month after moving its Nine O'Clock News programme to 10pm.
fields.body:
For BBC director general Greg Dyke, now may be a good time to reflect on that hoary old cliché, it never rains but it pours.

It is exactly one month since the BBC braved the critics and the traditionalists and moved its Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.

And what a month it was. For everyone working in news, whether newspapers or television, it was a spectacular four weeks. But for an organisation that was ditching a television institution, the series of extraordinary events - from the Hatfield rail tragedy to the flood crisis and renewed fuel shortage scares - couldn't have been more timely.

Although much of the news was tragic, TV news editors knew ratings were guaranteed because regardless of how much viewers had read in the day's papers or heard on the radio, everyone would still tune in to see the pictures of floods, the rail disaster, the Singapore Airlines crash and, last week, the farcical race for the White House.

But the BBC hadn't counted on ITV's guerilla scheduling. The enormity of the news stories of the past month were enough to justify news specials for a channel that just about keeps its news in peak-time.

In all, ITV commissioned six specials in the 9pm slot vacated by the BBC1 bulletin. The frequency of the "specials" were enough to raise questions about ITV's intentions.

Was it trying out the 9pm slot in a bid with a view to making it permanent? The ambushing of the timeslot certainly brought rich ratings rewards and ITV controller of news Steve Anderson can barely disguise his glee.

"The BBC could have done us immense damage if their news had still been at 9pm, getting eight or nine million viewers," says Mr Anderson. "But by moving the news Greg Dyke has allowed ITV to step in at 9pm, scoop BBC News on the big stories and cap their audience at 10pm."

The Hatfield rail crash news special on Tuesday October 17 - the day after the BBC1 bulletin moved to 10pm - pulled in an audience of 8.5m.

Between Monday October 30 and Wednesday November 8, ITV has scheduled a further five 9pm flood special bulletins that have averaged 10m and a 40% share, with the highest - pulling in 11.7m on that first night - the most-watched news programme on any channel this year.

Mr Anderson stresses that the decision to run 9pm news specials is justified on editorial grounds, given the "unique" run of big stories over the past four weeks. But he also admits that tactically ITV is using the scheduling ploy as a "ratings weapon" to try to smother the fledgling BBC1 10pm news at birth.

However, that, he says, is as far as it goes. With clever scheduling, the 9pm slot could work in the short term.

In the coming months ITV will try to exploit a possible shortage of peak-time programming at the BBC. Ratings smash One Foot in the Grave ends next week and ITV bosses reckon the BBC will struggle when the stockpile of programmes suitable for the 9pm-10pm slot run out.

BBC head of TV news Roger Mosey is having none of this. "ITV said their aim was to kill the Ten O'clock - well they've failed to do that," he declares.

And the figures back him up. On the five nights when ITV has run flood news specials, the BBC's 10pm news did indeed trail in the ratings.

However, on those nights the 10pm news averaged 5.4m and a 24% share, a higher slice of the audience than that achieved by the 10pm bulletin in the fortnight before the bad weather had anxious viewers tuning in in spectacular numbers.

But that still leaves the great imponderable of what audience the BBC1 bulletin might have got if ITV had not run its 9pm specials.

And even more interesting for Mr Mosey and BBC director general Greg Dyke - what audience it could have had if the Nine O'Clock News had remained intact?

Mr Mosey also dismisses the argument that the Nine O'Clock News would be getting big audiences if it still existed.

He says the Nine O'Clock News was sometimes getting less than 4m viewers, so the "notion that it would now be getting 8m or 9m is just not plausible" and "deeply baroque".

Mr Mosey is keen to stress the strength of the BBC's TV news offering across its portfolio, with the relaunched Breakfast News closing the ratings gap with GMTV, the main channels handing over to News 24 for rolling coverage of big breaking stories, and the One and Six O'Clock News pulling in big audiences with their flood coverage.

And he questions the significance of the ratings for ITV's 9pm specials, arguing that many of the viewers are there by accident - tuning in for Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and finding a 10-minute bulletin precedes it.

"I don't think they're getting news audiences in at 9pm," he says, "it's just another version of 'news at when'."

"Did they do anything about the American presidential election? - no. The BBC had through the night coverage," he adds.

Mr Anderson admits that there is a "Millionaire effect" on some nights, worth maybe 2m viewers, but points out that on two nights when the hit quizshow has not been around the 9pm news specials have had higher ratings than the programmes scheduled around them.

In the longer term, Mr Anderson says ITV remains committed to the news scheduling deal agreed with the ITC in September, while continuing to run peak-time news specials when big stories break.

But he believes the events of the past fortnight show that the BBC's strategy for moving its news is "coming apart on every level".

"They said they were moving from nine to 10pm to get bigger news audiences - we've demonstrated that there are far more people watching news at nine."

The official BBC line is that the 10pm news move will be assessed as part of the annual BBC1 performance review, published in the annual report next summer.

Mr Mosey says that within the BBC, "nobody has any doubt that 10pm is the best time" for the bulletin.

It may be the best time and the BBC has fared well in its first four weeks. But the truly big battle has yet to commence.

Come January, when ITV moves its news back to 10pm, nerves really will be frayed at the BBC. The lighter, tabloid feel of News at Ten has always been a ratings-winner and it could very well be a ratings killer, albeit on three nights a week.

webTitle: Napoli sack Zeman

fields.headline: Napoli sack Zeman
fields.trailText: Napoli, Serie A's bottom side, sacked coach Zdenek Zeman on Monday. Napoli said in a statement that the club's board of directors had voted unanimously to dismiss the 53-year-old Czech.
fields.body:
Napoli, Serie A's bottom side, sacked coach Zdenek Zeman on Monday. Napoli said in a statement that the club's board of directors had voted unanimously to dismiss the 53-year-old Czech.

The former Lazio and Roma coach took over at promoted Napoli in the close season but his team have failed to manage a win in their opening six games and have just two points. Napoli drew 1-1 at Perugia on Sunday.

webTitle: The Edge

fields.headline: The Edge
fields.standfirst: Tired of meaningless statistics? With The Edge from IQ Sports, you get the numbers that count, so you can see precisely where a match was won and lost
fields.trailText: ARSENAL 0 - 0 DERBY
fields.body:
ARSENAL 0 - 0 DERBY

Key man: Mart Poom was again superb, making 8 saves. Arsenal threw everything at him, too, having 6 shots in the last 15 minutes alone.

Weak link: In a rare off day, Thierry Henry failed to hit the target with any of his 7 attempts. Rory Delap's two mind-boggling misses deserve a mention, though.

The Edge: Derby were living on the edge with their offside trap. They successfully caught their hosts offside 8 times, but Sylvain Wiltord and Henry beat the back line on 13 occasions. However, the Gunners were profligate. Their crossing was nearly as bad as their finishing - only 6 of 31 crosses found team-mates.

ASTON VILLA 2 - 0 TOTTENHAM

Key man: Ian Taylor scored twice and won all of his 7 tackles.

Weak link: Tottenham's tackling in defence - Ramon Vega won only 6 of 14, Stephen Carr 6 of 24 and Ben Thatcher 6 of 14. Chris Perry tried his best to make up, winning 23 of 29.

The Edge: Villa connected on 23 of 29 crosses and had 56% of net possession. Tottenham completed only 1 of 14 crosses.

BRADFORD 0 - 1 EVERTON

Key man: Paul Gerrard denied Bradford's attacking trio of Stan Collymore, Benito Carbone and Ashley Ward with 5 saves and 13 claims.

Weak link: Carbone completed only 3 of 10 crosses, lost 11 of 14 tackles and did not have an attempt on goal.

The Edge: Passing was the difference. Everton were accurate on 9 of 14 crosses, Mark Pembridge completed 36 of 39 passes and Kevin Campbell 27 of 28. Only 5 of Bradford's 28 crosses found a team-mate.

CHELSEA 1 - 1 LEEDS

Key man: Gustavo Poyet was rewarded for his 80% passing accuracy and 6 scoring attempts with the crucial equaliser.

Weak link: Lucas Radebe committed 6 fouls - the sort of erratic form which could prove problematic in the Champions League.

The Edge: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink had 7 scoring attempts against his former club, while opposite number Alan Smith had only 1. There were over 350 challenges in this game (including an incredible 47 by Frank Leboeuf), but also 55 fouls - shouldn't the 1970 FA Cup final be put to rest?

IPSWICH 2 - 0 CHARLTON

Key man: Jamie Clapham was a class above. He completed 40 of 42 passes, including 18 of 18 in the forward third, and had 3 attempts on goal on target.

Weak link: Charlton defending poorly down the flanks, allowing Ipswich to make 30 accurate crosses.

The Edge: Ipswich totally dominated with 61% of net possession. Midfielders Clapham, Jermaine Wright, Matt Holland and Jim Magilton completed 201 of 232 passes, and had 19 scoring attempts between them.

LEICESTER 1 - 1 NEWCASTLE

Key man: Arnar Gunnlaugsson completed all 12 of his passes and scored with his only attempt.

Weak link: Alan Shearer completed only 19 of 38 passes, and his only attempt was not on target.

The Edge: The match was spoiled by poor crossing - Leicester completed only 4 of 15 crosses, and Newcastle 4 of 17.

LIVERPOOL 4 - 1 COVENTRY

Key man: Goals aside, Emile Heskey's tackling - he won 7 of 9 challenges - unsettled Coventry's game.

Weak link: Coventry caught Liverpool offside 6 times, but 9 through balls made their way through the trap to red shirts.

The Edge: Coventry's attack was lame: they connected on only one of 11 crosses and could only latch onto a single through ball - and Craig Bellamy's effort was easily parried by Sander Westerveld. Unsurprisingly, their goal came from a one-off 35-yard effort. Meanwhile, Liverpool connected on 22 crosses and through balls and created a wealth of opportunities.

MANCHESTER UNITED 2 - 1 MIDDLESBROUGH

Key man: Roy Keane and Nicky Butt won 18 of 20 tackles as United dominated in midfield.

Weak link: Despite taking the lead, Boro had little ambition - United's last man Wes Brown had to make only 3 tackles.

The Edge: Dwight Yorke helped United to 63% of net possession. He completed 18 of 28 passes in the forward third and had 5 attempts on goal.

SUNDERLAND 2 - 2 SOUTHAMPTON

Key man: Don Hutchison had a goal and an assist and completed 28 of 35 passes.

Weak link: Sunderland attempted 28 crosses (compared to 11 by Saints) but only 13 went to team-mates.

The Edge: The home side enjoyed 60% of net possession, but were denied by Southampton's tough tackling: Jason Dodd, Claus Lundekvam, Dean Richards, Wayne Bridge and Matthew Oakley battled to win 50 of 55 tackles.

WEST HAM 4 - 1 MANCHESTER CITY

Key man: Paulo Di Canio and Frederic Kanoute were firing on all cylinders. They had 8 scoring attempts on target, of which two found the back of the net.

Weak link: Paolo Wanchope did not enjoy his return to Upton Park. He was tackled 8 times and did not manage an attempt on target.

The Edge: West Ham were solid at the back. Stuart Pearce battled with 22 successful tackles and 16 clearances and Rio Ferdinand won all 17 of his tackling attempts. West Ham's crossing was effective as well - 19 of 24 crosses found a team-mate.

webTitle: Wisden.com to relaunch for next English summer

fields.headline: Wisden.com to relaunch for next English summer
fields.trailText: Wisden.com, the acclaimed website from cricket's best-known publishers, is about to undergo a major relaunch. We will reopen for business in time for next summer's Ashes series with a site which will not just be bigger and better - it will go beyond anything yet seen on the web.
fields.body:
Wisden.com, the acclaimed website from cricket's best-known publishers, is about to undergo a major relaunch. We will reopen for business in time for next summer's Ashes series with a site which will not just be bigger and better - it will go beyond anything yet seen on the web.

Meanwhile, please bear with us, as much of the site is closed for refurbishment. The daily columns and features have been suspended, and editorial is confined to a weekly Wisden Verdict. But you can still Ask Steven anything you want, check the Wisden World Championship standings, and find out what's in the latest issue of Wisden Cricket Monthly, the Wisden Almanack 2000, or the Australian Almanack 2000-01.

Cricket Unlimited, the site run by Wisden in conjunction with The Guardian for the past three years, is to be discontinued, but you can still find the Guardian's cricket coverage on Guardian Unlimited.

If you are a regular user, we apologise for the break in service and look forward to welcoming you again in a few months' time - email us and we will email you back when the new site is up and running. Better still, send us your wish-list and we will do our best to make it come true.

If you are new to Wisden, please feel free to have a look around the site, and find out more about John Wisden, the Almanack, Wisden Cricket Monthly, or wisden.com.

Tim de Lisle, Editor

webTitle: ITouch losses will not halt expansion programme

fields.headline: ITouch to press on with expansion despite losses
fields.trailText: ITouch, the text message and WAP technology company, will continue to expand at break-neck pace, despite reporting heavy losses, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
ITouch, the text message and WAP technology company, will continue to expand at breakneck pace despite reporting heavy losses.

The company, which is 50%-owned by Independent News & Media, owner of the Independent newspaper, said its presence in six different countries was not enough.

Itouch, which has operations in the UK, South Africa, the Republic of Ireland, New Zealand, Australia and Israel, said it was looking at a number of possible new countries in conjunction with major media partners.

The company posted third quarter pre-tax losses of £9.8m on revenues of £2.2m.

Ireland and South Africa are the biggest markets for its technology, which combines voice, data and text messaging on mobile phonea, but the US remains untouched.

ITouch's main UK foothold is its financial news service for the Vizzavi mobile phone portal. ITouch wants to build on this relationship as owners Vivendi and Vodafone invest in the UK market.

Ivan Fallon, chairman of iTouch, said: "With our technology base, geographic spread and strong partnerships, iTouch remains well-positioned and continues to take advantage of the explosive growth in demand for mobile information service."

ITouch has first-mover advantage in the mobile phone technology market but it will be waiting to see if its technology is a hit with users of next generation handsets.

webTitle: Net shopping boom as Britons go online

fields.headline: Net shopping boom as Britons go online
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: The number of Britons buying goods and services on the internet has more than doubled since the start of the year, according to research published today.
fields.body:
The number of Britons buying goods and services on the internet has more than doubled since the start of the year, according to research published today.

The number of online shoppers in the UK rose from 2.26m in January to 4.7m now, the study says.

People were also buying via their computers more often, with 1.45m consumers making four or more purchases online since the beginning of the year.

The most popular items were holidays, books, computer games and music, said the survey, produced by global information company Experian, which questioned more than 500,000 internet users.

The research showed that online shoppers were mainly young and wealthy. It said that 37% of internet shoppers surveyed said they did not consider the worldwide web to be a valuable educational resource.

webTitle: BCOM3's Fizdale steps down

fields.headline: BCOM3's Fizdale steps down
fields.trailText: 11.45am: One of the industry's most distinguished executives, Rick Fizdale, is retiring from active management after nearly 30 years, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
One of the industry's most distinguished executives, Rick Fizdale, is retiring from active management after nearly 30 years.

The BCOM3 boss will leave the company on December 31.

Mr Fizdale, the group's vice-chairman and one of the key figures behind its launch, will continue to serve on the BCOM3 board of directors as vice-chairman but will no longer play an active role in running the business.

His departure from the business ends a career that started in the creative department of Leo Burnett.

He is one of the few in the industry who have successfully made the transition to management.

BCOM3 was formed in March this year after the merger of Leo Burnett and MacManus and backed by Dentsu, Japan's biggest ad agency, with a multi-million pound investment.

Prior to the merger, Mr Fizdale was chairman at Leo Burnett.

Fizdale has spent his entire career at the agency. He joined in 1969 as a copywriter, rising through the ranks of the creative department. He became senior vice president of creative operations in 1979 and deputy director of creative services in 1982.

He was named president and chief creative officer for Leo Burnett three years later and became chief creative officer for the agency's global network in 1985. In 1992 he added the title of chairman and chief executive officer.

Under Mr Fizdale's watch as CEO from 1997, Leo Burnett grew from a global network of 84 offices in 75 countries to one that includes nearly 300 operating units in 90 countries.

The agency also picked up major new business assignments from Heinz, Procter & Gamble, Coca Cola and Delta Airlines.

Roger Haupt will take over as chief executive officer.

"No one has done more to uphold the agency's creative standards, client-focused philosophy and work ethic than Rick has," said Linda Wolf, current CEO of Leo Burnett USA.
