webTitle: Casting news: Daldry plumps for Woolf homage

fields.headline: Daldry plumps for Woolf homage
fields.trailText: Plus: Culkin to be reborn as period film maestro?; Bedazzled stars to reunite for Tennessee Williams play
fields.body:
Stephen Daldry's next film will be The Hours - a homage to Virginia Woolf. Nicole Kidman, Merly Street and Julianne Moore will star, and shooting is due to begin in London, early next year.

The 20-year-old Macaulay Culkin, currently gracing London's West End in Madame Melville, has caught the eye of producer James Ivory. People News reports that the former child star is being courted by the Merchant Ivory producer. "[James] is convinced that Macaulay would be perfect for his next film," said an unnamed source. What the next film actually is remains to be seen.

Brendan Fraser and Frances O'Connor, currently starring together in Bedazzled, will act opposite each other again in a theatrical production of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof. The Tennessee Williams play will be staged in London's West End early next year.

webTitle: Fight for two nations in one city

fields.headline: Fight for two nations in one city
fields.standfirst:
Thursday sees byelections in Preston, West Bromwich, and Glasgow Anniesland. In the first of a three-part series on the polls we look at the late Donald Dewar's Glasgow seat

Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Friends of the late Donald Dewar like to tell how he would go to the edge of his Glasgow constituency, Anniesland, to remind himself what he stood for. On one side lay Bearsden, a desirable suburb. On the other lay Drumchapel, a bleak housing estate, that formed the main part of his seat.
fields.body:
Friends of the late Donald Dewar like to tell how he would go to the edge of his Glasgow constituency, Anniesland, to remind himself what he stood for. On one side lay Bearsden, a desirable suburb. On the other lay Drumchapel, a bleak housing estate, that formed the main part of his seat.

Two nations in one city; health, education and opportunity determined by a separation of a few hundred yards of park. It was a divide that drove Mr Dewar, and will play a large role in deciding who succeeds him in Anniesland.

The byelection on November 23 will be a double-header because Mr Dewar held seats at both Westminster and in the Scottish parliament. On paper it should be straightforward. He had a 15,000 majority for Westminster and an 11,000 majority for Holyrood, and his standing in the constituency was immense. In the old days, when it was called Garscadden, it was said you did not count Labour votes, you weighed them.

"Nothing is guaranteed," said John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde University. "You can't assume people will vote Labour out of affection for Donald Dewar. He had a personal vote - so in a sense that makes it less safe for Labour, because that will disappear. People will vote on the candidates in front of them and what they think of the issues that affect them and the constituency."

Anniesland occupies the north-west corner of Glasgow. It has upmarket enclaves, Kelvinside and Jordanhill, but is typified by council estates and established working class neighbourhoods. It has the second highest proportion of over-55s in Scotland, and has come close to the top in UK-wide surveys of poverty and ill-health. Analysts say the issues will be as they have always been: jobs, pensions, housing, social justice.

"Anniesland raises the whole question of whether or not Labour can reconnect with some of its core supporters," said Mr Curtice. "The party will want to stem the decline in its vote."

It is an awkward fight for Labour, and the party's campaign has played heavily on the theme of following in Mr Dewar's footsteps. On Friday Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, flew up from London to chat with pensioners, play carpet bowls, and eat in the supermarket cafe where Mr Dewar dined.

Labour's Westminster candidate is his former election agent, John Robertson; the Holyrood hopeful is Bill Butler, a Glasgow councillor and left-winger whose wife, Patricia Ferguson, is MSP for the neighbouring constituency of Glasgow Maryhill and deputy presiding officer at Holyrood.

Mr Butler, 44, has faced awkward questions as to the authenticity of his leftist credentials after his support for the proposed transfer of council homes to housing associations, widely opposed among Glasgow housing groups.

"The Labour party is a democratic party. I will have my say, we will draw up a political position, and then I will go out there and fight for party policy," he says. "I think those categories of old and new Labour are slightly passé. I see myself as middle-aged Labour."

He rejects predictions of a harder fight for Labour, which has taken a pounding in Scottish polls.

"I don't see either of these fights as easy. We are confident but not complacent. We are going to fight for every vote. We are fighting on social justice, the bread-and-butter issues that Donald would have wanted. And Donald would have said you have got to get on with it."

The Scottish National Party has lost no time in doing so, and poll pundits say that, despite the odds, Anniesland is within its grasp - requiring a 22% swing to take the Westminster seat and a 19.5% swing for the Holyrood seat, feats that it has managed elsewhere. In Hamilton South the SNP nearly took George Robertson's seat with a 22.5% swing.

"Very big swings are required, but the SNP has shown itself capable of doing that in a byelection," said Malcolm Dickson, a Glasgow polling analyst. "They have also shown they can be a very effective campaigning machine. No one should imagine it's cut and dried."

SNP officials say they are confident they can deliver an upset. "Labour has let Anniesland down, both from Westminster and Holyrood," said campaign officer Calum Smith. "Look at statistics regarding health, and the concern over the housing stock transfer. There is a feeling of alienation here - we can address that."

Tom Chalmers, the SNP's Holyrood candidate and a local lawyer, said they had been encouraged by the response of constituents and sensed a real desire for a change.

In the constituency itself, however, there seems little heart for an all-out political fight in a byelection that no one wanted. fields.bodyText: Friends of the late Donald Dewar like to tell how he would go to the edge of his Glasgow constituency, Anniesland, to remind himself what he stood for. On one side lay Bearsden, a desirable suburb. On the other lay Drumchapel, a bleak housing estate, that formed the main part of his seat. Two nations in one city; health, education and opportunity determined by a separation of a few hundred yards of park. It was a divide that drove Mr Dewar, and will play a large role in deciding who succeeds him in Anniesland. The byelection on November 23 will be a double-header because Mr Dewar held seats at both Westminster and in the Scottish parliament. On paper it should be straightforward. He had a 15,000 majority for Westminster and an 11,000 majority for Holyrood, and his standing in the constituency was immense. In the old days, when it was called Garscadden, it was said you did not count Labour votes, you weighed them. He had a personal vote - so in a sense that makes it less safe for Labour, because that will disappear. webTitle: In brief: No Lee-way for Will Smith's race portrayal

fields.headline: No Lee-way for Will Smith's race portrayal
fields.trailText: Plus: New 2001 print in 2001; foreign film Oscar prospects submitted; female psyche no mystery for Gibson, Streisand to get lifetime gong; and more Hannibal goodies online
fields.body:
 Never one to be afraid of speaking out, the latest target of Spike Lee's wrath is Will Smith, and his role in Robert Redford's The Legend of Bagger Vance. At a Harvard University discussion panel on race held last week, Lee voiced his displeasure over Smith's decision to play a mystical and spiritual golf caddy in the movie. In a subsequent interview with the New York Post, Lee criticised Smith's role as Matt Damon's subordinate in the film he described as "Driving Mr Damon", for painting such a rose-tinted picture of racial relations in the Depression-era South. You can check what Will Smith thought of the part: read an interview with the actor at Mr Showbiz.

 A remastered version of Stanley Kubrick's classic 2001: A Space Odyssey will close the 2001 Berlin Film Festival, before being rereleased worldwide on March 7 - the second anniversary of the director's death.

 Screendaily has published a list of the films that have been submitted for this year's foreign language Oscar. The Academy will announce the full list on November 20.

 Intrigued by the thought of Mel Gibson in touch with his feminine side? In What Women Want, he stars as a chauvinistic Chicago ad exec who, after getting electrocuted in the bathtub, realises he's able to read women's minds. You can watch the trailer on Entertainment Weekly's site.

 Barbra Streisand is to receive the 2001 American Film Industry Life Achievement Award - even though she hasn't appeared in a movie for four years. The singer-cum-actress is the 29th recipient of the prestigious award, which will be presented in February. AFI board member Howard Stringer said: "Barbra Streisand is a living legend who epitomises the essence of American film. She is a pioneer in everything she does, whether it's acting, directing, writing, producing or singing."

 The official site for Ridley Scott's Hannibal has new pictures and a trailer. The movie will open in February next year.

webTitle: Advertising upheaval holds back Emap profits

fields.headline: Advertising upheaval holds back Emap profits
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Emap has been hit by upheaval at its new advertising sales house, with its flagship consumer magazines such as FHM bearing the brunt of the damage. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Emap has been hit by upheaval at its new advertising sales house, with its flagship consumer magazines bearing the brunt of the damage.

The publisher of celebrity title Heat and lads' mag FHM said profits had been affected by the chaos caused by the creation of a new central internal advertising house, Emap Advertising.

Ian Griffiths, head of finance at Emap, said: "We managed the whole change process quite badly. We managed it too hard and too quick. Change is a very difficult thing to manage and it was a fundamental change we were making."

First half pre-tax profits were frozen at £92m, the same as last year, although revenues rose 3% to £567m.

The group said the cost of expanding its digital operations and bedding down acquisitions contributed to the slump in profits growth.

Kevin Hand, Emap chief executive, said: "It has been a challenging six months for Emap with some disappointments but many positive achievements."

Emap will be concerned that its Lifestyle division, which handles the glossy magazines including FHM, was the hardest hit by the upheaval, with advertising revenues falling 8%.

A volatile magazine market in the US also affected the international launch of FHM, with the US division reporting a £3m shortfall in turnover as it was stung by a crowded marketplace.

Some cheer was raised by cut-price entertainment weekly Heat, which has recovered from a difficult start and will reach an average circulation of 150,000 in the next six months.

Despite the uncertain results, Emap is pushing ahead with the expansion of its digital services by investing £120m over the next three years.

Emap aims to make a big splash in the digital market next year, with the launch of the Slam joint venture with Channel 4 and several websites with French internet company Wanadoo.

webTitle: Angels no box office lightweights

fields.headline: Angels no box office lightweights
fields.trailText: Charlie's Angels continued to defy its critics with a second week on top of the US box office, fighting off strong competition. Adam Sandler's Little Nicky, in which the comedian plays the kind-hearted son of Satan (Harvey Keitel), opened in second place, taking $18.1m
fields.body:
Charlie's Angels continued to defy its critics with a second week on top of the US box office, fighting off strong competition. Adam Sandler's Little Nicky, in which the comedian plays the kind-hearted son of Satan (Harvey Keitel), opened in second place, taking $18.1m.

One of the US's biggest and most bankable stars, Sandler's last two movies - 1999's Big Daddy and 1998's The Waterboy - opened with $41.5m and $39.4m respectively. The relatively meagre sum of $18.1m represents something of a disappointment to Little Nicky distributors New Line Cinema.

"I think we would have wanted it to open higher, but you need to look at the reality of the marketplace," said David Tuckerman, New Line's president of domestic distribution.

Charlie's Angels, however, has far exceeded expectations, and has grossed $75.4m in the 10-day period since it opened. The Drew Barrymore production looks set to pass the $100m mark before the Thanksgiving weekend.

The US top 10 contained two other new releases. The military drama Men of Honor, which stars Al Pacino and Cuba Gooding Jnr, opened at third place, and the sci-fi thriller Red Planet was at number five.

Red Planet, director Anthony Hoffman's story of an ill-fated mission to Mars, met with howls of critical derision. "It's a giant roach motel of a movie, where actors check in but don't check out," writes the Boston Globe, "Red Planet leaves a trail of slime," says the Toronto Star, while the more sombre San Francisco Chronicle advised its readers, "This spaceship misfire manages to be overblown and undernourished at the same time."

Intrigued? Watch the trailer here.

webTitle: The worst run place in Britain?

fields.headline: The worst run place in Britain?
fields.standfirst: A lack of political will has left Hackney bankrupt and unable to provide its citizens with services.
fields.trailText: It was, all too appropriately, a march to absolutely nowhere. The 500 Hackney residents and council workers, who joined last Monday's demonstration against proposed emergency cuts to council services, trudged through the wind and the rain on a long, circuitous route that took them only from Hackney Town Hall all the way back to Hackney Town Hall.
fields.body:
It was, all too appropriately, a march to absolutely nowhere. The 500 Hackney residents and council workers, who joined last Monday's demonstration against proposed emergency cuts to council services, trudged through the wind and the rain on a long, circuitous route that took them only from Hackney Town Hall all the way back to Hackney Town Hall.

For the poor benighted citizens of this poorest of London boroughs - a place that should serve as a warning to us all about what can happen when local government goes pitifully wrong - it just reinforced what they had always thought: in Hackney, nothing ever seems to move on.

It was there, even in the style of the protest. Had it been shot in black and white by Pathé it could not have looked more like a relic from an earlier age.

There were the Socialist Workers' Party placards. There were the fluttering union banners and the votes of support from striking health workers from distant corners of the nation. And there, too, were the rousers of the rabble with their rhythmic call-and-response chants by megaphone and their insistence that the solution was to 'Tax the rich. Make them pay'.

This is the borough described by one resident as 'Britain's North Korea. It's the place modern politics forgot'. The protesters' chants at least had the virtue of simplifying the situation down to a failure of leftist will by local councillors. But it is not that straightforward, however much you might wish it to be so. True, the crisis is down to a failure on the part of councillors but, as with everything in this deprived corner of East London, there are lots of other people more than deserving of blame.

Last month the Borough Treasurer, George Jenkins, announced that Hackney did not have enough money to meet the commitments it had made up to the end of this financial year. In short, like New York in the Seventies, it was going bust. Under the terms of local government legislation Jenkins was forced to issue a Section 114 order, which immediately barred the council from spending any money until it had agreed budget cuts, which means finding savings of around £4.5 million this year and £18m next.

Coming in the same week as Chancellor Gordon Brown was opening up his bulging exchequer to buy off pensioners and fuel protesters, the proposed cuts made Hackney look like the council that New Labour had left behind.

The effect of the 114 order was almost immediate. Headteachers across the borough passed a vote of no confidence in their education service - already part-privatised due to previous failures - and wrote to parents informing them that, because they would not be able to employ supply teachers, their children might not have classes to go to. Parks and gardening trucks ran out of fuel and were told not to fill up. Council work men were given orders to do the minimum work possible.

In one instance, a council tenant had a new bath fitted but was told he couldn't have any taps because that would mean extra expense. Another was told they could fix the stopcock in his toilet cistern but not the leaking pipe to it, leaving him unable to flush.

Wetherell Day Nursery closed because of a leaking roof nobody could afford to fix. Then a manager in the council's waste service dismissed all the temporary staff, and rubbish collections, always erratic, stopped. This weekend the streets overflow with rotting garbage. The rats, at least, are getting fatter.

It was supposed to be so different. In June, Hackney gained a new managing director, Max Caller, former chief executive of Barnet council, who answered an advert looking for somebody willing to take on 'the job from hell'. It was by no means underselling the challenge: there had been damning Ofsted reports on Hackney schools and part of the social services department had already come under direct central government control.

The month Caller started work, proclaiming a commitment to give the people of Hackney 'a better deal and a joined-up council doing the right things for them', the District Auditor issued a report that uncovered widespread mismanagement and inadequate accounting on a vast scale. Last week, just as the council was meeting to discuss the latest cuts, there was yet another damning report, this time by the new Best Value Inspection Service set up under recent local government legislation.

'Hackney is not a well-run council and is letting down the people who live in the borough,' said Wendy Thomson, director of inspection at the Audit Commission. 'It is simply not delivering best value in council tax collection, payment of housing benefit, refuse collection, street sweeping or children's services.' No fewer than 17,000 people, she said, were awaiting payment of housing benefit.

At the same time, Caller issued his own report, stuffed full of staggering allegations. Almost nothing at all, he said, was known about who was spending what. Local managers would hide the true costs of their services or would tell democratically elected members what they thought they wanted to hear instead of the truth. As a result, a £5m contract with a private company for rubbish collection had to be delayed when it emerged that the cost of running the service was double that. Managers were also ignoring orders.

When the council passed a resolution insisting no more permanent staff be employed, managers simply employed temporary ones, who turned out to cost more. It was clear, Caller announced, 'that the various moratoriums that were imposed were either not understood, ignored or subverted'.

Ask the political classes of Hackney how it got to be this way and they will sigh and tell you it is a very long story. Partly, they will say, it is simple economics. The borough has few pockets of wealth and receives the fourth-highest central government grant in the country - £1,220 per head of population. There are deep, dark pools of unemployment and poverty and areas where crime and drug abuse are rife.

It was not always like this. Though there has long been poverty here, it was once a thriving borough with big department stores on the high streets and fine Georgian and Regency Squares now left isolated in the midst of dilapidated council estates.

Throughout its history, those with money who have soaked up its rich diverse culture have eventually moved out. (In the Eighties, for example, a young married couple with promising careers as barristers lived in the Mapledene area of Hackney. In time they, too, decided to move to up-and-coming Islington and never looked back. Their names were Tony and Cherie Blair.)

But economic deprivation does not explain all or, at least, not the most recent problems. 'There's simply been a failure of political culture in Hackney,' says Jules Pipe of the Labour Group who, with his Tory colleague Eric Ollerenshaw, now leads the council. He points at a split in Labour in 1996, when more than a dozen Labour members left the party. 'You will never get to the bottom of that split. It was just two groups of people who mutually hated each other. But the moment it became a hung council the idea of an administration with a scrutinising opposition went out the window. In short, there was an absence of administration.'

Councillors busied themselves with feverish infighting to such a degree that the then chief executive, Tony Eliston, said he would install traffic lights in the council chamber to control floor-crossing by members. (One councillor, David Phillips, has sat as Labour, Hackney New Labour - nothing to do with the Blair-Mandelson version - Conservative, Independent, LibDem and now Green Party.)

Meanwhile, without any scrutiny by councillors to trouble them, unelected managers set about creating fiefdoms within the council.

In 1997 a new plan, 'Transforming Hackney', placed budgets in the hands of individual managers in an attempt to get council services closer to residents. Without any central financial management at all, Hackney council was at the mercy of legions of incompetent council officials.

The question Hackney residents are now asking themselves is whether the severe cuts announced last week - up to 500 jobs may go, employees are being given new working terms and conditions, council trading units are being closed down, services are being withdrawn - are merely a symptom of the chronic disease or the cure.

Pipe is in no doubt they are curing their ills. Labour and the Conservatives have decided to co-operate - shoving the Lib Dems into opposition - and so there is now a form of political stability for the first time in four years. 'Under Max Caller and his new team we also have management in place which has finally been able to identify the problems,' he says.

Caller agrees. 'We have been able to take the decision that needed to be taken. We have introduced management controls which make it possible to handle the finances. I am determined to get best value for the people of Hackney.' Budget cuts, he says, are not necessarily the same as cuts in services. 'We simply need to improve efficiency and productivity.' How that will be done, he does not say.

Whether the cuts agreed last Monday night will achieve all of this is open to question. Several are in complete contradiction to central government policy. For example, next year Hackney will cut more than £600,000 from its budget for early education at the same time as the Government is shoving it to the top of its agenda.

Likewise, the borough has cut 48 beds from its residential care services for people coming out of hospital and slashed away at the budget for home care. The most likely outcome is that, because there will be nowhere to discharge them to, patients will lock up hospital beds, thus lengthening waiting lists.

Even Caller admitted, in his report to the council, that this will have 'immediate repercussions on health, particularly through the winter period'. Likewise he admitted the changes he was proposing to the social services would mean cutting back on preventative work, even though it is a statutory requirement of all councils.

Despite all of this, Whitehall will not be intervening to bail out Hackney.

'I'm horrified by the position there,' said Local Government Minister Hillary Armstrong. 'It's a position no council should have got itself into. It's a position no residents should have to experience. But throwing money at the problem is not the solution. They have to get their own house in order.'

So is she abandoning Hackney? 'Far from it. We will back them all the way. We just have to hope that they've got to the bottom of the deficit and that nobody's hiding any more debt.'

Perhaps most worrying for the people of Hackney is that, technically, the borough is still bust. Despite the cuts, the budget is in no way balanced and it is only because of loan facilities agreed with central government late on Friday that the council can continue to spend money at all.

Should there be any problems at all with these loans and the budget falls short, the Borough Treasurer will be forced to issue another Section 114 order. All spending will cease immediately.

Toilets will remain unfixed. Roofs will leak. Rubbish will go uncollected. For the long-suffering people of Hackney, it will be business as usual.

As a result, a £5m contract with a private company for rubbish collection had to be delayed when it emerged that the cost of running the service was double that. Managers were also ignoring orders. When the council passed a resolution insisting no more permanent staff be employed, managers simply employed temporary ones, who turned out to cost more. It was clear, Caller announced, 'that the various moratoriums that were imposed were either not understood, ignored or subverted'. Ask the political classes of Hackney how it got to be this way and they will sigh and tell you it is a very long story. Partly, they will say, it is simple economics. The borough has few pockets of wealth and receives the fourth-highest central government grant in the country - £1,220 per head of population. There are deep, dark pools of unemployment and poverty and areas where crime and drug abuse are rife. It was not always like this. Though there has long been poverty here, it was once a thriving borough with big department stores on the high streets and fine Georgian and Regency Squares now left isolated in the midst of dilapidated council estates. Throughout its history, those with money who have soaked up its rich diverse culture have eventually moved out. (In the Eighties, for example, a young married couple with promising careers as barristers lived in the Mapledene area of Hackney. In time they, too, decided to move to up-and-coming Islington and never looked back. Their names were Tony and Cherie Blair.) But economic deprivation does not explain all or, at least, not the most recent problems. 'There's simply been a failure of political culture in Hackney,' says Jules Pipe of the Labour Group who, with his Tory colleague Eric Ollerenshaw, now leads the council. He points at a split in Labour in 1996, when more than a dozen Labour members left the party. 'You will never get to the bottom of that split. It was just two groups of people who mutually hated each other. But the moment it became a hung council the idea of an administration with a scrutinising opposition went out the window. In short, there was an absence of administration.' Councillors busied themselves with feverish infighting to such a degree that the then chief executive, Tony Eliston, said he would install traffic lights in the council chamber to control floor-crossing by members. (One councillor, David Phillips, has sat as Labour, Hackney New Labour - nothing to do with the Blair-Mandelson version - Conservative, Independent, LibDem and now Green Party.) Meanwhile, without any scrutiny by councillors to trouble them, unelected managers set about creating fiefdoms within the council. In 1997 a new plan, 'Transforming Hackney', placed budgets in the hands of individual managers in an attempt to get council services closer to residents. Without any central financial management at all, Hackney council was at the mercy of legions of incompetent council officials. The question Hackney residents are now asking themselves is whether the severe cuts announced last week - up to 500 jobs may go, employees are being given new working terms and conditions, council trading units are being closed down, services are being withdrawn - are merely a symptom of the chronic disease or the cure. Pipe is in no doubt they are curing their ills. Labour and the Conservatives have decided to co-operate - shoving the Lib Dems into opposition - and so there is now a form of political stability for the first time in four years. 'Under Max Caller and his new team we also have management in place which has finally been able to identify the problems,' he says. Caller agrees. 'We have been able to take the decision that needed to be taken. We have introduced management controls which make it possible to handle the finances. I am determined to get best value for the people of Hackney.' Budget cuts, he says, are not necessarily the same as cuts in services. 'We simply need to improve efficiency and productivity.' How that will be done, he does not say. Whether the cuts agreed last Monday night will achieve all of this is open to question. Several are in complete contradiction to central government policy. For example, next year Hackney will cut more than £600,000 from its budget for early education at the same time as the Government is shoving it to the top of its agenda. Likewise, the borough has cut 48 beds from its residential care services for people coming out of hospital and slashed away at the budget for home care. The most likely outcome is that, because there will be nowhere to discharge them to, patients will lock up hospital beds, thus lengthening waiting lists. Even Caller admitted, in his report to the council, that this will have 'immediate repercussions on health, particularly through the winter period'. Likewise he admitted the changes he was proposing to the social services would mean cutting back on preventative work, even though it is a statutory requirement of all councils. Despite all of this, Whitehall will not be intervening to bail out Hackney. 'I'm horrified by the position there,' said Local Government Minister Hillary Armstrong. 'It's a position no council should have got itself into. It's a position no residents should have to experience. But throwing money at the problem is not the solution. They have to get their own house in order.' So is she abandoning Hackney? 'Far from it. We will back them all the way. We just have to hope that they've got to the bottom of the deficit and that nobody's hiding any more debt.' Perhaps most worrying for the people of Hackney is that, technically, the borough is still bust. Despite the cuts, the budget is in no way balanced and it is only because of loan facilities agreed with central government late on Friday that the council can continue to spend money at all. Should there be any problems at all with these loans and the budget falls short, the Borough Treasurer will be forced to issue another Section 114 order. All spending will cease immediately. Toilets will remain unfixed. Roofs will leak. Rubbish will go uncollected. For the long-suffering people of Hackney, it will be business as usual.

webTitle: The cave people of Goreme

fields.headline: The cave people of Goreme
fields.standfirst: Dr Nick Banks reports on an exercise in sustainable living
fields.trailText: Nick Banks reports on an exercise in sustainable living.
fields.body:
One hundred thousand years ago Cappadoccia in central Turkey was a land of fire and brimstone. Volcanoes rained down ash. As layer upon layer fell, the ash became compressed to produce a stone called Tuffa.

This stone has made the area fertile for crops - despite scorching Cappadoccian summers, the stones irrigate the fields, slowly releasing water absorbed during the autumn and winter rains.

In the centre of the region there is a tiny town known as Goreme. This has been variously settled, by the Christians of Byzantium, then the Seljuk Turks and finally the tourists, carpet shops, guesthouses and now internet cafes.

The Tuffa stone has made Goreme a strange place. The landscape has formed dozens of mushroom shaped rock structures. Averaging about thirty metres in height, some of these supply houses to the local population. Inside the domes of these rock mushrooms may be found hundreds of furnished cave-rooms - some connected by terraces and walkways, some standing alone, some with satellite dishes, some abandoned and on the verge of collapse.

People have lived in the cave houses of Goreme for centuries - and for good reasons. The caves have amazing thermal properties that make them perfect for the local climate. In the hot summers the rooms are cool whilst in the often bitterly cold winters, the heat absorbed in the tonnes of rock overhead during the hot months is gently and slowly released.

But the cave dwellers have long found their inhabitations under threat. In the 60s a local bureaucrat decided that living in a cave was not an appropriate way of life in a "modern" society. The bureaucrat's case was bolstered when a cave house collapsed in the neighbouring village, killing the family within.

New subsidised housing was thrown up and the cave dwellers were encouraged to move out. Many did so voluntarily, particularly the young, seeing the housing as a step up the social scale and a step closer to the West. Others were not so keen and were moved against their will.

One winter was enough to convince many of the movers that there was something to be said for the old ways after all. The new houses were poorly insulated, costing ten times as much to heat as the caves. Instead of the garden rubbish which had previously been used for heating, quantities of coal were required. In Turkey this is not cheap so family members had to go out and get jobs rather than working the land or looking after the household.

The new houses were inadequate in other ways. Whereas bread and dried fruit could be safely stored for months in the caves, it quickly began to rot in the damp and stuffy new buildings. Farmers had no place to put their tools and machinery. There were no walled courtyards behind which women could work and talk. The decision disrupted both the local economy and culture.

There seems to be no central plan for how to develop the area sensitively, even inspirationally. A group of residents led by Andus Emge, a German who has lived in the cave houses for many years and who has written a PhD dissertation on the subject are trying to develop such a scheme.

Andus has set up an organisation called Concept_C, which brings together architects, technologists, planners, social scientists and residents to encourage a new vision for the area. A number of conferences have already been held and more are planned. The conclusions of these meetings are then discussed with local officials.

It is a vision which somehow avoids the creation of a sterile open air museum and instead brings the best of modern technology and building techniques together which the evident advantages of the cave architecture and lifestyle.

In the process jobs are made and the cave houses of Goreme remain wonders which above all provide unique, practical and sustainable housing.

• To find out more about Concept_C and the cave houses of Goreme go to Andus's home page at www.uni-koeln.de/~a0144

webTitle: Gilliam's Quixote rides on

fields.headline: Gilliam's Quixote rides on
fields.trailText: Reports of the demise of Terry Gilliam's The Man who Killed Don Quixote are greatly exaggerated, according to a mysterious spy who has contacted Ain't It Cool
fields.body:
Reports of the demise of Terry Gilliam's The Man who Killed Don Quixote were, it seems, greatly exaggerated. Someone calling himself "I am Spartacus" has written to spy site Ain't It Cool News with the following message.

"As someone who's been involved with the production, I felt it was time to set the record straight. The movie started filming on location in Spain on September 25. On the second day there was a flash flood on location that washed away the cameras, the set etc. This caused delays to the production and, subsequently, when Jean Rochefort who was playing Quixote, fell ill, this led to the movie closing down after less than two weeks of principal photography."

The secret reporter continued: "Rochefort retreated to Paris, where doctors tried to ascertain what was wrong with him - double disk hernia as it turned out, something that suggested many problems, given that the movie required him to ride a horse for the majority of his screen time.

"After weeks of debate and numerous meetings between Gilliam, the producers and the insurers it was decided to TEMPORARILY cease production.

"Now naturally there are no guarantees anytime any movie of this scale closes down - but every effort is being made to re-start this film. Last week there were reports in the French press, picked up by various sites, that made it sound as if the production is over.

"This is simply not the case - as of now, Gilliam is working toward getting this movie made, with a proposed re-start date of January 2001. Despite reports last week, if and when the film gets up and running again it will most definitely be with Johnny Depp and Terry Gilliam involved.

"Gilliam is contracted to direct this movie - there is no way it's happening without him. Depp meanwhile has kept his schedule free to accommodate this. The wild card is Rochefort, whose health still needs to be determined. Vanessa Paradis meanwhile, who was playing the female lead, will have to be re-cast as she has longstanding prior commitments to her recording career."

webTitle: BBC Worldwide moves into e-book publishing

fields.headline: BBC Worldwide moves into e-book publishing
fields.trailText: 12.15pm:The BBC has made its first foray into e-book publishing, which could lead to users downloading Delia Smith's latest recipes, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The BBC has come up with the ideal solution for those who know their Palm from their elbow but don't know how to cook an egg.

In the not-too-distant future, BBC Worldwide could allow PDA users to download Delia Smith's latest recipes on to their pocket organisers.

This week the commercial arm of the BBC made its first foray into e-book publishing with the launch of OnTheEdgeBook.co.uk, a website where users can download a book 10 days before the paperback hits the shops.

The move is part of a new BBC Worldwide initiative to rejig book and magazine content for download onto PDA (personal digital assistant) devices.

A spokeswoman for BBC Worldwide said the possibilities were endless and it was looking at repurposing a range of back-catalogue titles, such as its Sci Fi, Dr Who and cookery range, and ensuring that it acquires digital rights for all new books and publications.

She said: "We're using this first e-book venture as a learning opportunity to find out about the logistics of it all. The thought is that the electronic format is a much better medium than CD-Roms for practical non-fiction such as cookery and gardening."

The first e-book initiative has been launched off the back of BBC2 dot.com drama series Attachments with a diary-based book from the characters in the show.

As an added incentive for PDA users to download the book, the digital version has been priced at £1 less than the paperback, which will go on sale next week at £6.99.

webTitle: Beatles fans get ticket to ride in cyberspace

fields.headline: Beatles fans get ticket to ride in cyberspace
fields.standfirst:
Album of number ones released

Beatles quiz
fields.trailText:
Album of number ones released

Beatles quiz
fields.body:
The Beatles today launched their first official release in cyberspace.

Fans can get a Ticket To Ride on the information superhighway when the £2m site goes live to coincide with today's release of the group's new greatest hits package.

Web designers from around the world have been recruited to come up with the site which - like most of their releases - has been coordinated at London's Abbey Road studios.

Each section of the site is based around one of the 27 tracks on the new album 1, all of which have been number ones.

For the I Feel Fine section, a Paris-based company has come up with a new video for the song animation using monochrome images taken from stills.

In the Yellow Submarine area, fans can play a Space Invaders-style game firing at the Blue Meanies, which featured in the Beatles' animated movie.

Another game area, Help!, allows players to become members of the band and interact with other fans from around the world.

The I Want To Hold Your Hand section allows web surfers to see the famous Studio 2 at Abbey Road as the Beatles themselves would have seen it. By clicking on Ringo Starr, for example, they can see the view he had from his drum stool.

Anthony Couchi of record company EMI, who was project manager for the site, said the remaining members of the band were personally involved in setting it up.

When the site launches today it will have just 10 sections, building up to the full 27 over the next three months.

The greatest hits collection, The Beatles 1, went on sale today and HMV in London's Oxford Street opened for one hour from midnight to allow fans to buy the album.

About 15 fans gathered at the store for the special opening, including Beatles fanatic Naoto Ito, who camped outside the shop from 7.30pm yesterday to become the first person to buy the album in Britain.

webTitle: Living it large

fields.headline: Living it large
fields.standfirst: Giles Smith looks down on the world from the Lexus RX300, a stylish cross between sports utility vehicle and luxury saloon
fields.trailText: Giles Smith looks down on the world from the Lexus RX300, a stylish cross between sports utility vehicle and luxury saloon.
fields.body:
Imagine the following contemporary motoring dilemma: you are the driver of a top-of-the-range saloon car, probably provided for you by your place of work and updated annually, or as soon as the carpets get a bit scruffy. Your vehicle is, more likely than not, made in Germany and gets a weekly valet. And you are entirely happy that it answers to your desires for comfort, power, needless in-car gadgetry and shameless salary-flaunting.

Yet something nags you. You see the way the market is going. The saloon car's hitherto unquestioned top role in the arena of status definition is now under pressure from (of all places) the sports utility vehicle - and in crude and worrying ways. People are driving vehicles that are much, much bigger than yours, although they may in fact be cheaper. With increasing frequency, people are questioning both your sexuality and your earning power by drawing alongside you in cars whose wheels come up to your roof.

If this is you, then what you do next is very simple. You contact the company's fleet department and ask them to move you along to a Lexus RX300. As a saloon person, you'll feel immediately at home with the RX300 from the minute you open the door and the smell of several square miles of quality leather hits you.

Indeed, all of the things one associates with a luxury saloon are present and correct in the Lexus: the CD-changer mounted in the glove compartment, the heated front seats (God forbid that your buttocks should ever go unpoached, even for a minute), the electric sunroof, the touch-screen navigation system.

And yet, unlike your old saloon, the RX300 is the size of a minibus. It's set up to go booming across mountain ranges the hard way: the distance from the top of the wheels to the wheel arches (a crucial status signifier in this area) is a journey all by itself. The driving seat posts you up high for enhanced visibility and superior sneering possibilities. Indeed, it puts you right up there at the level of bus drivers and mounted policemen. And all this with the comforts of your old Audi entirely intact.

It's that canny hybrid, then: an executive sports utility vehicle or, to use the market terms, a premium off-roader. The big question remains: having paid a premium price, who would wish to take a car like this off the road? It might get scratched. Anyway, the premium off-roader is not an original idea, though Lexus can perhaps be credited with having put their own twist on it by producing a hitherto unthought-of meeting between the SUV and a brand of quiet style.

The RX300 looks like a Range Rover after a year spent learning some manners. Note the total absence, on the front of the vehicle, of the anti-elephant devices and snow-shovels that encumber the leading edges of the traditional SUV. Note the tasteful invisibility of the spare wheel. And note overall the general favouring of gentle slopes and smooth arcs over the blunt ends and comically muscular haunches typical of the genre.

The overall design has gone down well in America, where Lexus was most famous for its saloons but where the RX300 is now its best-seller. Here, it makes the other vehicles in its class look hulking and brutish, with the possible exception of the BMW X5, but that will cost you nearly half as much again, and it's only fair that £45,000 should buy you a car that doesn't look entirely like a steel bucket.

At around £30,000, the RX300's genuine rivals for price are the Jeep Grand Cherokee and the Land Rover Discovery. As befits an attack vehicle, the Jeep is a big bunch of hard lines and does not easily please the eye; while the Discovery is a rural monster, which should be driven only by people with ponies to deliver. On style grounds, the RX300 cleans up.

The extent of the illusion within is uncanny. You know you are in an SUV because you have to pull your self up into the seat slightly and because your wing mirrors are the size of portable television screens. Rumour has it that, on a clear day, you can see seven adjoining counties in those wing mirrors.

But despite all that, you have, at the wheel, the nearly seamless impression of sitting inside a saloon, albeit a particularly capacious one with flatteringly comfortable seats. (Your passenger is a chaste arm's length away from you, as if in business class. The people in the back? You can forget about them. They're miles behind.)

And, just like a top-grade saloon, the RX300 seems determined to eliminate all discomfort caused by that old motoring bugbear - contact with the road. The engine whispers almost inaudibly, somewhere out in the front. In any case, the gearbox is automatic, so the engine has its own agenda. You just have to sit there, your foot lightly on the accelerator, feeling your own worth coursing through the leather.

Just about the only indication that you are in motion at all is the fact that the petrol tank sheds a gallon every 21 miles or so. It's not an astoundingly economical choice, the executive SUV, but you would probably have realised that already. And hey, who's paying, anyway?

The lowdown

Lexus RX300 SE

Price: £32,550

Top speed: 112 mph

Acceleration: 0-62 in 9.2 seconds

Consumption: 21.7 mpg

At the wheel: Pierre-Yves Gerbeau

On the stereo: Melody FM

En route for: the Channel tunnel

As befits an attack vehicle, the Jeep is a big bunch of hard lines and does not easily please the eye; while the Discovery is a rural monster, which should be driven only by people with ponies to deliver. On style grounds, the RX300 cleans up. The extent of the illusion within is uncanny. You know you are in an SUV because you have to pull your self up into the seat slightly and because your wing mirrors are the size of portable television screens. Rumour has it that, on a clear day, you can see seven adjoining counties in those wing mirrors. But despite all that, you have, at the wheel, the nearly seamless impression of sitting inside a saloon, albeit a particularly capacious one with flatteringly comfortable seats. (Your passenger is a chaste arm's length away from you, as if in business class. The people in the back? You can forget about them. They're miles behind.) And, just like a top-grade saloon, the RX300 seems determined to eliminate all discomfort caused by that old motoring bugbear - contact with the road. The engine whispers almost inaudibly, somewhere out in the front. In any case, the gearbox is automatic, so the engine has its own agenda. You just have to sit there, your foot lightly on the accelerator, feeling your own worth coursing through the leather. Just about the only indication that you are in motion at all is the fact that the petrol tank sheds a gallon every 21 miles or so. It's not an astoundingly economical choice, the executive SUV, but you would probably have realised that already. And hey, who's paying, anyway? webTitle: Tranmere topple Watford off the top

fields.headline: Tranmere topple Watford off the top
fields.trailText: The Tranmere manager John Aldridge never knowingly overstates. He refused to lavish praise on his side, despite the fact they had played as if they, and not the visitors, were Premiership-bound. Instead he said: "The percentage wasn't good enough and the lads know that."
fields.body:
The Tranmere manager John Aldridge never knowingly overstates. He refused to lavish praise on his side, despite the fact they had played as if they, and not the visitors, were Premiership-bound. Instead he said: "The percentage wasn't good enough and the lads know that."

His lads must be a remarkably philosophical group if they can direct criticism at themselves so soon after sweeping aside a team who, until last week, had displayed an air of invincibility.

Aldridge did offer faint plaudits for Jason Koumas, a 21-year-old midfielder who may well be playing in the Premiership before long.

Koumas's precise play created both goals. He laid on the first with a deadly free-kick to the far post which his industrious captain Sean Flynn headed on for Clint Hill to score after 19 minutes and then, in the second half, outwitted the Hornets' defence to allow Scott Taylor to fire home .

Mark Hughes, an old adversary of Aldridge and the current manager of Wales, made note of Koumas's potential, and more importantly his birthplace, after Tranmere's Worthington Cup win over Leeds last week. Koumas has an English father and Greek ancestry. But he was born in Wrexham and Hughes duly invited him to the Wales training camp in La Manga this week.

Koumas declined. "Wales asked me to join them but England have been in touch as well," he explained. "My nan is from Cyprus so I can also play for them. I am going to talk it over with my family before I decide."

Koumas, perhaps mindful of Ryan Giggs's decision to play for Wales and his subsequent lack of World Cup experience, may have designs on playing on an illustrious world stage. Cyprus would therefore seem the sensible choice.

Graham Taylor, one manager who knows all about missing World Cups, had no excuses for his side's second consecutive defeat. He could not attribute this loss to being played on the wrong day. Nor could he blame the curse of winning October's manager-of-the-month award. He has won one already this season and it did not disturb his side then.

He could, however, reasonably blame his central defender Richard Jobson, a former Hornet who returned to Vicarage Road last week.

Jobson, now 37, was with the club during their glory days of the early 80s but has been far from glorious on his comeback. He has been a noticeable factor in both of the club's recent losses. He scored an own goal against Sheffield Wednesday and was then totally out-paced by Tranmere's livewire attack, spearheaded by the highly physical Wayne Allison at centre forward.

Jobson's deficiencies meant extra work for Robert Page, the captain, who partnered him in central defence. Page also offered Watford their best scoring chances as he hit the woodwork twice in the second half.

Tranmere, though, deserved their victory. Although it might pain Aldridge to agree.

webTitle: Saha improvises to keep Fulham fluent

fields.headline: Saha improvises to keep Fulham fluent
fields.trailText: Jean Tigana, as both player and manager, could have taught John Coltrane a thing or two about improvisation. But even he surpassed himself when the Fulham bus got becalmed in traffic and he ordered his players to do their pre-match warm-up by jogging two miles to the stadium.
fields.body:
Jean Tigana, as both player and manager, could have taught John Coltrane a thing or two about improvisation. But even he surpassed himself when the Fulham bus got becalmed in traffic and he ordered his players to do their pre-match warm-up by jogging two miles to the stadium.

Fulham carried their unpredictability on to the pitch and it was all too much for this featureless Wimbledon side to handle. On a filthy afternoon in south London they gradually capitulated, Fulham retaking their rightful place at the top of the table.

"I watched them four times before this game and a lot of good it did me," said the Wimbledon manager Terry Burton. "They've got lots of options and they can hit you from all sides."

Fulham simply proved that they are the best side outside the top flight and probably better than a third of those in it. It was not just their skill and fluidity that caused the opposition problems on Saturday but their willingness to stand up to Wimbledon aggression and keep coming back for more. "Everyone talks about their passing ability but they are the hardest-working team in this league," said Burton.

Also the most inspirational, their improviser-in-chief was Louis Saha, the young Frenchman who is currently setting the First Division alight. He continued to build on a jaw-dropping start to his Fulham career by scoring twice to take his tally to 17 this season. "My ambition is to do well in the Premier League with Fulham next season," he said.

It is a remarkable record considering that there seemed little to suggest, before Tigana made him his first signing this summer at £2.1m from Metz, that he was capable of such a sudden impact. Although he played for the French Under-18s he appears to have scored only four times for Metz and a loan spell at Newcastle in January 1999 proved frustrating. He made 11 appearances for the club, five as substitute, producing two goals and a fractured cheekbone that interrupted his progress.

"He's got unbelievable pace and a great touch and if teams are playing tight and pushing up we can just get the ball over the top and he's on to it in a flash. The only problem is we can't keep up with him," said Fulham's midfielder Lee Clark.

Tigana has compared the 22-year-old to Thierry Henry and the comparison is apt. Both are lithe, brave, lightning fast and ruthless. If anything, Saha is the more two-footed as he showed with his goals.

The first came out of nothing, a sudden turn into space outside the box and an explosive right-foot shot. The second was a penalty after Alan Kimble had felled Luis Boa Morte, confidently dispatched left-footed. Barry Hayles rounded off an impressive team effort with a tap-in but the day belonged to Saha.

webTitle: Moravcik adds a touch of artistry to Celtic industry

fields.headline: Moravcik adds a touch of artistry to Celtic industry
fields.trailText: Celtic Park is becoming a shrine to pragmatism. This might offend those steeped in a club tradition that has often been more about style than success, but as the Scottish Premier League points pile up which dissenter will quibble? Martin O'Neill's side are now five points clear.
fields.body:
Celtic Park is becoming a shrine to pragmatism. This might offend those steeped in a club tradition that has often been more about style than success, but as the Scottish Premier League points pile up which dissenter will quibble? Martin O'Neill's side are now five points clear.

Pragmatism, that is, except for one gorgeous moment in the 37th minute. In Lubomir Moravcik it has long been known that Celtic possess one of Europe's special talents; the only problem, as O'Neill has often griped, is that he lay hidden for so long in the eastern bloc and is now 35 years old.

Moravcik, though, is full of feints, flicks and dribbles, a man who can wallop free-kicks to all heights and angles, and swing in venomous corners with either foot. Yesterday, receiving Didier Agathe's short corner six yards from the touchline, he tried something different: a left-foot shot which sped past St Johnstone's Alan Main into the net. The goal will live long in Celtic's folklore.

O'Neill, meanwhile, is in danger of breaking a record that was set in the great war. With 13 wins and two draws, Celtic have now passed their previous unbeaten Premier League start, in 1984, and have also matched the run of 15 unbeaten games set under Jock Stein at the start of the 1966-67 season. The Celtic record stretches back to 1917 when the team went 36 games unbeaten.

Poor St Johnstone actually prodded the ball around crisply and with purpose, but once Chris Sutton had cracked in Celtic's opener after 12 minutes the visitors were on a hiding. Sutton, beginning to look slightly shambling, as in his sabbatical year at Chelsea, nonetheless clouted his shot into the top corner.

Aside from Sutton and Moravcik, only Henrik Larsson, as ever, managed to attract any attention. In the first half he ran through to meet Moravcik's pass and shoot past Main, and in the 59th minute he dispatched one of his exquisite chips, drawing the goalkeeper before wedging the ball up and beyond his flapping arms. When Larsson is behaving like this you know Celtic are showboating.

Rab Douglas, bought from Dundee and in Celtic's goal in place of Jonathan Gould, allowed a consolation effort from Craig Russell past him with nine minutes remaining.

 Aberdeen gifted visiting Rangers three points last night when Thomas Solberg was dispossed by Ronald de Boer, who duly squared for Michael Mols to score. Arild Stavrum had given the Dons an early lead but Kenny Miller equalised before half-time.

webTitle: Lester hat-trick fuels the Forest fire

fields.headline: Lester hat-trick fuels the Forest fire
fields.trailText: The last manager of Gillingham has gone on to take charge of England within five months of leaving Priestfield. The way things are going, with his team struggling for form, Andy Hessenthaler would be silly to expect such a startling career progression.
fields.body:
The last manager of Gillingham has gone on to take charge of England within five months of leaving Priestfield. The way things are going, with his team struggling for form, Andy Hessenthaler would be silly to expect such a startling career progression.

Yesterday Hessenthaler's men were forced to give best to a Nottingham Forest side taking their inspiration from Jack Lester, who scored a hat-trick, and a manager who, having been burdened initially by the expectation that he was an England coach in waiting, is quietly turning them into a serious force again.

There was a period after Gillingham equalised Lester's opening goal when David Platt's team had no answer to quick, accurate passing which produced a stream of crosses from either flank, all destined for Iffy Onuora's head.

Then, just as Gillingham were preparing for a half-time team talk resonant with optimism, up popped Lester with his second goal after Ben Olsen and Robbie Blake had combined down the right. It was as unexpected as Peter Taylor's squad selection and his old team could not find an effective second-half response.

"Forest are a very good team and we found it hard to break them down," Hessenthaler admitted. "When it was 1-1 we looked the only side likely to score. After that we were probably guilty of trying too hard."

Gillingham's desperation led to more Forest opportunities. Although Lester took the honours there was no more influential player than Andy Johnson, whose economical distribution fashioned many openings. His toil deserved goal but Nicky Southall cleared his header off the line.

Gary Jones set up Lester for his hat-trick strike as Gillingham roared their offside appeals. After that, from Johnson's superb ball, Lester drew a fine save from Vince Bartram, then screwed a chance wide of the post.

Platt said of Lester, his £350,000 signing from Grimsby. "I did not realise he was such a good finisher but two weeks on the training ground put me straight."

Lester's opener particularly bore the hallmarks of a natural finisher, climaxing a move begun by Johnson with a smart drive angled away from the goalkeeper.

That swift counter-attack was typical of Forest, who now boast six away wins. When Alan Rogers was carried off with a knee injury early on some of their threat might have disappeared but the American substitute Olsen worked the right flank industriously.

Gillingham had taken only 10 minutes to cancel out Lester's first, Onuora climbing to meet Ty Gooden's cross.

webTitle: Global internet summit flops

fields.headline: Global internet summit flops
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The world's first global internet summit has been cancelled because of lack of interest. The three day World Internet Forum, due to begin today in London, was unable to attract enough people willing to turn up in person.
fields.body:
The world's first global internet summit has been cancelled because of lack of interest. The three day World Internet Forum, due to begin today in London, was unable to attract enough people willing to turn up in person.

Speakers from governments and businesses around the world have been told they are no longer needed.

Among them were Chris Smith, the culture secretary, and Patricia Hewitt, the minister for e-commerce.

The conference, at the Hilton Metropole hotel in central London, was to have become an annual event, but organisers are now reconsidering.

Robert Blaney, chief executive officer of the forum, said: "It would be both unfair and unsatisfactory to both sponsors and speakers to continue with an audience that is anything other than of the highest quality and sufficient numbers. In the absence of this audience, we regretfully have no alternative but to cancel the forum in London.

"While this decision is very late we have given as much time as possible and applied every effort to rectify the position, but sadly to no avail."

Future summits are expected to go ahead, with representatives from global corporations and ministers from as far afield as Norway and Bermuda discussing the role of government in the internet, the future of online business and its implications for society.

webTitle: Cottee fears going downhill from Underhill overkill

fields.headline: Cottee fears going downhill from Underhill overkill
fields.trailText: Tony Cottee had managed a hat-trick, a missed penalty and a sending-off on previous debuts but even by those standards this one was remarkable. He started the afternoon by scoring and ended it celebrating Barnet's record League win. The player-manager must feel his job is a walk in the park.
fields.body:
Tony Cottee had managed a hat-trick, a missed penalty and a sending-off on previous debuts but even by those standards this one was remarkable. He started the afternoon by scoring and ended it celebrating Barnet's record League win. The player-manager must feel his job is a walk in the park.

Then again, if anyone has reason to worry about a 7-0 victory it is Cottee. He marked his arrival at Everton in 1988 as Britain's record signing by scoring three times but ended up facing his local window cleaner in an A-team match at Morecambe and returned cheaply to West Ham.

"I scored after 34 seconds for Everton, got a hat-trick and we won 4-0," he said. "And where could I go from there? Every game was an anti-climax. I'm not going to say I'm disappointed we won 7-0 but it does put a bit of pressure on because people expect that every week."

Barnet fans would doubtless settle for five and in any case Cottee seems a quick learner. His first game was a 0-0 draw at high-flying Rochdale, where he stayed in the dug-out. At 35 he is being guided by John Still, who switched from manager to director of football when Cottee arrived from Norwich.

"On my first day I went to the training ground and when I started speaking to the professionals I said: 'I've played at Old Trafford and Anfield but I'm more nervous than I ever was there.' The first time I came into the office I sat down and thought: 'What do I do?' The phone rang and John said: 'You can pick it up, you know'."

Barnet, of course, are very different from what Cottee is used to. David Ginola's 11-year-old son may attend the club's soccer school but some of the squad earn around £100 a week and Cottee accepted a pay cut to take the "wonderful" player-manager post he has been readying himself for for two years.

"The things that would have shocked me I was prepared for by my venture to Malaysia," he said. "At Barnet we also don't have anyone to clean our boots - although they might sort me out because I'm the manager - and you take your kit home. My wife is washing mine like she did in Malaysia."

The training facilities, he stresses, are tremendous, even if "having a dog turd on the pitch is not quite what I'm used to". And his stylish approach was obvious as Barnet climbed to eighth, helped by inept Blackpool defending.

Cottee, who departed after an hour, showed why he plans to play for the 2 years of his contract by running through to clip in the first. His strike partner Tony Richards scored two and the impressive Darren Currie got a hat-trick with Mark Arber heading No6.

webTitle: Britain doubles Sierra Leone force

fields.headline: Britain doubles Sierra Leone force
fields.trailText: A Royal Navy taskforce with 500 troops arrived off the Sierra Leone coast yesterday as doubts deepened about the commitment of rebels to a ceasefire signed two days earlier.
fields.body:
A Royal Navy taskforce with 500 troops arrived off the Sierra Leone coast yesterday as doubts deepened about the commitment of rebels to a ceasefire signed two days earlier.

The Royal Marines on board HMS Ocean will nearly double the size of British forces in Sierra Leone in what Britain describes as a "show of strength" and commitment. But the government also stresses that the troops will back up UN peacekeepers rather than take on an offensive combat role.

The rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF) called the British soldiers mercenaries and said their presence could threaten the ceasefire. But others see the real threat to the truce as the rebels themselves.

The key test of the RUF's commitment to the ceasefire is straightforward enough. If it gives up control of the diamond fields that have fuelled its brutal nine-year war, the end of the conflict could well be within grasp.

But the timing of the deal - as the British troops arrived ahead of an expected offensive by the Sierra Leone army on diamond areas - raises suspicions that the rebels are again buying time by manipulating a desperate desire for peace.

The optimists note that the RUF now stands little hope of winning outright; its founding leader, Foday Sankoh, has been captured and the rebels' principal backer, the Liberian president, Charles Taylor, is under growing foreign pressure to end the conflict.

And then there is the British presence. Royal Marines are expected to stage an amphibious landing on the beaches of the capital, Freetown, this week, knowing full well that there are plenty of people to report back to the RUF on a revived British commitment.

But sceptics note that the delegation that signed the ceasefire may not represent those who control rebel troops, that the RUF still controls the bulk of the country, and that Mr Taylor has many good financial reasons to keep the war going.

The Sierra Leone government is cautious. It welcomed Friday's ceasefire agreement and the rebels' pledge to demobilise but said that it "wishes to assure the public that as a result of past experience, it has no intention of relaxing its stance".

Sierra Leone has travelled this path before. The Lome peace treaty signed in July 1999 gave the RUF seats in government and a general amnesty for the many atrocities in return for the dismantling of its army. But Mr Sankoh wanted total power and used the peace deal as cover while he planned to seize Freetown - until the intervention of 1,000 British troops in May put the rebels on the defensive.

The latest accord keeps open the possibility that the Lome agreement could be revived and the RUF returned to a powersharing government. But there are many issues to be resolved, including the fate of Mr Sankoh, who faces the prospect of trial before an international court for crimes against humanity.

And there are doubts as to what extent the rebels' representative at the latest peace talks, Colonel Jonathan Kposowa, speaks for the fractured RUF leadership.

If the diamond fields were the key test, then Col Kposowa was keen to lower expectations. After describing the agreement as a "stepping stone" and saying it was no guarantee the war is over, he brushed aside the issue of the diamond mines.

"Instead of finding solutions to the problem, they are telling us about diamond, diamond, diamond. I don't think that's the problem," he said.

The rebels have reason to stall. With the rainy season ending, the Sierra Leone army, under British direction and training, is planning a new offensive. It is still far from being a real army but troop numbers have grown and it is being re-equipped with British guns, lorries, radios and uniforms.

Brigadier David Richards, the officer who oversaw the British intervention in May and saw his arguments for an even stronger involvement thwarted by the Foreign Office, has returned to Freetown to coordinate the Sierra Leone army's offensive.

The redeployment of a large British force in Freetown is a recognition that Brig Richard's original strategy against the RUF failed. In May, he laid out a plan to use the Sierra Leone army to attack rebel strongholds, and UN peacekeepers to hold the captured territory as government forces advanced on the diamond fields.

But, although the UN force in Sierra Leone is the largest peacekeeping operation in the world with 13,000 troops, it proved incapable even of playing a reliable backup role. Disagreement between the UN force's Indian commander and senior Nigerian colleagues has ended with the withdrawal of the entire Indian contingent from the operation.

A British brigadier is expected to join the UN command in Freetown this week in an attempt to coordinate the peacekeepers and the government army.

Although Whitehall has said that British troops are in Freetown merely as a "show of strength", it could be that new arrivals will plug a vital gap by providing the logistics, air power and occasional firepower so badly needed if there is to be any prospect of forcing the rebels to give up.

webTitle: Tessem loses way after Beattie's long-range magic

fields.headline: Tessem loses way after Beattie's long-range magic
fields.trailText: After a pulsating contest sparked by a stupendous long-range strike, with two rip-roaring comebacks and a pair of misses that would have had a pub-team regular cringing, just about everyone left Wearside cursing.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
After a pulsating contest sparked by a stupendous long-range strike, with two rip-roaring comebacks and a pair of misses that would have had a pub-team regular cringing, just about everyone left Wearside cursing.

The talk among the departing Saints fans should have been about James Beattie's 40-yard half-volley which swerved and soared into the net via Thomas Sorensen's fingertips, but it was Jo Tessem who found himself the centre of attention. "I've got no words to express that chance at the end," said Southampton's manager Glenn Hoddle. "You simply can't miss like that in the Premiership."

Indeed, Tessem's last-minute profligacy defied belief. With parity restored after Dean Richards headed Hassan Kachloul's corner through a crowded goalmouth, Chris Marsden hoofed the ball upfield towards Beattie. The striker leapt to challenge Michael Gray, an aerial mismatch, and nodded the ball to Tessem, who advanced into the area unopposed.

The aghast Sorensen was rooted to his line, the match flashing before his eyes. But his Norwegian opponent, standing virtually on the penalty spot and with his composure gone, speared his shot past the post.

"Jo would usually bury that," said Beattie. "But he had a really good game so we forgave him."

Beattie's 12th-minute opener was the highlight of a wonderfully entertaining afternoon. The 22-year-old almost joined Crystal Palace for £2.75m last month even though Simon Jordan, the First Division club's chairman, said: "Even his mother knows he's not worth that." Then came two goals to beat Chelsea, plus Saturday's stupendous strike; Mrs Beattie always said her son was priceless.

Beattie's blast should have been forgotten under a deluge of home pressure before half-time. Niall Quinn hauled Sunderland level and the Wearsiders put on what their manager Peter Reid described as "our best attacking display of the season".

But chance after chance was passed up. Kevin Phillips saw his header saved by Paul Jones and, when the goalkeeper parried a second effort from the England striker, Don Hutchison missed from a yard out.

Southampton were more threatening after half-time and felt hard done by when Hutchison recovered to batter Sunderland into the lead with 10 minutes remaining, his shot taking a hefty deflection. But, after Richards secured a deserved point, the home partisans stomped angrily away.

"You can understand the fans' reaction because it was game, set and match at 2-1," said Gray. "But there were silly mistakes being made all over the field." Thankfully for him, not all were from Sunderland.

webTitle: Sugar takes sideswipe at new saviour Sullivan

fields.headline: Sugar takes sideswipe at new saviour Sullivan
fields.trailText: Tottenham suffered a slow, long death in the afternoon. And there is little hope of immediate resurrection under a new saviour, according to Alan Sugar.
fields.body:
Tottenham suffered a slow, long death in the afternoon. And there is little hope of immediate resurrection under a new saviour, according to Alan Sugar.

There is no "short-term fix", intones George Graham, and his equally criticised chairman echoed the words yesterday in dealing brusquely with the multimillionaire David Sullivan's interest in a stake in Tottenham as a stepping stone to taking over at White Hart Lane.

Sullivan, who currently cannot buy more than a 9.9% share in Spurs because of his Birmingham City interests, would not get Tottenham "on the cheap", insisted Sugar, who told his would-be successor that if he wants to invest serious money then he would have to "stump up the £70m some say we need to build up a championship-winning side".

Spurs' share price is 60p but Sugar also told Sullivan to "forget about basement prices and tune into the true value of about 140p a share".

Meanwhile the supporters' emotional investment in Spurs is being exhausted. In the Bull Ring city, George Graham and his team were goaded almost beyond endurance by an Aston Villa who had clearly been practising their moves for this performance. It was a wonder that chants of ole did not accompany every flourish.

Villa's fans gleefully chorused "George Graham is an Arsenal fan", something that Tottenham supporters already knew. It is more disturbing for them to learn that this seasoned, knowing manager cannot explain their dismal away form. "It would be easy to sort it out if I knew," Graham admitted.

"You're Spurs - and you know you are," sang their fans lustily of David Ginola after a long period of silent lament at the 11 still wearing the white shirt. Ginola closed his 13-minute cameo with arm aloft to the away section before disappearing down the tunnel. With that signal, the light must have gone out of many Tottenham lives.

Villa are good and getting better by the game. Yet their fans are not entirely happy, brandishing large cards embossed with the "£" sign as the teams emerged. The message to Doug Ellis is to reopen the cheque-book for a new striker.

Gregory playfully approved of the protest. "We need one or two others to take us on. I'm not complaining but we are by no means paupers." With a new striker, Gregory's target of a top-three place would surely become more expectation than hope.

Gregory has a genuine team in which weaknesses are covered willingly. Currently the strikers Dion Dublin and Julian Joachim do not score, so the midfielders pitch in. Ian Taylor compensated beautifully here with two goals matching the high precision of the side. A clever header from Alan Wright's cross and a calm shot after a Dublin backheel were the minimum Taylor and his colleagues deserved.
