webTitle: Too clever for his own good?

fields.headline: Too clever for his own good?
fields.standfirst: Under David Yelland, the Sun has wised up but lost readers. However, says Roy Greenslade, if the red-top thinks it can turn to the chattering classes for extra circulation it is mistaken
fields.trailText: Under David Yelland, the Sun has wised up but lost readers. However, if the red-top thinks it can turn to the chattering classes for extra circulation it is mistaken.
fields.body:
In a London club, which must remain nameless because of the rules, you understand, a gentleman who once worked in the higher echelons of the Daily Mirror, as it was then called, was asked what he thought of the Sun at present. Unhesitatingly, he replied: "I think it's becoming a serious political paper. Very good, very good."

A neighbour, a distinguished former executive at a serious broadsheet newspaper, nodded in agreement. "Don't see it much," he said. "But people show it to me. Yes, better, I think. More serious, yes."

If Sun editor David Yelland had been there he would have preened himself at burgeoning credibility for his paper among the chattering class. Indeed, he may be smiling as he reads this. There is little doubt that Yelland has devoted more space to politics than his predecessor, Stuart Higgins, with splashes, full-page leading articles, and all manner of spreads.

This is no accident, because he has made it clear in the past that he wants the Sun to be at the heart of Britain's political discourse. He has also chosen to do so in a traditional Sun way. Hence "the most dangerous man in Britain" tag applied to Tony Blair, and the plastering of William Hague's head on to a parrot, first deceased and then resurrected.

Political editor Trevor Kavanagh is given plenty of chances to air his views. Hardly a day passes without a leader disparaging the idea of the European single currency.

Yelland's current agenda reminds me of the Sun during Larry Lamb's final years as editor. Previously, he had managed to maintain a delicate balance between serious and trivial editorial content. Then, after his knighthood and drawn closer still to Westminster and Whitehall through his friendship with Margaret Thatcher, he overdid the politics.

It wasn't that his political diatribes were out of step with the majority viewpoint of his audience. What clearly upset readers was not only the fact that politics dominated the paper, but that it was too hectoring, too lacking in subtlety, too unappetising for palates used to a less meaty diet. The result? Readers began to drift away. Lamb's Sun plunged from almost 4m at the end of 1978 to 3.6m at the beginning of 1981. And the main beneficiary? Not the Daily Mirror, which continued its downward drift, but none other than the Daily Star, launched in November 1978 and selling more than 1.5m by the middle of 1981.

Yelland might well consider this history lesson as he studies the latest sales figures in the table on the right. The Sun fell below 3.6m in October.

Yet its deserters do not appear to be climbing aboard the Mirror ship which is finding it tougher still to hang on to circulation, and is some 2.5% down on last year. Instead, the red-top that is bucking the trend by adding sales is the Daily Star: up last month by almost 6% over October last year and almost 3% up on its six-monthly average too.

Of course, the overall numbers are small, and the continuing contribution of its Dublin-based Irish edition remains crucial. But it's not too improbable to surmise that some Sun readers are turning to the Star in its less strident, less fleshy guise under editor Peter Hill and his deputy, Hugh Whittow.

With Express Newspapers up for sale (and please, Clive Hollick, don't give us that claptrap about it not being so) the Star's modest, but significant, turn-around in fortunes couldn't be better timed. With the Sun selling virtually 3m more than the Star, Yelland and his boss, Rupert Murdoch, are hardly going to panic. On the other hand, they might just wonder if the paper is now unbalanced.

The Sun's dilemma, trying to "wise up" its material without alienating its core audience, raises a wider point about the famed "dumbing down" debate which rages persistently around the broadsheets. The Guardian's editor, Alan Rusbridger, last week countered the widely-held notion that the serious press is just not serious enough any longer.

Implicit in his article, which points out the need to appeal to a wider audience, is the insistence that broadsheets are the natural inheritors of the future newspaper-reading audience.

This isn't entirely true, of course. The Daily Mail has shown that it is possible to use the tabloid format without adopting a red-top agenda. Indeed, its creators - Vere Rothermere and David English - always maintained that their aim in transforming the broadsheet Mail into a tabloid was to synthesise the two. The fact that their experiment took more than 20 years, and the editorship of Paul Dacre, to become successful, shows how difficult a task it was.

It also illustrates how improbable it is for red-tops, trapped by the majority of their declining readership into supplying tits and trivia , to effect change. They cannot broaden their agenda in the way that broadsheets have done to satisfy people who now have a greater range of interests than ever before. This isn't about dumbing down. It is a concrete recognition of a cultural change.

Hang on, Yelland might well say. Look at the figures. The Guardian isn't taking away our readers. The Times is drifting downwards. The Daily Telegraph struggles to keep its sale over 1m. The Independent is relying on bulks and printing abroad to give its circulation a gloss.

But this is a snapshot view, a superficial argument that overlooks the long-term trend. In general, the British population is becoming more middle class, enjoying better educational standards, social conditions and economic benefits.

Though broadsheets are finding the market difficult at present, using similar devices to boost sales as the red-tops, these are the papers gearing themselves more obviously to a changed audience. Their larger, more diverse, packages are more appealing both to readers and advertisers.

If we turn to the Sundays, there is clearer proof of this trend. The red-tops are losing sales by the month and the Sunday Express is, to be frank, at crisis point. Only the broadsheets and the Mail on Sunday offer any sign of stability, with the Sunday Times at 1.4m and the Observer enjoying a renaissance. The Sunday Telegraph is finding life more difficult and the Independent on Sunday is also treading water.

But these titles offer better value for money than their rivals, provide better quality, and unashamedly plug celebrity interviews alongside intelligent analyses of the American presidential election. In the end, I am sure that class will count. Are you still smiling, Mr Yelland?

Yet its deserters do not appear to be climbing aboard the Mirror ship which is finding it tougher still to hang on to circulation, and is some 2.5% down on last year. Instead, the red-top that is bucking the trend by adding sales is the Daily Star: up last month by almost 6% over October last year and almost 3% up on its six-monthly average too. Of course, the overall numbers are small, and the continuing contribution of its Dublin-based Irish edition remains crucial. But it's not too improbable to surmise that some Sun readers are turning to the Star in its less strident, less fleshy guise under editor Peter Hill and his deputy, Hugh Whittow. With Express Newspapers up for sale (and please, Clive Hollick, don't give us that claptrap about it not being so) the Star's modest, but significant, turn-around in fortunes couldn't be better timed. With the Sun selling virtually 3m more than the Star, Yelland and his boss, Rupert Murdoch, are hardly going to panic. On the other hand, they might just wonder if the paper is now unbalanced. The Sun's dilemma, trying to "wise up" its material without alienating its core audience, raises a wider point about the famed "dumbing down" debate which rages persistently around the broadsheets. The Guardian's editor, Alan Rusbridger, last week countered the widely-held notion that the serious press is just not serious enough any longer. Implicit in his article, which points out the need to appeal to a wider audience, is the insistence that broadsheets are the natural inheritors of the future newspaper-reading audience. This isn't entirely true, of course. The Daily Mail has shown that it is possible to use the tabloid format without adopting a red-top agenda. Indeed, its creators - Vere Rothermere and David English - always maintained that their aim in transforming the broadsheet Mail into a tabloid was to synthesise the two. The fact that their experiment took more than 20 years, and the editorship of Paul Dacre, to become successful, shows how difficult a task it was. It also illustrates how improbable it is for red-tops, trapped by the majority of their declining readership into supplying tits and trivia , to effect change. They cannot broaden their agenda in the way that broadsheets have done to satisfy people who now have a greater range of interests than ever before. This isn't about dumbing down. It is a concrete recognition of a cultural change. Hang on, Yelland might well say. Look at the figures. The Guardian isn't taking away our readers. The Times is drifting downwards. The Daily Telegraph struggles to keep its sale over 1m. The Independent is relying on bulks and printing abroad to give its circulation a gloss. But this is a snapshot view, a superficial argument that overlooks the long-term trend. In general, the British population is becoming more middle class, enjoying better educational standards, social conditions and economic benefits. Though broadsheets are finding the market difficult at present, using similar devices to boost sales as the red-tops, these are the papers gearing themselves more obviously to a changed audience. Their larger, more diverse, packages are more appealing both to readers and advertisers. If we turn to the Sundays, there is clearer proof of this trend. The red-tops are losing sales by the month and the Sunday Express is, to be frank, at crisis point. Only the broadsheets and the Mail on Sunday offer any sign of stability, with the Sunday Times at 1.4m and the Observer enjoying a renaissance. The Sunday Telegraph is finding life more difficult and the Independent on Sunday is also treading water. But these titles offer better value for money than their rivals, provide better quality, and unashamedly plug celebrity interviews alongside intelligent analyses of the American presidential election. In the end, I am sure that class will count. Are you still smiling, Mr Yelland? webTitle: The networks giveth and the networks taketh away

fields.headline: The networks giveth and the networks taketh away
fields.standfirst:
Joe McGinniss, writer of the definitive book on the 1968 US presidential campaign, says last week's shambles was inevitable

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Joe McGinniss, writer of the definitive book on the 1968 US presidential campaign, says last week's shambles was inevitable.
fields.body:
ABC was first with the report, describing the news as "extraordinary". On CBS, the announcer muttered, "Good heavens!" Gathered before their sets in ritualistic fashion, millions of Americans were equally taken aback. They'd learned from experience to expect drama, tension and surprise on these nights, but this was startling news indeed. And, certainly, none of the polls had predicted it.

Within the hour, the Associated Press informed its members that the report had been erroneous, but the damage was done. America had been misled by the one medium it had learned to trust. It was sobering indeed to consider that, as Dorothy Thompson wrote in the New York Tribune: "A few effective voices . . . can convince masses of people of a totally unreasonable, completely fantastic proposition."

Was this the report that Al Gore had captured the state of Florida? Or was it the later bulletin to the effect that George Bush, and not Gore, had won Florida, and, hence, the presidency? In fact, it was neither. The above reactions occurred in the autumn of 1938, when Orson Welles mischievously chose to heighten the dramatic effect of his American radio presentation of War of the Worlds by making it seem that a Martian spacecraft had landed in a small New Jersey town.

Ah, what a simple, guileless people we must have been. How often, and with what condescension did later generations of journalists look back and laugh at Welles's spoof, scoffing at the widespread panic it caused.

That had been, of course, before the dawn of the Information Age, and at a time when not even a Wellesian imagination could have conjured anything resembling the internet.

You might think, nonetheless, that as Americans, we'd take a dose of scepticism with our scoops. After all, we've learned to mistrust. The school of hard knocks to the heart that opened in the 1960s taught us that nothing was as it seemed; that glittering image more often than not was merely a mask for sordid reality.

Many of the most affecting images carried into our homes, hearts and minds by TV were every bit as spurious as Orson Welles's "Martians". The Camelot so carefully crafted for television by Kennedy courtiers turned out to be pasteboard facade; our government used television to repeatedly lie to us about every aspect of the Vietnam war; and, despite millions of dollars spent on commercials designed to persuade us of the opposite, we discovered that cigarettes did cause cancer, alcohol did destroy lives, automobiles were not inherently safe, and - most of all - politicians were not to be trusted.

From my own first book, The Selling of the President, 1968, I carried forward as a mantra the dictum of the adviser to Richard Nixon that, "it's not what's there that counts; it's what's projected". He meant, of course, projected by and through television.

"The medium is the message," Marshall McLuhan wrote in those same long-ago 60s, but what he intended as a warning to the masses became instead a guiding light for the politically savvy and media elite, who understood instinctively the potential for distortion and deception it implied.

One is tempted, therefore, to see it as progress when, after decades during which politicians spent near-infinite amounts of time and money using television to deceive the people, at long last - and however inadvertently - came television's turn to trick the tricksters.

"If we say somebody carried a state, you can take that to the bank," Dan Rather proclaimed on CBS, only moments before he said: "Al Gore has won the state of Florida." An hour later, however - withdrawing our deposit and hiding it under the mattress, as it were - Rather said Florida was "too close to call". But not for long: the networks thrive by purporting to be voices of authority and uncertainty is not a welcome guest behind their walls. In less time than it would have taken a Martian to propel himself from Grovers Mill, New Jersey to New York City, Rather's CBS and the other four networks announced that it had not been Gore, as they'd earlier said, but instead George Bush who'd taken Florida.

And with that wee-hours announcement, champagne corks popped, skyrockets soared, and strangers kissed strangers (of the opposite sex, it must be stressed) all over Austin.

The ever-effusive Rather confusingly exhorted viewers to, "Sip it, savour it, photostat it, hang it out on a wall: George Bush is the next president of the United States!"

Hearing that, candidate Gore called candidate Bush to concede. After all, if they'd seen it on television (and did not recognise it as one of their own manipulations), it must be true.

But then NBC's Tom Brokaw intoned without a shred of irony, "What the networks giveth, the networks taketh away," and, quick as a wink, both Florida's electoral votes and Bush's putative presidency vanished into a murky Everglades swamp, the bottom of which we've apparently not yet seen.

Still, as Americans, we rest easy. Let others fret about messy, confusing reality. We can just go on living in the simple two-dimensional world our television networks have constructed for us, in order to assure that none of us is ever tempted to have an original thought.

webTitle: Panic in the City as capital fears reappear

fields.headline: Panic in the City as capital fears reappear
fields.trailText: City's socks were the same fluorescent yellow used for the coats of matchday stewards. In a way, then, it was fitting that as trouble broke out all around them City's players stood there doing nothing. "It's hard to understand," said Joe Royle after watching a 1-0 half-time lead turn into a 4-1 defeat.
fields.body:
City's socks were the same fluorescent yellow used for the coats of matchday stewards. In a way, then, it was fitting that as trouble broke out all around them City's players stood there doing nothing. "It's hard to understand," said Joe Royle after watching a 1-0 half-time lead turn into a 4-1 defeat.

It was easy to understand, really. West Ham finally clicked, as their manager had been predicting all season. And City did not know how to cope.

If Royle's players perform like that next Saturday it will be even more embarrassing. A game with Manchester United is not the time to be as limp as lettuce in a prawn sandwich.

Saturday's game began so promisingly for City. Their neat-passing football left West Ham looking every bit like a side struggling in the wrong half of the table. Ian Wright's adopted teenage son Sean Wright-Phillips, making his full Premiership debut, tormented his dad's old team with his pace and trickery on the right, Alfie Haaland never stopped running and City appeared more than capable of getting a result.

On 32 minutes, they took the lead. Wright-Phillips again roasted Stuart Pearce and forced Shaka Hislop into a diving save. From the corner Spencer Prior rose high above a statuesque defence to head home.

Soon Stuart Pearce cleared off the line from Haaland and three points appeared to be heading north, to the credit of a City team forced to play Paulo Wanchope as a lone striker. The Costa Rican, returning here for the first time since joining City, was booed throughout.

But West Ham emerged a different team after half-time. They worked hard in midfield and shrugged off the absence of the injured Joe Cole to take a grip. They could have scored six.

This time Paolo di Canio was not the catalyst. He had hit the bar with a typically audacious chip in the opening minutes but then suffered an attack of what the Italians call "dribblomania" - taking on one man too many . Instead it was Frédéric Kanouté and Trevor Sinclair who took centre stage. Soon after the restart the former picked up the latter's clever pass and crossed for Steve Lomas to sweep home.

City's defence, now panicking, conceded another goal five minutes later, Michael Carrick crossing for Sinclair to convert by the far post.

Kanouté's run and cross led to the third goal, Ian Pearce celebrating his recent return with a header past the keeper.

Kanouté wasted three chances but finally the Frenchman did earn his side a fourth goal when Richard Dunne pulled his shirt and Di Canio converted the penalty with a cheeky chip over Nicky Weaver.

It was the 13th goal conceded by City in London this season, though Royle's thoughts seem to be on the other end of the pitch after reports linking him with Bordeaux's £3.5m-rated World Cup-winning striker Christophe Dugarry.

webTitle: Johnson shows England the right stuff

fields.headline: Johnson shows England the right stuff
fields.trailText: Seth Johnson may not be everyone's idea of England's future but the 21-year-old Derby player, deployed here as a left wing-back, gave an admirably disciplined defensive performance against one of the most talented forward lines in Europe.
fields.body:
Seth Johnson may not be everyone's idea of England's future but the 21-year-old Derby player, deployed here as a left wing-back, gave an admirably disciplined defensive performance against one of the most talented forward lines in Europe.

By the end, with Arsenal still desperately battering on the Derby door, Arsène Wenger employed four strikers but not even the full multinational force of Dennis Bergkamp, Sylvain Wiltord, Nwankwo Kanu and Thierry Henry could find a way through.

Even when they threatened to do so, Johnson was on hand, notably with a superb match-saving tackle on Henry that was timed to perfection just as the Frenchman was about to atone for an uncharacteristic miss earlier in the second half.

That tackle alone confirmed why Peter Taylor had, many said surprisingly, selected Johnson for the England squad to face Italy in Turin on Wednesday.

Even the former Crewe player admitted he was shocked when news of his elevation to the senior squad was broken.

"The England call up was a complete surprise. I wasn't expecting anything," Johnson revealed.

"I had heard rumours that I might be in the squad but there was no way I was convinced. I have to admit that I don't think I've been playing particularly well this season.

"But the call-up gave me a lot of confidence for the Arsenal game. I had been built up a bit in the papers and so I had to justify that, but the result was more important than my call-up.

"I've taken a lot of stick off the lads in the dressing-room. I couldn't afford a bad game today, otherwise the lads would have called me an England flop."

There can be no danger that Johnson was called anything other than a hero after his performance at Highbury, although Jim Smith can be proud of all his players.

Predictably, Arsenal had the majority of possession and dominated territorially, but Derby were resolute in their determination to put 11 players behind the ball as quickly as possible and shut down space around their goal.

The plan worked to perfection and the visitors can be very disappointed they did not actually win the game, having created the best chances themselves on the counter-attack.

Rory Delap hit the bar from only six yards and had a header cleared off the line by Martin Keown, then the lone striker Malcolm Christie failed to hit the target from the edge of the area with just the goalkeeper John Lukic to beat and Delap volleyed wide from another breakaway.

Keown conceded: "Derby soaked up the pressure and were dangerous on the break, so all credit to them."

Defending Arsenal's listlessness, Keown added that Derby "didn't go all the way to Ukraine for half a week before the game".

"Going that far takes it out of you and leaves you exhausted, while Derby were able to prepare and focus on this game.

"We should still have had enough to win the match and if we'd have scored the all-important early goal it would have been a very different match, because they wouldn't have been able to sit back and play the way they did."

Arsenal failed to score early, though, and Johnson can travel to Italy full of pride that he helped nullify Wenger's side.

And it is testament to his commitment to the Derby cause that he is more concerned about next Saturday's basement battle at Pride Park with Bradford, banished to the bottom by Smith's team, than representing his country.

"To be honest the game against Bradford has to be more important than going away with England this week," he said. "I'd love to be involved in Italy, but it's a massive game against Bradford next week."

webTitle: Grip loses tongue after battle of the bores

fields.headline: Grip loses tongue after battle of the bores
fields.trailText: The report that Tord Grip eventually sends to the next England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson on the present state of English footballers may well begin by echoing the Duke of Wellington when he said that he did not know what effect his men would have on the opposition but by God they frightened him.
fields.body:
The report that Tord Grip eventually sends to the next England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson on the present state of English footballers may well begin by echoing the Duke of Wellington when he said that he did not know what effect his men would have on the opposition but by God they frightened him.

On Saturday Grip emerged speechless from this mundane 1-1 draw which did little but confirm the obvious, namely that below Manchester United and Arsenal the Premiership is evolving into a prosaic contest for the third Champions League place.

It should be explained that Grip's loss of words applied only when reporters sought his views on the English players he had seen so far. Maybe he felt that if he could not say anything nice he must not say anything at all.

Even Newcastle's manager Bobby Robson refused to be drawn into commenting on either the international situation or the youthful approach of the caretaker coach, Leicester's Peter Taylor, to Wednesday's friendly in Italy beyond saying that Taylor had to start somewhere and this was as good a way as any.

Certainly the pattern of this game offered precious few clues as to how Taylor's club 19-30 of an England team will perform against the experienced Italy side that Giovanni Trapattoni is likely to field.

One problem was that barely a third of those on the pitch were English, another that three of those were 30-plus, and yet another that Alan Shearer, though still 30, has retired from internationals.

So the versatility shown by the 34-year-old Robert Lee in continuing to make a success of his switch from midfield to libero, a move prompted in part by Robson's long casualty list, was irrelevant in immediate England terms. Lee's ability to bring the ball out from the back and set up movements with accurate passes were a feature of an often featureless game.

Kieron Dyer, in and out of Kevin Keegan's England team and curiously left behind for Euro 2000, probably ensured himself a place in Taylor's Turin side through the consistently good use he made of his pace in probing for a vulnerable spot in Leicester's strong defence, which on Saturday turned out to be Gerry Taggart's slowness on the turn.

The regularity with which Dyer, used by Robson to roam in space behind Shearer, found space near goal in the inside-right position might have seen Newcastle ahead before half-time. Dyer, however, tended to let down his good approach work with poor crosses.

When tactics were compared, Taylor's approach appeared more direct, Robson's less rigid.

Leicester's strength lies in defence, with the dauntless Matt Elliott, and midfield, where Muzzy Izzet, Neil Lennon and Robbie Savage have a nice balance of pace, precision and aggression. Up front, however, Taylor is still searching for an effective combination, but hoped the power of Ade Akinbiyi and Trevor Benjamin would sooner or later take a toll of Newcastle's weakened defences. So the ball tended to be played long to the strikers in the hope that one or other would turn Aaron Hughes or Alain Goma.

Yet Newcastle's back markers, and especially Goma, stuck so assiduously to their task that Leicester had created only half-chances by the time Arnar Gunnlaugsson replaced Benjamin early in the second half. The Icelander's willingness to run at defenders with the ball gave Leicester another attacking option and just past the hour his left foot gave them the lead with a well struck free-kick from 25 yards.

Within five minutes Robson had substituted Lee, who had a calf strain, with another striker, Daniel Cordone. It gave Leicester's defenders more to do and with a quarter of an hour remaining Dyer's first-time pass sent in Gary Speed to his left to bring the scores level via the far post.

Akinbiyi, sent clear and onside by Gunnlaugsson, should have won the match in the 88th minute but with Goma on his heels he shot wide. A draw was the fairest result but whether Grip was much wiser for the experience one had to wonder.
fields.bodyText: The report that Tord Grip eventually sends to the next England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson on the present state of English footballers may well begin by echoing the Duke of Wellington when he said that he did not know what effect his men would have on the opposition but by God they frightened him. On Saturday Grip emerged speechless from this mundane 1-1 draw which did little but confirm the obvious, namely that below Manchester United and Arsenal the Premiership is evolving into a prosaic contest for the third Champions League place. It should be explained that Grip's loss of words applied only when reporters sought his views on the English players he had seen so far. Maybe he felt that if he could not say anything nice he must not say anything at all. Even Newcastle's manager Bobby Robson refused to be drawn into commenting on either the international situation or the youthful approach of the caretaker coach, Leicester's Peter Taylor, to Wednesday's friendly in Italy beyond saying that Taylor had to start somewhere and this was as good a way as any. Certainly the pattern of this game offered precious few clues as to how Taylor's club 19-30 of an England team will perform against the experienced Italy side that Giovanni Trapattoni is likely to field. One problem was that barely a third of those on the pitch were English, another that three of those were 30-plus, and yet another that Alan Shearer, though still 30, has retired from internationals. webTitle: Case for defence deserts Robson

fields.headline: Case for defence deserts Robson
fields.trailText: In terms of Middlesbrough wins, Bryan Robson remains on 99 not out and desperately in need of a scrambled single. The nineties have been very nervy for him, and the danger remains that he will be stumped before he gets his century.
fields.body:
In terms of Middlesbrough wins, Bryan Robson remains on 99 not out and desperately in need of a scrambled single. The nineties have been very nervy for him, and the danger remains that he will be stumped before he gets his century.

Such are the lack of expectations placed upon visitors to Old Trafford these days that Robson actually left his alma mater with another nul point but no new damage to his buffeted reputation.

The suffocating reality, however, is that this was Boro's sixth consecutive defeat of a season that is still to bring them a clean sheet. While United's corporate clients nibble on their prawn sandwiches, Middlesbrough's rank-and-file supporters must be choking on their pork scratchings.

The acid test will come in the next fortnight when the whiff of mutiny hanging over the Riverside threatens to become intolerable unless Robson's team can bring their ignominious run to a close against either Leicester City or Bradford City.

If not, the case for his defence may well become unsustainable.

By then Robson should have something approaching a full-strength side available and his argument that Middlesbrough are merely suffering the natural consequence of a debilitating casualty list will no longer be a convenient get-out clause. But for the time being, as the United juggernaut rolls on relentlessly, Boro's season promises more stomach-turning lurches than a fare with an Italian taxi driver.

"People have been saying get me out but I would not contemplate walking away unless I thought we were going backwards," said Robson. "I still think we are going forward. This is the strongest squad I have had and, even if the league table says otherwise, I think we are a mid-table team."

Maintaining that level of optimism, Robson might well expect Brian Deane to be challenging Teddy Sheringham for the Premiership's golden boot. But the Middlesbrough manager's defiance was understandable after watching his side come so close, so agonisingly close, to repeating their feat of December 1998.

When Christian Karembeu strutted into the United penalty area to lob Middlesbrough into a jaw-dropping first-half lead the last team to win a league match at Old Trafford were suddenly embraced by a giddy sense of deja vu.

Alas, though the Frenchman's finish was exquisite, the timing could have been better, much better. United had the best part of an hour to work on their opponents before finally pummelling them into submission with a quick one-two into the solar plexus midway through the second half.

Nicky Butt's close-range finish made amends for being dispossessed in the build-up to Karembeu's goal and, as is so often the case at Old Trafford, there was an air of inevitability about the left-foot shot that Sheringham expertly angled into the top corner of Mark Schwarzer's goal three minutes later.

"There is no better side than United at chasing a game from being behind," volunteered Robson. "Other teams can look vulnerable at the back but never United. I've seen them do it to the best teams in Europe, never mind us."

So business as normal for the champions, although the lack of space in their treatment room will be disconcerting for Sir Alex Ferguson before Saturday's derby against Manchester City. Wes Brown will have a scan today on a knee problem, Roy Keane has a tight hamstring and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer limped off after 40 minutes with an ankle injury.

With Andrew Cole due to undergo an achilles operation tomorrow, and Jaap Stam and Ryan Giggs already on the sidelines, United's vast pool of resources is looking unusually depleted before they mark the short trip to Maine Road.

By a quirk, if Middlesbrough had held on to the lead after Karembeu's goal it would not merely have given Robson his 100th league win (in 258 matches) but would have condemned Ferguson to his 100th league defeat (in 555 matches). Whether Robson will go ton-up or belly-up remains to be seen.

webTitle: Burley's tractor boys are up for the long haul

fields.headline: Burley's tractor boys are up for the long haul
fields.trailText: So the tractor boys have done it again. Another city slicker sent packing, three more points collected and confidence soaring. The Ipswich team should be sent in to help with the floods; the players seem to believe they can walk on water.
fields.body:
So the tractor boys have done it again. Another city slicker sent packing, three more points collected and confidence soaring. The Ipswich team should be sent in to help with the floods; the players seem to believe they can walk on water.

The manager could probably lend a hand too. George Burley has worked his own miracles in fashioning a side who have taken to their new surroundings like an England player in a casino. Yet, in his eyes, the key to success is simple: "The players work hard for each other," he explained. "There's a belief, entertainment value. We've got no fear and there's quality from players who are international class."

Ipswich also have a set of fans who would settle for a mug of Bovril over a prawn sandwich any day of the week. "They are genuine supporters, a great bunch," said the goalkeeper Richard Wright. "They've always stuck behind us, even in the First Division when things weren't going so well, and we do appreciate it."

There is, however, one potential cloud on the horizon. Burley has had the luxury of using only 17 players in the league so far this season and, though he feels this is his strongest squad since he became manager six years ago, his side might struggle if shorn of the likes of Wright, Matt Holland and Jamie Clapham.

Holland in particular is central to Ipswich's success. He did a circuit of the pitch to applaud the fans at the final whistle; it might have been a lap of honour after he rounded off a superb display with a cracking goal to break the deadlock. "He's my Captain Marvel," Burley said. "I thought he was absolutely outstanding. He would play inside left or in goal if you asked him. He is so brave, so strong and so honest and with his ability he is great to have in the side. His hunger and ambition rubs off on the boys."

On Saturday his finishing prowess did too. Ipswich had seen more long-range efforts go off target than an American television network on election night before Holland turned Mark Kinsella and fired home. Four minutes later Marcus Stewart followed the skipper's lead by lifting the ball round Greg Shields and slotting past Steve Brown on the line.

Charlton's defence had otherwise been immaculate, Alan Curbishley's reversion to a 4-5-1 formation nullifying the home side's attack despite their dominance of possession. In the first half Charlton even created the better openings, profligate finishing from Jonatan Johansson and Claus Jensen letting them down.

Two seasons ago, after a promising start, Charlton did not win a Premiership game in November, December or January. Their next five games are against Chelsea, Sunderland, Liverpool, Manchester United and Leicester, but Curbishley, unlike Burley, has been hampered by injuries to key players and once the likes of Andy Hunt and Richard Rufus return the club's fortunes should improve.

Burley gave them his endorsement: "It's a long season but I can't see Charlton being relegated. I think all three promoted clubs have a great chance of staying up."

"We have got a difficult run now," Curbishley said, "but I think we have given ourselves a decent chance of survival this season. You can't be overawed by the Premiership and I don't think the three promoted sides have gone into it like that. But it is a long season; we can testify to that from two years ago."

This time around, however, they should survive. Finishing higher than Ipswich, though, may be out of their reach.

webTitle: Bradford's fancy dans fail to answer McCall of duty

fields.headline: Bradford's fancy dans fail to answer McCall of duty
fields.trailText: Stuart McCall's temporary stewardship of the Premiership strugglers Bradford City had been well regarded on the streets leading towards Valley Parade. He was from Yorkshire stock, was Stuart, not like that Chris Hutchings, who should never have been appointed.
fields.body:
Stuart McCall's temporary stewardship of the Premiership strugglers Bradford City had been well regarded on the streets leading towards Valley Parade. He was from Yorkshire stock, was Stuart, not like that Chris Hutchings, who should never have been appointed.

But McCall's protestations that he had no interest in the Bradford job long-term suggested he recognised the immensity of the task. It took two minutes to confirm it. The player-manager scuffled for possession on the right flank and signalled for Dan Petrescu to sprint on to a hopeful long ball into the corner. Petrescu, who does not care to sprint on to hopeful long balls, looked bemused and stayed where he was.

This Bradford side mixes like oil and water. The proud, scuffling professionals who salvaged their Premiership status on the final day of last season must now try to understand some of the most complex minds in the game.

Benny Carbone, wearing white boots with terracotta tongues, has seemingly entered his Flowerpot Men period. Stan Collymore, dangerous every time he gets possession, never once made the sort of committed and intelligent run off the ball that would ensure he received it more often. The "buzz" that the chairman Geoffrey Richmond had claimed to have heard in the dressing room was probably a badly tuned Walkman.

Everton did not really deserve the victory; a substantial injury list and a record of one win in nine matches had immersed them in caution. But when Gary Naysmith reacted quickest to score five minutes from time, after Joe-Max Moore's shot rebounded off the goalkeeper Matt Clarke, one sensed that greater ambition might have secured their victory earlier.

For Bradford, two first-half chances fell randomly to Collymore and brought a more than respectable response but Paul Gerrard saved on both occasion.

Bradford dominated possession after half-time but did yawningly little with it. Gerrard saved spectacularly from Gareth Whalley's close-range header midway through the second half and McCall, striving dependably to the last, skimmed a 25-yard shot wide to loyal oohs and aahs. That was about it, really. Once Everton scored, Kevin Campbell and Thomas Graveson might have nicked two more.

McCall is suspended for next week's meeting of the bottom two, at Derby, and the lack of goals will occupy most of his thoughts. To rely upon Collymore and Carbone is to demand a lot of telepathy.

Bradford have opened a new sports store at Valley Parade this week, and on Saturday a man shouted through a megaphone that its prices were "20% cheaper". It is called Up Front. If only the caretaker manager could find a budget striker in there.

webTitle: Campaign MediaBusiness

fields.headline: Campaign MediaBusiness
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 13
fields.trailText: The Starcom Motive Partnership and the Edinburgh-based agency Media Faulds could have a partnership deal wrapped up by Christmas.
fields.body:
The Starcom Motive Partnership and the Edinburgh-based agency Media Faulds could have a partnership deal wrapped up by Christmas.

Emap Advertising has created a 20-strong sales force for its youth magazine portfolio.

BBC Online has asked 24/7 Media to create its first e-mail marketing campaign.

Sportal.com has agreed a 12-month, pan-European online advertising and sponsorship deal with Ford.

Caspian Publishing is gearing up to launch Real Finance, a monthly title for finance directors and senior financial managers.

MediaVest is splitting its press department into two teams - one for planning and one for buying.

Vogue's gold-themed December issue boasts 324 pages and has generated nearly £2m in ad revenue.

Outrider, Tempus Group's digital media division, is opening a Scottish office.

i-Level has beaten nine agencies to win BT's online media task.

Carat has ended its boycott of Channel 5 by placing the station on the Sunday Times' media schedule.

Guardian Unlimited has notched up another sales first by being the first media owner to book an ad campaign across six platforms.

Emap Advertising has created a 20-strong sales force for its youth magazine portfolio. BBC Online has asked 24/7 Media to create its first e-mail marketing campaign. Sportal.com has agreed a 12-month, pan-European online advertising and sponsorship deal with Ford. webTitle: Point and click your way to a new leader

fields.headline: Point and click your way to a new leader
fields.trailText: As people and politicians in the US await the final conclusion of the race for the White House, I would argue that we are just one step away from the whole electoral process taking place online. By Chris Cramer.
fields.body:
As people and politicians in the US await the final conclusion of the race for the White House, I would argue that we are just one step away from the whole electoral process taking place online. That's everything from candidate selection to campaigning and voting with total interactive coverage broadcast to the home, the PC, the hand-held device and the mobile phone.

It wasn't just the broadcasters who were wrong-footed by poor voting data from last week's US elections. Channels such as CNN and ABC were quickly able to correct the predictions - and then correct them again when new data seemed to give George Bush the keys to the White House. Far and away the reddest faces were those of newspaper editors around the world who were forced to commit to the early forecasts - the printed front-page headlines can now be filed away for their curiosity value.

So time to ponder, maybe, the future of the national and local election process - and how the internet age might help us.

When I started covering political elections, in the 1960s for print and in the 1970s for radio and TV, it was all pretty routine. Politicians made their statements, they went to air, and only then did their opponents get to work to dissect and dismantle the arguments put forward. That rebuttal was as good as the speed and efficiency of the party's research department and also the investigative reporter. But now campaigning and political news coverage has gone into cyberspace.

We have online "e-buttal" units challenging statements seconds after they have been made. Al Gore and George Bush were both using the technology to set up their own campaign websites with the very latest e-answers and e-spin updated minute by minute.

"Push" technology was being used to send information to target groups, community forums were being set up to give politicians an instant "pulse of the nation", and recipients were urged to pass on a rebuttal to a friend or their local newspaper. We even had online "toolboxes" so that you could establish your very own website to support your chosen candidate.

The online rebuttal units would kick in minutes after a political statement, spit back the appropriate data, and then offer voters the opportunity to email the rebuttals to the undecided voter. And while all these cyberwars were under way, the humble journalists were working on the major news sites using a variety of online technologies to add to the immediacy of the event and its coverage. At CNN.com we were bracing ourselves for a record night of 10m page views each hour. In the weeks before that, we offered searchable archives so that users could interrogate history for data that would either support or challenge what was being said on the political hustings. Most of the major sites carried in-depth specials examining the key issues, with interactive maps and charts recording every move.

This is true voter empowerment. Technology and the web is now giving voters the chance to TAKE PART in the political event, to be better informed, to drill down into the facts, to have our say and to talk to each other about what is really going on. Some examples: if you want to watch every speech on the campaign trail, it's all there; if you want to read the transcript, it's all there. Do you want to rant or vent your spleen? Find a political soulmate to share your disillusionment? Then it's all there.

For the politician, there is no place to hide online. Every word, every slip, every policy is there for us to examine, research and, if necessary, challenge. Strip out the platitudes, avoid the handshakes and baby-kissing. Facts, facts and then more facts.

For the savvy politicians the web has become an electronic thermometer to take the temperature of the nation. Indeed, a fresh dynamic has entered the sometimes cynical world of political campaigning and it is here to stay.

As the threat of litigation hangs over the entire US election process and some of the electorate in Palm Beach County take to the streets over a clumsy ballot form, there's already a feeling that, as technology develops, we are just a short step away from the entire process taking place online. From candidate selection to campaigning and then onto the vote itself. Forget the three-hour queues to vote, forget the intimidating ballot box - just point your mouse and click.

Congratulations - you have a new president. Have a nice day!

 Chris Cramer is president of CNN International Networks

"Push" technology was being used to send information to target groups, community forums were being set up to give politicians an instant "pulse of the nation", and recipients were urged to pass on a rebuttal to a friend or their local newspaper. We even had online "toolboxes" so that you could establish your very own website to support your chosen candidate. The online rebuttal units would kick in minutes after a political statement, spit back the appropriate data, and then offer voters the opportunity to email the rebuttals to the undecided voter. And while all these cyberwars were under way, the humble journalists were working on the major news sites using a variety of online technologies to add to the immediacy of the event and its coverage. At CNN.com we were bracing ourselves for a record night of 10m page views each hour. In the weeks before that, we offered searchable archives so that users could interrogate history for data that would either support or challenge what was being said on the political hustings. Most of the major sites carried in-depth specials examining the key issues, with interactive maps and charts recording every move. This is true voter empowerment. Technology and the web is now giving voters the chance to TAKE PART in the political event, to be better informed, to drill down into the facts, to have our say and to talk to each other about what is really going on. Some examples: if you want to watch every speech on the campaign trail, it's all there; if you want to read the transcript, it's all there. Do you want to rant or vent your spleen? Find a political soulmate to share your disillusionment? Then it's all there. For the politician, there is no place to hide online. Every word, every slip, every policy is there for us to examine, research and, if necessary, challenge. Strip out the platitudes, avoid the handshakes and baby-kissing. Facts, facts and then more facts. For the savvy politicians the web has become an electronic thermometer to take the temperature of the nation. Indeed, a fresh dynamic has entered the sometimes cynical world of political campaigning and it is here to stay. As the threat of litigation hangs over the entire US election process and some of the electorate in Palm Beach County take to the streets over a clumsy ballot form, there's already a feeling that, as technology develops, we are just a short step away from the entire process taking place online. From candidate selection to campaigning and then onto the vote itself. Forget the three-hour queues to vote, forget the intimidating ballot box - just point your mouse and click. Congratulations - you have a new president. Have a nice day!  Chris Cramer is president of CNN International Networks

webTitle: All PR is a waste of money

fields.headline: Face up to who your real sources are
fields.standfirst: All PR is a waste of money, or a scam, say the newspapers. Not so, argues  Julia Hobsbawm, who calls for journalists to be more honest about where their - good - stories come from
fields.trailText: All PR is a waste of money, or a scam, say the newspapers. Not so, argues Julia Hobsbawm, who calls for journalists to be more honest about where their - good - stories come from.
fields.body:
How ethical is public relations? Not very, if you believe what you read in the papers. "When the going gets tough, the feeble call PR," said the Observer earlier this month, citing the growing number of PR teams deployed by beleaguered companies such as Railtrack. The Daily Mail echoed this tone days later with the headline: "In the war on rural crime, police told to spend our money on PR". Spend our money on PR? Why, isn't that the same as a fat cat spending his shareholder's money on a jolly in the Bahamas?

The constant inference throughout the media is that PR is either a waste of time, a waste of money, or a downright scam. Well no, actually, it isn't. The vast amount of day-to-day public relations in both the public and private sector does tally with its rather worthy (and wordy) definition by the Institute of Public Relations as "the planned and sustained effort to establish and maintain mutual understanding and goodwill between an organisation and its publics".

The main conduit to mass publics, particularly with a consumer issue such as rail travel or policing, are the mainstream media. Unlike advertising, which has total control of its message, PR cannot convey information without the influence of opinion, much of it editorial. How does the consumer know what is fact, and what has influenced the presentation of that fact? PR alone is clearly not solely to blame. Today, the media seem guided by the simple mantra: "Get it first", as demonstrated last week by the US television networks.

I've worked on the other side of the PR/journalism divide and I know how unspeakable it is to get a call from someone who either knows nothing about what they are pitching, or does not have the wit to see both sides of a story.

Having said that, I can't think of one story that I have placed, in either print or broadcast media, which has been a 100% accurate rendition of the facts I have presented. Most have been more like 50% at best, once you've taken sub-editing, interpretation and head lines into account for print, and interview or story context into account for broadcast. That's "freedom of information". So the obvious bias from PR in the first place, and the less obvious bias of journalism, means that the consumer's diet of fact is being eroded by both trades, each one blaming the other.

The contract between the two trades is inescapable and co-dependent. The Guardian has recognised this dysfunctional relationship in the political lobby, which so often spins out of control. This is no surprise: both journalism and PR are at best interpretation or oral history and at worst political bias and malicious wounding.

So why the continued media scapegoating of PR? Well, we are increasingly the gatekeepers to crucial access for a story, barring the way to a simple quote by a bureaucratic procedure that can look like, and sometimes is, a way of buying time and agreeing "a line" first. Like lawyers, the majority of the PR trade believes in the taxi-rank school of appointment, namely that everyone has the right to representation, regardless of the merit of their case. I disagree with this policy, but it doesn't mean that unethical systems of information automatically follow suit.

These days the high street is your best ethical barometer: you probably know how much child labour went into your trainers. Or how wage exploitation produces delicious but dodgy coffee. If you don't, organisations such as Fairtrade will tell you, so that the end product is seen as the sum of its parts, not the packaging and appeal to consumer taste alone. How it gets to the shelves is now part of whether it moves off those shelves.

So let's have more transparency in the media to show readers, viewers and listeners what the true makeup of their information is. Maybe media need to show their PR content, in much the same way that food labelling does for sugars, additives and vitamins. A list in every piece and in every closing broadcast credit of the ingredients that make up each story. Should it happen? I think journalism would prefer to continue to bite the hand that feeds it. But even a pilot scheme for a limited period would show whether consumers avoid stories with too high a PR content. But then again, maybe the stories just wouldn't taste the same without . . .

Julia Hobsbawm is chairwoman of Hobsbawm Macaulay Communications.

webTitle: Heskey turns dreams to reality

fields.headline: Heskey turns dreams to reality
fields.trailText: If there is a vague and largely unfathomable law governing the art of managerial selection it is undoubtedly sod's law. For it is often the case that even the most learned of coaches is at his most effective when his options are at their most limited.
fields.body:
If there is a vague and largely unfathomable law governing the art of managerial selection it is undoubtedly sod's law. For it is often the case that even the most learned of coaches is at his most effective when his options are at their most limited.

Gérard Houllier is hardly one to tinker unnecessarily with the make-up of his team because he has always been acutely aware of the fragile nature of the modern-day footballer's ego; it is called man-management and the Frenchman is a fine exponent of what just might be a dying art.

Although Liverpool won comfortably enough against Slovan Liberec in the Czech Republic on Thursday there was, self-evidently, room for improvement. And so the pack was shuffled. Out went such luminaries as Robbie Fowler, Christian Ziege and Jamie Carragher, all carried to the touchline by the wind of change.

With Dietmar Hamann inactive because of injury, this was a new-look Liverpool - yes, another new-look Liverpool - and, in truth, probably the one that average Joe Scouser would have marked down as his dream team.

Michael Owen returned to domestic action four weeks after his nasty head injury, Markus Babbel switched to right-back and, most significantly, Gary McAllister and Steven Gerrard were paired in central midfield for the first time.

The effect was fitfully telling and absorbing as Liverpool shaped as if to sweep Coventry aside. The irony was that, despite the presence of Owen and the on-fire Emile Heskey, Liverpool found it so difficult to transform water into wine; chances were created with piggish regularity only to be squandered.

Indeed had Liverpool converted, say, 25% of the opportunities that fell their way in a one-sided opening half, those in blue who worked so studiously to undermine the theory that Coventry teams at least give their all would have spent the interval discussing not tactics but damage limitation.

Long before McAllister swept in a low and sweet drive against his former employers in the 13th minute, Coventry had moved to the cusp of capitulation.

Thereafter, the afternoon retained a semblance of a competitive edge only because Liverpool players queued up to make fools of themselves - Owen, Heskey, Vladimir Smicer, they were all at it.

At one point, in the minutes after David Thompson drilled home a magnificent shot from great distance, it did seem possible - just - that this alarming wastefulness might cost Liverpool the match. It did not because Coventry could not even conjure up a fightback when invited.

The game had appeared over when Gerrard headed in a McAllister corner but it took Thompson's blissful strike to remind Liverpool there was still work to be done.

And done it was. Heskey's ninth and 10th goals of the season - a nice header and a delightful chip from the edge of the area, both in the final few minutes - finally placed daylight between two sides of quite differing merit.

"We have played a lot of games in a relatively short period of time so I am very, very happy with this result," said Houllier.

And so Liverpool again find themselves treading on the coat-tails of the leading two. As for Coventry, the annual fight for survival is now under way.

webTitle: Doing the business

fields.headline: Doing the business
fields.standfirst: The hiring of Jeff Randall is a sign that Greg Dyke wants to put City and company coverage up there with politics and foreign affairs. But, reports Maggie Brown, the boss's plans haven't thrilled everyone
fields.trailText: Tucked away in a far corner of the BBC News empire in west London sits a tiny group of journalists who last week found they'd suddenly become very fashionable indeed. I've come to a once well-kept secret, The Working Lunch. This snappy daily half hour of live business and money news is broadcast at 12.30pm every weekday on BBC2 to pensioners, home workers, and students - sandwiched incongruously between schools programmes and Fireman Sam.
fields.body:
Tucked away in a far corner of the BBC News empire in west London sits a tiny group of journalists who last week found they'd suddenly become very fashionable indeed. I've come to a once well-kept secret, The Working Lunch. This snappy daily half hour of live business and money news is broadcast at 12.30pm every weekday on BBC2 to pensioners, home workers, and students - sandwiched incongruously between schools programmes and Fireman Sam.

Until Greg Dyke praised it for innovation at the CBI conference last week, Working Lunch, though running for six years, was virtually ignored by BBC news bosses, who love their politics and define a good day's work as making waves with the Today programme. The Lunch team simply toils away, head down from 5.30 each morning. This explains how the shirtsleeved presenters Adam Shaw and Adrian Chiles, a gritty Brummie who could pass as Warren Clarke's son, have honed their unconventional style, mixing a dash of slapstick and repartee with informed reporting. (On one notable occasion, M&S knickers were brandished to demonstrate the store's problems).

It also goes to explain how they alighted on a key weapon, their own broadcast truck, which trundles from the Rolls Royce shopfloor in Derby, via a Dudley aluminium factory and on to the Lewes floods for a story about insurance claims, giving the programme a non-metropolitan, even non-BBC feel. They've also "adopted" two pensioners, to comment acidly on government concessions.

Programme editor Tracey Hobbs says: "We don't ram business down the audience's throats. I like to think we make it relevant to people's lives." Their worry is that Dyke's new-found enthusiasm could be a poisoned chalice, subjecting them to far more scrutiny - hence less risk taking, and more boring conventional news packages.

Dyke's decision, as the corporation's editor-in-chief, to hire Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall in an attempt to make business as important as politics and foreign affairs means that the whole BBC machine has to sit up and take notice. His traditionally liberal-minded staff may be sceptical - not least the all-powerful news programme editors - but even Newsnight is getting its own dedicated business reporter, joining 11 existing on-air business journalists.

Dyke's proposals contained a specific commitment to experiment with an hour-long Working Lunch from December 11 - a commitment that has not met with unbridled enthusiasm. Randall says the idea of a business programme at lunchtime is bizarre, pointing out that most business professionals are only available to watch or listen at around 7am or after 10pm.

But Randall is not alone in having doubts. Here on the shopfloor the team are not entirely thrilled. Sure, they are preparing extra material: Adrian and Adam spent an afternoon last week working at a firm selling Christmas hampers, a follow-on from their look at the micro-economics of running a fish and chip shop.

As Hobbs says: "An evening slot would be lovely". The problem is obvious: people who would genuinely find the programme relevant and take viewing figures over 1m- business employers and employees - are all working at 12.30pm. The presenters are mobbed when they go to events attended by small investors, but virtually ignored at the CBI.

And they share a common problem with all other news programmes. Business leaders by and large refuse to go on television or radio, recorded or live, expecting to be monstered. Chiles points out that the financial services authority, devised to protect investors, hates speaking to Working Lunch, as do the big banks.

Hobbs says she's inundated by new internet companies, desperate for a mention, while most press officers of quoted companies refuse to let the team through to their chief executives. She was part of Dyke's charm offensive at the CBI and finds she is wringing acceptances from bosses by meeting them at dinners. "They need to come on and be answerable". On the other hand, she muses: "I wouldn't like the programme to turn into a load of men in suits. We want to get under the skin of what's really going on". Her response to Randall's appointment as business news editor is equally pragmatic: "If he's got a contact book, he could help us".

Hobbs however is worried by more gritty matters: she gets complaints that the BBC doesn't care about business, because the programme runs for only 42 weeks a year ("so business stops over the summer" is a typical tart comment), and is forced to make way for Wimbledon, party political conferences and (most recently) the Olympics.

In yet another part of the BBC, Dyke's new diktat is emerging on screen. That tired old workhorse, The Money Programme, has been completely changed for this autumn under the award-winning Robert Thirkell, whose clear success with Troubleshooter, Blood on the Carpet and Back to the Floor showed how business could be enthralling human drama. Thirkell is now running a specialist factual business programme unit, with 50 people to service the BBC's new ambitions.

The revamped Money Programme has thrown out the presenter and dropped the magazine feel to become a feature programme with voice-overs by actors, and snazzy titles. But it is still uneven work in progress, at the formative stage rather than cutting edge. In another development, BBC Knowledge has just piloted Money Talks, a round table discussion with business executives in a format that has been adapted from arts TV. This specifically addresses one of the business world's grouses: that they are not accorded the airtime to develop their case. The problem here is: where is the audience?

Mark Damazer, the BBC news executive who recruited Randall for Dyke, addresses head on the key issue underlying the appointment: is the BBC, once so disdainful of business, now to be forced to go soft and present, unquestioning, its motives, as it changes the balance of output in tune with its multi-millionaire director general and chairman? "No one expects us to lay out the red carpet. But we will let them have the time and space to lay out their strategies. On the other hand, we're not there to say everything is fine. But the threshold of what makes a [business] story will be lowered".

The key to Randall's appointment is the impact he will make on programmes and how quickly he can build a power base within a corporation of empire builders. He says his initial priority is to make his presence felt on Today and the News at Ten. But he won't reinvent the corporation's business coverage by steamrollering his way on to news bulletins. The acid test of his success will be whether he can build a team to serve all of the 40-plus BBC news programmes. Otherwise he's just a very expensive reporter, on a package worth about £150, 000 a year.

To the nitty-gritty question of whether Randall can broadcast reports (and indeed handle a terse interview with a chief executive at 8.30am on Today), Damazer answers: "He's got a fantastic voice, to have a bit of Essex won't do any harm. He's charismatic, got a tremendous track record, it looks to me like he's going to be a very good broadcaster."

But these past few weeks have proved that television news ratings react above all to a lively news agenda. The combination of an American election debacle, floods, the conjoined twins and Bond-style jewel heists at the Dome have sent news ratings on both BBC1 and ITV through the roof. Winning time from that lot to explain the fortunes of Vodafone, BT or the Abbey National's mating rituals on a cramped 30-minute news programmes will be tough. Randall's only card will be the backing of the editor-in-chief. It's a good card to hold. Further down the road, Dyke has promised to expand BBC output under two big brand headlines, Money and Business, with visions of websites and maybe a dedicated subscription business channel. For Randall, that's clearly the endgame. But as Damazer points out: "Nothing is going to happen very quickly".

webTitle: Keegan's legal bills will be paid by FA

fields.headline: Keegan's legal bills will be paid by FA
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has been told that the Football Association will cover the cost of the legal action he has threatened against the News of the World, which alleged that when he was England coach he played a major role in big-stakes gambling with his players.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has been told that the Football Association will cover the cost of the legal action he has threatened against the News of the World, which alleged that when he was England coach he played a major role in big-stakes gambling with his players.

The costs for an action against the newspaper, which claimed that at times the kitty reached £40,000, might run to thousands of pounds.

England's caretaker coach Peter Taylor has promised to keep an eye on the 24-man squad that assembled last night to prepare for Wednesday's friendly in Italy.

"There's got to be some kind of time limit on cards," he said. "I don't want heavy gambling. They earn good money and if they lose some it won't make much difference. But if they lose a lot of money it might. So that would concern me."

Paul Ince, a member of the former coach's Euro 2000 squad, said: "It's an insult to Keegan to suggest that he would sanction the winning and losing of thousands of pounds.

"Players will test each other out. Brag and poker can be examinations of a person's bottle and when one of us gets bluffed out of a kitty, especially the biggest ones of three or four hundred quid, he takes unmerciful stick. But team spirit is never the loser."

Sir Alex Ferguson will miss Saturday's derby at Manchester City as he will be attending his eldest son's wedding in Cape Town.

Cambridge United have sacked their midfielder Neil Mackenzie for "persistent misconduct". The 24-year-old was allegedly involved in a city-centre incident and is due in court next Monday.

Three police officers were injured during clashes between fans of the Greek clubs Panathinaikos, Manchester United's next Champions League opponents, and Olympiakos, who meet Liverpool in the Uefa Cup third round. Supporters threw stones at police, who responded by firing tear gas, and five people were arrested. The game, at the newly reopened Apostolos Nikolaidis stadium which Panathinaikos use for league games, was goalless.

webTitle: Battle fatigue rules Smith out of Turin

fields.headline: Battle fatigue rules Smith out of Turin
fields.trailText: David O'Leary yesterday broke with tradition in favour of downright honesty when he withdrew Leeds United's 20-year-old striker Alan Smith from the England squad for Wednesday's friendly international in Italy.
fields.body:
David O'Leary yesterday broke with tradition in favour of downright honesty when he withdrew Leeds United's 20-year-old striker Alan Smith from the England squad for Wednesday's friendly international in Italy.

The England caretaker manager Peter Taylor had already been informed by his assistant, the Manchester United first-team coach Steve McClaren, that he had lost the United defender Wes Brown from his 26-man squad because of a knee injury.

But when O'Leary rang to inform Taylor that Smith would not be going to Turin either, the Leeds manager admitted he felt the player just needed a rest. An ankle injury, picked up in yesterday's 1-1 draw at Chelsea, was more of an afterthought.

"I wouldn't say his ankle is anything ridiculous, as he would have come off if it had been," O'Leary said. "But he needs a break really because he's been playing week in and week out and because of the way he plays. There's still plenty of time to come for him."

The Aston Villa captain Gareth Southgate is expected to recover from stitches to a facial wound he received in Villa's 2-0 win over Tottenham on Saturday. He and his club-mates David James, the oldest member of the squad but set to be named as goalkeeper in Turin, and Gareth Barry, together with all other members of the England squad, were expected to join up last night.

There was further positive news for Taylor as Emile Heskey scored twice for Liverpool against Coventry, Steve Gerrard was also on target and Michael Owen put his head injury problems behind him to start yesterday's match.

Roma's captain Francesco Totti and the Juventus defender Mark Iuliano have withdrawn from Italy's squad because of injury. Totti, a highly important member of the coach Giovanni Trapattoni's squad, suffered a recurrence of a muscle strain during Roma's 2-1 win over Reggina at the Olympic stadium yesterday.

Trapattoni has called up the Fiorentina defender Daniele Adani and the experienced, versatile Juventus player Gianluca Pessotto in their place. The Italy coach is likely to play Udinese's Stefano Fiore in Totti's usual role, just behind the front two.

 The Manchester United captain Roy Keane (hamstring), Sunderland striker Niall Quinn (back) and Derby utility player Rory Delap (achilles) are all out of the Republic of Ireland squad for Wednesday's friendly against Finland at Lansdowne Road.

webTitle: Brand aid

fields.headline: Brand aid
fields.standfirst: Ovaltine
fields.trailText: What is it?
fields.body:
What is it?

"A delicious blend of barley, malt and cocoa fortified with eight vitamins and minerals," according to marketing. Best known as the bedtime tipple of Alan Bennett characters and Val Doonican fans. Likely to make anyone over 25 break into song and bring back hazy memories of a cheerful country girl with a sheaf of wheat and a basket of eggs.

What's the problem?

Declining sales. Manufacturer Novartis is battling rival Horlicks, but both have struggled in recent years.

So?

Novartis is launching a £2m campaign to highlight the drink's energy-giving properties. Marketing manager Paul Simpson says: "People think it's designed to make you go to sleep, but actually for all of the last century, it was promoted as an energy-giving drink."

History

First made by Dr George Wander, a Swiss chemist, in 1909. A year later, his son Albert set up a company to manufacture Ovaltine in Hertfordshire. It was recognised as an official sports drink at the 1948 Olympic Games at Wembley, where 25,000 cups were served to athletes. Muhammad Ali has claimed to drink the stuff and it has been supplied to every Mount Everest expedition since 1933, including Sir Edmund Hillary's successful attempt in 1953.

Who drinks it?

50% of drinkers are women; 40% men and 10% children. The company is mainly targeting women over 35.

What the experts say

Tim Barson of brand consultancy Identica believes Ovaltine faces an uphill struggle. "I'd question the wisdom of spending all that money on advertising when the basic product's still the same. If you want to change people's perceptions, you have to look at the taste, format and distribution of the product. Otherwise it's likely to be wasted money."

The future

Trendy cafes and bars across the country. Vodka Ovaltine, anyone?

webTitle: Future Network shares dive after profit warning

fields.headline: Future Network shares dive after profit warning
fields.trailText: 10am: Future Network, the media group with Elisabeth Murdoch on its board, has issued a profit warning that has almost halved its share price. by Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Future Network, the magazine and online media group with Elisabeth Murdoch on its board, has issued a profit warning that has almost halved its share price.

The stock was marked down nearly 45% or 217.5p to 272.5p, a quarter of its peak value this year at 937p.

In a statement to the Stock Exchange, the company blamed the mark-down on the re-evaluation of its French business earlier this year.

Future Network was forced to call in accountants Deloitte & Touche after a £1.1m shortfall was discovered.

The company also blamed the "continued softness" of the computer games market in the final months of the year, pointing to Sony's announcement of a cutback in its allocation of PlayStation 2 units in Europe by nearly 20%, following a 50% allocation in the US.

Future Networks chief executive Greg Ingham said: "We are naturally disappointed that these vital Q4 numbers look set to come in below the original high goals we set ourselves.

"We remain focused on strengthening our management team and business processes, improving the performance of each and every one of our business units and in building great products for the future from our record investment we have made this year."

webTitle: World champion among victims

fields.headline: World champion among victims
fields.standfirst: More about the Kitzsteinhorn tunnel disaster
fields.trailText: As the identities of the victims slowly became known yesterday, Germany's skiing chief, Helmut Weinbuch, called it "the greatest tragedy in the history of skiing as a sport".
fields.body:
As the identities of the victims slowly became known yesterday, Germany's skiing chief, Helmut Weinbuch, called it "the greatest tragedy in the history of skiing as a sport".

The dead almost certainly included the world champion freestyle skier, Sandra Schmitt, as well as three trainers from the German national association and four young competitors earmarked as future champions. Ms Schmitt's parents were also believed to be among the dead.

Austria's APA news agency reported that four members of the hearing-impaired national ski team were also killed. Among them was reported to be the slalom and giant slalom world champion, Josef Schaupper.

With two weeks before the start of the world cup season, Germany's leading competitors were due to take part in a training session on a specially reserved course in the area yesterday afternoon. It was not clear whether other members of the national team were feared dead.

Mr Weinbuch, the general secretary of Germany's skiing federation, the DSV, said: "We can barely comprehend the scale of the ac cident and our hearts go out to the victims' relatives."

Ms Schmitt, 19, from Mörfelden, near Frankfurt, took the moguls title at the 1999 freestyle world championships at Meiringen in Switzerland. It was Germany's first victory in a world championship freestyle event.

The Olympic skier Tatjana Mittermayer, who cheated death by travelling up to the glacier on a ski-lift, said: "Sandra was the emblem of our team. In the coming world championship, she would definitely have been a medal contender".

The instructors and the three boys and one girl who died were part of a DSV training group. Half the group had gone on an earlier train and were waiting for the others to arrive.
