webTitle: Candles and prayers for blaze victims

fields.headline: Candles and prayers for blaze victims
fields.standfirst:
Nation mourns as 155 die in Alpine tunnel disaster

More about the Kitzsteinhorn tunnel disaster
fields.trailText: Nation mourns as 155 die in Alpine tunnel disaster
fields.body:
Silent, stunned villagers gathered in Kaprun's Catholic church for Mass last night, on the first of two days of mourning across Austria following the catastrophe which left 155 skiers and snowboarders dead after fire swept through a funicular train in the worst-ever Alpine accident.

At 3pm local time, relatives and friends gathered at the foot of Kitzsteinhorn, close to the tunnel, for a private memorial service. The governor of Salzburg province, Franz Schausberger, said it had been a "shattering scene", but that the relatives had requested the service.

"We understand Christ's wail on the cross, My God, why have you abandoned me?" the priest, Peter Hofer, said in his sermon.

The authorities know of 155 people who are missing and are believed to be victims. No Britons are believed to be among them.

Candles were lit in the snow outside shops and a youth hostel where relatives of the victims were being counselled. Church services paid tribute to the dead and black flags hung from municipal buildings in the pretty Austrian village which lies 50 miles south-west of Salzburg, in the shadow of the dramatic snow-covered Kitzsteinhorn mountain.

A fire in the 3,300-metre long tunnel, which started on Saturday morning, continued to burn until yesterday afternoon. Firefighters began attempting to secure the charred carriage before beginning the task of removing the human remains from the upper part of the tunnel. Charred bodies were found in the funicular carriage, outside it in the tunnel, as well as underneath it.

Rescue workers talked of scenes "so terrible it cannot be described", and said the aluminium train, which was believed to have been filled to its 180-person capacity, had been reduced to its chassis.

Officials said there were 18 survivors, aged between 12 and 63. Twelve of them fought through the flames and headed down the mountain. Those who escaped from the carriage but went towards the mountain top were overcome by poisonous fumes.

The German world champion freestyle skier, Sandra Schmitt, and her parents were among the dead.

Eyewitnesses reported an explosion minutes after the train set off. There is also speculation that the carriage was already on fire before it entered the tunnel.

Kaprun, a village of 2,900 which has 5,000 tourist beds, had been celebrating the first official day of its high ski season when the accident happened on Saturday.

Yesterday only a deluge of journalists who have descended on the town with their satellite trucks, and the buzz of rescue helicopters, in terrupted the hush of Kaprun. Most skiers had broken off their holidays early and deserted the town.

Many holidaymakers became emotional as they told how acquaintances they had met at their hotels had failed to return on Saturday evening, even after rescue workers had brought 2,500 stranded skiers down from the mountain. Others stressed how lucky they were not to have taken the fatal train.

"We arrived on the Friday night and got drunk," said a Dutch man from Amsterdam, sitting with a group of friends outside the Hotel Orgler. "The next day we had hangovers and missed a 9.30 appointment at the ski school. Only afterwards did we discover the fate of the people who travelled in the train we could well have taken."

Inside the hotel, a notice decorated with a black cross informed guests: "The piste is closed until further notice."

Leaflets for a service at Kaprun's Catholic church, which were printed days before the accident, were eerily poignant. "Only God knows the hour," they read.

An elderly woman coming out of the church said the accident was "a heavy blow" to Kaprun, not least because of its effect on the tourist indus try. "It has ruined our livelihoods," she said.

Kaprun is an extremely popular resort, particularly among snowboarders, attracted by the tourist board's promise that "Kitzsteinhorn never sleeps". Most were partaking in a snowboard party including "splash-pipe" demonstrations and "straight jumps".

Others were training for the world snowboard championships, due to be held here on November 24. Kitzsteinhorn was also scheduled to host the 2002 world mountain bike championships. Its future is now uncertain.

webTitle: Harrowing search for victims of tunnel tragedy

fields.headline: Harrowing search for victims of tunnel tragedy
fields.standfirst:
Skiers, mostly young, had no chance as tunnel sucked up heat and smoke

More about the Kitzsteinhorn tunnel disaster
fields.trailText: An extensive and harrowing salvage operation to uncover the victims of a fire which engulfed an Alpine train in Austria got under way last night. The 155 victims so far have been identified with "90% certainty".
fields.byline: Kate Connolly in Kaprun,  Paul Kelso and Tim Radford
fields.body:
An extensive and harrowing salvage operation to uncover the victims of a fire which engulfed an Alpine train in Austria got under way last night. The 155 victims so far have been identified with "90% certainty".

For much of the day rescue teams were prevented from approaching the remains of what was once described as the world's safest train by extreme temperatures, toxic fumes and concerns that the 5cm thick cable by which the wreckage is suspended could snap and send it plummeting towards the valley below.

Forensic scientists worked with rescue workers in the tunnel, using special lighting. "It will take a very long time, and it's dark and very cold," Franz Schausberger, governor of the province of Salzburg, said.

A fireman hinted at the horror. "It looked absolutely terrible," he said, "so much so that I can't even begin to describe what I saw because I don't want to upset the victims' relatives."

Two railway workers who went into the tunnel on Saturday reported that the train's metal base was all that remained following the 1,000C blaze.

The fire, whose cause is as yet unknown, began at the lower end of the train's single carriage with the train 600m into the tunnel. Just 18 people reacted quickly enough to save themselves.For the rest there was no hope.

One survivor told doctors that he used a hammer to smash a window and throw his daughter to safety. At least 10 others followed him. Another survivor, a woman, said: "My only thought was to get out and I could save myself in the last second because a window was kicked in and I could fight my way outside." Another six people waiting at the station at the top of the tunnel also escaped.

The Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, called the Kaprun disaster "the biggest tragedy in the history of Austrian winter sport". Joined in Kaprun on a visit to relatives of the victims by the vice chancellor, Susanne Riess-Passer, he said that the whole country had been stunned by the tragedy. "We're here as a sign of solidarity," he said.

But he stressed that Austria continued to be "one of the safest countries in the world" for winter sports. "The safety guarantee is still top of our agenda for visitors to Austria," he said. "We have an extremely high level of safety. We invest billions in our lift companies every year and we need our best experts to work out what happened and we'll do our best to solve it."

The buzz of rescue helicopters was the only sound cutting through a crisp autumn day, a repeat of Saturday's perfect skiing conditions that drew crowds of young skiers and snowboarders for a gala opening to the winter season.

Empty cable-car gondolas, used on Saturday to evacuate 2,500 people, floated above pylons carrying the track up a one-in-two gradient to the mouth of the tunnel, which still belched out occasional clouds of smoke more than 24 hours after the fire.

A sign in the ticket window said simply: "We are mourning". Another rescue worker shook his head as he remembered the predominantly young skiers and snowboarders packed into the train. "They had no chance," he said.

It remains unclear how the fire began. Rumours in Kaprun circulated all day with suggestions that fireworks, cooking gas canisters, a cigarette or a can of diesel on board may have been to blame. Erix Buxbaumn, Austria's head of public security, speculated that a fire on the tracks, possibly caused by an electrical fault, set the train on fire.

"We have received information that the light of a fire was already visible to outside witnesses as the train was entering the tunnel," said Mr Buxbaumn. He indicated that if the driver had spotted the fire it would have been too late to stop. A second train, thought to have been carrying just a driver, was travelling down the tunnel at the time of the fire. The driver is presumed dead.

Pressure is bound to mount on the cable car operating company, Gletscherbahn Kaprun, which admitted that there was no contingency plan for a fire in the tunnel. "It wasn't provided for - we were taken by suprise," said Manfred Mueller, head of technical operations.

There were no fire extinguishers on board and the automatic doors are understood to have locked shut, trapping the skiiers in what within minutes became a tomb. The end would have been brief. The tunnel, raked upwards at an angle of 45 degrees, sucked up heat and smoke.

Once the blaze began consuming oxygen it would have created a vacuum that set more air rushing towards it, to fan itself from a small flame into a big one. Confined fires always burn more furiously than unconfined fires, and the tunnel, drawing oxygen at an accelerating rate from below it, is a perfect example of a confined space.

For those who did not react immediately, the consequences were terrible and swift. Machines are built of steel and alloy, but parts will burn, if there is enough heat around. Human flesh will start to suffer mild injury after one second at 65C but fires generate 10 times that, and go on getting hotter as oxygen supplies roar in. Fires under such circumstances accelerate with amazing speeds.

At such temperatures, metals buckle and melt, stone chars and anything else bursts into flame. Polymers burn furiously at around 1200 C, releasing clouds of smoke also rich in combustible gases - and poisonous ones such as hydrogen cyanide. But the main killer in such cases is carbon monoxide. Even small quantities can begin to stupefy victims. Inhaled in large quantities, unconsciousness is followed swiftly by death.

Identification of the dead promises to be exacting. Officials and Red Cross volunteers spent much of yesterday compiling the names of some 2,500 hotel guests and local skiers thought to have planned to ski Kitzsteinhorn on Saturday. As many of them returned to hotels or contacted helplines they were removed from the list of possible victims.

Last night the number of Japanese victims fell from 17 to 10, after a party of missing Japanese who were on their way home were located. The number of Austrian victims stood at 52, Germans accounted for 42, and there were eight American citizens, two Slovenes, a Croat, and 40 people whose nationality is unknown.

Bill McGuire, professor of geohazards at University College London, and a keen skier who has used the tunnel, said such tunnels were inherently dangerous.

"This is the in way of getting up the Alps these days. A lot of cable cars are being replaced by these things: they plunge through the mountains and take people up to 7,000 feet in a couple of minutes," he said.

fields.bodyText: An extensive and harrowing salvage operation to uncover the victims of a fire which engulfed an Alpine train in Austria got under way last night. The 155 victims so far have been identified with "90% certainty". For much of the day rescue teams were prevented from approaching the remains of what was once described as the world's safest train by extreme temperatures, toxic fumes and concerns that the 5cm thick cable by which the wreckage is suspended could snap and send it plummeting towards the valley below. Forensic scientists worked with rescue workers in the tunnel, using special lighting. "It will take a very long time, and it's dark and very cold," Franz Schausberger, governor of the province of Salzburg, said. A fireman hinted at the horror. "It looked absolutely terrible," he said, "so much so that I can't even begin to describe what I saw because I don't want to upset the victims' relatives." Two railway workers who went into the tunnel on Saturday reported that the train's metal base was all that remained following the 1,000C blaze. The fire, whose cause is as yet unknown, began at the lower end of the train's single carriage with the train 600m into the tunnel. Just 18 people reacted quickly enough to save themselves.For the rest there was no hope. One survivor told doctors that he used a hammer to smash a window and throw his daughter to safety. At least 10 others followed him. Another survivor, a woman, said: "My only thought was to get out and I could save myself in the last second because a window was kicked in and I could fight my way outside." Another six people waiting at the station at the top of the tunnel also escaped. The Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, called the Kaprun disaster "the biggest tragedy in the history of Austrian winter sport". Joined in Kaprun on a visit to relatives of the victims by the vice chancellor, Susanne Riess-Passer, he said that the whole country had been stunned by the tragedy. "We're here as a sign of solidarity," he said. But he stressed that Austria continued to be "one of the safest countries in the world" for winter sports. "The safety guarantee is still top of our agenda for visitors to Austria," he said. "We have an extremely high level of safety. We invest billions in our lift companies every year and we need our best experts to work out what happened and we'll do our best to solve it." The buzz of rescue helicopters was the only sound cutting through a crisp autumn day, a repeat of Saturday's perfect skiing conditions that drew crowds of young skiers and snowboarders for a gala opening to the winter season. Empty cable-car gondolas, used on Saturday to evacuate 2,500 people, floated above pylons carrying the track up a one-in-two gradient to the mouth of the tunnel, which still belched out occasional clouds of smoke more than 24 hours after the fire. A sign in the ticket window said simply: "We are mourning". Another rescue worker shook his head as he remembered the predominantly young skiers and snowboarders packed into the train. "They had no chance," he said. It remains unclear how the fire began. Rumours in Kaprun circulated all day with suggestions that fireworks, cooking gas canisters, a cigarette or a can of diesel on board may have been to blame. Erix Buxbaumn, Austria's head of public security, speculated that a fire on the tracks, possibly caused by an electrical fault, set the train on fire. "We have received information that the light of a fire was already visible to outside witnesses as the train was entering the tunnel," said Mr Buxbaumn. He indicated that if the driver had spotted the fire it would have been too late to stop. A second train, thought to have been carrying just a driver, was travelling down the tunnel at the time of the fire. The driver is presumed dead. Pressure is bound to mount on the cable car operating company, Gletscherbahn Kaprun, which admitted that there was no contingency plan for a fire in the tunnel. "It wasn't provided for - we were taken by suprise," said Manfred Mueller, head of technical operations. There were no fire extinguishers on board and the automatic doors are understood to have locked shut, trapping the skiiers in what within minutes became a tomb. The end would have been brief. The tunnel, raked upwards at an angle of 45 degrees, sucked up heat and smoke. Once the blaze began consuming oxygen it would have created a vacuum that set more air rushing towards it, to fan itself from a small flame into a big one. Confined fires always burn more furiously than unconfined fires, and the tunnel, drawing oxygen at an accelerating rate from below it, is a perfect example of a confined space. For those who did not react immediately, the consequences were terrible and swift. Machines are built of steel and alloy, but parts will burn, if there is enough heat around. Polymers burn furiously at around 1200 C, releasing clouds of smoke also rich in combustible gases - and poisonous ones such as hydrogen cyanide. But the main killer in such cases is carbon monoxide. webTitle: How was the US election for you?

fields.headline: 'I haven't had so much fun since the Gulf war'
fields.standfirst: Merope Mills asks key players, how was the US election for you?
fields.trailText: Merope Mills asks key players, how was the US election for you?
fields.body:
Tom Hammond - political director, CNN

We have a great many regrets. We had many problems calling the race incorrectly and we're looking at why that happened. We were part of the conglomerate that commissioned the exit polls and like all the other American networks we trusted the data we were looking at and got it wrong not once, but twice. We all share responsibility for what happened and we're going to take a good look at precisely what went wrong. Once we've determined that, we're going to make sure that there's no opportunity for that to happen again. We're still going to use exit polls because we have a pretty good record of using them and we always compete to be first. We just have to compete even harder to be right.

David Dimbleby - BBC1

Luckily, we were not on the air when the American networks called the election for Bush, having finished at 6am English time. When we were on air, what I said when Florida was first given to Gore was: "Florida has been called for Gore." I didn't say: "We're calling it," so we were reporting second-hand what the American networks were saying. And we were very sceptical about it in the studio, saying this combination of exit polling and real votes is, at best, slightly dodgy.

American elections are usually unbelievably boring to cover because nothing ever happens. But this time the emotion of it all came through to the studio guests who were swaying one way or another as the results came in. And Peter Snow's graphics were brilliant, so much better than the American networks'. Quite beautiful.

I think the American channels found the whole thing extremely discomforting. Dan Rather's face was an absolute picture. He was virtually saying he regretted it all. In every way it was very enjoyable. Confusion is always attractive. It allows you to see where people really stand. I loved it. It was well worth doing.

John Humphrys - Today

I actually put it down to the fact that I wasn't there. I've covered five presidential elections and I decided I did not want to do anymore ever again because I got bored of them. I suspect that's why it went to pieces. The coincidence is considerable. But I can't say I wished I was there - of course it's exciting but it's also a shambles. As hacks we're all talking about and patronising the frightful American media, but the fact is we've done it ourselves, haven't we? It's a case of physician heal thyself. We all want to be the first to call things and we all use exit polls and sometimes they leave us with a great deal of egg on our faces, as has happened to the BBC in the past. We're all guilty. It wouldn't be a bad idea if we concentrated more on reporting what has happened and a wee bit less on anticipating what we believe is going to happen. But, of course, if we did that the Today programme would have difficulty filling its three hours every morning.

Peter Snow - BBC1

It was very exciting and dramatic. Although Gore was behind throughout most of it, it was clear he could jump ahead when we got to California and I hope I was making that point on the programme. But the other issue was, of course, whether we were getting the real results or not. We've always taken the network polls to be pretty reliable in the past. I don't remember any other cases of having to change states from one colour to another because they'd made a mistake. It has been a lesson for everybody - us as much as them. In future we have to wonder whether, even if the network is calling it in the states, should we call it too? Unless we have our people at every count - which would be a hugely expensive operation - how on earth do we know that they're getting their call right?

The lesson for us this time is that we should explain to people in more detail precisely what we are reporting, which is essentially a forecast of a result. We need to alert the viewer to the possibility - which in this case turned out to be a fact - that this forecast could change. It's quite wrong to give a forecast until you're absolutely sure that it's right. We've learned to take them with a bit more than a pinch of salt next time.

Jeremy Paxman - Newsnight

The great slew of stuff happened after we were off the air, so I was watching all of the American channels. CNN seemed to do quite well. I don't know who was the first to start making the mistakes but all I can say is it's bad enough miscalling a state once. To miscall it twice is very, very unfortunate. I get the strong impression that the commercial pressure that they're under to be ahead of the game was certainly what led to them making such a big mistake.

John Suchet - ITN

I was on the ITN news channel and they had to prise me out of the chair because I just did not want to get up. It was the most exciting television news that I've been involved in since the outbreak of the Gulf War. The real star of our show was our Washington correspondent Tom Bradby. He just happened to walk past a TV with CBS on and heard out of half an ear that Florida was in doubt after all, and it may be that Bush hadn't won. He crashed onto the programme and half way through telling us it suddenly occurred to him he may have misheard it. He started saying, "Well John, I'm beginning to wonder whether or not I did hear that and I can only say I hope I did, and I hope I'm getting it right." Well, he was getting it right. We must have had it on air within seconds of the Americans saying it was all in doubt because of Tom Bradby's alert one ear.

Alec Russell - the Telegraph.

We had "Gore Captures Key State" as one of our early headlines but the copy did say the election was still on a knife-edge despite that dramatic early twist. That went to print just after Florida had been recalled. It was a bit unfortunate, but there was nothing we could do.

It was a superb night. It was almost like old-fashioned journalism again when front pages are being changed on a great running story. We had an edition that went at 5am so we weren't really that worried about the early editions because there was nothing you can do. When Florida was called it looked like a significant moment so we felt we had to make the point. In fact, when it was recalled it happened about five minutes before another edition went, so we breathed a huge sigh of relief - because then the final edition would have kept the fact that Gore was supposedly winning Florida. After that, two of us sort of staggered round the corner to the local hotel and slept from 5am until 8am before we started up again.

Jon Snow - Channel 4 News

I was chasing around in Washington DC between the Democrats and the Republicans and trying to find out what was going on but it was one of those moments when practical, on-the-ground journalism provided rather less than sitting in front of the television. But then sitting in front of the television provided considerable confusion.

NBC had a brilliant guy called Tim Russert and his equipment was not any sort of computer console, but rather a piece of plasticised cardboard - a kind of rub-clean effort with a washable felt tip pen. He was doing sums all night and he was basically saying that it was all down to Florida. And, of course, he turned out to be right. I thought initially the thing was some kind of elaborate joke. That perhaps their computer had broken down. But as the night went on, the camera spent more and more time transmitting this extraordinary piece of cardboard and it turned out that he was the man of the night.

But of course the thing was a shambles and is a lesson in not co-operating on exit polls. They all dived into the same dark hole of one wrong exit poll which it made it pretty difficult for the American consumer, let alone the British media, to follow.

Edward Pilkington - the Guardian

As editors, in our blood, the instinct was, how far can we go? Can we write "Gore heading for the White House"? As it happens, we were very fortunate to have Martin Kettle in Washington who had done a full list of all the states and who they would probably go to. By using that we realised that most of those states sweeping to Gore in the middle of the night were all on our checklist. So that dampened down our excitement which was very valuable because we decided to continue to be cautious and that's really how we managed to avoid any major embarrassments. We went with what we thought was certain and we'd been advised all through the night that Hillary was a certain win. It was a good decision that made us look more alive and focused than other papers. There was one very scary moment when the last edition had gone when the BBC swung over to the Hillary headquarters and said even that looked in doubt. We thought we were in trouble but our New York correspondent said that it was OK. As I was leaving the office and listening to the car radio, Lazio came on and gave his concession speech. That was a moment of relief.

Mark Dowdney - the Mirror

We had a nightmare because, like everyone else, we were misled by the early declaration of Florida for Gore. We were a bit suspicious of it even though all the American networks seemed sure. Both I and our US editor had advised extreme caution because it was so close beforehand, so we went with "Al roaring" as a headline. We didn't actually make a prediction for president and we were fortunate that there was a very, very strong home story that we could splash instead.

Julia Somerville - ITN

It was wonderful that we came out of the studio almost as ignorant as we went in several hours earlier. We reported that Gore had won Florida, but we credited the fact that it came from the networks. The highlight of the night for me, though, had to be Dan Rather saying: "Mothers of America go wake up the children and bring them down into the living room because tonight, history is being made." Wonderful old ham.

Nick Pollard - Sky News

I think it's fair to say we were very much dependent on how the American networks interpreted the Voter News Service data. We followed their lead and reported when they called the states, but my view is that they were slow realising what the story was. One of the difficulties for all of us was that, when it was clear that the entire focus of attention was Florida, it was extremely difficult to get any coverage there. My overall sense of the American networks' coverage was that it was incredibly studio-bound. So in that sense, I have to say British television covered the whole thing a lot better.

fields.trailText: Good morning and here are the media stories from today's papers. Today we expand our Monday morning briefing with a summary of Sunday Business media stories. http://www.mediaguardian.co.uk
fields.body:
Good morning and here are the media stories from today's papers. Today we expand our Monday morning briefing with a summary of Sunday Business media stories. http://www.mediatheguardian.com

THE GUARDIAN

Is there a government mole in the Dome? Senior ministers face up to the possibility of a high-level mole after a leak of cabinet minutes from a crucial meeting in 1997 discussing whether or not to build the Dome. P1-2
Mirror editor Piers Morgan hit by new claims after leaked internal emails show the Press Complaints Commission got key facts wrong in their investigation into share dealing scandal. P2
Coronation Street has been criticised by the TV regulator for being too sadistic. P7
No mobile phones allowed at Buckingham Palace. P8
Ant & Dec are being lined up for a sitcom described as the new "Likely Lads" as part of a plan by ITV to develop the stars into mass appeal entertainers. P9
The world's first global internet summit has been cancelled because of lack of interest. P9
Users of BT's mobile internet phones will soon have access to special offers from their favourite retailers. P26
MEDIA SECTION
Key media figures including David Dimbleby and Jeremy Paxman give their views on the US elections. P2-3
Maggie Brown explores why Greg Dyke's shake-up of City and business coverage hasn't pleased everyone at the BBC. P4-5
If Sun editor David Yelland thinks he can turn to the chattering classes for extra circulation he is mistaken. P6
PR supremo Julia Hobsbawm says journalists should be more honest about where their stories come from? P8
The rise of virtual brothels in Amsterdam and the impact they are having on future of TV and the internet. P8-9
Journalism and copyright on the internet. P58
Queercompany, the gay portal determined to stay out of the gayghetto. P60

THE TIMES

Anne Wood, creator of the Teletubbies, has picked up a lifetime award at this year's British Academy Children's Film & Television awards. P13
Reality TV comes under fire from Mariella Frostrup-hosted Panorama. P13
A plan to privatise Channel 4 has been ruled out by culture secretary Chris Smith. P13
Westlife beat Spice Girls in their race to claim the number one album. P13
Yes Television, the interactive TV group, will today unveil plans to become the first company to offer video-on-demand services in Australia. P25
Ratner to sell gems over the internet. P26
EMI to start detailed merger talks this week with Bertelsmann. P26

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

Mobile phones banned from Buckingham Palace amid fears that ringing tones could cause embarrassment at state functions. P5
The battle between Carlton Communications and Go Racing to secure the £750m horseracing media rights could end in a week. A photo finish is expected. P23
Incisive Media, the personal finance publishing group, aims to raise £40m on the London stock exchange. P23

THE INDEPENDENT

Downing Street begins investigation after leaked documents point the finger of blame for the Millennium Dome at Tony Blair. P1
Jenny Page, the fired Dome boss, could run the Royal Opera House. P7
Winners at the British Academy Children's Film & TV awards. P8
The World Internet Forum is cancelled after only 80 delegates sign up. P19

FINANCIAL TIMES

Whitehall seeks to quash Dome leak reports. P2
New mobile phone service to direct shoppers to the bargains. P4
Oftel faces tough questioning from MPs worried about BT opening up its local network. P4
BT is planning to seek a multi-million pound compensation claim against Vodafone and Vivendi for being frozen out of their internet alliance in France. P27
The value of mergers and acquisitions in the telecommunications industry has fallen sharply this year as expenditure on third generation mobile phones licences forces companies to focus on the balance sheets. P27

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

Bertelsmann and EMI merger likely to attract less scrutiny than Time Warner plan. P4
An arbitration ruling on a BT and Vivendi internet venture sparks more discussion on the ownership of Cegetel. P5

DAILY EXPRESS

The Beatles greatest hits album will dominate the charts in the run-up to Christmas. P5
Asian women have been excluded from massive TV campaign by health officials. P8 Is Greg Dyke turning BBC 1 into the Weakest Link? P13
The winners at the Bafta Kids TV awards. P15
Coronation Street under fire from TV regulator for being too violent. P25

THE DAILY MAIL

Documents leaked to the Mail reveal which of the rich and famous have made donations to the Labour party. P4-5
More on the leaked Dome minutes. P6
John Humphrys's tribute to cultural icon Inspector Morse, who expires on Wednesday. P13
Marks & Spencer may ditch its names as 50 stores move downmarket. P21

THE MIRROR

Big Brother star Craig tipped for £500,000 five-album deal. P7
Euan Blair has been a member of the audience for Have I got News for You and laughed at jokes about his dad. P13
One in 10 Britons now shop on the internet. P15
Leaked reports show that Blair forced Dome plans through. P21

THE SUN

webTitle: New Media Diary

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: • Word reaches the diary of more disquiet at News International's troubled internet arm News Network, or at least what is left of the division after the numerous shake-ups. The grim reaper has finally barged his way through the doors and cast his shadow over FiredUp.com and Revolver.com. A quick scout across the two sites, now residing in the intensive care department at Wapping by all accounts, is rather telling: both appear deprived of any recent attention. Revolver.com news hasn't been updated for a month and bizarrely, FiredUp.com does not, repeat does not, have any non-NI advertising at all. As always, no one is talking. In fact, no one actually knows who is still left at News Network after the staff culls of recent months.
fields.body:
 Word reaches the diary of more disquiet at News International's troubled internet arm News Network, or at least what is left of the division after the numerous shake-ups. The grim reaper has finally barged his way through the doors and cast his shadow over FiredUp.com and Revolver.com. A quick scout across the two sites, now residing in the intensive care department at Wapping by all accounts, is rather telling: both appear deprived of any recent attention. Revolver.com news hasn't been updated for a month and bizarrely, FiredUp.com does not, repeat does not, have any non-NI advertising at all. As always, no one is talking. In fact, no one actually knows who is still left at News Network after the staff culls of recent months.

 Over at Revolution towers, it seems that staff are fighting to get hold of a copy of their leader Richard Lord's new book, The Net Effect, having been given one copy to share between themselves and Internet Business. Diary's give-away comments last week created a monster, leading to more than 20 requests for said free book. Faced with such a difficult dilemma, the diary used a series of complex elimination procedures and advanced mathematics to come up with the lucky winner. You heard it here first: the fortuitous recipient is Lee Maguire of NTK fame, who pointed out that rubberburner.com was a spoof (I was duped, shocker!) I'm sure Lee will put Lord's book to very good use.

 Spare a thought for Jon Bains, chairman of agency Lateral, who is not having much luck in the sky. After his cardinal faux pas with a certain top Virgin Radio exec on a plane to New York last year, his latest airborne shenanigan almost led to him being arrested and the plane making an unscheduled landing in central Europe. What terrible thing did Bains do to get a big ticking off from the captain and a police threat? Nothing, he claims, just playing a DVD on his laptop. "How can a CD alter the navigation system?"asks Jon. Who knows. Enlightened folk, please email your answers to the usual address.

 Is it a magazine? Is it a catalogue? No, it's a Magalog (geddit?) and ready to plop out of a Maxim near you. In typical Loaded-style laddish fashion, the inaugural Firebox.com magalog oozes breasts and gadgets. Editorial judgment is sparse in the first 16 pages, where clearly the remit was to show as much cleavage as possible. Then it all starts to make sense. Read between the lines and you'll find yourself being told subconsciously to go and visit Firebox.com and buy gadgets. Clever what these marketing types are able to come up with these days.

Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: Play the service game

fields.headline: Play the service game
fields.trailText: What is the most asinine buzz phrase in television? A couple of years ago it would have been "high quality" - a term used indiscriminately and without definition to justify any programme or schedule.
fields.body:
What is the most asinine buzz phrase in television? A couple of years ago it would have been "high quality" - a term used indiscriminately and without definition to justify any programme or schedule. More recently "dumbing down" was top, itself an excruciatingly dumb accusation usually aimed at entertainment, which has always been a primary function of broadcasting. But now "public service" has sprinted up the charts. Its use and abuse are, at best, lazy and, at worst, dishonest. The forthcoming communications white paper has to grapple with what public service means in a multi-media age.

So what is public service broadcasting? Is its name taken in vain when a politician who doesn't watch television at all insists news should be not just in primetime but bang in the middle of primetime? Or when documentary makers say Channel 4 and the BBC should commission more of their work as of right? How much credence should we give to the squeals of commercial broadcasters when BBC1 revamps to present a more competitive schedule, as it has done many times before? All these positions are completely self-serving. Public service broad casting, like Humpty Dumpty's speech to Alice, means whatever they want it to mean.

An unnamed ITV executive was quoted last week as saying "BBC1 had seven hours of public service broadcasting in weekday peak last year, whereas there wasn't a single PSB programme in the same period this year." This is, of course, ludicrous. When is a programme PSB and when is it not? My own company's series, Changing Rooms, was broadcast at the time. I like to imagine it is informative and entertaining. This matches the BBC's charter. So who is to say Changing Rooms is not public service? Obviously ITV would rather BBC1 did not compete so hard since it is the only other mass audience channel. But if ITV wants to clip its wings, with PSB obligations as the weapon, it will have to do better than this.

It is time to insist on a rational approach, beginning with a truistic but useful definition of PSB: the publicly beneficial services we require broadcasters to supply in return for the privilege of the spectrum they occupy. These requirements are enforced by the government via regulators. That is all there is to it. So examples of the BBC's PSB responsibility are news and education; Channel 4 is required to provide specified amounts of multi-cultural programming; ITV must broadcast defined hours of regional programmes. We can argue that, say, the BBC's requirements should be wider, or better regulated. But it is dishonest merely to invent them as it suits.

Perhaps the woolliest attitudes are revealed by those who hark back to the "golden age" of BBC1 when Kenneth Clark strode purposefully through the schedules. He had to because there was no other terrain. The idea of scheduling Civilisation in BBC1 peaktime now would be ridiculous and pointless when there is BBC2 and, shortly, BBC3 & 4 to accommodate a whole range of programming. BBC1's job, albeit with a mixed schedule, is to remain one of our two mainstream channels with an entertainment-driven schedule.

Michael Tracey has written a lament for the supposed golden age (The Decline and Fall of Public Service Broadcasting, OUP). He sets out eight distinguishing principles for PSB, including being universally available and universally appealing, not just to broad audiences but a range of minorities too. He also singles out a commitment to public education and independence from vested interests such as advertisers. Who could disagree with such a wish list? But on a practical level such objectives need to be defined as responsibilities of particular broadcasters. They can then meaningfully be referred to as public service programmes without the prejudice and inaccuracy that currently plagues the debate.

The only useful definition of PSB is services we ask broadcasters to provide in return for the privilege of the spectrum they occupy. Broadcasters could, of course, merely be asked to pay for that privilege rather than taking on any PSB responsibilities. And all the resultant monies, along with the BBC's licence fee, could become a PSB fund for any programme makers and broadcasters to bid for. After 2006 the BBC will have to prove that it is the most beneficial way of providing the bulk of the PSB that we want. There are alternatives.

Peter Bazalgette is creative director of Endemol Entertainment UK

webTitle: Professionals binge on crack

fields.headline: Professionals binge on crack
fields.standfirst: Clubbers' taste for designer drug drives up treatment figures. Investigation  by Jason Burke, Nick Paton Walsh and Tracy McVeigh
fields.trailText: At closing time last Thursday night, Vic Taylor, a 34-year-old businessman, left his local in the quiet, respectable, middle-class area of Sale in Manchester. With four good friends, he went back to a comfortable, semi-detached house to smoke some crack.
fields.byline: By Jason Burke, Nick Paton Walsh and Tracy McVeigh
fields.body:
At closing time last Thursday night, Vic Taylor, a 34-year-old businessman, left his local in the quiet, respectable, middle-class area of Sale in Manchester. With four good friends, he went back to a comfortable, semi-detached house to smoke some crack.

For the first hour, they smoked intensely, quickly building up the levels of the drug in their bloodstream. Then they relaxed into a cycle of drink, cannabis and the small, off-white 'rocks' that give one of the most powerful and psychologically addictive highs of any drug known to man. 'We pile it on to start with for the first few, and then ease off as it takes effect,' says Vic. 'We pass round the same pipe. But it always seems longer and longer between each of your turns.'

By tonight, Vic will have spent £1,000 and not slept for three nights. Twice a month, he goes on a binge. His wife looks after his four children and, on the Friday, his staff take care of his business.

'Every so often I have a think how serious it's getting,' he said. 'Then I try to drink myself into a stupor to stop. I've never considered myself a drug person - I don't fit into that scene. I've never done heroin, Ecstasy's not for me, and neither's speed. Crack's becoming a designer drug. It's not the low-life drug it used to be.'

An Observer investigation has revealed that crack is becoming the drug of choice for a growing legion of middle-class users. The days when its use was limited to the worst of the inner-city ghettoes are over. At one London drug treatment centre, more than 60 per cent of crack addicts are in employment.

Last week drug workers spoke of civil servants, solicitors, film and video workers, small businessmen and local authority managers who had all sought help from public drugs centres in the past few months. And, they said, these were 'the tip of the iceberg'.

Adam Frankland, a worker with Turning Point, the largest drink and drugs mental health charity in the UK, said his unit in west London had dealt with six chefs and four estate agents in recent months. Chefs are said to like the drug because it allows them to keep going late into the night after an evening's work. The new brand of users is helping to boost crack figures in Britain to record levels. Police figures show that more arrested drug offenders report using crack than heroin - a historic first.

Drug workers confirm that in some areas they are treating more cocaine and crack users than opiate addicts. Figures from the Home Office's British Crime Survey reveal that one in 30 British men aged between 19 and 24 has used crack - twice as many as in 1996 and four times as many as in 1993.

When crack cocaine - which is made by heating powdered cocaine to make concentrated 'rocks' - first appeared in Britain nearly a decade ago, there were apocalyptic prophecies of mass addiction and social devastation. Many dismissed such forecasts as alarmist. Now such optimism is looking misplaced

Dr Michael Donmall, of Manchester University's Drug Misuse Research Centre, said: 'Many said that what happened in the USA could not happen here. But we have not avoided significant elements of their problems.'

The majority of crack users are still living in deprived and disenfranchised urban areas. The paranoia, violence and crime associated with the drug - crack users can easily get through £500-worth of 'rocks' in a day - causes huge, and well-documented, damage.

But the 'white-collar crackheads' are a new and different phenomenon. Many can finance their habit without recourse to theft, fraud or prostitution and are often unapologetic about their habits. Paul, an Oxbridge arts graduate, is a 37-year-old corporate communications manager with a major company in London. He has held down a successful career, married and become a father, all the while maintaining what he calls 'a recreational class-A drug habit'.

'I started smoking heroin about nine or 10 years ago with two friends, because I liked the feeling it gave me. Other people were dabbling with Ecstasy and cocaine, but I preferred something which eased my mind, not sent it racing. I didn't want to be a babbling idiot,' he said.

'I switched to crack because my regular dealer did last year. People think you have to be an addict, but that is nonsense. I have a pipe, but it comes out once every few weeks. This is something I enjoy and I have the money to indulge myself, so why the hell not?'

Such use is increasingly common. Smoked in cigarettes or with cannabis, crack is difficult to detect in a crowded nightclub.

Aidan Gray, national co-ordinator of Focus, a specialist crack research and support agency, said crack is now the drug of choice for many clubbers. In central London, smaller 'clubbing rocks', half the price and half the size of normal, are sold for around £10 each. 'Crack is more and more popular on the dance scene,' Gray said. 'There are clubs in London - and elsewhere in Britain - which are known for crack use.'

Gray said that the vast bulk of recreational crack use is undetected. 'The statistics don't reflect the scale of it at all. If wealthy people are in trouble, they will usually go to private clinics or doctors. Or they just keep using and no one ever knows.'

Nor is the problem restricted to London, Manchester and Merseyside. In the North-West, there has been a tenfold increase in cocaine use - mainly crack - in the past 10 years. In Scotland, according to some reports, the number of new crack addicts has risen twelvefold in the past four years. The police say they have detected people travelling into London from throughout the Home Counties to buy crack.

Many fear that, with the numbers of affluent crack users growing every day, the drug may lose its stigma and its dangers will be forgotten.

'You can go into work on a Monday and say you took a lot of Ecstasy last night, and these days your colleagues may not give you any grief,' said Tim Bottomley, manager of a drugs project in Manchester. 'Currently you can't do the same with crack. If crack becomes acceptable, that's when it will be most dangerous.'

Some names have been changed in this article.

In central London, smaller 'clubbing rocks', half the price and half the size of normal, are sold for around £10 each. 'Crack is more and more popular on the dance scene,' Gray said. 'There are clubs in London - and elsewhere in Britain - which are known for crack use.' Gray said that the vast bulk of recreational crack use is undetected. 'The statistics don't reflect the scale of it at all. If wealthy people are in trouble, they will usually go to private clinics or doctors. Or they just keep using and no one ever knows.' Nor is the problem restricted to London, Manchester and Merseyside. In the North-West, there has been a tenfold increase in cocaine use - mainly crack - in the past 10 years. In Scotland, according to some reports, the number of new crack addicts has risen twelvefold in the past four years. The police say they have detected people travelling into London from throughout the Home Counties to buy crack. Many fear that, with the numbers of affluent crack users growing every day, the drug may lose its stigma and its dangers will be forgotten. 'You can go into work on a Monday and say you took a lot of Ecstasy last night, and these days your colleagues may not give you any grief,' said Tim Bottomley, manager of a drugs project in Manchester. 'Currently you can't do the same with crack. If crack becomes acceptable, that's when it will be most dangerous.' Some names have been changed in this article. jason.burke@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Grossman to be hospital 'foodie tsar'

fields.headline: Grossman to be hospital 'foodie tsar'
fields.standfirst: New recipes and 'hospital waitresses' promised
fields.trailText: The American food expert and television presenter Loyd Grossman is to be made the first NHS 'food tsar' in an attempt to improve the standard of hospital meals across the country.
fields.byline: by Kamal Ahmed, political editor, The Observer
fields.body:
The American food expert and television presenter Loyd Grossman is to be made the first NHS 'food tsar' in an attempt to improve the standard of hospital meals across the country.

Officials from the Department of Health last month approached Grossman, the man known as much for his American drawl as for his recipes, to ask him to tour the country and check standards.

A panel of chefs, including Mark Hix, head chef of the restaurant group which owns the prestigious Ivy and La Caprice restaurants in London, and Anton Edelmann, head chef at the Savoy, will advise Grossman on blackspots.

They will come up with new recipes for hospital food which has long been stained with the reputation for over-cooked meat and cold mashed potato.

Grossman, who presents TV's Master Chef and Through the Keyhole , has been given a budget of £40 million over four years to tackle the problem.

He is set to recommend hotel-style service for patients, including 'hospital waitresses' who will take room-service style orders 24 hours a day.

Ward housekeepers will also ensure that the standard of food is maintained and that patients are able to choose from a menu of choices similar to a restaurant rather than ticking boxes against 'potatoes' or 'cabbage' on a form. An approved list of hospital caterers who can hit high standards will also be drawn up.

'I want to come up with some fairly simple measures which will make the patients' experience of food in hospital a decent one,' Grossman said. 'This seems to be a genuine effort by the Government to improve standards. It will benefit a lot of people.'

Government officials said that £45m a year is wasted on food that is thrown away because it has been left by patients.

A report by hospital dieticians earlier this year revealed that patients were only getting between 50 per cent and 75 per cent of the nutrition they needed from the food they were served. Some food is so poor it actually puts back people's recovery.

Research has also shown that the low standard of food is cited as one of the public's biggest complaints about hospitals. Department of Health sources said that patients do not feel they are getting a professional service and often find cold plates of food left on their bed.

Families, particularly with children in hospital, are forced to bring in food from places such as McDonald's

The elderly are often not asked about their dietary requirements and are given inappropriate food for their illness.

'Public consultation has told us it is about getting the basics right that means the most to patients,' said Health Minister Gisela Stuart. 'There are no quick fixes but we can begin by making the whole patient experience better by improving the basics of care, starting with the food that they eat.

'The NHS provides over 300 million meals each year at a cost of over £500m. It is fair to say that the food is of variable quality, it is not provided when patients want it and too much of it is wasted as a result. This is simply not good enough. Diet is an integral part of patient care and recovery.'

Hospitals have told the Government that although they support efforts to improve food standards, over-stretched budgets means that money for patients' meals is often the first to be cut.

A recent survey revealed some hospitals spend less than £2 per patient per day on food

webTitle: Net assets pay dividends

fields.headline: Net assets pay dividends
fields.standfirst: The key aspect of your university years may turn out to be what relevant experience you managed to acquire, not your degree, says Daniel Forman
fields.trailText: The key aspect of your university years may turn out to be what relevant experience you managed to acquire, not your degree. By Daniel Forman.
fields.body:
I was interviewed for my job shortly after graduating from Manchester University in the summer. As with so many jobs in new and old media, it was what I had done in my spare time at university rather than anything I had learned on my course that swung it.

NUS was looking for someone with experience of writing and editing for students. I had worked part-time for three years on my college newspaper, Student Direct, doing exactly that. The valuable and transferable skills I had developed there, working against deadlines, proofreading messy copy, writing and devising snappy headlines, were suddenly able to command a salary. Crucially, I had also gained some web experience, having helped establish an online version of Student Direct. Largely on the strength of this, I got the job.

There seems to be no clear or established route into new media jobs akin to the regional papers and broadcasters, traineeships and postgraduate courses that dominate entry into traditional media. Most schools of journalism now offer modules or whole qualifications in online journalism, but these are yet to produce a sufficient number of graduates to satisfy the considerable demand for labour of the ever-expanding web.

The majority of these jobs have been taken by experienced media professionals who have transferred their skills, be it from television or print, to the net. But increasingly graduates will want to start their careers online and, similarly, websites will want to recruit directly from university or college. What is less clear is how they will do that. Many, like me, might move quickly from amateur to professional journalism without any formal training. Others may take the route of a course to put themselves - expensively - ahead of the pack.

However there are certain factors that give any web wanabee a clear headstart. Work experience, as with all media and indeed most professions, is vital. I had spent time in the offices of newspapers and a PR firm and had had a regular holiday job in a publishing company. Work experience like this is not always easy but all the cliches about it are true: it did provide me with valuable contacts and allow me to get some work published, the sort of small advantage that can make the difference in a competitive marketplace.

A passing acquaintance with the internet is also useful. Technologically, I'm no genius. I am certainly less than fluent with html. But I've never been afraid to learn and software can do most of the tricky stuff for me. What I could do was to talk with some conviction about writing that worked well online and that did not, why some sites thrived while others went bust and the differences between an online publication and print. These insights were gleaned from hours spent in front of a screen at university, taking advantage of the combination of free net access and free time.

I had also had some experience of the NUS as a member, having attended its annual conference and been involved in my own student union. With specialist websites this knowledge of the subject matter is not essential, it can always be picked up along the way, but it was certainly a factor in getting my break. And with that break it will be easier to move on in new media with some solid experience behind me. Above all, though, I think the opportunity I got on my student publication to get my hands dirty at all levels, experiment, make mistakes, take risks and simply learn about journalism was one I would never be allowed to repeat in a professional environment.

Unquestionably I use more of what I learned in the Student Direct office on a day-to-day basis than anything I learned from a lecture. The benefits of formal training are obvious - a solid grounding in law, for instance, is as important on the web as it is anywhere else if libel suits are to be avoided. But the very nature of the web is so revolutionary that much of what is learnt one year in a journalism degree may well be outdated the next. The working practices of web journalism are also far less established than they are in broadcast or print and so it might also be difficult to know what to teach to a new media student.

The likelihood, of course, is that new media journalists will continue to be recruited from any number of backgrounds and, as with so much else on the web, those who dare to predict what will happen will be the ones who get their fingers burned.

Daniel Forman is content developer at the NUS website: www.nusonline.co.uk

webTitle: My media

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Jenny Eclair
fields.trailText: Jenny Eclair
fields.body:
Newspapers: I get the Sun every day because it makes me laugh. I also get the Guardian now and again, and buy the Daily Telegraph for the cryptic crossword. I get all the Sundays but my favourite is the Sunday Times.

Magazines: I get all the glossies - Marie Claire, Elle, and, if I'm feeling flush, Vogue. I'm too old for Cosmopolitan - I don't think I could find my G-spot now. I get Hello! and OK! and Time Out every week.

Books: I've just finished Helen Simpson's Hey Yeah Right Get a Life. It was quite expensive - £15 for under 200 pages. My book is £10 for 407, but it's quite big type. I love all the Harry Potters. My favourite book is The Swish of the Curtain by Pamela Brown - a children's book.

Films: I enjoyed O Brother Where Art Thou? even though it was toe-curling. Carrie is my all-time favourite film - I like anything that celebrates the female condition.

Television: I don't watch the soaps and daytime television. Frasier is my favourite and I also like Cold Feet and Fat Friends. I'd like to watch the news but can't remember what time it's on. I'm still a fan of Top of the Pops and enjoy Ant and Dec, Paul Whitehouse, The Royle Family and Louis Theroux.

Radio: I love Radio 4. I think they produce some very good plays and comedy. I'm a huge Archers fan. Occasionally I listen to Radio 1 and, embarrassing to admit, Jonathan Ross on Radio 2.

Adverts: I like the ones where men dress as ladies.

New media: I don't have time for the internet but I'm bowled over by email.

Jenny Eclair is a comic and writer. Her first novel Camberwell Beauty is out now.

webTitle: My New Media

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: James Black
fields.trailText: James Black, founder of petrolbusters.com
fields.body:
Favourite sites? Onepageinfo.co.uk, which I created because I needed it. It has lots of relevant links for me - search engines, reference links. My other favourite is thepaperboy.co.uk, a cracking site that has every online newspaper so you can find out what's going on virtually anywhere in the world.

Last online purchase? A domain name. I can't tell you what it was because that would give away what I'm trying to do.

Most recent technological faux pas? Hitting the reply button when I meant to forward something. It had a note attached to it which was an honest view of something that wasn't really for them to see.

Main news sources on the web? I flick through foreign newspapers and look at interesting stories, but I don't really read regular online news from the UK.

Most persistent spam emailer? On petrolbusters, there's one guy from Scotland who is always emailing us. He makes no sense to anyone anywhere, but every few days we get an update on his activities.

Time spent on web? About six months ago it would have been about five hours a day. Now, it's about five minutes a day. I don't have the time any more and I've also got four children. So I'm trying to be daddy and businessman.

Next boo.com/clickmango? Whoever is spending the most on advertising. They're always the ones to fall flat on their faces. TV advertising is a sign of lunacy. Petrolbusters had a promotional budget of £28.

Least useful site/s on web? There's one that is full of pictures of bus stops in the Ukraine. I've only been on the site once. I found it very interesting, butI'll never go back there. It's as amusing as it is useless.

Most useful site/s? It depends what you're doing. A site that has lots of links is good. I go to all the news sites from onepageinfo and if it's shopping, I don't type in the URL, I go from marketstreet.co.uk, which has got every site on it.

What screensaver do you use? I don't. At least one of your screensavers will corrupt something else.

Most irritating thing about the web? Speed, and people leaving up out-of-date stuff. Also, I wish there were arbiters who could go through sites saying "That's a damn lie".

Do you bother with old media? Yes. If people don't read the newspapers they're not going to find out about whatever site is online. The internet does not take care of itself. We need old media to bring people on board.

James Black is the founder of petrolbusters.com, which was recently sold to the TheAA.co.uk

webTitle: Northern and inner cities to get £120m in attempt to cut premature deaths

fields.headline: Northern and inner cities to get £120m in attempt to cut premature deaths
fields.standfirst: Health inequalities targeted in cash allocations
fields.trailText: Leeds, Teesside, Manchester and Liverpool will top the list of gainers from a £2bn package of spending increases for English health authorities to be announced on Tuesday by the health secretary, Alan Milburn.
fields.byline: By John Carvel, social affairs correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
Leeds, Teesside, Manchester and Liverpool will top the list of gainers from a £2bn package of spending increases for English health authorities to be announced tomorrow by the health secretary, Alan Milburn.

Mr Milburn intends to redirect resources to inner city areas with excessive rates of premature death. He will use £120m from the budget for 2001-02 to tackle health inequalities identified in an in dex of "years of life lost" (YLL). In addition to awarding funds to areas with high numbers of old people, the new formula will provide extra help for parts of the country where too many people die before 65.

Leeds will get an inequality bonus of £5m, Teesside £4.5m, and Manchester and Liverpool £4m each. Other areas with YLL increases of more than £2m will include Gateshead/ south Tyneside, east Lancashire and Salford/Trafford.

Most of the beneficiaries will be northern authorities, but the bonus will also be directed towards a few inner city areas in the south, such as east London, which will get more than £3m.

A Department of Health source said: "In the past authorities got credit for the number of old people in their area.

"That will continue, but the government now recognises the formula does not adequately recognise parts of the country where people die young. As a result resources were skewed away from areas where life expectancy was lower and where more needed to be done to tackle coronary heart disease and cancer."

Mr Milburn feels able to switch resources because the growth in next year's budget is big enough to avoid cuts in other parts of the country.

The average increase for English health authorities is expected to be more than the 6% growth in real terms promised in the last budget, following savings in other parts of the Department of Health programme.

The YLL formula in effect doubles this year's £60m allocation for tackling health in equalities. "We will ensure that choice is no longer between an NHS that simply treats illness and one that is able to do more prevention," the source said.

Infant mortality rates in the worst areas are more than three times as high as in the most advantaged areas. High rates of smoking head the list of preventable reasons for premature adult deaths.

The allocations will also provide an extra £60m to help nurses to meet higher housing costs in London and the south-east.

In a series of other financial announcements, Mr Milburn will today invite bids for at least 18 new hospital building schemes worth at least £2.3bn over the next two years. The government will also name 16 projects at existing hospitals in London, the south-east, north-west, north and Yorkshire which will share £390m for new facilities.

webTitle: 'Squalid conditions' damage patients' mental health

fields.headline: 'Squalid conditions' damage patients' mental health
fields.standfirst: Interviews of psychiatric patients reveal 'untherapeutic environment'
fields.trailText: Squalid conditions in NHS psychiatric wards are damaging patients' mental health, according to a survey published today by the charity, Mind.
fields.body:
 Squalid conditions in NHS psychiatric wards are damaging to patients' mental health, according to a survey published today by the charity, Mind.

After interviews with 343 former patients, it said more than half found their wards "an untherapeutic environment", compared with a quarter who found conditions satisfactory.

According to the survey, 30% of patients said illegal drugs were being used on the wards and 16% said they had experienced sexual harassment while in the care of hospitals.

Almost two-thirds of patients had problems getting a restful night's sleep, 45% said they did not get enough food and 31% not enough to drink.

Just under half said ward conditions had a negative effect on their mental health, compared with 27% who said they had a positive effect. Forty-five per cent found the atmosphere depressing.

webTitle: Randall set to miss out on Sunday Business bonus

fields.headline: Randall set to miss out on Sunday Business bonus
fields.trailText: 8am: Jeff Randall, who last week left Sunday Business to join the BBC as business editor, could miss out on a lucrative bonus because of fallen sales at the paper, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Jeff Randall, who last week left Sunday Business to join the BBC as business editor, could miss out on a lucrative bonus because of fallen sales at the paper.

Mr Randall was set to net a six-figure sum on his departure, if sales hit the target set at launch of 80,000 within three years, according to insiders.

A spokesman for Press Holdings, owner of Sunday Business, said that the terms of Mr Randall's exit package were "still under discussion" and refused to comment further.

Mr Randall refused to comment, but it is believed his bonus is made up of a flat cash pay-out topped up by a six-figure sum related to sales.

One source said he could stand to make more than £500,000 but that the performance-related part of his bonus will be subject to negotiation.

The latest ABC figures show the paper's sales have declined modestly - by under 1,000 to 56,807. But bulk sales for the newspaper - papers sold in batches to organisations - accounted for 16,740, nearly 30% of total sales.

The sales figures will increase pressure on Press Holdings to make editorial and strategic changes to the paper when Mr Randall steps down in March to go to the BBC.

Circulation on the paper nudged past the 70,000 mark earlier this year shortly before Press Holdings doubled the cover price to £1 - a move Mr Randall opposed.

It is thought that Press Holdings is unlikely to want to reinstate the cheaper pricing on the paper. But one insider commented "People are going to be looking very closely at the implications to the paper's long-term strategy."

webTitle: ITV's Likely Lads look to the bigger picture

fields.headline: ITV's Likely Lads look to the bigger picture
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Ant and Dec are being lined up for a sitcom described as the "Likely Lads of the new millennium", as part of a plan by ITV to develop the former children's television stars into mass appeal entertainers.
fields.body:
Ant and Dec are being lined up for a sitcom described as the "Likely Lads of the new millennium", as part of a plan by ITV to develop the former children's television stars into mass appeal entertainers.

The Guardian has learned that their new deal with the commercial network extends beyond the plans for a prime-time entertainment show which emerged last week. As well as the sitcom, they may star in films and drama series.

David Liddiment, the network's director of programmes, is impressed with the performers' potential for mass appeal, shown by the success of their Saturday morning ITV show SM:TV Live, targeted at children, and their BBC quiz Friends Like These.

The BBC had been hoping to woo the pair for a similar wide-ranging role, but the commercial lure of ITV appears to have won and Mr Liddiment has signed them up as part of his attempts to reposition the channel. While the deal does not tie them to ITV, they have no further plans to work with the BBC.

Ant and Dec - Anthony McPartlin, 24, and Declan Donnelly, 25 - have already filmed provisional material for their new comedy. It is thought the programme will build on the material from SM:TV Live. They have also held talks with Granada Television's comedy drama department, which has produced the critically acclaimed show Cold Feet.

They first starred in the children's drama Byker Grove. Their popularity soared recently - SM:TV Live gets audiences of up to 2.5m viewers against 1m for the BBC's rival Live and Kicking.

Mr Liddiment's attempts to meet the challenges of the digital TV age have to be balanced with the risk of alienating traditional audiences. While younger-minded viewers are attracted by series such as Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned and and Lily [Savage] Live, ITV's older followers will watch virtually anything that stars Bruce Forsyth or Cilla Black .

Nevertheless, since he took over, Mr Liddiment has been refreshing the portfolio of "ITV stars". He began the drive by signing exclusive deals with a number of actors, including Sarah Lancashire and brought Skinner, Baddiel and Savage to the channel. Last week the Frank Skinner Show drew almost 9m viewers, about 2m more than the BBC's flagship chat show, Parkinson.

ITV plans two major "event TV" shows for next year which are also designed to appeal to a young audience as well its traditional viewers: Popstars follows the creation of a band from auditions to the development of a CD; and Survivor! is ITV's answer to Big Brother, a game show in which participants live on a desert island.

Shows

webTitle: 365 boss hits back at rumours

fields.headline: 365 boss hits back over cutback rumours
fields.trailText: 8am: The publishing director of 365 Corp has denied he is reducing original content and has cut freelance rates, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The publishing director of the sports-to-romance media company, 365 Corp, has reacted strongly to speculation that he is scaling back on original content and has cut freelance content rates.

Danny Kelly rubbished speculation that freelance music writers have turned against the digital publishing company because it was no longer interested in paying for quality work.

"This is an four-month-old story, " said Mr Kelly, "It's just those journos who aren't writing for us any more keep bringing it back up to try to put pressure on us."

He said there were about 15 freelancers who were no longer writing for 365 because they had refused to sign the new multi-platform digital content contracts.

These contracts were introduced several months ago in order to use the content across different platforms, such as Wap, PDA and the internet.

Mr Kelly pointed out that a number of freelances refused to sign because they thought they should be paid additional money when their work is used more than once.

He added that there had been no cutbacks in original content and that 365 had, in fact, taken on more full-time staff.

Mr Kelly stressed that freelance rates had not been cut and denied that 365 had not increased its rates in line with freelance demands.

365 Corp, which has around £45m left in the bank after its IPO according to its last interims in August, employs more than 600 staff globally.

webTitle: Mirror editor hit by new share claims

fields.headline: Mirror editor hit by new share claims
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The position of the Mirror's editor, Piers Morgan, came under fresh scrutiny yesterday as leaked internal emails from the newspaper suggested that the Press Complaints Commission had got key facts wrong in its investigation into his share dealing earlier this year.
fields.body:
The position of the Mirror's editor, Piers Morgan, came under fresh scrutiny yesterday as leaked internal emails from the newspaper suggested that the Press Complaints Commission had got key facts wrong in its investigation into his share dealing earlier this year.

The emails showed that Mr Morgan informed Anil Bhoyrul, editor of the paper's controversial City Slickers page, that he had bought shares in technology company Viglen on January 17, the day before the Slickers tipped the shares.

The Department of Trade and Industry is inquiring into share dealings by Mr Morgan. It is also investigating trading by Mr Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, the two "Slickers" who were sacked by the paper in February for gross misconduct.

Mr Morgan's stock market transactions were severely criticised in a report by the Press Complaints Commission earlier this year. Yet the commission rejected one allegation - that Mr Morgan discussed his £20,000 purchase of Viglen shares with the Slickers before they tipped the company.

Mr Morgan has always maintained he bought his Viglen shares after spotting an advertisment which suggested the company was setting up an internet division. He has indicated that it was a coincidence that the paper tipped the stock the following day.

However, in an email to Mr Bhoyrul in the afternoon of January 17, Mr Morgan revealed he had switched his money from another technology firm, Pace Micro Technology, to Viglen: "I sold them this morning for bloody Viglen, congratulations, halfwit."

In their evidence to the DTI, the Slickers have alleged that Mr Bhoyrul had advised Mr Morgan that morning to switch from Pace to Viglen. Pace shares then surged at lunchtime, causing Mr Morgan to call Mr Bhoyrul a "halfwit" in mock frustration.

Trinity Mirror yesterday insisted that it was aware of the email all along. It was unable to say whether the email had been shown to the PCC during its investigation.

Mr Morgan, who is abroad, and Mr Bhoyrul declined to comment.

webTitle: 'Violent' Coronation Street censured

fields.headline: 'Violent' Coronation Street censured
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Coronation Street, folk memory of a world long gone, has been criticised by the TV regulator for being sadistic.
fields.body:
Coronation Street, folk memory of a world long gone, has been criticised by the TV regulator for being sadistic.

The episode in question, in September, had Jez Quigley trying to murder Steve McDonald for testifying against him. When Jez, who had been attacked by Steve's father, found himself in the same hospital as his enemy, he tried to smother helpless Steve, but instead collapsed and died himself, with blood dripping from his mouth; it transpired a broken rib punctured his lung.

In an implicit endorsement of the soap's place in a gentler Britain, four viewers complained that the scene was too violent for a family audience. The Independent Television Commission agreed. Yesterday it stated that Jez Quigley's character "clearly enjoys inflicting pain". Such depiction of violence was in breach of the programme code, it ruled.

Granada, the show's maker, argued the scene should have been taken in the context of the storyline: the scene was menacing rather than violent, and viewers would have been prepared for the confrontation.

However, the commission ruled "menace may itself be an issue - up to this point Jez's character had injected some humour into this violent storyline". Depicting Jez enjoying inflicting pain "could be disturbing to younger children".
