webTitle: Greenpeace joins drivers for chat, tea and a message

fields.headline: Greenpeace joins drivers for chat, tea and a message
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: One articulated lorry on the M1 was trying to go even slower than the truckers yesterday: the "fuelled up on flower power" Greenpeace bio-diesel truck,  writes Angelique Chrisafis .
fields.body:
One articulated lorry on the M1 was trying to go even slower than the truckers yesterday: the "fuelled up on flower power" Greenpeace bio-diesel truck, writes Angelique Chrisafis .

It was pulling a solar-powered trailer with eight volunteers to provide environmentally sound tea and organic biscuits for the convoy.

"We are absolutely nothing to do with the convoy," said Rob Gueterbock, Greenpeace climate and energy campaigner, as the team's compressed natural gas-powered Volvo and van slowed down to 10mph to avoid getting swept into the demonstration by over-anxious police.

Mr Gueterbock was trying not to lose sight of the convoy, but as numbers dwindled it was not always easy.

"We are here to make the link to truckers that cheap fuel means more floods as long as those fuels are based on oil," said Mr Gueterbock, looking out of the van's mirrored windows over flooded fields.

"Because of extreme weather more than 3,000 people have lost their homes this autumn, roads have been blocked and crops destroyed. Protesters wanting lower tax is like turkeys campaigning for Christmas."

Over chips and beans at the truck-stop, one haulier said that although he admired Greenpeace's persistence in trailing the convoy to London he would not touch their tea in case it gave him diarrhoea.

"They might have put something in that tea and the police have closed all motorway exits so if I get the shits, I've got nowhere to go to the lav," he said.

But he was in a minority. By yesterday afternoon almost all the protesters and their canine mascot, Minnie, had stopped at the solar powered trailer for tea in a mug saying "change your oil for good".

"Fair do to them. They are well organised and they are good conversation," said Jim Kendrick, a drain clearer from Cumbria who had joined the convoy before travelling to York to pump floodwater.

"Cor, that bio-diesel has no smell to it at all, it's beautiful," said John Warburton from Bury, Greater Manchester, an engineer who had joined the convoy in his Corsa. "We want your fuel," he was shouting outside the Greenpeace van.

A number of truckers and farmers had already signed Greenpeace's green fuel fund petition to ringfence £500m a year from petrol tax for non-oil based fuel. But the two camps did not agree on the tax issue. Greenpeace wanted higher tax on oil-based petrol and diesel.

"You're after a short-term fix," said Mr Warburton to Mr Gueterbock.

"No, no, no, you are after a short-term fix," Mr Gueterbock replied.

"So where are all your supporters then?" Mr Warburton asked. Mr Gueterbock said that Greenpeace was not there to outnumber protesters, just to make the case for the climate.

By yesterday evening, however, Greenpeace volunteers did outnumber the hauliers on the demonstration.

webTitle: Fuel protest convoy loses momentum

fields.headline: Fuel protest convoy loses momentum
fields.standfirst:
Drivers pull in for the night at 2pm after covering 36 miles
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The fuel protesters' go-slow convoy looked more like the Wacky Races than the Jarrow crusade yesterday as seven lorries, four cars and four vans left Cannock, Staffordshire, at midday, drove 36 miles down the M6 and M1 at 40mph and called it a day at 2pm.
fields.body:
The fuel protesters' go-slow convoy looked more like the Wacky Races than the Jarrow crusade yesterday as seven lorries, four cars and four vans left Cannock, Staffordshire, at midday, drove 36 miles down the M6 and M1 at 40mph and called it a day at 2pm.

"We are 24 hours ahead of schedule because the police are pushing us on so we have no choice but to go small distances each day till we reach London," said haulier Paul Stobbart at Libourne truck stop near Rugby, Warwickshire, where the convoy pulled in for the night.

Mr Stobbart, 32, who was a protester at the Stanlow refinery blockade in Cheshire in September, had brought his wife and daughter and had attached a caravan to the back of his lorry for night stops. The other protesters spent a third night in their lorries or vans.

Morale among the core of protesters was unflagging. "We are confident and we are in control," said Andrew Spence of the People's Fuel Lobby, who was leading the convoy last night. "We are heading for London and have some surprises in store for tomorrow."

The question was numbers. TV crews counted a maximum of 20 vehicles pulling in at the end of yesterday's protest. More than half of these were cars belonging to the public. But several vehicles joined the protest for a stretch on the motorway including at one point an Eddie Stobart 38-tonne truck, which pulled out minutes later after it seemed its driver had got into the wrong lane.

On arrival at Rugby, John Coxon of the People's Fuel Lobby, who had sent a car to count the numbers on the motorway, said there had been 223 vehicles on the M6 protest. The press said the maximum was nearer 40. In the protesters' camp there was continued talk of 40 lorries joining from Bedford today but there had earlier been talk of 40 lorries joining from Cumbria and then the south-west and these have not yet materialised. By last night television documentary makers outnumbered hauliers.

Some protesters were running out of money. Tony Finlay, 28, from the Less Tax on Fuel campaign, joined the convoy at Durham in an F-reg Fiesta. He is not a haulier and is unemployed but he had spent £51 on fuel by the time he reached Staffordshire and yesterday had only £5 left.

"Other protesters have given me some diesel, but I only have three-quarters of a tank left. I just hope it gets me to London. I'm not stopping. I'm going to keep going until the fuel runs out."

West Midlands police yes terday took the numbers of the protesters' vehicles and made them carry identifying stickers. Protesters claimed police had filmed them from unmarked motorbikes.

Hauliers and farmers said the media had put protesters off joining the convoy by skewing reports of its size.

"The government is leaning on the media," said Arnold Pennant, a farmer from Denby who was at the Stanlow blockade.

As the convoy headed south Gordon Brown yesterday swept aside threats from the European Union to challenge his plans to introduce a "Britdisc" scheme to make foreign hauliers pay to use British roads. The move is part of the government's pre-budget efforts to buy off the fuel protesters.

Over the weekend the EU's transport commissioner, Loyola de Palacio, signalled concern about the Britdisc. Under EU law the proposal must not discriminate against drivers from any EU state. British truckers will have other road taxes adjusted to make up for the cost. But Mr Brown told BBC1's Breakfast With Frost: "I am not going to have the commission telling us in Britain that when we want to have a fair system of paying fair licence fees for foreign hauliers using British roads we can't do it."

webTitle: Bin Laden: the question facing the next US president

fields.headline: Bin Laden: the question facing the next US president
fields.standfirst: As the Taliban prepares to complete the takeover of Afghanistan, Luke Harding reports on the Islamic group's banker, and his challenge to the west
fields.trailText: As the Taliban prepares to complete the takeover of Afghanistan, Luke Harding reports on the Islamic group's banker, and his challenge to the west
fields.body:
If either of the US presidential candidates had dropped into southern Afghanistan last month, he might have spotted a fleet of brand new Land Cruisers heading west towards the mountains.

Inside one of the vehicles, a tall, 43-year-old Saudi dissident by the name of Osama bin Laden, was busy plotting his next move. As his convoy sped away, towards the remote Hindu Kush, the chances of a Cruise missile landing anywhere near him in the immediate future receded almost to nothing.

And yet one of the new president's first decisions - assuming he ever makes it into office - will be whether to launch another US missile strike against Afghanistan.

The signs are ominous. Over the weekend, the US positioned its naval ships a few miles away from the Pakistani coast, in readiness for a possible attack.

Since October 12, US investigators have been searching for hard evidence implicating bin Laden in the attack on the USS Cole in Yemen, in which 17 US sailors died. But bombing his deserted camp would be a futile and preposterous gesture.

The fact that Afghanistan is in such a mess, and run by an Islamic fundamentalist movement, is, after all, partly the fault of the US.

It was the US that helped to train and equip the Mujaheddin back in the 1980s, as they waged their war against the invading Soviet Union.

One of the fighters who benefited from such US largesse was an obscure volunteer from Saudi Arabia with close links to its royal family - Osama bin Laden.

In 1986 the CIA even helped him build an underground camp at Khost, where he was to train recruits from across the Islamic world in the business of guerrilla warfare.

Twelve years later, the Americans bombed the same camp after holding bin Laden responsible for the devastating US embassy bombings in east Africa.

Some 34 people were killed in the Khost attack. Bin Laden left the camp an hour earlier.

By this stage, American policy had come full circle. The cold war over, a new generation of Mujaheddin leaders had sprung up - the Taliban.

Bin Laden's jihad against communism was transformed in the 1990s into a war against the west in general, and the US in particular. Having played Frankenstein, the CIA is now chasing after its very own monster.

Another missile attack will merely add to Afghanistan's misery. The country is already in the thrall of a massive and unreported humanitarian catastrophe.

In the south and west, there has been virtually no rain for three years. The road from Herat, close to the Iranian border, to Kandahar, the southern desert city, winds through a series of half-abandoned villages and giant empty riverbeds.

Some 12m people have been affected; of whom 3m are close to starvation. Pakistan's decision, last week, to shut its border with Afghanistan, has cut off the only escape route for drought-affected families.

When the UN imposed sanctions a year ago because of the Taliban's refusal to hand over bin Laden, the suffering in Afghanistan increased. The move has not hurt the elite Taliban, who are well off.

They continue to receive generous support from Pakistan. It is ordinary Afghans who have suffered.

Those in jobs earn a salary of around $4 a month, not enough to live on. Women who have been forbidden by the Taliban from working congregate outside the few functioning restaurants in bombed out Kabul every lunchtime, in the hope of getting something to eat.

The US is right about the nexus between bin Laden and the Taliban's secretive spiritual ruler, Mullah Mohammed Omar. The two men speak every day on their satellite phones and go fishing together - sometimes with grenades, sources say.

Mullah Omar is even rumoured to have married one of bin Laden's daughters, a claim that the Taliban deny.

Bin Laden, a multi-millionaire, continues to bankroll the Taliban's war in the northeast. His own Arab fighters take part in the battle at the frontline. No amount of US pressure is likely to persuade Mullah Omar to give up bin Laden.

The Taliban may be medieval. They are certainly uncompromising. And they are often barbarous.

But the uncomfortable reality for western policy makers is that they now control 95% of Afghanistan. With help from Pakistan, the US's erstwhile cold war ally, the Taliban are poised to complete their victory over the opposition led by General Ahmad Shah Masood, possibly as early as next summer.

If Mr Bush or Mr Gore ever make it to the White House, they need to begin a robust but constructive dialogue with Afghanistan.

The alternatives are far worse: the spread of jihad, and the spectre of an Islamic revolution in nuclear Pakistan.

webTitle: Folk singers to teach university degree

fields.headline: Folk singers to teach university degree
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Newcastle University is to launch England's first degree in traditional and folk music, with some of the country's finest singers and instrumentalists hired as tutors.
fields.body:
Newcastle University is to launch England's first degree in traditional and folk music, with some of the country's finest singers and instrumentalists hired as tutors.

Students will take a range of modules and will be given intense tuition on instruments which could range from the fiddle to Northumbrian pipes.

The music studied will come from the whole of the British Isles, including the Irish Republic, and tutors could include singer Sandra Kerr, piper Kathryn Tickell and Shetland fiddler Chris Stout.

The first group of up to 25 students will join the course next year and will be based at the university; after that students will work at the new music centre about to rise on the banks of the Tyne at Gateshead.

The course, based in part on courses operating in Scandinavia, is an academic recognition of the cultural value of traditional music, a form often mocked despite its occasional appearances on CDs contending for a Mercury prize.

The BMus course has been promoted in conjunction with Folkworks, an educational charity established in 1988 by the pipe and concertina virtuoso Alistair Anderson and arts manager Ros Rigby to promote traditional music, dance and song.

webTitle: Leader: Schama's drama puts the stars to shame

fields.headline: The history man
fields.standfirst:
Schama's drama puts the stars to shame
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Top of the list - over 7,000 copies sold last week, more than 22,000 since publication - is the autobiography of David Beckham. Not far behind come the Beatles; two memoirs of singers soaring to superstardom; one in much the same vein from Terry Wogan; the life of a motorbike ace; and more Posh 'n' Becks. Seven of the top 10 hardback non-fiction titles in the regular Whitaker Booktrack/Bookwatch lists belong to the world where sport, showbiz and celebrity meet.
fields.body:
Top of the list - over 7,000 copies sold last week, more than 22,000 since publication - is the autobiography of David Beckham. Not far behind come the Beatles; two memoirs of singers soaring to superstardom; one in much the same vein from Terry Wogan; the life of a motorbike ace; and more Posh 'n' Becks. Seven of the top 10 hardback non-fiction titles in the regular Whitaker Booktrack/Bookwatch lists belong to the world where sport, showbiz and celebrity meet. Two others come out of Dundee: Our Wullie 2001, featuring "a naughty wee boy with a bucket" from a DC Thomson comic, and The Friendship Book 2001, garnered from Woman's Weekly.

And yet, right up at number two, with 5,000 copies sold last week and over 18,000 in all, is a book by someone who never played for Manchester United and may never even have owned a bucket, let alone been naughty: the historian Simon Schama, with his History of Britain, part 1. Of course he would never have got there without the aid of a branch of showbiz, in the form of his linked TV series which ends on BBC1 tonight. Not everyone has approved. It seems to be all kings and queens, some complain. It is almost all about England, with Scotland and Wales and Ireland reduced to the status of places where battles happen.

Yet the turbulent, often bloody evolution of church and state which has been Schama's agenda so far is inevitably dominated by aristocratic big hitters. And in any case, no one, least of all Schama, pretends that his work is definitive. The glory of the exercise is the way it seems to have worked up a taste for well-told history which, with luck, will lead people on to other historians, in whose hands social and economic history can be every bit as enthralling. And surely, the discovery that Schama's account of Britain till Queen Elizabeth is outselling Anthea Turner's account of herself by a margin of 40 to 1 is a matter for celebration, not cavilling.

webTitle: Media Monkey

fields.headline: Media Monkey
fields.trailText: Monkey hears with regret that plans are under way for Jimmy Young, now in his mid-70s, to stand down from his Radio 2 slot next year.
fields.body:
Monkey hears with regret that plans are under way for Jimmy Young, now in his mid-70s, to stand down from his Radio 2 slot next year. But who could combine the legend's skills at spinning discs and interviewing prime ministers? This dilemma is thought to have led Radio 2 to Radio 5 Live's Nicky Campbell. But direct poaching within the big happy BBC radio family is frowned on and Campbell himself seems to be keener on current affairs talk than reverting to pop and prattle (sorry, political debate). Perhaps Simon Mayo who is musing on a move to 5 Live afternoons next year, should skip straight to Radio 2?

 In tribute to Peter Jay's theories of niche writing (his famous rebuke to a baffled sub-editor that his piece was written for just three people in the country and that the sub was not one of them is certainly Monkey's journalism motto), Monkey would like to remind him of a now potentially embarassing encounter from his past with his new colleague, Jeff Randall. Randall, who last week swiped the "BBC business editor" half of Jay's title, was once an impressionable 20-something aspiring hack who won an essay prize which took him to a rather grand party in Washington DC. There he was shepherded around the great and the good by a well-meaning professor who boomed, "That's your ambassador over there, you must say hello. Peter Jay, come and meet one of your brightest citizens over here." An overawed Randall was somewhat downcast to be entirely overlooked with a dismissive stare by the then high-flying ambassador. Let's hope he doesn't bear grudges.

 After ITV gave its BBC News rivals a pasting with a week of news specials on the floods, the BBC responded with a half-hour edition of its own. The current affairs department was apparently livid that the Panorama team didn't produce the show, which was edited by the ratings-minded Mark "Pops" Popescu of the Six O'Clock News. A source at BBC newsgathering reveals the reason why the Panorama lot were reduced to merely a contributing role: "They were too slow, too busy thinking about it while we got on and did it. And anyway, we've got all the waders."

 The appointment of a chief executive for the ITV network looks as remote as ever. No progress has been made, despite the desperate bleatings of advertisers. In fact the whole thing has been pulled back for a rethink, says a relaxed Leslie Hill, network chairman. This is due to the emergence of Granada (with Carlton) in the driving seat and a more cheery mood as autumn seems to go ITV's way. It's one way to save £500,000 a year.

 With no series from Armando Iannucci's gang announced in the just-unveiled winter 2001 season, Channel 4 staffers turn tight-lipped and ashen-faced when the Day Today maestro is mentioned. And you can see why: it was back in March 1999 that Michael Jackson, who commissioned the Saturday Night Armistice at BBC2, proudly announced that he'd poached the team back, and in the spring channel high-ups were predicting a series this autumn; now the earliest one could appear is April. A record gestation period for comedy?

 Radio 2 may be getting trendier, but the list of "defining artists" of the 70s, 80s and 90s who will top the playlist of its digital spin-off, Network Y, suggests uncertainty away from easy-listening territory. Among the defining artists of - presumably - the 70s are: the Beatles (disbanded 1970); the Beach Boys (effectively disbanded 1967); Jimi Hendrix (died 1970) and Janis Joplin (died 1970). Not classified as defining artists of any decade, on the other hand, are Madonna, Prince and Oasis.

 Channel 4 is planning the second series of Big Brother, to be screened some time next year. One idea under consideration, apparently, is to start the show off with two houses and merge them later, just as Survivor! starts off with two tribes on a desert island who come together for the finale. One lot of insufferable egotists was bad enough, but some C4 execs are balking at the prospect of a double dose of Nasty Nicks. Meanwhile the channel has been boasting to its advertisers that the press frenzy over Big Brother 1 pulled in coverage worth £15m if the same space had been bought for ads, and "in excess of £50m" taking into account that it was editorial. Monkey is proud to note that the top four papers who contributed to this were the Sun, the Star, the Mirror and the Guardian.

 CNN's London office went to great pains and expense last week with a glitzy US election night party in the River Room of the Savoy, providing champagne and canapes throughout the night for all those Brits not on the US Embassy guest list. The place was packed: those attending included David Elstein, Lord (Marmaduke) Hussey, Norman Lamont, and a huge flock of MPs - just the right sort of opinion-forming gathering for CNN to flaunt its election coverage . . . Ah well. Never mind.

 Patricia Hodgson, chief executive of the independent television commission, is reaping a great deal of criticism for her performance at a recent Royal Television Society seminar on the forthcoming communications white paper. This is because she told the audience that a draft of the document had been circulated to regulators, for their comments and input, in September. Monkey was delighted to have light shed on the mysteries of bill-drafting, and the way vested interests have their say - but those mere mortals who have been told not to expect a word on the paper until December are a little puzzled and hurt at being excluded.

Catch up with the Monkey every day at: www.mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: We want porn

fields.headline: We want porn
fields.standfirst: Virtual brothels in Amsterdam, not head-scratching mainstream broadcasters, have sorted the future of television and the web. Guy Davies  and  Anthony Wonke
fields.trailText: Virtual brothels in Amsterdam, not head-scratching mainstream broadcasters, have sorted the future of television and the web.
fields.body:
The sex business is clever. It helped establish VHS as the video format of the past 20 years. It relied on a silent yet enormous market for material, millions of enthusiasts who realised that a small machine in the living room meant they no longer had to hide projectors under the bed, or take the risk and creep into Soho clubs.

Today, the same business is driving another revolution - the internet. The phenomenal demand for porn and the ease of access via the net has put the new young e-businesses that supply it at the forefront of a media revolution. The audience for adult material is computer literate - research by the Adult Channel in the UK shows that the rate of computer ownership is significantly higher for those who log on to their SXTV site than the national average.

The epicentre of the development of adult material via the web is Amsterdam. When Channel 4 asked us to make a series about the liberal city, we saw first hand exactly how the sex industry is driving internet business expansion. It has been so successful that in as little as two years, pornography will have broken through the barriers of broadband technology, building on its current pre-eminence in ADSL and video on demand.

While broadcasters in the UK scratch their heads and wonder where they fit in with this technological progress, young, dynamic companies such as Amsterdam's Interclimax, which we found and filmed behind the scenes for Channel 4, have solved the problems and are making big money. With more than 1m visits a day, the Interclimax site is an extraordinary commercial success, and adult channels in the UK are beginning to look at these businesses to see what lessons can be learned.

When you walk into Interclimax in Amsterdam, it's like walking into a sexual Big Brother. Cameras are everywhere in the "voyeur house", including the toilets and under the receptionist's seat. Many of the girls live in and it feels like a 21st-century version of the Nevada brothel Nick Broomfield filmed in Chicken Ranch.

Downstairs, 21 chat rooms are taking hits from punters 24 hours a day. The ambience recalls an upmarket facilities house in Soho, not a sex business. Interclimax pumps out movies on associated websites, and traffic on its main site (even with its stop-frame action) is building every day. Credit card details ripple through the screen as money is taken - it is porn chat and action on demand. One of its most valued employees is the wonderful Natasha, whose job is to spend all day every day digitising hardcore gay porn for transmission. Only in Amsterdam.

But Interclimax's founder, ex-porn star Claudia Von Lubak, sees herself as running a media business that just happens to be about hardcore sex. "We are constantly expanding and in two years we aim to float on the stock market with full support from Dutch banks. They don't care what we produce just as long as we make money," she says.

In the meantime Interclimax is busy receiving 40m visits a month, producing its own porn films to be shown online and setting up a specialist porn and sports internet magazine to crack the vast Asian PC market. Many companies see Asia as a lucrative gap to be filled while other clients are tucked up in bed in the middle of the American or European night.

The audience for adult material may not be vocal, but its characteristics and habits are one stage evolved from the average viewer. A combination of the arrival of the web and the growth of premium sports and movie channels is developing a pay-per-view culture in the UK, but in porn this is already well established.

This audience is used to subscription and last-minute decisions. The Adult Channel describes its highly successful pay-per-night service as "an impulse buy". The sex business has cleverly realised that it has a product that people will seek out and buy, and the financial success this brings puts companies such as Interclimax at the forefront of media developments.

Convergence, via broadband, will allow adult businesses to become broadcasters, driving ever-increasing traffic to sites and services which are all metered. The UK audience is becoming far more tolerant and interested in hardcore material and now has the means to purchase it discreetly and at a low cost.

Jeremy Yates, deputy managing director of the Playboy Channel UK, which includes the hardcore subscription Adult Channel, is noticing the change day by day: "We're seeing the chat room for our show SXTV absolutely clogged around transmission. This is full-on sexual conversation in Britain. We know in many homes it's not just single men online, it's couples watching the show from bed with the PC to hand." The Adult Channel's long-term plan is to combine both TV and online experience - and broadband technology will make this happen.

In Amsterdam's sex industry the money is in the internet, not the red-light district. We soon realised in filming that the showcase sex theatres were a contracting part of the market. Toine Rodenburg, who managed the site for the famous Casa Rosso sex theatre, told us: "From here we take the material, use a private line to send it to an overseas server and put it out all over the world."

The material in this case was a British couple in their 30s who came to the city with a fascination for the sex business. Their job was to have penetrative sex for up to eight hours a day on a small podium in a wired-up attic at the top of the theatre building. It's shift work and they loved it.

Lulu and Boots's sexual stamina was pushed to the limit while they wondered about the people, many regulars, who would log on to watch them and come back night after night. For Lulu it is not just the physical demands of performing sex for eight hours, but the mental strain of "chatting" with up to 70 online punters in one go. "The hardest thing to deal with is the virtual hecklers who get irate and call you a dirty slag in capital letters. You also have to be diplomatic and patient, as regular subscribers get pissed off if you can't remember their fetish for black knickers."

Even reborn as a global media business, the sex trade chews people up. The girls we met working the chat rooms are mainly from eastern Europe, often needing money quickly to send back to their families. Those who live in at Interclimax are looked after, they share dormitories and security is good - but the reality is that many speak little English and are alone in an unfamiliar city. Many girls stay only a few weeks in the voyeur house and the chat rooms. Their lives revolve around the fantasies and messages from clients on the screen. Many leave, and Von Lubak never hears of them again.

After we finished filming them, Lulu and Boots decided go into business themselves. They're currently setting up their own website where they combine live sex with special shows and theme nights. They will also provide the subscriber with information about things to do in Amsterdam when not watching them have sex.

They have no plans to return to Britain, which they still see as uptight about sexual expression. But the reality is more complex. The internet/ broadband potential for adult material is changing the Britain they left.

webTitle: How to go green

fields.headline: How to go green
fields.standfirst: As world leaders meet to talk (and talk) about global warming,  Ros Coward offers 10 practical steps we can all take to help save the planet
fields.trailText: As world leaders meet to talk (and talk) about global warming, Ros Coward offers 10 practical steps we can all take to help save the planet.
fields.body:
Today, world leaders are meeting in the Hague to discuss climate change and what - if anything - can be done to combat global warming. Their discussions will be full of abstractions about "carbon trading" and "flexible mechanisms". But for many us here, the issue has suddenly become far from abstract. Extreme weather conditions have brought home the fact that our climate is changing - and changing fast. It may be easy to be fatalistic about it, but the truth is that although we humans have caused the problem, we also have the solution. "Think global and act local," said Friends of the Earth founder David Bower, who died last week. In many small but important ways we can make a difference. Here are my top tips for how to begin:

1 Count your food miles

What you eat and where you buy it affects global emissions. Pollution from transport is the fastest growing source of carbon dioxide emissions, so it is madness to fly out-of-season vegetables across the world to supermarkets. Supermarket treatment of British food is also absurd; centralised distribution means food is taken miles by lorry to another area, often returning back to the starting point. We should lobby supermarkets for a system of classifying food according to the distance travelled: 0 for local food, 1 for British, 2 for Europe, and 3 for intercontinental. Better still, we should shop at farmers' markets. Local growers get more money: less transportation means less pollution. Ideally, says Sustain, "You should also buy organic, not just for health reasons but because it is sustainably produced. It avoids conventional pesticides which are petro-chemically based, and it uses more human labour which is renewable energy."

2 Airmiles: no smiles

By 2020, there will be 1.56bn tourists, double the current numbers. We should think about the impact of our own journeys. Are there alternatives to flying? Could we manage without hiring a car? How can we conserve energy in our host country (other than sleeping by the pool all day)? The Association of British Travel Agents found 85% of British tourists on package holidays believe it is important not to damage the environment. But the vast majority don't do anything: only 18% said they switched off air-conditioning in hotels to save energy, only 17% said they ask for towels not to be washed daily.

3 Recycle this newspaper

Use the recycling bin. Astonishingly, the UK still only recycles between 8% and 9% of everything that can be recycled. Newspapers, magazines and notepaper make up 30% of household rubbish. Waste disposal is a major contributor to greenhouse gasses. Even better, avoid buying things you don't really want, and shun unnecessary packaging. What better time to start than in the run-up to Christmas. "Making things to throw away uses up natural resources and wastes energy," says the Women's Environmental Network, "only buy what you need. Buy goods that are durable, that have components which can be re-used or recycled."

4 Turn off anything that winks at you

A video recorder on standby uses almost as much electricity as one playing a tape. Small changes in small habits make big differences. Turning down the thermostat by one degree, not leaving TV and music centres on standby, turning off lights, putting lids on cooking pots, and only half-filling kettles can cut energy consumption by 30%, saving you money as well as saving the planet, as they used to say in more innocent times.

5 Buy your electricity at the windfarm

This is one the door-to-door power sales sharks won't offer you, but you can buy green energy if you ask. Many suppliers now offer it. For some suppliers it means investing in the development of renewable energy technology, such as wind power. Others pledge to use energy from existing renewable energy supplies, putting into their supplies green electricity to match the amount used by green consumers. Future Energy runs an accreditation scheme to check suppliers are as green as they claim. Friends of the Earth will soon publish a green league table so you can compare suppliers. So far only 16,000 have signed up, significantly less than in green-conscious Germany and Holland. If 1m chose green energy in the UK, 5% of our power supplies would be renewable, considerably reducing harmful emissions.

6 Do the obvious: lag the loft

We all know about saving energy in the home, don't we? In reality only 1.4% of the population has bought energy-efficient white goods such as dishwashers or washing machines even though 50% claim they have, according to a survey by WWF and Energy Saving Trust released today. One quarter of the UK's overall carbon dioxide emissions come from our homes but less has been done to reduce pollution from this area than any other. Each house emits six tonnes of carbon dioxide every year, more than the average car. Simple improvements, such as lagging the loft, fitting double-glazing and using low-energy light bulbs make a huge difference. People know about these but are surprisingly ignorant about other things they can do. When you buy new appliances, look for the European Union eco-symbol: energy-efficient appliances use 25% less energy than ordinary ones.

7 Let the worms do the work

Half of all our waste is biodegradable. Buy a kitchen compost bin; it can save as much as a ton of rubbish per household per year. You can even help the process. Women's Environmental Network's home composting guide says: "Wee on it - the nitrogen accelerates the process." To take this to its logical conclusion, arrange a natural burial for yourself or a loved one. Green Burials offers the woodland coffin which comes flat packed and can be assembled in 10 minutes. It is ideal for a woodland burial.

8 Leave the rainforest where it is

Check all wooden furniture and timber comes from sustainable sources. Rainforests may not be the fashionable symbolic cause they once were, but they are still the planet's lungs. Their products pop up all over the place. WWF says the only guarantee that timber comes from forests which are socially and environmentally well-managed is Forestry Stewardship Council approval. Only buy wood with the FSC symbol.

9 Just stop using petrol

Yes you can, and the car industry may (eventually) help you. Hydrogen-powered cars are loved by car designers and could become a reality in about 10 years. Meanwhile, consider converting to liquified petroleum gas (LPG). You won't be alone: a new pump for this is opening every day. Visit the Powershift website to find out how. Meanwhile, you can cut down on conventional petrol use just by changing driving habits - the one positive lesson that can be learned from the fuel protests: no rapid acceleration, lower speeds, keeping tires at the right pressure. Join the Environmental Transport Association. It offers all the services of the AA and RAC, but is not part of the road lobby.

10 Well, you can always walk

Or cycle. The majority of car journeys are less than five miles and, honestly, once you've stepped out, you'll find it's really not that bad. The only energy used is your own and that's healthy. You only have to look at the collective girths of the people's fuel lobby to know this makes sense.

These changes will save you money which you should invest in an ethical saving account. They are profitable and they put the pressure on business to clean up its act.

Contact Energy Efficiency Hotline 0345 277 200

Useful links
Friends of the Earth's website: www.foe.org.uk
World Wide Fund for Nature's website: www.panda.org
Women's Environmental Network website: www.wen.org.uk
Energy Savings Trust's website: www.est-powershift.org.uk and www.saveenergy.co.uk

webTitle: BA Concordes may fly soon

fields.headline: BA Concordes may fly soon
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: British Airways is virtually certain to fly Concorde alone if the investigation into the Air France crash drags on indefinitely, Whitehall sources confirmed last night.
fields.body:
British Airways is virtually certain to fly Concorde alone if the investigation into the Air France crash drags on indefinitely, Whitehall sources confirmed last night.

On the eve of an Anglo-French meeting in Paris to examine progress on the accident investigation, the sources backed BA's view that Concorde will fly again as soon as possible.

The remaining stumbling block is the reissuing of the plane's certificate of airworthiness by the civil aviation authority. The certificate was withdrawn pending a CAA inquiry into possible flaws in Concorde's fuel tanks. According to a preliminary report by investigators into the Air France Concorde crash near Paris in July, in which 113 people died, the fuel tanks could have been hit by debris from the tyres or the runway.

The Whitehall sources said BA had wanted to await the outcome of the French investigation and relaunch Concorde at the same time as Air France. But if the French inquiry goes on for months, BA may act by itself.

BA has been cooperating with the CAA and the aerospace industry in producing a modification to the design to protect the fuel tanks.

Reports from within the industry suggest that the British inquiry is almost complete, and that its findings will satisfy the CAA. A certificate of airworthiness for BA's seven Concordes, it is said, would then be a formality. BA's service between Heathrow and New York could restart by the summer. BA has continued to pay its Concorde staff of 200 and pilots are being kept fully trained.

The crash has raised doubts about how long BA can continue to fly Concorde, even though the Air France disaster was the first in Concorde's 25 year history. The original plan was to fly it beyond the end of the decade, but it seems likely that it will have to be withdrawn from commercial service before then.

webTitle: Saverfone offers Wap retail service

fields.headline: Saverfone offers Wap retail service
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Users of British Telecom's mobile internet phones will soon have access to special offers from their favourite retailers.
fields.body:
Users of British Telecom's mobile internet phones will soon have access to special offers from their favourite retailers.

Although the take-up of Wap (wireless application protocol) phones has proved disappointing, mainly because the text-based service failed to live up to the initial hype, new services are being added to try to attract customers.

Next month Saverfone, launches a Wap-based marketing system along with retailers ranging from Austin Reed and F Hinds to Country Casuals and Maplin.

Wap-phone users, estimated to be 1.2 million by January, will be able to receive details of special offers via their phones.

Saverfone research suggests as many as 79 per cent of consumers make unplanned purchases at least once a week and special offers provide a strong incentive when it comes to making a purchase.

But the same research also found a strong resistance from people to receiving a general flood of unsolicited marketing messages on their mobile phones. As many as 59 per cent of people surveyed did not like this idea, which has already launched in the United States.

The Saverfone service will allow consumers to chose the retailers from whom they wish to receive special offers. They can block those they are not interested in.

The consumer pays nothing for the service apart from the time spent online and for a trial period it is also free to retailers. Saverfone says that after that period is over it will decide how much to charge retailers.

webTitle: Met police chief backs employing 'minor' criminals

fields.headline: Met police chief backs employing 'minor' criminals
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The head of the Metropolitan police yesterday defended a decision to allow convicted criminals to join the force in an attempt to boost recruitment.
fields.body:
The head of the Metropolitan police yesterday defended a decision to allow convicted criminals to join the force in an attempt to boost recruitment.

Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the Metropolitan police, confirmed that applications from potential officers convicted of "minor" offences would be considered for the first time.

The move, which was implemented in September by chief superintendent Alan Given, head of the Met's new recruitment task force, was condemned as "a dire lowering of standards" by Glen Smyth, chairman of the Metropolitan Police Federation, which represents 25,000 officers; by the National Police Federation, which represents officers in England and Wales; and by Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary.

However, Sir John insisted that those guilty of serious offences would not be recruited. "We are not taking criminals on in the Metropolitan police," he said on BBC1's Breakfast With Frost.

"We are looking to see if people have convictions for speeding or for not having a TV licence, for instance, and that type of offence or any offence that might take place 15 years ago.

"I think people like that are entitled to join the police, provided, of course they have got the right references when they want to join."

The Met needs 25,600 officers to police London and is 500 officers short this year, according to Sir John.

In addition retirement, death, and officers leaving the force has left the capital with a 3,000 shortfall.

Police applicants have to declare previous convictions on their initial form and until now, a criminal record disqualified them. "The whole idea of the policy is to try to rule people in rather than to automatically rule them out," said a Scotland Yard spokeswoman. "We will be more flexible in considering applications. Non-payment of a TV licence or traffic offences will not exclude potential officers.

"Those individuals will still have to justify their recruitment by passing the interview stages, the medical and the physical tests.

"We're not wanting to lose someone who may turn out to be a talented officer just because they once committed a minor offence," she said.

The spokeswoman was not able to say whether anyone with past convictions had passed the selection process under the new rules.

Mr Smyth described the move as "incredible". He argued that it would place officers in the uncomfortable position of patrolling with colleagues they had once arrested.

"You can envisage a situation where officers who have a service record as long as mine have to deal with those they have encountered as juveniles," he said.

He added that serving officers could face dismissal for offences that potential recruits had committed and it could lead to officers being forced to admit previous convictions to defence lawyers in court.

Scotland Yard said the review of recruitment carried out by chief supt Given made several recommendations including lifting the ban on applicants with tattoos. The Met is also considering relaxing the rules on the stipulation that hair must be "short and tidy" to encourage more black recruits, who may have dreadlocks, to apply.

The Met needs 25,600 officers to police London and is 500 officers short this year, according to Sir John. In addition retirement, death, and officers leaving the force has left the capital with a 3,000 shortfall. Police applicants have to declare previous convictions on their initial form and until now, a criminal record disqualified them. "The whole idea of the policy is to try to rule people in rather than to automatically rule them out," said a Scotland Yard spokeswoman. "We will be more flexible in considering applications. Non-payment of a TV licence or traffic offences will not exclude potential officers. "Those individuals will still have to justify their recruitment by passing the interview stages, the medical and the physical tests. "We're not wanting to lose someone who may turn out to be a talented officer just because they once committed a minor offence," she said. The spokeswoman was not able to say whether anyone with past convictions had passed the selection process under the new rules. Mr Smyth described the move as "incredible". He argued that it would place officers in the uncomfortable position of patrolling with colleagues they had once arrested. "You can envisage a situation where officers who have a service record as long as mine have to deal with those they have encountered as juveniles," he said. He added that serving officers could face dismissal for offences that potential recruits had committed and it could lead to officers being forced to admit previous convictions to defence lawyers in court. Scotland Yard said the review of recruitment carried out by chief supt Given made several recommendations including lifting the ban on applicants with tattoos. The Met is also considering relaxing the rules on the stipulation that hair must be "short and tidy" to encourage more black recruits, who may have dreadlocks, to apply.

webTitle: Three boldly go to market

fields.headline: Three boldly go to market
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Despite plunging share prices and investor apathy, three technology companies will today brave the icy waters of the new issue market and announce plans for stock market listings.
fields.body:
Despite plunging share prices and investor apathy, three technology companies will today brave the icy waters of the new issue market and announce plans for stock market listings.

Stephen Moore, 36, a former builder of exhibition displays will become the latest dot.com millionaire when the company he founded two years ago, Expocentric, lists on the London Stock Exchange on Wednesday.

Expocentric provides technology services to the international exhibitions markets. Running in parallel with physical exhibitions Expocentric offers exhibitors a virtual version of their stand for use in cyberspace, allowing visitors from all the over the world to "attend" exhibitions.

Ahead of the listing Expocentric raised £31.5m via a placing of 17.7m shares with institutions at 192p. This valued the company, which intends to use the proceeds to develop its business on an international scale, at £112.2m and Mr Moore's holding at £24.5m.

Mr Moore said: "The strong response from institutional investors reflects the enthusiasm that exists for our market leading exhibition technology."

Meanwhile, Comeleon will today announce plans to raise a minimum of £7m via a placing of shares with institutions and a listing on the Alternative Investment Market (AIM).

Comeleon is looking to cash in on the trend for personalising mobile phones with replaceable covers. It has developed a printing technique that allows high quality images to be reproduced on plastic.

The Newcastle-based company plans to use the cash raised in the placing to increase its manufacturing capacity. Comeleon is currently applying for full Nokia process approval which if obtained will give the company direct access to Nokia distributors in 56 countries in Europe, Middle East and Africa.

UbiNetics, a wireless telecom group, will today reveal that it has raised £50m through a private placing with blue chip institutions including Fidelity and Schroders as a precursor to a stock market listing in London next year.

The company, spun out of PA Consulting Group, develops and manufactures wireless testing. It has two main businesses: one division specialises in developing equipment for the next generation of mobile phones, allowing network operators a chance to test their products in a fully functional simulated environment. The other develops off-the-shelf solutions, which enable laptop computers and personal digital assistants (PDAs) to access the web without the need for a fixed telecom connection. As part of the placing PA Consulting invested £15m and will retain a 66% stake.

The company intends to invest £100m in further product development, manufacture and distribution over the next two years.

webTitle: Software police run anti-piracy program

fields.headline: Software police run anti-piracy program
fields.standfirst:
Bounty-hunters are tempted with £10,000 rewards
Net news
fields.trailText: In a secret location in London a team of internet investigators surf the net hunting for sites that publish pirated software. Fed with leads from emails, a phone hotline and tip-offs from industry sources the Business Software Alliance works to stem the flow of unlicensed software online.
fields.body:
In a secret location in London a team of internet investigators surf the net hunting for sites that publish pirated software. Fed with leads from emails, a phone hotline and tip-offs from industry sources the Business Software Alliance works to stem the flow of unlicensed software online.

"We keep the location a secret to protect our staff from reprisals by angry pirates," says Margo Miller, head of the BSA's European enforcement unit.

The web is the latest battlefield in a piracy war which, the BSA estimates, last year alone cost the software industry worldwide £7bn in missed revenue.

"In the UK 26% of new business software installed last year was illegal," says Miller. "That's one in every four computers running a complete suite of pirated programs."

And that is before the figures for games and non-business software are factored in. Industry insiders estimate the total amount of illicit software installed stands closer to 35%.

The BSA's sponsoring partners include Adobe, Macromedia, Microsoft and Symantec. "If you take that figure of 35%, then we missed out on $50m in sales last year," says Sue Thexton, vice-president of Macromedia Europe.

"All that could have gone towards research and development costs."

Miller says: "Every single software product you can think of is available somewhere illegally on the internet. You can get everything from direct program downloads, serial numbers and cracked software, to compilation CDs put together by professional racketeers who sell pirate software through online stores and in auction sites."

In the past three months Miller's team sent out 846 "cease and desist" warnings to ISPs (internet service providers), 91% of which lead to the closure of offending web sites. Online auction sites are a particular problem - BSA investigators found over 80% of software sold there was illicit.

On the web, professional fraudsters run only a small portion of the pirate software, or "warez", sites. Most sites are "not-for-profit", run as a service for friends. "We find many warez sites are run by teenagers," says Miller.

Dan, a 15-year-old schoolboy from Alberta, Canada, recently set up a site offering everything from the latest version of Microsoft Office, to the graphics package Adobe PhotoShop and scores of PC games.

Pornography

"Lots of warez sites are full of pornography and dead links. I wanted to create a site where you could find what you wanted quickly without having to click through tens of ads," he says. Dan uses one of the big free online US sites to host the illicit files. "That way it's easier to set up again if someone closes you down. I don't see I'm doing any harm. The people who use this software usually can't afford the real thing anyway, like students. No one is losing anything."

Miller sees things differently. "I think we perhaps should make an example of one of these kids to send a message that piracy is illegal in every form."

Steve Keyser, owner of Tera-byte, the ISP that hosts Dan's web site, can't see what the fuss is all about: "If you follow through half the warez links I think you'll usually find there's nothing at the end, just endless ads. And the software you do find probably doesn't work, or might well have a virus in it. You'd be a fool to use pirate software."

Yet millions of people do. For the BSA and ISPs alike the problem is that as soon as one site is shut down another will pop up under a different name or on another ISP. Type "warez" into any search engine and the list of matching sites will run to hundreds of thousands. With a little persistence you will find what you want.

Though most ISPs co-operate with the BSA, there is a hard-core of defiant companies which ignore the organisation's demands. Miller suspects these are probably run by pirates themselves. "In the UK alone there are three ISPs who have not complied with our repeat warnings. We are considering legal action if they do not come into line soon," she says.

Mike Newton, who lobbies the European parliament for the BSA, says: "ISPs should take responsibility for what is on their servers. We will be publishing guidelines for ISPs in a few months. But there's no use tackling this just in Europe. It is a global problem and we have to have global laws."

The BSA has announced a reward of up to £10,000 for information on organisations using illegal software. Meanwhile, Microsoft is taking matters into its own hands. The company announced a truce to anyone using pirated software: "It's not an amnesty," explains Julia Phillpot, Microsoft UK's anti-piracy manager.

"If you've bought a packaged copy of a Microsoft product that looks like the real thing and you have proof of purchase we will swap the package for one authentic unit." The aim is to build up evidence of professional pirate traders to help with future legal action against them.

Microsoft is installing anti-piracy precautions in its next release of Office. "We have built in what we call the Office Automation Wizard," says Phillpot. "It's an online registration system that is very hard to break. If, after 50 uses, you don't register your new software then the program will lock up until you do."

But with the imminent introduction of broadband internet access, and the increased popularity of file-sharing systems like Napster, Hotline, Gnutella and Freenet, downloading pirated software from the net will soon be as quick and easy as sending an email.

Laurence Westwood, chief investigator at the Foundation Against Software Theft, admits the situation is going to get much, much worse: "With the introduction of these file sharing systems and as bandwidth increases we're going to have a very big headache."

Robin Hood

For Nick, a London music producer in his late twenties, the rise of online piracy is inevitable: "I've long used Hotline (an ancestor of Napster) to get all my software. I've downloaded thousands of pounds worth to my machine. It's just a way of life, and once the download speeds increase I'm sure everyone will be doing it."

For others getting software free is a matter of Robin Hood-like pride: "I never pay for software if I can help it," says Bill, a web designer.

"The industry is rich enough as it is, and the corporations pay more than enough for their software licences. Most people can't afford it anyway, why should they start paying now?"

Meanwhile Miller and her minions will keep on hunting. But the smart money would be wise to think of a business model that avoids piracy altogether, rather than try to fight the flood.

webTitle: High court to rule on Bulger pair's right to privacy

fields.headline: High court to rule on Bulger pair's right to privacy
fields.standfirst:
Straw backs ban on revealing killers' new lives after jail
Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: A high court judge will be asked today on behalf of the two killers of James Bulger, who are now 18, to extend the bar on the media publishing information on them when they get out of jail.
fields.body:
A high court judge will be asked today on behalf of the two killers of James Bulger, who are now 18, to extend the bar on the media publishing information on them when they get out of jail.

If they succeed, they will create case law that could open the door for Myra Hindley, Rosemary West and other killers to assume new identities protected from disclosure on their release.

Lawyers for Jon Venables and Robert Thompson will ask Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court's family division, to extend a temporary ban on publicity, even though they have passed their 18th birthdays.

There is no precedent in English law for a blanket ban on publication to protect a childhood killer who subsequently reaches adulthood.

An injunction protecting Mary Bell, who was convicted in 1968 for killing two small children when she was aged 11, was in fact granted to protect her daughter; the latter was made a ward of court for the purpose, and her protection will lapse in a few years' time when she reaches 18. If Thompson and Venables win their case, she will be able to apply for a publicity ban in her own right.

Dame Elizabeth granted the two a temporary injunction in July, just before they turned 18 in August. She decided it would be unfair to make a final decision without hearing full argument "on the difficult issues, raising points so far untouched in English law which will be likely to affect other cases".

In a three-day hearing that starts today, lawyers for four newspaper groups, led by News Group Newspapers, will argue against the injunction. Lawyers for the home secretary, the attorney general and the official solicitor will endorse the plea by Thompson and Venables that the ban should be extended.

Lawyers predict that the pair will succeed, though the case could go as far as the House of Lords. They were boys of 10 when they abducted the two-year-old and battered him to death on a railway line in Liverpool in February 1993.

Last month Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, recommended that their tariff - the minimum term in prison required for retribution and deterrence - should expire immediately.

They could be released on licence as early as February, with new identities to facilitate their reintegration into society. Their lawyers argue that this would be endangered if the media were free to publish pictures of them or details about their new lives.

The case will be the first important test of how the English courts will weigh up the competing rights of privacy and freedom of expression since the Human Rights Act came into force last month. The act incorporated the European convention on human rights into British law - making its guarantees, including privacy and free speech rights, enforceable in UK courts.

Venables's QC, Edward Fitzgerald (who also acts for Hindley), will argue that the young men's right to a private life, and the restriction on the right of free speech that prevents the disclosure of information received in confidence, entitle them to an injunction.

A further argument, backed by the home secretary and the attorney general, is that there is a statutory right to rehabilitation, continuing after release on licence, and this would be defeated by allowing publicity.

Mr Fitzgerald won a ruling last year from three appeal court judges, headed by Lord Woolf, which will give strength to this argument.

In a case brought by Broadmoor special hospital to try to stop publication of a book by a schizophrenic patient, the judges ruled that courts can grant injunctions to prevent interference with the performance by public bodies of their public responsibilities.

webTitle: Northern and inner cities to get £120m in attempt to cut premature deaths

fields.headline: Northern and inner cities to get £120m in attempt to cut premature deaths
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Leeds, Teesside, Manchester and Liverpool will top the list of gainers from a £2bn package of spending increases for English health authorities to be announced tomorrow by the health secretary, Alan Milburn.
fields.body:
Leeds, Teesside, Manchester and Liverpool will top the list of gainers from a £2bn package of spending increases for English health authorities to be announced tomorrow by the health secretary, Alan Milburn.

Mr Milburn intends to redirect resources to inner city areas with excessive rates of premature death. He will use £120m from the budget for 2001-02 to tackle health inequalities identified in an in dex of "years of life lost" (YLL). In addition to awarding funds to areas with high numbers of old people, the new formula will provide extra help for parts of the country where too many people die before 65.

Leeds will get an inequality bonus of £5m, Teesside £4.5m, and Manchester and Liverpool £4m each. Other areas with YLL increases of more than £2m will include Gateshead/ south Tyneside, east Lancashire and Salford/Trafford.

Most of the beneficiaries will be northern authorities, but the bonus will also be directed towards a few inner city areas in the south, such as east London, which will get more than £3m.

A Department of Health source said: "In the past authorities got credit for the number of old people in their area.

"That will continue, but the government now recognises the formula does not adequately recognise parts of the country where people die young. As a result resources were skewed away from areas where life expectancy was lower and where more needed to be done to tackle coronary heart disease and cancer."

Mr Milburn feels able to switch resources because the growth in next year's budget is big enough to avoid cuts in other parts of the country.

The average increase for English health authorities is expected to be more than the 6% growth in real terms promised in the last budget, following savings in other parts of the Department of Health programme.

The YLL formula in effect doubles this year's £60m allocation for tackling health in equalities. "We will ensure that choice is no longer between an NHS that simply treats illness and one that is able to do more prevention," the source said.

Infant mortality rates in the worst areas are more than three times as high as in the most advantaged areas. High rates of smoking head the list of preventable reasons for premature adult deaths.

The allocations will also provide an extra £60m to help nurses to meet higher housing costs in London and the south-east.

In a series of other financial announcements, Mr Milburn will today invite bids for at least 18 new hospital building schemes worth at least £2.3bn over the next two years. The government will also name 16 projects at existing hospitals in London, the south-east, north-west, north and Yorkshire which will share £390m for new facilities.

The government will also announce this week the appointment of the TV chef Loyd Grossman as unpaid adviser to the NHS on improving the standard and nutritional value of hospital meals. Chefs including Anton Edelmann of the Savoy will advise him on new recipes in a £40m upgrade of hospital catering.

 Squalid conditions in NHS psychiatric wards are damaging to patients' mental health, according to a survey published today by the charity Mind.

After interviews with 343 former patients, it said more than half found their wards "an untherapeutic environment", compared with a quarter who found conditions satisfactory.

According to the survey, 30% of patients said illegal drugs were being used on the wards and 16% said they had experienced sexual harassment while in the care of hospitals.

Almost two-thirds of patients had problems getting a restful night's sleep, 45% said they did not get enough food and 31% not enough to drink.

Just under half said ward conditions had a negative effect on their mental health, compared with 27% who said they had a positive effect. Forty-five per cent found the atmosphere depressing.

webTitle: Hijacked Russian plane lands in the desert

fields.headline: Hijacked Russian plane lands in the desert
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: A bizarre hijacking operation, in which a Russian domestic flight diverted in the middle of the night from its route to Moscow to an airfield in the Israeli desert, was peacefully resolved yesterday with the surrender of the man responsible.
fields.body:
A bizarre hijacking operation, in which a Russian domestic flight diverted in the middle of the night from its route to Moscow to an airfield in the Israeli desert, was peacefully resolved yesterday with the surrender of the man responsible.

No one was able to explain why the lone hijacker had undertaken the highly dangerous operation, which swept 58 passengers and crew thousands of miles across the world in an ageing Russian Tupolev 154, running critically low on fuel.

Israeli officials described the man - believed to be a Chechen national carrying a fake bomb - as "disturbed" and said his demands had been wildly contradictory, rambling and incoherent.

All of the crew and passengers - most of them Dagestani football fans who had been hoping to see their team play in Moscow -left the Vnukovo Airlines plane unharmed, after the hijacker gave himself up to Israeli security forces.

Nevertheless, that the incident occurred at all threatened to prove embarrassing for the Russian security forces and an investigation was expected.

The aircraft took off from Makhachkala, the capital of Dagestan, which borders Chechnya to the east, where security measures have been placed on high alert since the start of Russia's campaign in the region last year.

The Dagestani finance minister was travelling on the plane, accompanied by four armed bodyguards from the Russian security force, the FSB. The hijacker, who was unarmed, is understood to have persuaded them to hand over their weapons.

At first it was believed that the hijack was an attempt to bring the Chechen rebels' cause to the world's attention, but later there was confusion over what had motivated the hijacker to start threatening to blow up the plane unless the pilot diverted to Israel.

Israeli officials said he had initially declared he was supporting the Palestinians in their continuing uprising against Israel, but subsequently claimed to be backing the Chechens' campaign for independence from Russia. Later he produced video and audio tapes, and two letters - one addressed to the "emperor of Japan" - warning of a conspiracy for world dominance by the Japanese.

During negotiations, the hijacker said he had been sent by his father to pass on a message "to the world and the emperor of Japan"; he had been instructed to deliver the two letters which "warned the world about the yellow race taking control of the white race," according to the chief of the Israeli army's southern command, Major General Yomtov Samia.

Gen Samia described the statements and the letters as "a load of nonsense, which indicate the mental condition of the writer and of the hijacker".

A Russian embassy official, who travelled to the military base in the southern Negev desert where the plane had landed, agreed that the hijacker "needs a psychiatric examination".

Confusion deepened when a Dagestani official tentatively identified the hijacker as Zagir Guseinov, a Chechen national living in Dagestan, who had a previous criminal record and was "an active member of extremist organisations".

Israeli sources said the man was called Amarchenov Avmerchan, but gave no further details.

The crisis began late on Saturday night, soon after the plane had taken off from Dagestan. Initially, the hijacker demanded that the aircraft fly to Tel Aviv, but permission was refused and the plane was directed to the desert airfield.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, was travelling to the US for talks on how to end recent Israeli-Palestinian violence at the time of the hijack. His plane changed direction twice as Mr Barak decided to return to Israel to help resolve the crisis, then decided to press ahead to Washington when the hijacker surrendered.

webTitle: Officehours: A change of boss can be trying

fields.headline: Bristles over a new broom
fields.standfirst: A change of boss can be trying, but there are advantages, says  Annabelle Thorpe
fields.trailText: A change of boss can be trying, but there are advantages.
fields.body:
'They say some bosses are closer to their secretary than to their wife - and at times it really felt like that with John," says Claire Trattles, who worked for five years as PA to the finance director of a publishing company. "We spent so much time together; and if he was out, we'd speak on the phone three or four times a day. I knew his favourite places for lunch, what he thought of all his clients, what perfume to buy for his wife. He had a very happy marriage, as I did, but our relationship was so comfortable. He could be stroppy at times, but so could I. Everything was very equal."

The happy state of affairs came to an abrupt end when Trattles' boss announced he was taking early retirement. "I was horrified," she admits. "I guess I thought things would just continue the same way. The worst of it was that, because he wasn't going to another job, I couldn't move with him. I was really upset, and when the new candidate was appointed, I couldn't help comparing him constantly with John."

This, according to business psychologist Charles Kay, is a serious error. "It can be hard to lose someone with whom you've had a close working relationship, but once that person has left the company you have to move on," he says. "If you try to compare a person you don't know with someone you have worked with for years, they are invariably going to come off worse. It's imperative to give the new person time to settle in, and allow time for you to get to know them."

"It's getting easier, slowly," admits Trattles, "but it's a totally different sort of relationship. He's incredibly pernickety - he wants to see and sign everything and I feel almost as though I've been demoted. Logically, I know that he's new to the job and he just wants to ensure that everything is running smoothly, but I can't help resenting his manner - it's like he's constantly behind me, looking over my shoulder."

In many ways, it is inevitable that a new boss will bring his or her own ideas and methods of working, but if these seem to be changing the PA's role, it is important to try to address the problem.

"It's not uncommon for a secretary or PA to come to see me if they have a new boss," says Martine Morgan, human resources director for a large consulting firm. "They may feel that they have lost some of their areas of responsibility, or that the new manager doesn't have the same trust in their abilities. It can be quite an insulting feeling and it does make people resentful.

"We advise them to talk about it with their manager, to say that they feel they are capable of more. It may be that the new manager hasn't realised the PA's competency and is simply working the way they did with their previous secretary."

Sometimes, however, a new boss can be like a breath of fresh air. "When my boss left I was quite relieved," says Jeanne Wade, who works in a large IT firm. "David was a really nice guy but he was totally disorganised. He was always forgetting meetings or lunches, he'd lose memos or forget he'd sent letters out, and blame me. It was never meant nastily, but whatever structures or administrative systems I tried to put in place never worked."

When a new boss was appointed, Wade took the opportunity to change the way she worked. "I was determined to present it as if things had always been this way," she says. "I made up whereabouts sheets, got a second desk diary so that I could have my own for him, pencilled in a weekly time for him to have a meeting with me. I was determined to try to take control of how things would be done from an administrative perspective, and make it seem that this was how I'd always done things."

"Close relationships at work are very positive, but they also mean things can get stuck in a rut," says Kay. "If you get on well with someone, and work comfortably together, it can be very difficult to instigate change. But when a new person joins, it can be a fresh start - there is no history between the two of you and it's a chance to streamline your working methods.

"Think about your old manager and rather than just thinking about how wonderful he was, try to remember what annoyed you about him, what made your working life difficult. Then put in place structures to ensure that it doesn't happen with the new boss. Try to concentrate on what you may have gained, rather that what you have lost."
