webTitle: Officehours: From recruited to recruiter

fields.headline: From recruited to recruiter
fields.standfirst: It's not uncommon for secretaries to become recruitment consultants. And, as  Bill Saunders  reports, their knowledge of life on the other side of the desk is invaluable
fields.trailText: It's not uncommon for secretaries to become recruitment consultants. And, their knowledge of life on the other side of the desk is invaluable.
fields.body:
By the age of 26, Jo Bareham found that her career had reached an impasse. At the time, she was working in the compliance department of a bank, doing the administrative work necessary to keep the bank on the right side of the financial regulations. She wanted to progress, but when she tried to change jobs she encountered a familiar problem. "The banking agencies wouldn't consider me because I was a secretary," she says. "And the secretarial agencies weren't listening to what I wanted."

Then, on her trip round the agencies, it was suggested to her that she should consider a career on the other side of the interview desk. It was not an idea that would have occurred to her, although her CV included a short spell in a human resources department. The change of career was a risk - even her parents voiced doubts on the matter - but four and a half years later she is happy she made the switch.

In case you have ever wondered where recruitment consultants come from, Bareham's story is far from unique. About a quarter of her colleagues at Joslin Rowe, where she began her new career and where she still works, have secretarial experience. Bareham herself would never consider working in any other field of recruitment. Having been there herself, she knows how secretaries feel. "I can understand their frustration," she explains.

She is also in a position to understand how and why secretaries all too frequently fail to exploit their potential. It is well known that most secretaries hope that their current jobs will prove a stepping stone to something else. Over on the recruitment side of the desk, there is wide agreement that these hopes are well-founded.

"Secretarial skills are highly transferable," says one recruitment consultant at Maine-Tucker who also made the jump from secretary to her current position. She should know, having joined a recruitment consultancy as office manager with a view to forging a career in recruitment. The job appealed to her, she says, because "it uses such a wide variety of skills". But she also liked "the autonomy, being in charge of your own desk."

For Bareham, this new independence was the scariest element of the change. She found it easy to establish rapport with her candidates, but going out to sell herself to potential clients was initially intimidating.

Of course, making the jump is far easier if you know where you want to land. For many secretaries, the problem is that they feel they could do more, but have no idea where they want to go. In which case, says the consultant at Maine-Tucker, they should cast the net wider and be more open-minded about where they work.

Mark Rodgerson, head of the secretarial division at secretarial re-cruitment consultancy Zarak Hay, cites the case of an ambitious secretary who was committed to banking. He persuaded her to try a job in a shipping firm. In a comparatively short time she was promoted to partner.

Nevertheless, a certain amount of of pessimism can creep in. Sally, who is almost 30, is a secretary at a firm of surveyors and utterly miserable in her job. She would like to move on, but, she says, "this is all I know how to do".

With the benefit of a view from both sides of the interview desk, how would the PAs-cum-consultants steer secretaries towards improving their job and career prospects? According to Bareham, there is one common flaw in CVs which can be easily amended - provided the candidate is prepared to invest the time. "Education is very important, especially as far as the banks are concerned," she says. "I often find myself advising a candidate to go to college part-time and improve their grades, especially if they are young."

Education aside, there are other influences at work, not of all of them fair. Personality is a big factor. Bareham confesses: "I have had candidates with weak CVs but marvellous personalities, which is great. I can send them out straightaway."

Personality is difficult to change, but the answer to the problem is to match the personality to the job. "Loud people don't go down very well in back office jobs, such as compliance," says Bareham, "and quiet types should stay away from the trading floor."

A degree of unfairness is unavoidable in the secretarial job market, however, which is why you need a recuitment consultant on your side. A similar administrative position will pay £25,000 in one bank and £18,000 in another for no particular reason. Moreover, some people underestimate their own potential. Bareham recently saw a graduate candidate in search of a junior secretarial position. Instead, she steered her into a job which involved research, and which also had the potential to return her to the job market with far stronger prospects.

The campaign to improve your career should begin with your current job, says Bareham. "It is important to be recognised for what you are doing in the company you are in." There is little to be gained from everyone realising how much they will miss you after you have handed in your notice.

Jumping back to the other side of the desk, how should secretaries assess a consultant? Bareham is disarmingly candid: the point of the consultant is to get the candidate a better job. "My reputation is on the line over this, so obviously there are some people out there who think I am a great recruitment consultant and others who think I'm useless." But life as a recruiter is not always quite as brutal as this. "I do get candidates ringing me up and saying someone else has found me a job, but I wish it had been you, you've done so much for me." This, says Bareham, is about the highest accolade she could wish for - and it does happen.

From her own days of job-hunting, she recalls visiting consultants who would go through the interview process without even discussing the job she had enquired about. This naturally creates a bad impression, and rightly so. A good recruitment consultant should take the trouble to talk to the candidate and make her (or him) feel as if she is the only person the consultant is working for.

In point of fact she won't be. A typical recruitment consultant will have about 100 candidates on the database at any one time. It is not surprising, then, that Bareham lists a good memory as an important asset for a consultant. But there is also an onus on the candidate to make sure she or he is remembered. It is important to keep in touch, even if it is just via the occasional email, to remind a consultant that you are still out there, and still hungry.

webTitle: Officehours: WPM

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: Image isn't everything, of course (although WPM would be the last to complain if a clothes/hairstyling allowance were to be bundled in with her benefits package), but it's true to say that, in certain jobs, you've got to look the part.
fields.body:
 Image isn't everything, of course (although WPM would be the last to complain if a clothes/hairstyling allowance were to be bundled in with her benefits package), but it's true to say that, in certain jobs, you've got to look the part. Sportswear and stilettos would be a little out of place on the reception desk at a swanky law firm, but might go down a storm . . . well, somewhere or other.

But these things are fairly easy to judge once you've joined a company, been shown the ropes and been teased for your taste in patterned tights. Interviews are the real hurdle, throwing you up against Important People right from the start and rarely allowing you any opportunity to sneak off to the toilets to revise your power suit for a pair of combats. But then again, they're not judging you on your appearance, are they? They've got your job history, your effusive references, your witty responses on the application form to go on.

So if that form asked for your bust size or enquired about the trouser-filling ability of male candidates, it might not set your mind at ease about the kind of judgements likely to be made about you at interview (provided, WPM supposes, that your statistics proved satisfactory enough to get you through to that stage). O'Neill's, the pub chain behind this unorthodox recruitment tactic, was contrite last week: "We do look for staff to work in O'Neill's who have a sense of humour," - come to think of it, WPM does find the busty barmaid a rather hilarious concept - "but if any offence has been caused we apologise unreservedly and accept that one of our managers may have overstepped the mark in this particular case."

Never mind the manager - spare a thought for existing staff at the pub in question (O'Neill's, Back Wynd, Aberdeen, for the lustily curious), who might find themselves under a little more scrutiny than usual this week.

 As might all of us office workers within the next few years, if dire warnings from the Recruitment Society turn out to be true. According to the society's Steve Huxham, within two years we can all expect genetic testing to be part of the application package, so family history could become as important as job history. Maybe even more important - after all, will your long years of experience count for much if tests reveal that you're "predisposed" to any number of conditions that wouldn't be too welcome in the office?

It's hard to see exactly what employers could gain from such highly personal information, unless it's all part of a plan to crack down on time lost by staff organising whip-rounds for flowers and fruit baskets. Of course, it could be that talk of genetic screening is designed to avert our attention while they stick the needle in for other purposes. The prospect of drug testing in the workplace - on a voluntary basis - looms large; it wasn't too long ago that it was reported that government ministers themselves might be asked to give a sample on a Monday morning. When asked if the practice could spread to the Houses of Parliament - where traces of cocaine have allegedly been picked up in the toilets - the government's drugs czar, Keith Hellawell, was reported as saying, "To be honest, I'm not sure if it qualifies as a workplace." So, if the trend heads towards your office, you know what excuse to use.

 A bit of a crisis could be in store for some employers then: soon to be faced with the agonising choice of hiring potential genetic timebombs or - and a worrying number of firms do seem to have a problem with this - Old People. Waking up to the fact that age discrimination is alive and kicking in our workplaces, and jolted into action by predictions that the over-45s (hardly ancient, WPM concedes) will account for 40% of workers by 2010, the House of Commons' employment sub-committee is to investigate the problems of ageism. Those with something to say on the matter should send emails to mulley@parliament.uk by January 19. If nothing else, it should be proof for less enlightened bosses that it's not just bright young graduates who know how to operate computers.

 Further proof would be to check out this week's chosen website, www.netstationers.co.uk the UK's first fully online office supplies site. It does all the usual stuff - envelopes, correction fluid, you know the drill - but all rather cheap and all rather swiftly delivered (by noon the next day). And to the end of the month, spending £100 will earn you Boots vouchers. So if that image does need a little rethink . . .
fields.bodyText:  Image isn't everything, of course (although WPM would be the last to complain if a clothes/hairstyling allowance were to be bundled in with her benefits package), but it's true to say that, in certain jobs, you've got to look the part. Sportswear and stilettos would be a little out of place on the reception desk at a swanky law firm, but might go down a storm . . . well, somewhere or other. But these things are fairly easy to judge once you've joined a company, been shown the ropes and been teased for your taste in patterned tights. Interviews are the real hurdle, throwing you up against Important People right from the start and rarely allowing you any opportunity to sneak off to the toilets to revise your power suit for a pair of combats. But then again, they're not judging you on your appearance, are they? They've got your job history, your effusive references, your witty responses on the application form to go on. So if that form asked for your bust size or enquired about the trouser-filling ability of male candidates, it might not set your mind at ease about the kind of judgements likely to be made about you at interview (provided, WPM supposes, that your statistics proved satisfactory enough to get you through to that stage). O'Neill's, the pub chain behind this unorthodox recruitment tactic, was contrite last week: "We do look for staff to work in O'Neill's who have a sense of humour," - come to think of it, WPM does find the busty barmaid a rather hilarious concept - "but if any offence has been caused we apologise unreservedly and accept that one of our managers may have overstepped the mark in this particular case." Never mind the manager - spare a thought for existing staff at the pub in question (O'Neill's, Back Wynd, Aberdeen, for the lustily curious), who might find themselves under a little more scrutiny than usual this week.  As might all of us office workers within the next few years, if dire warnings from the Recruitment Society turn out to be true. According to the society's Steve Huxham, within two years we can all expect genetic testing to be part of the application package, so family history could become as important as job history. Maybe even more important - after all, will your long years of experience count for much if tests reveal that you're "predisposed" to any number of conditions that wouldn't be too welcome in the office? It's hard to see exactly what employers could gain from such highly personal information, unless it's all part of a plan to crack down on time lost by staff organising whip-rounds for flowers and fruit baskets. Of course, it could be that talk of genetic screening is designed to avert our attention while they stick the needle in for other purposes. The prospect of drug testing in the workplace - on a voluntary basis - looms large; it wasn't too long ago that it was reported that government ministers themselves might be asked to give a sample on a Monday morning. When asked if the practice could spread to the Houses of Parliament - where traces of cocaine have allegedly been picked up in the toilets - the government's drugs czar, Keith Hellawell, was reported as saying, "To be honest, I'm not sure if it qualifies as a workplace." So, if the trend heads towards your office, you know what excuse to use.  A bit of a crisis could be in store for some employers then: soon to be faced with the agonising choice of hiring potential genetic timebombs or - and a worrying number of firms do seem to have a problem with this - Old People. Waking up to the fact that age discrimination is alive and kicking in our workplaces, and jolted into action by predictions that the over-45s (hardly ancient, WPM concedes) will account for 40% of workers by 2010, the House of Commons' employment sub-committee is to investigate the problems of ageism. Those with something to say on the matter should send emails to mulley@parliament.uk by January 19. If nothing else, it should be proof for less enlightened bosses that it's not just bright young graduates who know how to operate computers.  Further proof would be to check out this week's chosen website, www.netstationers.co.uk the UK's first fully online office supplies site. It does all the usual stuff - envelopes, correction fluid, you know the drill - but all rather cheap and all rather swiftly delivered (by noon the next day). And to the end of the month, spending £100 will earn you Boots vouchers. So if that image does need a little rethink . . .

webTitle: Sec's tips

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 11. Training courses
fields.trailText: Been on another training course? Did it fill you with enthusiasm and good intentions? Or did you get nothing out of it, and leave as soon as you could, to return to a desk overflowing with messages? Training is a key part of your career, but you need to know how to make the most of it.
fields.body:
Been on another training course? Did it fill you with enthusiasm and good intentions? Or did you get nothing out of it, and leave as soon as you could, to return to a desk overflowing with messages? Training is a key part of your career, but you need to know how to make the most of it.

 Take responsibility for your own training . Don't be fobbed off with any old course with "secretary" in the title, but think about what you, personally, need. Plan with your boss, in an appraisal, for example. Think about the skills you may need in the future.

 Choose training carefully . Don't go by the course title, but get a list of contents and learning objectives, and make sure at least 80% is relevant to you. Be wary of those which promise to revolutionise your working life in one sitting.

 Don't just roll up on the day. Think about the course beforehand and make a list of three priorities you want fulfilled by the end of it. If those don't appear to be forthcoming, speak to the trainer during a break and ask if these areas will be covered. If not, ask where you may find help - do they have other notes?

 Forget your desk. Give yourself up to the course - concentrate, participate and learn. Don't rush out at coffee time to make 10 urgent calls. Get organised before you leave the office. Ask someone to cover for you, and explain any urgent matters. Relax, and you'll be able to make the most of the day.

 Take good, short notes. Writing cements the ideas in your mind better than reading handouts. But equally, listen first and digest what's being said before you begin scribbling. Don't write down anything you don't understand - ask! And jot down questions for the trainer as you go along, before you forget them.

 At the end of the course make an action plan of things you're going to do differently. Try to put the course into practice as soon as you get back to your desk. Collect all handouts, etc, and fill out the course evaluation forms honestly - in that way, you'll help those who take the course after you.

 Give your manager feedback. Explain what you're going to change and schedule regular updates to see how it's progressing. The more you involve your manager in your training, and the more he or she can see benefits, the more likely you are to be able to go on other courses. Which means you'll be even more of an asset to the business.

webTitle: Rooting for success

fields.headline: Rooting for success
fields.standfirst: From small beginnings, Trees for London has grown into a healthy charity.  Hilary Whitney  talks to its administrator, Emma Hill
fields.trailText: From small beginnings, Trees for London has grown into a healthy charity. Hilary Whitney talks to its administrator, Emma Hill.
fields.body:
London's trees don't have an easy time. With traffic congestion, pollution and global warming on the increase, not to mention recent gales that have seen many ripped up and blown down, tree planting to keep the capital's natural cycle going is an essential task.

Trees for London is an independent charity inspired by the simple philosophy that trees are of enormous importance to everyone who lives and works in the capital. "The organisation was started by a group of friends who were getting increasingly fed up with the high level of pollution in London," explains Emma Hill, who has been the project administrator for Trees for London for two and half years. "They were big party people and hit on the idea of charging people to come to their parties and using the profits to fund tree planting. They managed to provide a few schools and community projects with some new trees, and it carried on like that for a couple of years until they realised that the scheme had great potential but it couldn't go any further without full-time paid staff." Graham Simmonds, who has since become the charity's chief executive, was initially appointed to find sponsorship and worked alone for six months until there was sufficient funding in place to employ Hill.

Hill had been working as an arts administrator for the Royal Society for the Encouragement of Arts and Commerce (RSA). Her first job after leaving school was in an attorney's office in South Africa and she travelled extensively before returning to England to complete an art founda tion course. She then moved to London where, after a stint of temping, she joined the RSA.

"I enjoyed working there, but my career just didn't seem to be going in the right direction," says Hill. "When I joined Trees for London, the post was only three days a week so I had to survive on a fraction of my former salary, but I knew it was too good an opportunity to miss." There are now five members of staff, based in Prince Consort Lodge in Kennington Park, but for a while it was just Simmonds and Hill. "We shared a desk in a Soho PR company's office and had just one phone and one computer between us," she says.

One of their first projects was to re-landscape a stretch of community woodland at Lismore Circus in Gospel Oak, north London. "It had deteriorated into a scrub area," Hill explains. "Michael Palin lives nearby and he kindly launched the project for us, and we planted an oak which is actually a descendent of the original Gospel Oak."

Projects are funded in a variety of ways. Sometimes a school or a community centre will make a request and Trees for London will find a way to raise the funds for the scheme. Quite often, organisations already have established links with a sponsor and have the finance in place, but need Trees for London to help them carry out their plans. "For instance, there is a school in Poplar that has a very good relationship with a large investment bank in the City. The bank approached us and asked us to provide the school with some more trees so I went to see the head teacher to discuss what sort of trees would be suitable. You have to take into account what trees are already there and where they'll be at least risk. In this instance, the head wanted trees to provide colour and softness."

Hill is always accompanied on these initial visits by an arboriculturalist ("I don't have the knowledge to make the assessments although I am studying for the Royal Horticultural Society certificate in horticulture"), who writes a report following the site visit. Hill then draws up a plan of action. "For example, if we're planting at a school I'll set up a workshop for the children so that they're really fired up about the trees. I'll get quotes from tree suppliers and if there's any landscaping to do, I'll get quotes from contractors, too.

"I'm constantly sending out letters to all the people concerned to make sure that everyone's up to date with what is happening. It's also very important to make sure that the sponsors are free to come on the planting day."

The recent heavy gusts and gales have not significantly increased Trees for London's work. "Sadly, we don't have the resources to replace trees immediately," Hill explains. "Each council has at least one tree officer with whom we work very closely, and if they have the money the tree might get replaced. But usually by this time of year their planting budget has been already been allocated so the tree will just be chopped up and replaced next year. Of course, it's a huge shame when this happens. Even if the tree is replaced, it will probably be at least another 60 or 70 years before it will look anything like its predecessor."

webTitle: Officehours: The inside track: Green workers

fields.headline: Green workers
fields.trailText: This autumn's depressing travel conditions, both natural and man-made, have at least benefited one group - cyclists. In London, for example, flooding closed Hyde Park to cars but not to bikes. "I had the park to myself this morning," said one happy cyclist, a woman more accustomed to risking her life daily on her five-mile commute.
fields.body:
This autumn's depressing travel conditions, both natural and man-made, have at least benefited one group - cyclists. In London, for example, flooding closed Hyde Park to cars but not to bikes. "I had the park to myself this morning," said one happy cyclist, a woman more accustomed to risking her life daily on her five-mile commute.

Similarly, September's fuel crisis revived interest in cycling. "We had lots of calls," says Peter Lewis, director of the London Cycle Campaign (LCC). "We had three days of cleaner air and less traffic on the road. It showed how things could be."

Under normal conditions, it is estimated that 170,000 brave souls cycle to work in the capital - about the same number go through the gates of a single central London Underground station in the rush hour. These cyclists are not the types who ride on pavements after dark, they are out in the middle of the road in all weathers. And their major complaint is that they are all but invisible, not just to the travelling public, but to individual drivers.

There is also some irony in the fact that although cycling is, on paper, the cheapest form of travel, it is easier for the privileged, because the problems city cyclists face do not end when they come off the road. There is only so much street furniture to which a bike can safely be chained. A more common solution is underground car parks. "I used to be a city solicitor," says Lewis, "and you'd be surprised at how many bikes you see in the car parks of city law firms." For cyclists who do not work for companies with car parking, or for that matter, showering facilities, life is that much more difficult.

The LCC is working to make employers more aware of cyclists' needs, through a project known as Business Cycle, in conjunction with the Capital Partnership, a group of local authorities in central London.

 The LCC's revised street plan, with recommended routes for cyclists, is available from Wednesday (020 7928 7220).

webTitle: Officehours: The word is foreign

fields.headline: The word is foreign
fields.standfirst: With more people than ever speaking English, you might think bilingual support staff were becoming redundant. Well, you'd be wrong, says  Kate Hilpern
fields.trailText: With more people than ever speaking English, you might think bilingual support staff were becoming redundant. Well, you'd be wrong.
fields.body:
Unless you've got a sexy French accent or a forthright German inflection to your English, you may be heading for minority status. The number of people with English as a second language has overtaken the number who speak it as their native tongue, the government has announced. At any one time, a billion people are learning English, and by the end of this year, 750m people will speak it well enough to use it for business. So if everyone's speaking our lingo, is it time for office staff who speak foreign languages to get their coats?

Far from it, says Davide Mele, director of international operations at recruitment consultancy Angela Mortimer, who claims there is more demand than ever for support staff with languages. "In fact, clients don't just want bilingual secretaries, they want multilingual ones. Thirty per cent of our current assignments require fluency in two languages other than English."

Secretaries with languages, he says, can expect up to 20% extra in their pay packets - proportionally more than ever before. Some companies refer to this as a "language allowance" while others simply incorporate the bonus in the salary.

A spokesperson for recruitment consultancy Adecco agrees: "There has been a sharp growth in the number of people speaking English. But because we work in an increasingly global marketplace - and by no means all foreigners speak English - there is more likelihood, rather than less, of having to deal with people in another language."

Linda Arnold, who has worked as a PA for Adecco for several years, claims that for the first time in her career she is using her French and Spanish on a daily basis. "I've noticed a progression in demand for languages over the past 10 years and more significantly still, within the past two," she says. The reason, she believes, is down to manners. "It would be bordering on rude to expect foreign clients to speak our language. They tend to be flattered when I make an effort to speak theirs. I believe it's particularly important for support staff to speak languages since they're often the first person a potential client speaks to. For them to be multilingual makes good business sense."

But, says Philippe Milloux, deputy head of the French Institute, money and status aren't the only benefits multilingual secretaries can expect in millennial Britain. "As the role of assistant grows to involve more and more responsibility, managers are increasingly taking them on business trips. Those who speak a foreign language are likely to get to travel abroad with them," he says.

The problem is that the French Institute is one of only a handful of colleges in Britain which incorporates languages into its secretarial training. "The emphasis in training high-flying PAs has become computer literacy rather than languages," says German tutor Regina Smith. Together with the fact that Britain has a poor record of people leaving school with language skills, the result is that the chances of PAs being multilingual are slim.

Your best bet for learning or brushing up on foreign languages, is evening classes or language tapes, says Smith. "Make sure you get an appropriate class, though," she cautions. "Many are aimed at holiday-makers and, while you might end up knowing how to ask for a bar selling tequila, you may remain in the dark when it comes to saying, 'Hold on a moment please, I'll see if he's free'."

Even in small companies, languages can be critical. Integral Vision, a Bedford firm, claims it lost a £250,000 contract in Germany because of communication difficulties. Nevertheless, agree all recruitment consultants, if you want to make the most of your language skills, it's still better to opt for a multinational employer.

webTitle: Definitions of a notional identity

fields.headline: Definitions of a notional identity
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair wants our nationality to be celebrated. But what is it?
Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: Driving north with an indomitable determination to allow neither floods nor Railtrack to cut me off from civilisation, I listened to a radio programme in which Michael Wills MP admitted that the prime minister had given him a special task. He is to encourage other members of the government to pay special respect to our national identity - always in their speeches and whenever possible in their policy decisions.
fields.body:
Driving north with an indomitable determination to allow neither floods nor Railtrack to cut me off from civilisation, I listened to a radio programme in which Michael Wills MP admitted that the prime minister had given him a special task. He is to encourage other members of the government to pay special respect to our national identity - always in their speeches and whenever possible in their policy decisions.

People who know Mr Wills tell me that he is among the brightest and best of the new political generation. He will need all his talents if he is to discharge his new responsibilities successfully. For he has to begin by deciding which nation he is going to identify. Then - having chosen between Great Britain, the United Kingdom and the countries which make up the still heterogeneous union - provide a working definition of what the appropriate national identity is. All the easy answers to his questions have more to do with fascism than philosophy.

Let me, in order to avoid the accusation of loving every country better than my own, describe my attitude towards England. It is the only place in which I want to live. Indeed, with the exception of Scotland - in which I spend a couple of happy weeks each summer - it is the only place in which I want to be for any length of time. English is the only language I speak and the only literature I know well. I enjoy England's unpredictable weather and its ever changing landscape. I still hope that the New Jerusalem can be builded here.

So I can answer the question about which national identity matters to me easily enough. I am British only by the legal definition of my citizenship. But I am English by instinct and emotion. However, Mr Wills cannot base his work on any such dichotomy. The national identity which our Scottish prime minister wishes to promote must at least embrace Great Britain. John Major's notion of a people bound together by village cricket, warm beer and old ladies cycling to church will not do for Tony Blair. It will not do for me either. Despite my sentimental attraction to the reigns of Elizabeth I and Queen Victoria (when the idea of England was established) the country in which I want to live is multiracial and more concerned with facing the hard challenges of the future than dwelling on the glories of the past.

There is a ready definition of British nationality which Mr Wills could use as the basis of his work. Quite rightly he has rejected it. It is usually illustrated by a description of territorial acquisitions and claims of military success. Both illustrations lead to the conclusion that there is something superior about this sceptred isle. We can argue about whether of not Rudyard Kipling's reference to "lesser breeds without the law" was a statement of his true opinion or an ironic criticism of a chauvinism which he had come to hate. Either way, it an eloquent illustration of what British identity meant at the end of the 19th century.

I fear that Mr Wills's definition, when he hits upon it, will have many of the same shortcomings. If what he said on radio is to be believed, he means to encourage a view of our national identity which is based on characteristic values - love of fair play, belief in justice, devotion to liberty. We can only define Britain by those admirable qualities if we assert or imply that they are absent, or less pronounced, in other nationalities. Are the French less compassionate and the Swedes more intolerant than we are? I am too insular to know the answer. But to suggest that we are superior to them in these respects is not very different from regarding them as lesser breeds without the law.

In truth Mr Wills's task is no more about encouraging respect for our national identity than it is about deciding whether Shakespeare belongs to England or to the world. His job is to make sure that ministers sound as if they are "standing up for Britain". That is an attitude which I wholeheartedly support on those occasions when Britain is right. But that is quite different from defending every element of "Britishness" - from outdated monarchy to antiquated independent nuclear deterrent - that the Tory party claim tests the government's love of country.

I feared that before I finished this there would be a reference to "love of country" - a phrase which, being properly English, I find embarrassing. So I cover my shame by describing how mine came about. Chickens are irrevocably attached to the first hen they see after they burst from the egg. For all of my formative years all I knew was England. Irrational affection has its advantages. Even when the old bird begins to moult, it remains an object of irrational devotion. But the irrationality should only go so far. Claims to superiority are both demeaning and dangerous.

webTitle: Mole theory on dome leak

fields.headline: Mole theory on dome leak
fields.standfirst:
Mole theory after leak of 'cabinet minutes' on dome
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Senior ministers were last night facing up to the possibility of a high-level mole among officials or advisers at the heart of government after a newspaper published what it claimed to be minutes of the cabinet's crucial 1997 discus sion before deciding to build the Millennium Dome in Greenwich.
fields.body:
Senior ministers were last night facing up to the possibility of a high-level mole among officials or advisers at the heart of government after a newspaper published what it claimed to be minutes of the cabinet's crucial 1997 discus sion before deciding to build the Millennium Dome in Greenwich.

Mr Blair, who left the cabinet early to attend a service at St Margaret's Church, Westminster, was quoted as saying, "If it's a success it could even make money." Gordon Brown worried about the cost of turning round what Chris Smith called "a shambles inherited from the Tories."

David Blunkett said he was deeply against it, while Clare Short predicted it would be "a political disaster". Robin Cook, another dome-sceptic, allegedly suggested: "We could always blame the Tories if we stop it now."

Ministers who backed the project included John Prescott, persuaded at the last minute by Mr Blair, Harriet Harman, Jack Straw, Mo Mowlam and Lord Richard, later sacked as leader of the lords.

"I start from the premise that someone has done this to damage Tony. It's designed to throw a spanner in the works," said one cabinet member last night. He believes the leak to be genuine. "It sounds fairly accurate," admitted another cabinet member, also quoted verbatim.

Freed from the need for ministerial caution, David Clark, one of the then-cabinet ministers correctly identified as opposing the dome, said: "It's a very serious issue that confi dential cabinet discussions have been leaked to the press because it's crucial that everyone feels free to speak their minds at cabinet."

The new row comes days after the National Audit Office condemned persistent and over-optimistic mismanagement of the dome, while opposition parties clamoured for the resignation of Lord Falconer, the minister responsible for the dome.

While No 10 was dismissive of the new report, cabinet ministers past and present gave weight to the story in the Mail on Sunday. Several of those quoted by the newspaper agreed that the words attributed to them - 17 of the 21 cabinet members are quoted in direct speech - were broadly accurate.

That led some to the conclusion that someone had passed over not the formal cabinet minutes which are famously bland and impersonal but the more extensive notes taken at all cabinet meetings by officials of under-secretary rank or higher.

Such minutes are not normally seen by ministers themselves, but are filed, electronically and on paper, by the cabinet secretariat as "confidential annexes" in the cabinet office registry adjoining No 10. The prime minister's private office also gets a copy, as does the Queen.

The timing is highly convenient for William Hague, whom Mr Blair blamed for his role in the early planning of the dome in 1996-97 when the Tory leader was Welsh secretary and sat on a cabinet committee called Gen(eral)36 chaired by Michael Heseltine.

The prime minister's use of that committee - and the key decisions it took - to taunt Mr Hague at Commons question time last Wednesday may have triggered the leak. Some MPs listening felt the exchange implied that Mr Blair had been shown the cabinet committee minutes of the previous government.

"He's not supposed to see them and a civil servant may have counter-leaked. Access to a previous government's papers is one of the elements of power which officials have over cabinet ministers," said one senior Labour MP.

It left some to wonder whether a disaffected official or a computer hacker had passed on the document to the Mail group, traditionally the prime recipient of anti-Labour leaks and sponsor of damaging books.

Given that Whitehall mandarins do not have shorthand and cabinet meetings are rarely tape-recorded, it also made MPs ask if a minister is keeping a diary.

Last summer a series of leaks to the Murdoch press of sensitive memos to and from Mr Blair were eventually blamed on raids on the dustbins outside the home of his pollster, Philip Gould.

Some MPs offered a simpler explanation. They pointed to previous reports in the Mail on Sunday, based on interviews not documents, including an alleged account of Mr Brown's tax strategy.

Entitled "Cabinet papers expose Brown tax ploy", it was presented as an official version of the chancellor's policy brief to the cabinet a few weeks after yesterday's similarly "verbatim" account of the dome cabinet on June 19 1997.

The tax story was discredited and yesterday's report contained what ministers said were two obvious discrepancies. Both Lord Irvine, the Lord Chancellor ("we need to know about the content") and the home secretary, Jack Straw ("every large project has risks") were quoted as speaking after Mr Blair left. Yet both attended the same church service.

Last night Peter Hennessy of Queen Mary and Westfield College, an authority on Whitehall, pronounced yesterday's account almost certainly genuine. He confirmed it is much more detailed than any minister would receive.

"That looks to me like the near verbatim notes taken by the cabinet secretariat. Now that is a Grade I listed leak. It's really terrific isn't it? It's blow by blow. Heaven knows where they've got it from or how," said Dr Hennessy. But he ruled out a civil service leak.

Downing Street was quick to dismiss the account as fiction. "Simon Walters [the report's author] has just written his first novel, now he's written his first play," quipped one senior official.

Asked about a leaks inquiry - a notoriously ineffectual response - another despairingly said: "We will ask the usual questions."

Mr Brown was dismissive. "I am not sure reading it if this is the meeting I was actually at," he told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost. "I did not know about this minute, I have never seen this minute. I have never seen this report, it has never been circulated to me."

webTitle: Bullied Koreans rage at US base

fields.headline: Bullied Koreans rage at US base
fields.standfirst:
Villages in the South want to be rid of American troops whose presence has brought years of silent misery
Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: At first, Lee Chun-bun glowers silently at the only white man she has come face-to-face with since the American troops came to her village more than 40 years ago. Then the hatred that has festered inside for decades explodes to the surface.
fields.body:
At first, Lee Chun-bun glowers silently at the only white man she has come face-to-face with since the American troops came to her village more than 40 years ago. Then the hatred that has festered inside for decades explodes to the surface.

"You killed my son, you ruined my land and you destroyed my life, but I've never been given a penny in compensation," spat the bent and wrinkled 92-year-old South Korean. "I was so scared of you and your guns. But not any more. Now I want compensation. Now, I want to bite you!"

Her venom may have been misdirected at this journalist, but it was representative of the anger expressed by many residents of this increasingly notorious village.

Mae Hyang-ri - home of the biggest US bombing range in Asia - is the focus of a growing "Yankee Go Home" movement in South Korea.

Most Koreans are grateful for the US presence, which bolsters defences against the army in the North, but in recent years, there has been a sharp change in the political scene and the public mood.

For most of the past 50 years of cold war, opponents of the US military were dismissed as communist sympathisers. The military dictatorship that ruled the country until 1993 suppressed any accusation that the bases were responsible for crime, pollution or deadly accidents.

But in 1997, Kim Dae-jung, a one-time critic of the bases, was elected president in the country's first democratic transfer of power. This year, the North has started to open up to the outside world, raising questions about whether South Korea needs to host 38,000 US troops.

In this new climate, numerous skeletons have been sent scuttling out of the US military cupboard.

Last year, Koreans were horrified to learn of the No Gun Ri massacre, in which hundreds of civilian were reportedly gunned down by US troops during the Korean war. More recently, the US forces headquarters in Seoul was forced to apologise after admitting that it has been dumping formaldehyde into the Han river.

South Korean protesters have fired paint bombs at the US embassy. Attacks on US servicemen have prompted the US command to issue a curfew for its personnel.

The demonstrators accuse the South Korean government of sacrificing its people to accommodate its US allies - and as evidence, they inevitably point to Mae Hyang-ri.

By any standards, the village is blighted by its American neighbours. Each day, its peace is shattered by more than 50 bombing runs by F-16s and other warplanes, flying so low that villagers say they can see the pilots' faces on their way to the target site, an island half a mile from the shore.

Each week, they drop tons of practice bombs and thousands of rounds of armour-piercing shells, which end up polluting the seabed and the tidal flats.

The local people have silently endured this relationship for almost 50 years, but in recent months they have started to speak up about their misery and the fatal accidents which they claim they have been forced to cover up.

Lee Chun-bun says her 16-year-old son was killed by a 12kg training shell that dropped without warning out of a clear blue sky in the late 1950s.

"When I lifted him in my arms, his face looked the same as ever, but the whole of the back of his head was missing," she recalls. "We were too frightened to complain; the Americans had guns and if you spoke out against them, you were labelled a communist.

"We wrapped the body in a blanket, then my husband buried it secretly in the hills. After that, the fury that boiled up inside him was more than he could take. Within a week, he was dead."

Fapyong, or death by anger, is officially recognised in Korea, unlike the death of Ms Lee's son, which, according to the authorities, has never been reported or investigated. None of the eight other fatal accidents claimed by the villagers has been recognised by the government.

"There is no evidence at all for such claims," said a defence ministry official.

It is indisputable, however, that the warplanes and helicopter gunships occasionally make mistakes, which impact on the villagers who live closer to the range than would be permissible in any other country.

The evidence is the cracked walls and broken windows in the village. which were caused by an accident on 16 June when a US plane with engine trouble was forced to drop six live bombs on the target range.

This sparked violent demonstrations outside the base. The US military has since stopped using a target on the shore and it has agreed to a revision to the Status of Forces agreement that covers the treatment of US troops in Korea.

Whether this will be enough to stifle the public perception that US troops are far less restricted in Korea than in neighbouring Japan remains to be seen. For the protesters at Mae Hyang-ri, nothing but a removal of the bases will suffice.

"The noise and stress drive me crazy. It makes me feel like my heart will explode," said Chun Man-kyu. "How can our own government allow us to be treated like this?"

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our account of Lou Kenton's experiences in the Spanish civil war, page 2, G2, November 10, there was a sentence starting, "When Khruschev's tanks rolled into Prague ..." They were Brezhnev's tanks.
fields.body:
In our account of Lou Kenton's experiences in the Spanish civil war, page 2, G2, November 10, there was a sentence starting, "When Khruschev's tanks rolled into Prague ..." They were Brezhnev's tanks.

In an item headed Grotesque M & S, page 25 (Finance), October 31, we said that Sir Richard Greenbury seemed "to pop up every six months or so and blame someone else for the muddle M&S has found itself in." Sir Richard has asked us to make it clear that he has, in fact, never criticised M&S or its management, and the Guardian accepts that.

In our summary of Peter Ackroyd's book, London, The Biography, page 16, The Editor, November 10, we accidentally reversed the course of history, saying "the Great Fire brought the Plague ..." In fact the Plague, from late 1664 to early 1666, preceded the Fire, September 2 to 5, 1666 (dates from britannica.com)

It was misleading to describe Psychomania, the film mentioned in our television notes, page 20, G2, Novem ber 10, as a rip-off of Quadrophenia. The Psychomania referred to dates from 1971. Quadrophenia did not appear until 1979.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible.
Please quote the date and page number.

webTitle: This shows that sometimes there are no happy endings

fields.headline: This shows that sometimes there are no happy endings
fields.standfirst:
Race for the White House
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Too many endgames and no sign of an end. The official message, of course, is keep calm, trust the process, show the resilience of American democracy. Fairness and justice (in so far as they're coterminous) must prevail. Any debacle can always be gift-wrapped in the star-spangled banner. Take a week or three and it will all be over, pavilioned in familiar self-congratulation.
fields.body:
Too many endgames and no sign of an end. The official message, of course, is keep calm, trust the process, show the resilience of American democracy. Fairness and justice (in so far as they're coterminous) must prevail. Any debacle can always be gift-wrapped in the star-spangled banner. Take a week or three and it will all be over, pavilioned in familiar self-congratulation.

Well, perhaps. But nobody has an easy way - indeed, any sure way - of getting from here to there. George W's duly summoned federal judge, Donald M Middlebrooks, could grant an injunction in Miami today and stop the rash of hand recounts spreading across the state: the unquantified number of overseas ballot envelopes due to be opened on Friday could, as expected, put a few thousand more votes in the Republican column: Al Gore could graciously concede and leave for a new career in touch football.

If you were betting, I suppose that might be the rosiest scenario for a resolution. Certainly the few hundred grey souls of Palm Beach County who think they might have punched the Buchanan rather than the Gore hole on election night are a pretty frail hook to hang your hat on. The ballot form, when examined, is no design triumph - but (a point the Democrats shrink from) electoral law gives you three ballot forms and three attempts to get it right; and you can always ask for help. The fact that some voters were too shy or confused to make certain may be deeply regrettable, but it doesn't justify White House limbo, especially when there's no means of proving what any individual actually did - as opposed to what they say or think they did. Tough cheddar.

The Buchanan glitch, however, is no longer the real point. Its role in history is merely as the broken lock on Pandora's box. Take some irate voters - the Buchanan confused - and move on to the 19,120 county ballots on the night deemed invalid for one reason or another. Those are the difference between a Democratic and a Republican victory in Florida and thus in America. Yesterday's small hand count - showing marked Gore gains - is good enough evidence for that. Extrapolate them in Palm Beach alone and Al's the big winner. And since we all know that now, since those figures swirl from every TV screen, Judge Middlebrooks can't make us forget it.

If Mr Bush gets his injunction, he'll be seen as the man who used the law to seize the Oval Office - justice without fairness. If he loses in court (and the judge is a Clinton appointment) then he'll have to get into the hand recount business himself - elsewhere in Florida Republican territory and in Iowa, Wisconsin and Oregon. Weeks, possibly months, not days. Perhaps Camelot might like to bid for the franchise.

It is not, you will see, much of a process: and, worse, it leaves out the human element. I was sitting quietly in a Florida hotel lobby watching cable news when Bush announced his legal crusade and the reaction of the Americans around me was, to put it gently, pretty damned irate. They'd been told for four days that Gore had been wrong to encourage lawsuits - now here was the monster hypocrite doing it himself. What a lousy piece of work!

And there lies the real, the burgeoning problem. Not that a solution, in extremity, can't be fudged out somehow: but that one half or other of this bemused, divided nation will never bring itself to accept it. This quagmire isn't about Palm Beach County any longer. If that county, with its 19,000 invalid forms, ballots again, then why not Dade and Broward and Jacksonville, all of them piling up invalids a mile high? Why not rerun the whole shooting match in every state that was too close to call? A constitutional doomsday solution to give bureaucrats and politicians alike the shakes.

There is, alas, no intrinsic fairness here. There is only the fairness of what politically appointed election officials or politically appointed judges decide. There is no way of stopping the argument.

For the moment, we see George W fingering his boil and looking perplexed, with Dick Cheney leering over his shoulder like a ventriloquist operating a dummy. We see Jim Baker - silkiest of fixers - delivering absurd lectures on the wonder of 40-year-old voting machines the manufacturers don't make any more. We see clearly, for the first time, what a Bush White House would be like. Texan outsiders marching on Washington as promised? No, the same gang of Old Pappy Bush's Washington outsiders wearing stetsons on camera.

This is not a fresh and healing administration in waiting. It's the lot America got rid of in 1992 reclaiming its turf. The election leaves it with no agenda for governing such division, even if it claims a victory. And the wretched thing is that Al Gore is no better placed.

He may, prudently, be staying quiet, toiling behind the scenes to flood Florida with lawyers and, perhaps, beginning to dent the shell of Bush confidence. But what if Middlebrooks lets the hand counts go on? What if the winner of the popular vote can eventually boast that he just about won the electoral college vote as well? How then would a President Gore work with a Senate and house which both have Republican majorities who believe "we was robbed"?

Americans, having rather little history, are prone to make too much of the history they have. The airwaves continue thick with learned professors prognosticating on what Grover Cleveland or Benjamin Harrison, let alone Harry S Truman, might have done. But history doesn't include a race like this, locked in increasingly visceral dispute, one which panders to all the worst instincts of the new breed of attack dogs on Capitol Hill. There is no kindly light at the end of this tunnel. A winning Gore would start losing from the moment he took the oath of office.

Does gridlock matter? Wall Street, last Wednesday morning, thought not. Its plump gurus emerged to praise a supposed result in which nobody would be able to do anything controversial and accustomed profits would flow. But Wall Street has got the jitters since, fretting over uncertainty - and the total certainty of total uncertainty looms. Both Bush and Gore have lost badly in the past few days. Neither Bush nor Gore - trading insults - will be able to do much more than preside for the next four years. Neither Bush nor Gore, whoever concedes in the court of public opinion, has any obvious way of claiming the only legitimacy that matters, emotional legitimacy.

Welcome to the land of happy endings, to American faith in the American way. But power, by the minute, is becoming detached from the public support - or acquiescence - that gives it meaning. Sometimes there are no happy endings.

fields.headline: Scrutiny, the party game
fields.standfirst:
Deliberations in the House of Lords veer from futility to farce, and the dinner hour doesn't help either
Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: Today the House of Lords debates sex, specifically the bill equalising the age of consent for homosexuals with that for heterosexuals. On form, it will be an excited debate, as this is a subject which their lordships love to talk about. However, it will also be futile. The bill repeats one destroyed by the Lords last year, and will therefore pass at the end of the session.
fields.body:
Today the House of Lords debates sex, specifically the bill equalising the age of consent for homosexuals with that for heterosexuals. On form, it will be an excited debate, as this is a subject which their lordships love to talk about. However, it will also be futile. The bill repeats one destroyed by the Lords last year, and will therefore pass at the end of the session.

But it will not be a lot more futile than much of the scrutiny of bills which is at present keeping the Lords up till all hours. If the House of Lords is good for anything, it ought to be good for discussing Northern Ireland. As on many subjects, its membership includes a formidable expertise: two recent Northern Ireland ministers, Paddy Mayhew and Alf Dubs; two former leaders from the main traditions, Gerry Fitt and Jim Molyneaux; and two great anti-sectarian figures, Billy Blease and Mary Blood.

Yet its November 8 deliberations on the police (Northern Ireland) bill were futility culminating in farce. This was in part because the House of Lords not only has a Conservative plurality (233 Tory peers to 201 Labour) but also a unionist bent. This was dramatically demonstrated before the recess when two ultra-unionists, Robert Cranborne and Norman Lamont, defied the conventions of the house to block temporarily another piece of Northern Ireland legislation.

As a result, Labour's whips were cracking. The Tories, however, decided to wound not strike. They forced no fewer than five divisions between 10.30pm and midnight, making sure first that they had sent enough of their people home to lose each of them. Scrutiny turned into a party game.

Not that the Tories are often keen to vote late at night. The significance of this was shown by the Lords' consideration last week of the criminal justice and court services bill. Then, the government lost six votes - four trivial, two not - between the start of business and the dinner hour. But at dinner most Tories, as usual, went home and their frontbench called no further votes. It is an odd form of scrutiny indeed where what changes are voted on depends entirely on whether they come before or after Tory peers are ready to turn to the pleasures of the night.

The idea that peers or anyone else can scrutinise legislation intelligently in the small hours of the morning is laughable, as the Commons has belatedly recognised. Yet Tories and the Lib Dem leadership have ganged up to block efforts by Margaret Jay, the leader of the house, to get MPs to start and finish work earlier one day a week.

Most seriously, the way the house goes about scrutiny is flawed. It debates specific amendments, rather than looking at the important issues in the round. These amendments are usually debated not in small committees, as in the Commons, but in the debating chamber, encouraging grandstanding rather than compromise.

Anyway, the chamber apes the Commons, with government and opposition arrayed against each other. This may have been defensible in the days of the hereditary principle, when birth was a mandate as strong as election and the Lords was as partisan as the place down the corridor. But today, no one seeks to claim that the Lords is a co-equal house. Composed of a mixture of hereditary peers and appointed ones, it has no legitimacy save that which comes from the power of its arguments. Its comparative advantage over the Commons can only lie in its expert, nonpartisan character. Yet it throws much of that away by running itself in a way that encourages polarisation.

Not content with going through this unproductive process once, we do it three times: on committee, report and third reading. Many noble Lords give the house pretty well identical speeches on all three occasions.

The difficulty of reform does not lie in devising better alternatives. The first of the three stages could be conducted in a committee, which would identify the main issues to be settled by the house as a whole. It might also take evidence. The house could refuse to tolerate repetition. The opposition could call fewer votes; in return, the government could resist the sort of macho posturing that denies all amendments in principle. The house, as in the past, should not normally sit past dinner. If that means earlier starts, so be it.

We are talking of an institution that remains both Conservative and conservative. The Conservatives resist anything that would reduce their capacity to make up for their weakness in the elected house by harrying the government in the unelected house. The conservatives, of all parties and none, are simply against change. Sadly, they are disproportionately powerful in the labyrinthine committees in which these things are currently decided, and so the house goes on doing a valuable job badly.

Margaret Jay is doing her best. She would be helped if the government claimed an electoral mandate for procedural reform. The next Labour manifesto should not only contain proposals to get rid of the remaining hereditaries and reform the membership of the house. It should commit the next government to reforming the procedures, by agreement if possible, by fiat if not. A modern constitution demands no less.

David Lipsey is a member of the House of Lords

webTitle: Comment: Harold Evans on US elections

fields.headline: Quite wrong about Nixon
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Fuzzy maths, continued. And fuzzy history, too. Pundits, who should know better, and politicians, keep citing the 1960 Kennedy/Nixon election as a model for how great men should behave in the little local difficulty we have here.
fields.body:
Fuzzy maths, continued. And fuzzy history, too. Pundits, who should know better, and politicians, keep citing the 1960 Kennedy/Nixon election as a model for how great men should behave in the little local difficulty we have here. They are all basically trying to put pressure on Al Gore to go quietly into the night, saying this is just what the noble Richard Nixon did after the 1960 squeaker when he put country above ambition and refrained from challenging the legitimacy of Kennedy's votes.

Such ignorance! First the facts. Mayor Richard Daley's Chicago machine voted the graveyards to give Kennedy the 27 votes of Illinois and the presidency. For a start, Kennedy did not need those votes. Michigan put him over the top at 5.45am. Nixon would have also needed the 24 votes of Texas. Flagrant fraud was alleged to have been perpetrated there by Senator Lyndon Johnson's henchmen and it is the combination of Texas and Illinois that could have given Nixon victory. The myth is that he took all this lying down. Nixon cultivated that idea because "charges of 'sore loser' would follow me through history" and remove any possibility of a further political career - but Nixon and his allies did mount a massive challenge. His friend, and biographer, Earl Mazo whipped up a frenzy in the press while keeping Nixon's name out of it.

G OP leaders went to enormous lengths to undo the results, right up to the electoral college that certified Kennedy as the winner by 303 electoral votes to 219. On November 11, three days after the election, Senator Thruston B Morton, the party's national chairman, and senatorial allies, launched bids for recounts or investigations in no fewer than 11 states - not just Illinois and Texas, but also Delaware, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, New Jersey, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania and South Carolina.

The effort was prodigious. Recounts were won in Illinois and New Jersey. There was some fraud, but not enough proven to change the outcome. In Illinois, the final recount showed that Kennedy's 8,858 majority had been overcounted by 943, but in 40% of precincts checked Nixon's vote was found to have been overcounted. That is quite a contrast with Florida today where the contested Bush majority of 1,784 has dwindled to an unofficial 327, where absentee votes remain to be counted, and where the protests of 20,000 disenfranchised voters in Palm Beach County are of an altogether different order to 1960.

Both sides today have legitimate grievances. The Bush campaign is justified in its complaint that Republican voters may have been deterred from going to the polls by the reckless prediction of the TV networks that Gore had already won. They would be entitled to seek recounts in other close races. And the Gore campaign is right to want an investigation of significant ballot irregularities. It has a duty to do that. Yes, we all know that every election has some mix-up or other, but this one affects many thousands of voters. It is bizarre that the Republicans and so many commentators are acting as if these citizens are eccentric nuisances for insisting on the basic principle of American democracy. The consternation should be instead on why Bush is trying to claim the presidency before he has won it, an impudence incited but not justified by Gore's stupidly premature concession.

The postal votes or the very necessary manual recounts resisted by the Republicans may produce a clear winner, but unless it is quite substantial I doubt whether any "final" count figure favouring either Bush or Gore now will dispel the dismay and anxiety throughout the country. The improprieties are too glaring and the result of a handful of votes too prodigious. America cannot afford to have a new president start his administration under a cloud. For Gore to assume the presidency in these circumstances would incite Republicans forever to say he gained it only by street demos and legal manoeuvre, and by the mischief brought by television. For Bush to assume the presidency, it would always be with the taint of why the ballots were so screwed up in his brother's state.

Short of a decisive recount, the best solution is submission to the people best qualified to know the mind of Palm Beach - the community of voters. A rerun in Palm Beach County open only to those who voted on November 7 would legitimise the successful candidate like nothing else can, whether its effect is pro-Bush or pro-Gore. There are plenty of state precedents for reruns. Better the fuss of this than a president with a mandate anchored in Florida's fuzzy maths.

 Harold Evans is the author of The American Century.

webTitle: Jonathan Cook @Nazareth

fields.headline: Jonathan Cook @Nazareth
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Being a postman in Nazareth is trickier than in most towns. The danger of attack by dog is probably no greater than elsewhere in Israel, but finding an address requires an unusually intimate knowledge of the tangle of back streets: most have no name, and the houses no numbers. Space is at such a premium that as families grow so do their homes - through a series of extensions and additions, most of them illegal. Any numbering system would soon break down. As one resident observed: "If the council can't find room to build pavements, how are we expected to find a plot for a new home?"
fields.body:
Being a postman in Nazareth is trickier than in most towns. The danger of attack by dog is probably no greater than elsewhere in Israel, but finding an address requires an unusually intimate knowledge of the tangle of back streets: most have no name, and the houses no numbers. Space is at such a premium that as families grow so do their homes - through a series of extensions and additions, most of them illegal. Any numbering system would soon break down. As one resident observed: "If the council can't find room to build pavements, how are we expected to find a plot for a new home?"

Nazareth, a town of about 60,000 inhabitants - two-thirds Muslim, one-third Christian - is the de facto capital of the Arab citizens of Israel. For that fact alone, it has attracted the less than disinterested attention of Israeli governments since the state's creation in 1948. They have contained the town's development and expansion by confiscating its outlying lands as part of a policy of "Judaising the Galilee", or settling Jews in Israel's Arab heartland. Although Nazareth's population has grown, its size has hardly changed. The result is a shameful paradox: the town has some of the country's highest real estate prices, even though it is poorer than most Jewish communities.

The shortage of space has led to growing antagonism between Muslims and Christians, particularly over the perception that the Greek Orthodox, Roman Catholic, Anglican and Maronite churches have a stranglehold on the town's best land. Until late September, headlines about violence in Nazareth usually referred to clashes between Muslims and Christians.

The most visible issue has been a dispute over Muslim demands to build a large mosque next to one of the Holy Land's most popular sites of Christian pilgrimage, the Basilica of the Annunciation. A government committee appointed to adjudicate approved the mosque but insisted on a reduction in its proposed size. In the meantime, Muslims have set up a "holy tent" on the site and regularly try to drown out Basilica services with the call to prayer.

Many observers suspect that Israel has secretly been encouraging this sectarian conflict. "Divide and rule," mumble Arab leaders in the town, including its communist mayor, Ramiz Jeraisi.

All that changed at the end of September, with the massacre of Palestinians at the Haram al-Sharif in Jerusalem. As elsewhere in Israel, Arabs in Nazareth spilled on to the streets to vent their anger, both at the deaths and at five decades of discrimination. Muslims and Christians were reminded that, whatever their differences, they are all second-class citizens in their own country.

The demonstration of unity brought a swift response from their neighbours - Jews from the development town of Upper Nazareth. Established in 1957 to accommodate east European immigrants, it was built on land confiscated from Nazareth. Since then, Nazarenes have watched as the Jewish town has grown and prospered, receiving bigger local council grants, priority for industrial development and special tax breaks.

Despite their advantages, some of the inhabitants of Upper Nazareth resent living so close to Arabs. Possibly inspired by the Israeli media, which accused rioting Israeli Arabs of being "traitors", gangs of young Jews descended on Nazareth, attacking homes to chants of "Death to the Arabs". When Arab youths retaliated, the police opened fire, killing two.

The scar left by these events will not easily heal. After years of "coexistence" between Nazareth and Upper Nazareth, the battle lines are being redrawn, this time between Jews and Arabs. Mohammed Zidan, a human rights lawyer in Nazareth, fears the rule of law has been undermined. "The population in Galilee is split 50-50 between Jews and Arabs, and now there is only distrust. Authority has broken down like it did during the war that founded Israel. The danger is we could slide towards civil war."
fields.bodyText: Being a postman in Nazareth is trickier than in most towns. The danger of attack by dog is probably no greater than elsewhere in Israel, but finding an address requires an unusually intimate knowledge of the tangle of back streets: most have no name, and the houses no numbers. Space is at such a premium that as families grow so do their homes - through a series of extensions and additions, most of them illegal. Any numbering system would soon break down. As one resident observed: "If the council can't find room to build pavements, how are we expected to find a plot for a new home?" Nazareth, a town of about 60,000 inhabitants - two-thirds Muslim, one-third Christian - is the de facto capital of the Arab citizens of Israel. For that fact alone, it has attracted the less than disinterested attention of Israeli governments since the state's creation in 1948. They have contained the town's development and expansion by confiscating its outlying lands as part of a policy of "Judaising the Galilee", or settling Jews in Israel's Arab heartland. Although Nazareth's population has grown, its size has hardly changed. The result is a shameful paradox: the town has some of the country's highest real estate prices, even though it is poorer than most Jewish communities. The shortage of space has led to growing antagonism between Muslims and Christians, particularly over the perception that the Greek Orthodox, Roman Catholic, Anglican and Maronite churches have a stranglehold on the town's best land. Until late September, headlines about violence in Nazareth usually referred to clashes between Muslims and Christians. The most visible issue has been a dispute over Muslim demands to build a large mosque next to one of the Holy Land's most popular sites of Christian pilgrimage, the Basilica of the Annunciation. A government committee appointed to adjudicate approved the mosque but insisted on a reduction in its proposed size. In the meantime, Muslims have set up a "holy tent" on the site and regularly try to drown out Basilica services with the call to prayer. Many observers suspect that Israel has secretly been encouraging this sectarian conflict. "Divide and rule," mumble Arab leaders in the town, including its communist mayor, Ramiz Jeraisi. All that changed at the end of September, with the massacre of Palestinians at the Haram al-Sharif in Jerusalem. As elsewhere in Israel, Arabs in Nazareth spilled on to the streets to vent their anger, both at the deaths and at five decades of discrimination. Muslims and Christians were reminded that, whatever their differences, they are all second-class citizens in their own country. The demonstration of unity brought a swift response from their neighbours - Jews from the development town of Upper Nazareth. Established in 1957 to accommodate east European immigrants, it was built on land confiscated from Nazareth. Since then, Nazarenes have watched as the Jewish town has grown and prospered, receiving bigger local council grants, priority for industrial development and special tax breaks. Despite their advantages, some of the inhabitants of Upper Nazareth resent living so close to Arabs. Possibly inspired by the Israeli media, which accused rioting Israeli Arabs of being "traitors", gangs of young Jews descended on Nazareth, attacking homes to chants of "Death to the Arabs". When Arab youths retaliated, the police opened fire, killing two. The scar left by these events will not easily heal. After years of "coexistence" between Nazareth and Upper Nazareth, the battle lines are being redrawn, this time between Jews and Arabs. Mohammed Zidan, a human rights lawyer in Nazareth, fears the rule of law has been undermined. "The population in Galilee is split 50-50 between Jews and Arabs, and now there is only distrust. Authority has broken down like it did during the war that founded Israel. The danger is we could slide towards civil war."

webTitle: Bush win would boost Cambridge firm

fields.headline: Bush win would boost Cambridge firm
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the British intelligent software company, could be in for a boost if George W Bush is elected president.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the British intelligent software company, could be in for a boost if George W Bush is elected president.

One of the Cambridge firm's non-executive directors, Richard Perle, is tipped to become the next defence secretary if Governor Bush succeeds Bill Clinton as president.

Analysts say Mr Perle's inclusion in a Bush administration would cement Autonomy's position in the key US market. Mr Perle, a prominent Pentagon official during Ronald Reagan's presidency and one of that government's key advisers on security issues, was appointed to the Autonomy board in February. Chief executive Dr Mike Lynch said then that Mr Perle brought high-level government contacts and experience to the company. Mr Perle is also chief executive of Hollinger Digital, the new media arm of Conrad Black's publishing group.

Al Gore, despite prompting mirth after claiming that he invented the internet, is seen as the preferred candidate for president by most Silicon Valley companies. Mr Gore's Democratic party has been largely friendly towards technology companies.
