webTitle: From Iceland to Arcadia

fields.headline: From Iceland to Arcadia
fields.standfirst: Hoerner leaves clothing retailer with an £800,000 severance package
fields.trailText: Iceland's chief executive Stuart Rose has infuriated the frozen food chain by resigning to take the top job at clothes retailer Arcadia, the owner of struggling high-street names such as Top Man, Principles and Dorothy Perkins.
fields.body:
Iceland's chief executive Stuart Rose has infuriated the frozen food chain by resigning to take the top job at clothes retailer Arcadia, the owner of struggling high-street names such as Top Man, Principles and Dorothy Perkins.

In a change to be announced this morning, Mr Rose will replace Arcadia's chief executive John Hoerner, who has resigned with a severance package of more than £800,000. Arcadia said Mr Hoerner, 61, was willing to retire after presiding over an improvement in the company's trading in recent months.

Mr Rose joined Iceland just five months ago from cash-and-carry firm Booker, which merged with the supermarket chain in a deal worth nearly £1bn. He was supposed to take on full management of the combined group gradually, as Iceland's founder Malcolm Walker wound down his role as chairman.

His early walk-out has ruined Mr Walker's plans to reduce his involvement and has made senior Iceland directors "very disappointed and angry," according to insiders.

Iceland sources accused Mr Rose of showing a lack of commitment since the merger, and of displaying great reluctance to travel to the company's head office in Deeside, Cheshire: "He's shown no willingness to spend time in Deeside - he's only been up there one day a week, although Malcolm's tried very hard to get him involved."

Mr Rose has preferred to work out of a Booker office in London. The source said Mr Rose had got to know "very few people" at Iceland, adding: "He's obviously much more passionate about fashion retailing than about frozen food."

Mr Walker will now take on the role of chief executive, as well as chairman. Iceland is likely to recruit an outsider to groom as his heir apparent.

Mr Rose was unavailable for comment. His move marks a return to the Arcadia, formerly Burton Group, which he left in 1997. In his previous stint, Mr Rose helped manage Debenhams and womenswear chain Evans. He left after losing out to Mr Hoerner in a battle for management positions.

Arcadia has been a victim of a collapse in the market for mid-priced clothes - it has been squeezed by discount stores such as Matalan and by the increasing popularity of designer labels. Its shares have collapsed from 500p to just 51p since 1998.

Although Arcadia insisted Mr Hoerner had resigned voluntarily, he has given no public indication of a desire to go. He said last month: "When I took on the Arcadia job, I made a commitment to see it through as a success and I intend to see it through. I don't know how long it will take. It's not something that's going to happen in three months."

Mr Hoerner has taken drastic action, axeing the firm's Principles for Men chain and closing 400 stores in a turnaround strategy called Brandmax. There have been encouraging signs since August, with retail sales density up 7.3%. and like-for-like sales up 4.8%.

Fashion, style and the prickly Rose

With his slick haircut, immaculate suits and ready one-liners, Stuart Rose cuts a confident and distinctive figure in the retailing world.

The 50-year-old rattles out speech like a machine gun and seems constantly restless to move on. In one interview, he admitted: "I'm intolerant, impatient. I'm good a visualising, but short on detail. I've got a low boredom threshold. I'm a bit lazy."

Rose grew up in Tanzania before going to boarding school in Yorkshire. He was unexceptional academically, and instead of going to university, took a job as a management trainee at Marks & Spencer.

He stayed for 17 years until 1989, when he joined Burton Group, now Arcadia. He re-emerged as the boss of Argos in the middle of a hostile takeover battle with Great Universal Stores. He fought hard but lost the battle, picking up £500,000 for two months' work. His appointment at troubled cash-and-carry company Booker marked him out as a turnaround specialist and he ruffled literary feathers by threatening changes to the Booker Prize.

Rose agreed to merge Booker with Iceland, but his style played awkwardly with Iceland's founder, Malcolm Walker. The opportunity to return to fashion retailing has proven tastier than a diet of frozen food.

webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Times
fields.body:
Sunday Times

EMI investors are set to receive a bonus of at least £1.50 a share - £1.2bn in total - if they agree to merge their company with Bertelsmann's music offshoot BMG. The two top jobs within the merged group would be taken by EMI's Eric Nicoli and Ken Berry. The government could reap billions from a further auction of the radio spectrum if it decides to sell the area used by the Ministry of Defence.

Industrial group Tomkins, at the centre of a scandal over directors' perks, has suspended three executives. There is no suggestion the three abused their perks, and staff remain puzzled.

Sunday Telegraph

Life insurance group CGNU is understood to have pulled out of the auction for mutual insurer Equitable Life, which was forced to put itself up for sale in July. The move will leave Prudential as the last remaining bidder for Equitable, which could be worth up to £4.5bn.

Pubmaster, the pub company which was part of the Brent Walker empire, is to be sold to a group of pub trade and property buyers backed by German bank WestLB, for around £200m.

Mail on Sunday

Nasdaq chief executive Frank Zarb, below, is planning to visit Britain to open merger talks with his counterparts at the London Stock Exchange. The move follows last week's failure of a £940m hostile bid for the LSE by Sweden's OM Group.

Sunday Express

One of Canada's biggest mutual funds, Trimark, has dumped almost half its holding in Huntingdon Life Sciences, the company being targeted by animal rights protesters.

Observer

Allied Domecq, the drinks company, is on the verge of sealing a deal to buy Stolichnaya, the vodka manufacturer and world's biggest-selling spirits brand. The deal gives Allied US distribution rights and marks an outmanoeuvring of Diageo, which lost the Stolichnaya rights after concerns in Russia that it was promoting its Smirnoff brand more heavily in the US.

Goldman Sachs, the world's biggest investment bank, is crunching the numbers this weekend for a possible £15bn bid from Barclays for Abbey National. Barclays is now the City's favourite to intervene for the former building society ahead of Lloyds TSB after Abbey put itself in play with a spurned bid for Bank of Scotland 10 days ago. Under pressure from City institutions, advisers to Abbey and BoS are trying to resurrect their £24bn merger.

Sunday Business

BT is set to reopen partial merger talks with America's AT&T after extensive restructuring moves by both companies in the past three weeks.

Brewer Scottish & Newcastle is expected finally to complete the long awaited sale of its Center Parcs division this week. It is expected to be sold to a joint venture between Deutsche Bank and French holiday company Pierre et Vacances for about £650m.

German holiday company Condor & Neckermann is believed to be ready to pay £600m-£700m for Thomas Cook.

IoS

Marks & Spencer is considering dropping the M&S name from up to 50 of its stores. It plans a revamp of the stores in depressed areas, reintroducing them as a new downmarket concept.

Leisure group Rank wants a high street bookmaker and has put Ladbrokes, owned by Hilton, at the top of its target list.

webTitle: US attacked for Glaxo merger delay

fields.headline: US attacked for Glaxo merger delay
fields.standfirst: Former SKB chief Leschly angered by lack of ruling on £130bn deal
fields.trailText: Former SmithKline Beecham chief executive Jan Leschly has attacked the US competition authorities for being "unreasonable" in delaying the drugs company's £130bn merger with rival Glaxo Wellcome.
fields.body:
Former SmithKline Beecham chief executive Jan Leschly has attacked the US competition authorities for being "unreasonable" in delaying the drugs company's £130bn merger with rival Glaxo Wellcome.

Mr Leschly, who was one of the architects of the deal, spoke out amid mounting frustration at the Federal Trade Commission's reluctance to make a decision on the transaction, which has left tens of thousands of staff unsure about their future. He said: "The FTC is taking its time. It has dragged this out in an unreasonable way - it shouldn't take a year to rule on a deal like this."

Mr Leschly now runs a $100m (£70m) fund called Care Capital, which is looking for investments in the drugs industry. He remains, however, a big shareholder in SmithKline with more than £85m in stock and options.

Although he had a poor relationship with Glaxo's chairman Sir Richard Sykes, Mr Leschly is a strong advocate of the merger: "I really would like to see the two groups come together."

The FTC is considering whether the combined corporation will have an excessive share of the market for smoking cessation products - SmithKline's Nicoderm chewing gum and Nicorette skin patches are thought to clash with Glaxo's Zyban anti-addiction drug.

This has infuriated executives, who point out that these products account for only 4% of total sales. Some industry experts believe political considerations could be delaying the deal - vice-president Al Gore has stressed his tough attitude towards big drugs companies during the US presidential election campaign and could be embarrassed if such a deal appeared to be waved through.

Unions believe 5,000 employees could be made redundant after the merger. All decisions have been put on ice until the deal, due to be finalised in August, is completed.

webTitle: Patently the poor will lose

fields.headline: Patently the poor will lose
fields.standfirst: Kevin Watkins
fields.trailText: Thomas Jefferson, the third President of the United States, saw knowledge as a shared public asset. "He who receives an idea from me," he wrote "receives instruction himself without lessening mine; as he who lights his taper at mine receives light without darkening me."
fields.body:
Thomas Jefferson, the third President of the United States, saw knowledge as a shared public asset. "He who receives an idea from me," he wrote "receives instruction himself without lessening mine; as he who lights his taper at mine receives light without darkening me."

As the architect of the first US patent system, Jefferson put principle into practice. In order to induce innovations that would enhance public welfare, inventors were rewarded for a short period with exclusive marketing rights. Above all, Jefferson wanted to ensure that America did not repeat the European experience, under which absolutist monarchs used patents to create monopolies, enriching themselves at the public expense.

Times change. Today, industrialised countries are using their control over the World Trade Organisation to create global intellectual property rules that reward monopolies, boost profits and seize the benefits of trade. The losers will be the world's poorest countries, where the WTO regime will raise the cost of technology and vital drugs and stifle innovation.

Under the new WTO intellectual property regime, patent protection will be extended to 20 years and be widened to include products such as seeds and medicines. More importantly, the new regime will be backed by the threat of trade sanctions against countries that fail to comply.

It is not difficult to see who wins from these rules.The big winners from all this are corporations in the north which account for over two-thirds of global expenditure on research and development, along with over 90% of patents. For them, stronger patents mean bigger profits. The balance-of-payments benefits are equally clear. Royalty payments to the US alone have almost doubled in the 1990s to over $33bn.

For developing countries, which start implementing the new WTO regime this year, the implications are devastating. Innovation in these countries typically takes the form of copying imported technologies and adapting it to local conditions. Enhanced patent protection will have the twin effect of restricting the scope for copying and increase the cost of technology transfer. The WTO patent regime will reinforce the technological divide between rich and poor. Countries such as India and Egypt have developed large-scale pharmaceutical industries that specialise in low-cost drugs for low-income populations through patent legislation allowing firms to copy expensive imported drugs, provided that they can find a new process for producing them. This practice will now be outlawed.

The public health implications of the new WTO regime are devastating. With HIV/AIDS rampant, life-saving drugs will be placed beyond the means of the poor as profit is placed before people. The hypocrisy of this defies credibility. Having developed themselves by copying imported technologies, countries such as the US are now seeking to deny poor countries the same opportunity.

Northern governments seek to justify the new WTO patent rules by saying that they will stimulate investment. In fact, there is no evidence to substantiate this. Rather, they have colluded in creating an intellectual property regime that subordinates the wider public good to the pursuit of corporate profit.

What is needed is a new set of rules that limits the scope and duration of patent protection. Achieving this will require that powerful governments place public interest and the needs of the world's poor above those of powerful transnational companies. But, as Jefferson realised, that's their job.

 Kevin Watkins is a senior policy adviser at Oxfam

But, as Jefferson realised, that's their job.  Kevin Watkins is a senior policy adviser at Oxfam

webTitle: Vital to allay concerns of parents and teenagers

fields.headline: Vital to allay concerns of parents and teenagers
fields.trailText: It has been a fun week. We have been spending a lot of time looking at colourful screenshots, deciding whether pink looks good with blue as we design what will be our latest version of the Rools website. We are redesigning the site as we gear up for our first customers.
fields.body:
It has been a fun week. We have been spending a lot of time looking at colourful screenshots, deciding whether pink looks good with blue as we design what will be our latest version of the Rools website. We are redesigning the site as we gear up for our first customers.

Talking of first customers, although they are not using the Rools online shopping service which we are testing, we already have thousands of people who have registered with us and want to use Rools to shop online.

We are starting to have to respond to greater numbers of customer inquiries - things like "I have forgotten my user name and password" and "where can I use my Rools card to get discounts?".

Handling customer service effectively is an issue for all companies with pressures to drive down costs. For Rools it is simply about numbers of bodies. We have to try to be as efficient as possible because we do not have the 3,000-person call centres that the big banks have. Technology has helped us. We have a slick system which automatically allocates e-mails to the right person.

Once we are launched, we will also be able to automate the responses. This kind of efficiency will give us a competitive advantage and it keeps the investors happy.

More important for us at the moment is keeping our customers happy. The most enjoyable thing we did this week was to call up the winners of our scooter competition.

We have been running a competition to win one of 10 microscooters on the Rools website for the past two months. We have had thousands of entries, and last Monday, our system selected the 10 winners.

We phoned each of them. It was a fun experience as for the most part, they were excited to have won. Two of our winners played it really cool - but you could tell they were hiding their excitement. We spoke to a number of parents in the process of confirming the addresses.

Nearly all were happy that their child had won. We had one concerned parent, though, who was suspicious about why his son was getting a scooter for nothing.

We have spent a lot of time and effort developing a communication programme and business model that will allay both parents' and teenagers' concerns.

At the end of the day, we are enjoying developing a new business and extremely advance technology and are creating a service which will be of value to teenagers. Making sure that message gets across is fairly easy as we have only a few thousand people to deal with.

Keeping that message alive and dealing with customers effectively will become a far greater challenge when we get into the hundreds of thousands.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com, a service that enables teenagers to shop online

webTitle: Man of steel

fields.headline: Man of steel
fields.standfirst: More than a century after his death, Isambard Kingdom Brunel is still the greatest engineer Britain has ever produced. Jonathan Glancey hails a visionary who refused to compromise
fields.trailText: More than a century after his death, Isambard Kingdom Brunel is still the greatest engineer Britain has ever produced. Jonathan Glancey hails a visionary who refused to compromise
fields.body:
Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806-59) was one of the greatest of all engineers. His protean works shaped the way we now view Victorian Britain - a waistcoated thing of cocksure, masculine endeavour - and the fast-disappearing industrial landscape that once made Britain the workshop of the world. To have designed and built the Royal Albert bridge in Saltash and the Clifton Suspension near Bristol alone would have made Brunel's name near-immortal. Add to these, in a life of just 53 years, the revolutionary Great Western and Great Eastern steamships, Paddington station, a prefab hospital for Florence Nightingale in the Crimea, the fastest railway locomotives of the day and an entire mainline railway - the Great Western from Paddington to Bristol - and you have a 19th-century Hercules.

Today, in the suitably hushed and cathedral-like setting of London's Design Museum, Brunel's life and legacy are celebrated in a calm, intelligent exhibition that makes you marvel not just at how one man could have achieved so much, but at how he led several revolutions in design, engineering and architecture. Certainly Brunel proves to be hard for modern commentators to cope with: in the past fortnight he has been described as "an architect" and even as "product designer" in reviews of the exhibition.

He was neither of these things. He was an engineer from the straps of his battered boots to the lofty rim of his stove-pipe hat. You can see that he was bursting with energy and had precious little time for the etiquette of his age in Robert Howlett's iconic photograph of him standing beside the massive chains of the "checking drum" from the Great Eastern steamship in 1857. Brunel's stance suggests a man who finds being photographed a damned bore. His restless hands are thrust into his high trouser pockets, one leg is bent as if he is ready to stride out of the camera's frame. His gaze is far off. There is a cigar cantilevered aggressively to one side of his wide mouth. So much to do, says Howlett's unforgettable portrait, so little time.

The Design Museum's exhibition, designed by Nicholas Grimshaw and Partners, is worthwhile because instead of trying to encompass the entire canon of Brunel's work, it focuses on seven key projects. There are commentaries by architects and engineers such as Grimshaw and Tony Hunt, who remain in thrall to their Victorian mentor. David Marks and Julia Barfield, architects of the London Eye, capture Brunel's perennial appeal nicely when they suggest that he remains a role model for designers, architects, engineers, artists and managers. "He had energy, talent and determination, creating visionary designs and applying new engineering principles, as well as co-ordinating and motivating people from all walks of life. He transformed the British landscape and changed peoples' lives."

He could also be silly. It sounds the stuff of music-hall song but Brunel once swallowed a gold sovereign while performing a trick at a children's party. The coin got stuck in one of his lungs. Doctors came and, as they charged their fees, said there was no cure for this disease - so Brunel devised a vertical turntable on to which he was strapped. As it turned, the coin was expelled.

He wasn't always successful either. The Great Eastern - at 692ft long and 18,915 tons (no bigger ship was built for 40 years) - proved to be, in the words of naval architect Fred M Walker, "designed for a market that had not been properly researched. She was just too large and built too soon for the technology of the time."

Brunel's determination to design on a colossal scale was both in tune with the ambitions of the ever-expanding British Empire and a godsend to those in charge of his physical legacy today. Famously, when he built the Great Western Railway during the late 1830s and 1840s, he did so to a track gauge of 7ft 1 / 4 in. This "broad-gauge" track enabled GW trains to run quickly and smoothly at a time when rail travel was a decidedly bumpy experience, although perhaps not quite as bad as the west-coast mainline today. The tracks of the rest of Britain's rail network were just 4ft 8 1 / 2 in apart. This was made the national standard early on; even so, the last broad-gauge trains ran from Brunel's superb Paddington station as late as 1892.

Thinking big also gave us the sublime Clifton Suspension bridge over the Avon Gorge near Bristol. Maybe it needn't be as dramatic as it is for the slight loads it carries, yet who can deny that Brunel's design, with its characterful Egyptian pylons at either end, enhances as it frames the Avon riverscape? At Saltash, Brunel did away with such fashionable niceties. Here, they are almost 20th-century functional. One bears the stark legend "I K Brunel Engineer 1859", added soon after Brunel's death from a heart attack on board the Great Eastern. He was photographed seconds before his collapse. The picture is in the exhibition and in the fine catalogue designed by Isambard Thomas, a descendant.

Brunel pushed the cause of prefabrication, mass production and the multi-disciplinary design practice. He also bequeathed to Britain a particular architectural legacy, the engineering-based buildings of, among others, Norman Foster, Richard Rogers and Nicholas Grimshaw (who continues to work on the redevelopment of Paddington station). In a prolific career, he built 25 railway lines, five suspension bridges and 125 other bridges. Add to this eight pier and dock systems, three ships, an observatory, a rifle, water towers, the prefab Crimean hospital and most of Swindon when the town was effectively refounded by the Great Western Railway in 1841, and it is no wonder he retains God-like status among so many engineers. The fact that he took risks - although not with lives - and was prepared to fail adds to his grandeur.

Today, as your Great Western diesel snarls west out of Swindon, look out for the locomotive works and other Brunel buildings; they are now a railway museum and a "designer retail outlet". You can't help thinking of Shelley's Ozymandias: "Look on my works, ye mighty, and despair." Luckily, the road bridge at Clifton and the bridge at Saltash remain to remind us just how much we owe this extraordinary man. The exhibition is a good one. No tricks. No gimmicks. Just major respect for the works of the engineer as hero.

Isambard Kingdom Brunel is at the Design Museum, London SE1, until February 25. Details: 020-7940 8790.

webTitle: Battle of the blands

fields.headline: Battle of the blands
fields.standfirst: It was the biggest chart clash since Blur versus Oasis: Westlife versus the Spice Girls. What does that tell us about today's music business, asks Caroline Sullivan
fields.trailText: It was the biggest chart clash since Blur versus Oasis: Westlife versus the Spice Girls. What does that tell us about today's music business, asks Caroline Sullivan.
fields.body:
You could be excused for being underwhelmed by the candidates in last week's big battle. One boasted long experience in public life, while the other had rocketed out of nowhere only a year ago. Yet many members of the public still complained that they couldn't tell them apart. Not that this stopped them pursuing victory with equal intensity, campaigning up and down the country right into the crucial last few hours.

The nail-biting finish proved to be more interesting than the contest itself, with the victor finally pulling ahead after a tense week that exposed both sides as power-hungry masters of PR. In an emotional concession speeech, the loser declared, "At the end of the day, it's about the big picture, not just this country," and flounced off to Gucci.

In a week when Britain seemed to be going to hell on a fast train (had any been running) and the rest of the world was focused on Bush and Gore, it's reassuring to know that we've got our priorities right. Westlife's ultimately successful struggle with the Spice Women for number one album figured heavily in the press all last week, with the tabloids even running daily counts ahead of yesterday's final chart positions.

The combatants did their damnedest to convince us the rivalry was personal. Westlife's Kian warned, "We're going to do as much as we can to kick their asses", while Mel C displayed a Liam Gallagheresque grasp of invective: "Westlife are a useless bunch of talentless tossers who don't deserve to be in the charts. They'll probably beat us to number one, which sums up how shit music is at the moment." Obviously, Ms C is in no way responsible for the manufactured teen-pop bands who have strangled the UK charts for the past three years.

Both camps held launch parties at London clubs within yards of each other on the same night. If nudity counts, the Spice bash was the runaway winner, with the previously demure Baby flashing hemispheres of bosom, while Posh was naked save for wisps of green chiffon. But Westlife put on more of a show, inviting not just a Spice tribute band but - oh, unkindest cut - Mel C's ex-boyfriend, J from Five. There wasn't much atmosphere at either bash, though, until Mels B and C directed an unprovoked string of F-words at a group of journalists.

We all enjoyed this scrap between two lots of dancers who, in a more righteous age, would have enjoyed careers as understudies to the First Elf in a provincial production of Cinderella. But it is a sad reminder that we live in a time when ambition is deemed more important than talent, and "music" is something that helps pop stars pass the time on the way to Camp Famous. As Kian put it, "If we don't go in at number one, I don't know where we go from here." May I suggest the chorus line of Riverdance?

So it has been an ignominious battle, pitting a band who took time out from solo careers for a temporary show of unity against a band who have had seven chart-topping singles, none of which most people could name. And the public has become increasingly sophisticated about the dark art of public relations: we've seen too many false "relationships" and "feuds" in the last few years to believe that this is anything more than massive hype to line the pockets of all concerned.

It gives the last big chart rivalry, the 1995 Blur/Oasis squabble (let's forget Victoria Beckham's catfight with Sophie Ellis-Bextor last summer), the feeling of a lost golden age. It may have been equally contrived, with Damon Albarn changing Blur's release date to challenge Oasis, but there was a sense of fun, like yobbos squaring off in the playground. While neither song (Roll With It and Country House) was outstanding, each could only have come from Gallagher or Albarn's pen.

By comparison, the Westlife/Spice contest, and the albums themselves, feel utterly impersonal. The whole affair has little to do with music and everything to do with making sure RCA and Virgin shareholders have a happy Christmas, and the protagonists can keep shopping at Prada.

However unconvincing the hissing and spitting, retailers were delighted with so-called Super Monday, which also saw the release of Fatboy Slim's Halfway Between the Gutter & The Stars - unexpectedly consigned to a dismal eighth place with only 21,000 sales by last Friday. "We've definitely had more people in because of these albums, and this really gets the ball rolling for Christmas," says Gennaro Castaldo of HMV. He's echoed by Paul Williams of trade magazine Music Week: "It's excellent news for retail. This is the most high-profile battle in years, and the media interest has generated plenty of sales. Record companies study each other's release schedules and usually avoid releasing in the same week as big records, but RCA [Westlife's label] were determined to be up against the Spice Girls. They wanted the battle to be played out."

Westlife had more to lose if they missed out on number one. Unlike the Spices, they have yet to break America, so a British chart-topper provides them with a foundation for another try. One of this year's hot industry topics has been the British and Irish inability to crack the US: in 1999, acts from these islands accounted for a total of 0.2% of the American chart, compared with 32% in 1986. George Michael, whose Wham! were part of that 32%, has blamed the downturn on a glut of manufactured, stage-school bands. But Westlife may be the biggest hope for success by a British-signed act in the land of Limp Bizkit. It's not that we haven't got a plethora of groovy young rock acts to throw at them, such as Coldplay and Doves, it's just that none of them is big enough to be considered sexy in a country where, if your last album didn't sell 10m copies, you're small potatoes.

The last huge British or Irish hit there was, of course, by the Spices, who are currently in transition from cultural icondom to...who knows what? If there are any lessons to be learned from the WestSpice stand-off, it's that Girl Power now exists only in 20th-century phrasebooks, and that winning is more important than anything else.

Last week Emma Bunton nicely summed up this sad ethos: "Westlife really deserve to be number one with the amount of promotion they've been doing." Not because they've made a good record, but because they've promoted it well. Makes you sick, doesn't it?

webTitle: No talks until killings stop, Jakarta told

fields.headline: No talks until killings stop, Jakarta told
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Separatist guerrillas in Aceh last night pulled out of peace talks planned for this week with the Indonesian government, as police and army brutality in the restive province continued unabated.
fields.body:
Separatist guerrillas in Aceh last night pulled out of peace talks planned for this week with the Indonesian government, as police and army brutality in the restive province continued unabated.

One day after tens of thousands of people rallied in the provincial capital, Banda Aceh, in support of a referendum on the province's sovereignty, the Free Aceh Movement (GAM) said it would not attend the talks in Switzerland until the police and army "stopped murdering civilians".

Human rights activists say the confirmed death toll since Wednesday in the province, on the northern tip of Sumatra, is 34 and that they are checking reports of other fatalities. More than 120 have been hurt.

The leader of the GAM, Amni Marzuki said of the security forces: "They claim to be fighting GAM but the reality is they are just killing innocent people who want to exercise their right to demonstrate freely."

The crackdown was ordered to prevent hundreds of thousands arriving in Banda Aceh for the weekend rally - police had claimed there would be a huge riot if numbers were not limited. But with people pouring towards the city, officials had no idea how to respond, except with the deadly tactics used by the previous regime.

A British researcher, Lesley McCulloch, said she witnessed "uncontrolled police and army brutality" several times last week. "I saw people being shot at," she said. "I saw people being forced to sing Indonesian songs and pray to the police at gunpoint... All this was because they wanted to attend the rally in Banda Aceh."

The tension is likely to remain high because organisers said the rally would continue until all those who wanted to attend could do so. "We are not going to give up," coordinator Muhammad Nazar said. "We owe it to all the people of Aceh to stay here so they can come and register their views."

He said GAM had nothing to do with the rally but that the rebels would support it "because just about everyone here wants independence".

webTitle: Country retreat for Republican first family

fields.headline: Country retreat for Republican first family
fields.standfirst:
Down on the farm the tension takes its toll
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: In George W Bush's one public appearance of the weekend, the Republican candidate referred all enquiries to the former secretary of state James Baker: "He'll be the person in charge of explaining our position on why we don't think we need three elections."
fields.body:
In George W Bush's one public appearance of the weekend, the Republican candidate referred all enquiries to the former secretary of state James Baker: "He'll be the person in charge of explaining our position on why we don't think we need three elections."

Mr Baker said that with a manual recount, "human error, individual subjectivity, and decisions to 'determine the voters' intent', would replace precision machinery in tabulating millions of small marks and fragile hole punches."

Republican strategists, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that pending the outcome of the Democrats' legal challenge to the presidential election in Palm Beach county - on which the result in Florida hangs - they were considering challenging narrow Gore victories in Wisconsin, Oregon or elsewhere, or possibly seeking recounts in other Florida counties.

"All options are open," Mr Bush told reporters at his ranch outside Waco, Texas. His running mate Dick Cheney was at his side.

The would-be president assured reporters and campaign officials that he was feeling great and had slept well at Prairie Chapel Ranch. "It's nice to be out in the country ... it's nice to be in the same bed two nights in a row," he said.

The tension of the past week has taken a physical toll on the Bush family. A boil had forced Mr Bush to appear with a plaster on his cheek, while his father, the former president, complained of chronic indigestion on election night. Both men retired to the countryside this weekend, one to walk his dogs and the other to hunt.

Wearing a cowboy hat and mud-spattered boots for a pre-arranged photo opportunity, he scolded his springer spaniel Spot for interrupting as he spoke to reporters. When the dog continued to bark, he quipped: "What she said was, 'let's finish the recount'."

Mr Bush was joined at the ranch by Mr Cheney and Andrew Card, who many predict will be White House chief of staff in the event of a Bush victory. In an attempt to head off accusations of arrogance from the Democrats, the Bush campaign team insisted that their man was spending no more time picking his cabinet than he was exercising in the gym over the weekend. There was even a suggestion that he was focusing on plans for a new house planned on the ranch with his wife.

A campaign spokeswoman in the Texan state capital Austin confirmed that the governor would "just hang out" at his 1,700-acre getaway. There were no public appearances yesterday.

While his son was relaxing, George Bush senior, or Pappy, flew to Spain to hunt red partridges and speak with King Juan Carlos.

In an interview with Time magazine published today, the former president contemplated a defeat for his eldest son. "There is life afterward, and George is very strong; he is very strong and resilient."

"He will land on his feet in five minutes, but there will be hurt, deep hurt."

The patriarch also played down any suggestion of tension between his sons, nicknamed the Shrubs. "The family will take pride that he went as far as he did," he said, rejecting any comparison with the Kennedys.

"We are not that way in this family. This is not about vindication or legacy or entitlement. It is about the love of a father for his son, the love of a mother for her son."

Meanwhile, Barbara Bush is said to have confided to a friend: "I was the mother of a president for 30 minutes, and I loved it."

webTitle: What the papers say

fields.headline: What the papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Los Angeles Times
fields.body:
Los Angeles Times

Yes, each side has legitimate complaints, but Statesmanship requires that the argument end long before the last lawyer sings. Bad design and voter confusion do not add up to fraud, and the truth is that nationwide this was a very clean election, compared with both America's history and most of the globe today.

Washington Post

There were headlines in some foreign newspapers mocking the world's greatest democracy for its difficulty in electing its own president. The mockery seems to us misplaced; so, too, the squeaking about a constitutional crisis. Control of the national government is at stake. But so is the legitimacy of the final result, whether people in the end will accept the outcome as having been fair. And on that will rest to some degree the ability of the winner to lead the country.

Miami Herald

Ultimately this test should prove the strength of American democracy. But it will also place a burden on whoever is named president to heal the rifts this untidy democratic process will leave in its wake.

webTitle: Democrat duo seek solace at the movies

fields.headline: Democrat duo seek solace at the movies
fields.standfirst:
Vice-president relaxes with sport, cinema but no fast food
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore went to the movies with his wife on Saturday night. The title of the film?: Men of Honour.
fields.body:
Al Gore went to the movies with his wife on Saturday night. The title of the film?: Men of Honour.

The vice-president's decision to watch a film about racial prejudice amid square-jawed self-sacrificing masculinity raised some eyebrows among cynical Washington watchers yesterday as he attempted to appear relaxed and unaffected by the closest campaign in US presidential history. He and Tipper were joined by Mr Gore's running mate, Joe Lieberman, and his wife. Both men wore matching brown sweaters, but neither ate popcorn, the traditional method of appearing to be a relaxed man of the people.

The film provided ample fodder for anyone looking for parallels with this year's Gore campaign. The New York Times described Men of Honour - which stars Democrat Robert de Niro - as "square and sentimental but not cynical". Mr Gore's decision to go out with Mr Lieberman, the first Jewish politician to be chosen for a presidential ticket, also seemed fitting for a film based on a true story about overcoming racial prejudice in the US navy.

Neither Mr Gore nor Mr Lieberman talked about the film much this weekend, and they completely avoided all questions about Florida, recounts or legal action.

Yesterday, the vice-president donned his usual dark suit and tie to attend a local church service in Virginia with his entire family. Saying a statesmanlike "good morning" to the assembled reporters, he shepherded Tipper, his daughters and son Al into the pretty, sun-dappled local church.

Mr Gore has said little since his eleventh-hour decision to turn back from accepting defeat early on Wednesday morning. His only official appearances have involved his family and Mr Lieberman.

The Gores played tag football together on Friday, before Mr Gore and his wife attended a dinner hosted by his son's football team on Friday night. Mr Gore, who went without sleep for 50 consecutive hours this week, was said to have attended almost every one of his son's Saturday morning games during the campaign.

After he returned to Washington, his campaign headquarters in Nashville, Tennessee, was disbanded and exhausted team workers followed him to the capital as a team of lawyers was sent to monitor events in Florida.

Mr Gore is expected to return to his duties as vice-president this week, when congress returns to the capital.

Donna Brazile, Mr Gore's turnout strategist, meanwhile revealed she had lost her Bible and lucky "grounding stones" given to her by her grandmother. Moments after she realised her suitcase was missing, on the morning after the election, the first reports surfaced of confusion among Democrat voters in Palm Beach.

webTitle: Future hangs on hunt for elusive particle

fields.headline: Future hangs on hunt for elusive particle
fields.standfirst:
A sample hand recount shows tiny, but maybe vital, difference
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: For the many tipsy revellers making their way from one Palm Beach nightclub to another, it was a bewildering sight. A huge throng of journalists and television cameramen were lined up outside an office building, staring for hours on end at the scene within.
fields.byline: Julian Borger in West Palm Beach
fields.body:
For the many tipsy revellers making their way from one Palm Beach nightclub to another, it was a bewildering sight. A huge throng of journalists and television cameramen were lined up outside an office building, staring for hours on end at the scene within.

On the other side of the plate glass window, there were no movie stars or national leaders, just a tableau of exhausted bureacrats slumped in their chairs holding manila rectangles of cardboard up to the fluorescent light, like connoisseurs comparing notes.

As far as the mostly oblivious Saturday night partygoers were concerned, it could have been a regular meeting of the cardboard collectors' club, but the reality was far stranger. Somewhere in those flimsy yellow rectangles lay the coded fate of the US and perhaps the world, and this sleep-derived group of local civic leaders from this affuent seaside resort had been entrusted with the task of deciphering it.

The more you peered into that coldly-lit room, the odder it seemed. The panel inside the media fishtank were poring over the cardboard in search of something called "chad", which in the past 48 hours has become to the US electoral process what the "quark" is to physics - a tiny and obscure particle on which absolutely everything may hinge.

This is what is known so far about "chad": It can be both singular and plural, it comes in a variety of forms including "hanging chad", "swing-door chad", "tri-chad" and even "pregnant chad", and it can be more visible to the naked human eye than it is to machines.

Chad occurs when voters are asked to express their preferences with punchcards dotted with very small perforated rectangles. On the Palm Beach ballot, there were 228 of such little perforations.

The voter is supposed to use a pointed instrument to knock out the tiny rectangles alongside his or her choice of candidate. What "alongside" means precisely is a point of bitter debate, but more of that later. If the perforated rectangle is punched but manages to cling on by one or more of the cardboard slivers connecting it to the card, it becomes "chad" and a threat to democracy.

It is a menace because when the voter's card is fed through an automatic vote-counting machine, the "chad" is often smoothed back into the hole, in effect nullifying the vote. It does not happen often, but with the margin between Governor George W Bush and Vice-President Al Gore in the decisive state of Florida a mere 327 votes out of some 9m cast across the state, it could be decisive.

Palm Beach county had opted to use something called a "butterfly ballot", on which the names of candidates were arranged on both sides of a central strip of punch-holes, which, in a few thousand cases, appears to have caused confusion as to which candidate was alongside which hole. According to the automated count, more than 29,000 votes - an unusually high number - were recorded as spoilt because they had been punched too many times, or not at all.

A manual recount was ordered in Palm Beach and three other counties which had problems of their own. In Palm Beach Here among the hotels and nightclubs, the task fell to the three-member canvassing board, consisting of Theresa LePore, the hapless elections supervisor who had designed the butterfly ballot, Charles Burton, a county judge, and Carol Roberts, a county commissioner. But for the sake of (literal) transparency, they were to be watched by the world's media and accompanied by assorted political observers.

The count, of a sample 1% of the county's votes, started at 2pm on Saturday with a solemn invocation from Ms LePore: "Never touch the chad".

At the outset the board tried to gauge how much light was showing through the little holes, bringing shouts of "There is light through there", and "that's just a micron of light".

It was soon clear that this was not going to work. No one, least of all the Republican and Democratic observers, was going to agree on what constituted enough light. So the board reverted to a 1990 rule, which stipulated that if any of the slivers holding the perforated rectangle to the voting card had been broken, it would count as a vote.

Three slivers was known as a "tri-chad", two slivers would be a "swing-door chad", one sliver was a "hanging chad". If the rectangle had been pressed so it protruded without any of its slivers being bro ken, it was a "pregnant chad", or sometimes a "dimple chad", and it did not count as a vote. As Judge Burton pointed out on more than one occasion: "You can't be a little bit pregnant".

The board examined 4,695 ballots and it took them 11 hours, deep into the early hours of yesterday morning.

"It was amazing", said the Green party's excited observer, Medea Benjamin, as she emerged into the warm night air. "The fate of the most powerful country in the world hangs in the balance with those stacks of cards."

After the recount, Mr Gore's vote total was up 33, and Mr Bush's by 14, a net gain of 19. If that was just 1% of the Palm Beach vote, the Democrats argued, then a total manual recount over the whole county could swing the election in Florida in the vice-president's favour.

In an exemplary stab at open democracy, the three board members stood in front of the cameras argued out the merits of calling a full recount, but they were clearly exhausted and sometimes struggled for coherence.

Carol Roberts, a Democrat, insisted that the board vote on the spot on whether to hold a recount. Judge Burton, a less committed Democrat, said the board should wait until Monday to ask for advice.

It was left to Theresa LePore to decide. She is also a Democrat who has reportedly cried every day since it was discovered that her ballot design could have cost the party the presidency. She looked pale and barely conscious. She initially seconded both Ms Roberts and Judge Burton's proposals, but when she was told she could not, she sided with Ms Roberts.

Ms Roberts, a petite middle-aged woman in steel-rimmed glasses, always seemed likely to win out. She remained grimly determined. The other two looked as if they would say anything to get some sleep.

The vote-counters dispersed into the night to rest before another few days of chad-squinting, barring a successful Republican injunction against the manual recount today. In the empty room a discarded election-day sign stood propped against a wall. "I Count, I Vote" it declared.

In the pre-dawn hours yesterday that seemed debatable, at best.

webTitle: New moves on drugs, guns - and interracial marriage

fields.headline: New moves on drugs, guns - and interracial marriage
fields.standfirst:
Local voting on key issues is a barometer of public feeling
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Interracial marriages in Alabama will for the first time have the full sanction of the state constitution. Voters in the state passed by 60% to 40% a measure that removed an ancient anomaly from the statute books making it the only state where such marriages were forbidden although the law was unenforceable and more of an embarrassment than a reality.
fields.body:
Interracial marriages in Alabama will for the first time have the full sanction of the state constitution. Voters in the state passed by 60% to 40% a measure that removed an ancient anomaly from the statute books making it the only state where such marriages were forbidden although the law was unenforceable and more of an embarrassment than a reality.

Initiatives for changes at state and county level in the areas of drugs and firearms laws and education policy were resolved last week even if voters still do not know who their new president will be.

While many of the measures may run into challenges in the courts, at federal level they are seen as a useful barometer of public feeling on such key issues. A total of 42 states voted on such propositions.

One of the most controversial measures, which would have legalised marijuana in Alaska, failed by 20%, although the measure received the support of the majority of voters in the state capital of Juneau. But in northern California, a measure in Mendocino county that would allow locals to grow up to 25 marijuana plants and instructing local sheriffs to place small-scale marijuana growers low on their list of priorities did go through. Such measures do not override state law, which still forbids growing marijuana, but the measure, passed by 58% to 42%, is seen as symbolic in an area where many marijuana growers live.

In California as a whole, a measure to give treatment to first time drug offenders rather than send them to prison was passed by 59% to 41%. The proposition had been supported by an unsuccessful Republican senate candidate, Tom Campbell, but was opposed by the actor and Democrat supporter Martin Sheen.

California has one of the highest numbers of prisoners among the states and the $120m (£84m) the drug treatment will cost is seen as likely to be outweighed by savings in prison costs. The passing of the measure by such a large percentage is seen by its sup porters as a first sign of the backlash against the "war on drugs" supported by the administration.

Another controversial measure in California that would have introduced $4,000 vouchers a child for schools was defeated. Its critics had claimed that it would destroy the state school system. Despite a multi-million dollar campaign, the measure fell by 71% to 29%. In Michigan, a similar measure with a $3 ,300 voucher failed. Other measures that failed included attempts to tie teachers' pay to student achievement in Oregon. Teachers had campaigned against both measures.

Nevada and Colorado, which voted as states for Bush as president, both passed propositions that legalise marijuana for medical use, bringing to eight the number of states to do so. In Nevada and Nebraska, a measure banning recognition of gay marriages from outside the state passed by 70% to 30%. Attempts to limit urban sprawl in Arizona and Colorado both failed.

In Maine, a measure that would have legalised doctor-assisted suicide was narrowly defeated. A measure that would have made it illegal to discriminate against gays and lesbians in housing and employment also failed.

Some gun reforms were also passed, despite heavy lobbying by the National Rifle Association at local and national level. Measures requiring background checks on people buying guns passed as expected, by 70% to 30%, in Colorado. Emotion had run high following the deaths of 15 people last year in the Columbine high school shooting. Oregon passed a similar measure.

Arizona passed a measure which ended bilingual teaching and required immersion lessons to bring non-English speaking children up to the required level. This measure reflected the argument over whether children in predominantly Spanish areas should be taught in their first language. It also reflected some of the feelings over illegal border crossings by Mexicans.

In San Francisco, proposition L, which would have slowed property development in the city and made provisions for rented accommodation, was still being counted on Sunday with the lead contantly changing. Property developers had put $2m into a campaign against the move, which was in response to rent rises caused by an e-commerce boom. Mayor Willie Brown campaigned strongly against the proposition.

webTitle: Bush court challenge as lead slips

fields.headline: Bush court challenge as lead slips
fields.standfirst:
Republican push to end recount as result tilts toward Gore
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A Florida court is due to make a ruling today which could determine the outcome of the agonisingly close US presidential election, after Republicans appealed to a federal judge to halt a manual vote recount which appeared yesterday to be tipping against them.
fields.byline: Julian Borger in West Palm Beach
fields.body:
A Florida court is due to make a ruling today which could determine the outcome of the agonisingly close US presidential election, after Republicans appealed to a federal judge to halt a manual vote recount which appeared yesterday to be tipping against them.

With tension rising in the absence of a clear result, political observers warned that unless the political parties backed down, a decision on the outcome could be forced all the way to the supreme court for the first time in US history.

A quick compromise looked unlikely as the gap between governor George W Bush and Vice-President Al Gore continued to narrow in the key state of Florida when manual recounting got under way yesterday. In Palm Beach county, a sample hand recount of 1% of the votes cast in last Tuesday's poll resulted in a net gain of 19 votes for Mr Gore.

A three-member local electoral board voted for a full hand recount across the county, since the sample showed that the discrepancy between the hand count and two earlier automated counts was potentially big enough to overturn Mr Bush's lead in Florida of 327 votes. The two candidates are so evenly balanced that whoever wins in Florida will be the next president.

A manual recount was also under way yesterday in Volusia county and another was due to start today in Broward county. In Miami-Dade, a fourth Florida county where the automated count was challenged by the Democrats, a decision on whether to go ahead with a hand recount was due to be made today.

In a separate development, police took possession of two ballot boxes found in Miami on Saturday - although it was not known if they contained ballot papers. One was found in the Sheraton hotel, the other in a church. There were also persistent reports that black voters were turned away from a polling station in the state capital, Tallahassee.

The manual recounting of votes is stipulated in contentious elections under Florida state law, but it could be halted today by the federal district court in Miami, where the Republican party is seeking an injunction against the count on constitutional grounds.

James Baker, a former secretary of state who is leading Mr Bush's post-electoral campaign, argued that by only recounting votes in counties with Democratic majorities, the hand recount would skew the result unfairly to Mr Gore. Furthermore Mr Baker argued, hand counting was subjective by its very nature.

"It's the principle that we're complaining about, the fact that you have here a situation where local election officials are given the power to interpret ballots," he said. The continued wrangling over the result, he argued, was "a black mark on our democracy and our process".

Mr Baker yesterday offered to withdraw the Republican lawsuit if the Democrats would suspend the manual recount and accept the existing count once absentee ballots from Americans living abroad were added by Friday.

Warren Christopher, another former secretary of state who is representing Mr Gore in the battle over ballots, insisted that a manual count was legal and would go ahead. He noted that Republicans in New Mexico had accepted the results of a manual count there, where it had reversed a narrow Gore lead to a four-vote advantage for Mr Bush after more than 570,000 votes were counted. A final batch of 189 votes has yet to be added. Nearly a week after the presidential election, the outcome is also uncertain in Oregon.

Mr Christopher said he expected the result to be settled in days. "We want to reach a full and fair result, but we want to do it in an expeditious way," he said.

However, if the manual ballot is allowed to go ahead and it swings the result in Mr Gore's favour, the Republicans have said they are ready to retaliate by calling for a new vote count in Republican-dominated Florida counties and possibly in other states, such as Wisconsin, where the automated count gave Mr Gore a victory by only 6,000 votes.

Mr Gore won about 216,000 more votes across the country than Mr Bush, but under US law it is not the national popular vote that decides the presidency. The president is chosen by a 538-seat electoral college, comprising electors deputed by individual states. It is winning states that matters, and yesterday Florida's 25 votes remained the key to the election.

webTitle: International in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Protesters die in Mozambique
fields.body:
Protesters die in Mozambique

The death toll from protests last week over last year's general election in Mozambique rose to 39 yesterday after several people died in hospital, state radio said.

The protests followed claims that the ruling Frelimo party rigged the election in areas dominated by the former rebel movement Renamo.
Reuters, Maputo

Six held over Kuwait 'plot'

Security officers have arrested two more Kuwaitis suspected of belonging to a terror group planning attacks on US forces in Kuwait, and a third has been held in Qatar.

Six suspects, all Kuwaitis, are now under arrest. A Moroccan suspect is still at large.
AP, Kuwait

DNA tests for Tutankhamun

Japanese and Egyptian archaeologists will conduct DNA tests on the mummy of Tutankhamun next month to try to determine his exact lineage, Egyptian officials said yesterday.

Samples will be taken from the mummy in its tomb in the Valley of the Kings.
Reuters, Cairo

webTitle: Swazis begin national strike

fields.headline: Swazis begin national strike
fields.trailText: Swaziland's monarchist government has reintroduced detention without trial ahead of a national strike starting today to demand political freedoms and an end to the abuse of power in the tiny kingdom.
fields.body:
Swaziland's monarchist government has reintroduced detention without trial ahead of a national strike starting today to demand political freedoms and an end to the abuse of power in the tiny kingdom.

The two-day strike, organised by the Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions (SFTU), was declared illegal last week after the union confederation's leaders were briefly arrested to prevent a pro-democracy rally.

The authorities' makhundu or "war bludgeon" powers allow for the detention of critics for 60 days without trial. The regulations were used 14 years ago to arrest political activists and journalists.

The strike comes on the heels of a petition drafted by the SFTU, three public service unions and a coalition of banned political parties which met in South Africa earlier this month. The petition calls for the legalisation of all political parties, an end to repressive labour laws and the scrapping of a system that permits traditional chiefs to arrest subjects almost at will and force them to work for nothing.

The union confederation has threatened to set up a government in exile if its demands are not met.

Swaziland's king, Sherborne-educated Mswati III, rules by decree with a hand-picked parliament. Political parties have been banned since a state of emergency was imposed 27 years ago.

Swazis have generally backed the monarchy but there has been growing discontent over the bar on political activity and recent draconian labour legislation. The crisis was brought to a head by the royal family's confiscation of property from about 200 families because the king's brother wanted the land.

The unions have the support of major business interests. On Friday, the national employers' federation wrote to the king criticising his policies for undermining the business climate.

The United States added to the pressure for reform last month by suspending valuable trade privileges to Swaziland in response to repressive labour legislation.

webTitle: Right seeks to vet 'textbook wrongs'

fields.headline: Right seeks to vet 'textbook wrongs'
fields.trailText: The descendants of Benito Mussolini's blackshirts have revived fears of totalitarian censorship by proposing to purge school textbooks of alleged Marxist bias.
fields.body:
The descendants of Benito Mussolini's blackshirts have revived fears of totalitarian censorship by proposing to purge school textbooks of alleged Marxist bias.

The National Alliance, a member of the centre-right opposition, wants a commission to excise offending passages dealing with 20th-century history. The appeal has alarmed the centre-left government and mortified some of the Alliance's own allies, who expect their coalition to win elections next year.

The National Alliance said councils that under its control would set up a "panel of experts" to vet reading lists. The party also controls the region of Lazio, which includes Rome.

Party spokesman Fabio Rampelli says the panel would be charged with "underscoring any insufficiency or arbitrary reconstruction of events".

"Some books distort the facts and omit entire historical periods with the mere aim of increasing Marxist historiography," he said.

Alleged bias includes twisting Mussolini's war record, ignoring partisan atrocities against fascists and distortions about recent events.

A history book by Augusto Camera and Renato Fabietti stands accused of assassinating the character of Silvio Berlusconi, the opposition leader who included the National Alliance in his 1994 government.

Mr Berlusconi's Forza Italia party distanced itself, saying that bias existed but that a panel was inappropriate. "The problem is finding the right cure," a spokesman said.

The prime minister, Giuliano Amato, will respond to the challenge in parliament tomorrow. His education minister, Tullio De Mauro, said: "In Italy we have free autonomous schools, in which free communities of teachers discuss, examine and decide, freely, which books they want to use."

His predecessor, Luigi Berlinguer, an ex-communist, said the plan smacked of Minculpop, Mussolini's culture ministry.

The row has undermined the National Alliance's efforts to rebrand itself as a mainstream party which had shed all remnants of racism, anti-semitism and totalitarianism.

A direct descendant of the Fascist party, it is led by the slick moderniser, Gianfranco Fini, whose diluted policies on law and order have angered some members. However, his moderating influence is said to be on the wane.

webTitle: Tables turned on Palestinian moneyspinner

fields.headline: Tables turned on Palestinian moneyspinner
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: One of Israel's tank shells pierced the upper fronds of the golden palm tree rising from the casino's roof; another dotted the "i" in Intercontinental at the adjoining hotel.
fields.body:
One of Israel's tank shells pierced the upper fronds of the golden palm tree rising from the casino's roof; another dotted the "i" in Intercontinental at the adjoining hotel.

And with that, and the machine-gun fire peppering its glass facade, the desert gambling den that is the Palestinians' most lucrative earner shut its doors.

As rubber bullets give way to helicopter gunships, the closure of the Oasis casino resort in Jericho this month marks the highest-profile casualty on a shadowy second front: Israel's war on the Palestinian economy.

The main weapon in Israel's arsenal is closure: a circle of steel around Gaza and the Palestinian cities in the West Bank. A system of Israeli army checkposts, concrete barricades, and bulldozed roads makes it virtually impossible to travel between cities in the West Bank, let alone to Israel, where some 125,000 Palestinians were working before the violence erupted at the end of September.

In Jericho, cut off by mountains and the desert from the rest of the West Bank, the sense of isolation is complete.

"This is a clear-cut case of economic punishment, collective punishment," said Abdelkarim Sedr, the city's mayor. "Israel is trying to punish every city, but it is hurting us most strongly in Jericho. They just could not stand the idea of us making money at the casino."

Until six weeks ago, the Jericho casino was the sole haven for the gamblers of the Holy Land. Off-limits to Palestinians, it was a magnet for Jewish punters, who arrived by the thousands every day.

Mr Sedr estimates the casino's direct losses since the shutdown at about £539,405 a day, with a knock-on effect on the guesthouses and cafes which used to service the resort's 2,000 employees.

There are also stories of agricultural destruction. Last week, Israeli soldiers bulldozed Ramadan Khamis Hameidat's fields on the outskirts of Jericho, levelling 4,000 banana trees. "They said it was for security because the trees were too close to the main highway," he said.

Hundreds of olive trees have been uprooted across the West Bank on the pretext of security.

The olive harvest is part of a new landscape of ruin across the West Bank. There is the half-built mall outside Ramallah, designed to attract Jewish customers in the days when peace seemed possible. In northern Tulkarm, there is the shell of a building meant to provide cheap office space for Israel's hi-tech industry.

In Gaza, the industrial park at the Karni border crossing, now transformed into one of the most lethal killing zones between Israel and the Palestinians. A future casualty could be Gaza's offshore natural gas project, led by BG International, formerly British Gas, which could fall apart because of security restrictions.

But there is nothing so devastating as the Israeli ban on Palestinian labour. Throughout the West Bank and Gaza, Palestinians cut off from their jobs in Israel are scrabbling to get by. In Hebron, where there is a 24-hour curfew, the local authorities have set up a soup kitchen for families whose savings have run out.

The Palestinian economy and trade ministry estimates that the siege cost at least £242m in its first month. A report by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian refugees put losses at £2.8m a day, with a further £161m lost because of Israeli trade restrictions.

webTitle: Bourbons surface to retake island

fields.headline: Bourbons surface to retake island
fields.trailText: Sicilian divers will this week try to plant a flag on a bubbling underwater volcano to thwart any claims of British sovereignty should it resurface.
fields.body:
Sicilian divers will this week try to plant a flag on a bubbling underwater volcano to thwart any claims of British sovereignty should it resurface.

The black lump known as Graham Island is threatening to reappear 169 years after a British naval captain planted a union flag and proclaimed it part of the empire.

To bolster their case, Sicilians, who call it Ferdinandea, summoned the descendant of the Bourbon King of Naples. In a ceremony filmed by a flotilla of camera crews, Prince Carlo di Bourbon lowered a plaque into the waves and told cheering locals: "It will always be Sicilian."

The island, 30 miles off the town of Sciacca, was first recorded in 10BC.

Concentric wave patterns suggest that the volcano, now six metres below the surface, is likely to rise in the near future, said the Italian National Institute of Geophysics.

When it last surfaced on July 18 1831, Capt Humphrey Le Fleming Senhouse led a British naval party to the summit and named it after the first lord of the admiralty, Sir James Robert George Graham.

The King of Naples, Ferdinand II, was furious at losing a potentially strategic base and sent a warship to replace the union flag.

A French party also landed and named it Giulia, setting the scene for a three-way war which was only averted when the island sank again on January 12 1832.

Lobbied by fishermen and sailors, Ignazio Cucchiara, the mayor of Sciacca, invited Prince Carlo to attend the ceremony with his wife, Countess Camilla Cruciani.

To accommodate television crews the plaque was lowered well before reaching the shoal, which is a danger to shipping.

The black lump known as Graham Island is threatening to reappear 169 years after a British naval captain planted a union flag and proclaimed it part of the empire. To bolster their case, Sicilians, who call it Ferdinandea, summoned the descendant of the Bourbon King of Naples. In a ceremony filmed by a flotilla of camera crews, Prince Carlo di Bourbon lowered a plaque into the waves and told cheering locals: "It will always be Sicilian." The island, 30 miles off the town of Sciacca, was first recorded in 10BC. The King of Naples, Ferdinand II, was furious at losing a potentially strategic base and sent a warship to replace the union flag. A French party also landed and named it Giulia, setting the scene for a three-way war which was only averted when the island sank again on January 12 1832. webTitle: Bosnian voters lose faith in nationalists

fields.headline: Bosnian voters lose faith in nationalists
fields.trailText: For the first time since the end of the war in Bosnia five years ago, parties not based on ethnic lines look set to win majorities in two of the country's three parliaments following elections this weekend.
fields.body:
For the first time since the end of the war in Bosnia five years ago, parties not based on ethnic lines look set to win majorities in two of the country's three parliaments following elections this weekend.

The need for jobs pushed ethnic issues far down the agenda in Saturday's general election.

Bosnia remains split into two entities - the Federation, where most of the Muslim and Croat population live, and the Serbian Republic. It also has a national government which has a say across both entities.

In the central parliament, social democrats, conservatives and liberal parties from both entities look set to form a majority coalition without the nationalists.

In the Federation, the Social Democratic party, led by a 46-year-old computer science professor, Zlatko Lagumdzija, looks set to win a majority. In the Serb-controlled half, the nationalist Serbian Democratic party (SDS) expects to win but may not have enough seats to rule alone. That should pave the way for Mladen Ivanic's Party of Democratic Progress (PDP) and the prime minister Milorad Dodik's Independent Social Democrats (SNSD) to share power with them.

Full results of the elections should become clear once the votes of up to 1m refugees and displaced persons are counted.

The Dayton peace accords which brought the war to an end in December 1995 are full of contradictions, allowing considerable power to be held by the two entities, but also the possibility of bolstering the institutions of the central state.

Overseeing the rebuilding of Bosnia is the international high representative, the Austrian diplomat Wolfgang Petritsch, who risks appeasing nationalists and alienating progressive forces by not doing enough to build central institutions.

In Sarajevo yesterday, Mr Petritsch announced the imposition of six laws to strengthen the central state. The laws include the establishment of a state court with jurisdiction in both halves of the country, and a law on pensions - both of which had been stalled by nationalists in the outgoing parliament.

Each ethnic group now believes it has lost the war: the Serbs because they failed to prevent the independence of Bosnia from Yugoslavia; the Bosnyaks - the Bosnian Muslims, the largest ethnic group - because of the continued existence of a Serbian republic created by the murder and expulsion of non-Serbs; and the Croats because they feel outnumbered and unheard.

But with unemployment running at over 40% in both halves of the country, and the continued exodus of young people, job creation has become the central platform of all parties, even nationalists.

Outside a polling station near the centre of the Serbian entity's capital, Banja Luka, people said that the economy had dictated who they had voted for. "To help our children get jobs, and to live in the prosperity we used to have before the war," said one middle-aged woman. She and her husband had split their votes between the economically conservative PDP and the more leftwing SNSD.

"Identity is less and less important here by the day," said Dragana Stoisavljevic, a 33-year-old secretary and interpreter. "People have realised that what they need is a job, and a place on the road to European integration."

Few are willing to predict how that future might be brought about. As Zeljko Kopanja, editor of the Banja Luka weekly, Nezavisne Novine, says: "The truth is always buried deep within the Bosnia mountains."

Mr Kopanja describes the likely winners in the Serbian republic, the SDS, as a terrorist group which should be banned - a feeling shared by the US ambassador to the UN, Richard Holbrooke. Mr Kopanja's own newspaper's investigation into Serb war crimes led to a car bomb attack on him in October last year in which he lost both his legs.

Mr Kopanja views the election as an important milestone in turning Bosnia and its neighbours into normal countries again and placing them "on the reserve bench of the European Union".
