webTitle: No end in sight as violence hits a peak

fields.headline: No end in sight as violence hits a peak
fields.standfirst:
Barak flies without much hope to meet Clinton as Israel increases economic pressure

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel and the Palestinians fought their way deeper into a guerrilla war yesterday, on a day when the peace process lost one of its most determined champions.
fields.body:
Israel and the Palestinians fought their way deeper into a guerrilla war yesterday, on a day when the peace process lost one of its most determined champions.

For two peoples who seem resigned to an increasingly bitter and protracted conflict, the death from lung cancer yesterday of Leah Rabin, the widow of the assassinated prime minister, Yitzhak, was eerily symbolic.

Only hours before Leah Rabin's death, Israel's airborne prime minister, Ehud Barak, was reaffirming his belief that his last-ditch meeting with President Clinton in Washington could produce little respite in the violence.

And just a few hours later another diplomatic high flier got first hand experience of the Middle Eastern war.

In the city of Hebron, a bullet grazed a car in the convoy of the UN human rights commissioner, Mary Robinson. The former Irish president was touring the West Bank to investigate charges that Israeli soldiers have used excessive force against stone-throwing Palestinians.

It was unclear yesterday whether Ms Robinson's convoy was fired on by Palestinian gunmen or by militant Jewish settlers in a heavily guarded enclave in the centre of Hebron.

Ms Robinson's visit to the region has been used as a political football by Israelis and Palestinians, both seeking to make capital out of the casualties of the last six weeks.

At his meeting with Mr Clinton last week, the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, demanded an international protection force for his people. Mr Barak was preparing to resist the idea equally strenously at his meeting with the US president.

Meanwhile, at the Arab summit in Qatar Mr Arafat was voicing his determination to keep the uprising going despite the human and economic toll of the violence.

"Despite the heavy human losses which exceed more than 200 martyrs and over 9,000 injured...our people are determined, more than at any other time, to continue their holy struggle in the al-Aqsa uprising [intifada] with the help of our brothers and friends," Mr Arafat said.

For Mr Arafat and Mr Barak, the visits abroad were an escape from the deteriorating situation at home. There was a surge in casualties at the weekend, triggered by the Israeli assassination of a lieutenant from Mr Arafat's Fatah organisation. At least 15 have died since Thursday, when an Israeli helicopter gun- ship killed the local Fatah commander and two women bystanders.

Israeli military analysts have begun using the word "Lebanon" to refer to the transition of the conflict from stone-throwing protests to the nightly shootouts concentrated on Jewish settlements and Israeli military posts.

For Israelis, the word produces a shudder. The overwhelming majority were heartily glad to end their occupation of south Lebanon last May. "How quickly and with what devotion have the Israel Defence Forces transferred Lebanon to the occupied territories - not only all its failed methods, but also the security gibberish with which they stupefied our brains in the 18 years of the useless war there," commentator Doron Rosenblum said.

Yesterday, military officials told Israeli newspapers that they would spare Fatah's polit ical leaders - especially if they are members of the Palestinian legislature. However, Fatah's street fighters are apparently fair game.

"Our gunsights are aimed right now at those who take up firing positions, or who directly send people to those positions," an Israeli military official told Ha'aretz newspaper.

As if on cue, the Israeli army admitted its second assassination of Fatah officials on Saturday, when soldiers blasted two men with anti tank missiles and tank cannon. An army statement said the men belonged to a "terrorist cell" that had been firing on the Jewish settlement of Psagot.

Yesterday, Palestinian civilians spent hours collecting the burnt remains of the two men. "I found an arm and a leg and burnt flesh about 200 metres (670ft) away from the building," said Omar Hassan.

Israeli troops fired tank-mounted machine guns on the Palestinian Christian village of Beit Jalla just as Sunday morning services were ending, badly injuring a 12-year-old boy, and several other worshippers. By lunchtime, there was retaliation against the Jewish settlement of Gilo, built on land confiscated from Beit Jalla, and annexed to the southern boundaries of Jerusalem.

At a local creche, toddlers lay stretched out on the floor of their classroom amid several extended bursts of fire. "It is like a war zone," said one Gilo resident.

In Gaza, in what is now a painfully familiar routine, Palestinian teenagers marched from a refugee camp in Gaza to the Erez checkpoint, where they were fired at by Israeli soldiers. At least one teenager was shot dead yesterday.

To the south of Gaza, the violence spilled over into neighbouring Egypt, when two farmers, who were tilling fields near the border, were wounded by Israeli gunfire.

webTitle: Pass notes

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: No: 1759 Inspector Morse
fields.trailText: No: 1759 Inspector Morse
fields.body:
Ah yes, the man with the extendible legs.
No, no, that's Inspector Gadget.

So who's this Morse fellow then?
He's the ITV detective, created by Colin Dexter and played by John Thaw, who swans around pretty Oxfordshire villages in a swanky sports car, listening to classical music and intermittently braying the word "Lewis!"

Any particular reason?
Lewis is his trusty, bland sidekick, played by Kevin Whately, who is chauffeured around pretty Oxfordshire villages in a swanky sports car, grimacing at classical music and intermittently croaking the word "Sarge?"

And what have the dynamic duo been inspecting lately? Cat stuck up tree in Abingdon? Minor act of vandalism in Chipping Norton?
No, the suspiciously high homicide rate in the Oxfordshire area, as usual.

Good heavens! What is the world coming to? It's not even safe to walk the streets of Oxford any more!
Well, it won't be after the end of this week.

Is that a threat?
No it's just that the last ever episode of Inspector Morse, called The Remorseful Day, will be shown this week.

Oh I get it, yes, Re-Morse. Clever, very clever.
As you would only expect from Inspector Morse. He is a man, after all, who does crosswords.

Cryptic ones?
But of course.

Wow.
Yes, and he likes opera.

I didn't realise anyone actually liked opera.
Inspector Morse does, for he is the thinking girl's crumpet.

Curious. Perhaps it is his reverberatory tones that woo the ladies?
For sure, he is Oxfordshire's answer to Barry White.

And now he's giving up the day job, I expect he'll spend his time down the local with a pint and the crossword puzzle, a couple of jaunts to Spain with Saga, and a rather natty sideline in home security systems?
Hardly. Morse is being put into permanent retirement. There'll be no carriage clocks where he's going.

Don't show:
Any remorse.

Do show:
Endless repeats of classic Morse episodes.

webTitle: Bad timing

fields.headline: Bad timing
fields.trailText: The unhelpful scheduling behaviour of the terrestrial channels continues in the treatment of Alan Bennett's Telling Tales (Wednesday, 9.45pm, BBC2). Its first two episodes were broadcast on a Saturday, the third on a Sunday, and this week's instalments screen on Wednesday and then Saturday again.
fields.body:
The unhelpful scheduling behaviour of the terrestrial channels continues in the treatment of Alan Bennett's Telling Tales (Wednesday, 9.45pm, BBC2). Its first two episodes were broadcast on a Saturday, the third on a Sunday, and this week's instalments screen on Wednesday and then Saturday again.

When a series is scheduled this way, it's usually on the theory that critics find it harder to hit a moving target. It seemed in advance, however, that Alan Bennett could not possibly be in need of such protection, his previous series of monologues being regarded as part of television's heritage. But, as the series unfolds, you do wonder if the BBC is punishing the series for under-achievement by transmitting it like this. These are Bennett's least satisfying pieces for TV. The problem is that his previous monologues - the two series called Talking Heads - were character pieces performed by actors including himself. The new set of 10 follow the same visual grammar - a single speaker addressing the camera with minimal changes of shot - but are autobiographical soliloquies delivered by Bennett apparently as himself.

The small but stinging domestic details - Bennett's signature as a dramatist - are still there. The revelation that he sleeps in the bed in which he was born, its footboard marked by scratches from the toe-nails of his mother during her labour with his brother, will become a fact as fixed in literary biography as Proust's cork-lined room. But Bennett - a shy man who now refuses interviews - delivers his scripts hesitantly and even sometimes archly, as if tripped in the delivery by the paradox of being a recluse who delivers autobiographical monologues on TV.

The worst moment in Mike Yarwood's television series was always when the impressionist declared "And now this is me", and indifferently crooned a tune. Bennett is one of the finest writers for television but Telling Tales feels like his Yarwood moment.

webTitle: Weekend TV

fields.headline: Partners in crime
fields.trailText: Typical, isn't it? You wait all year for some decent drama on TV, and then two come along at once.
fields.body:
Typical, isn't it? You wait all year for some decent drama on TV, and then two come along at once. Quite literally at once: Cold Feet (ITV) and The Stretch (Sky One) occupied the airwaves from 9pm to 11pm on Sunday night, forming a rare quality zone that the rest of the week will be hard pushed to match.

The Stretch was Sky One's "Event Of The Week" and reunited Leslie Grantham and Anita Dobson for the first time since their EastEnders heyday. While the hype surrounding this "legendary acting partnership" had to be taken with a pinch of salt, there was little doubt that Grantham and Dobson still make sparks fly, and have good claim to be regarded as the Spencer Tracey/Katharine Hepburn of the criminal underclasses.

Terry Green (Grantham) had been sent down for a murder that he said he didn't commit. This left estranged wife Sam (Dobson) as caretaker manager of his criminal empire. At first she was unsure, and expressed this through facial tics and a largely fawn wardrobe. After half an hour, though, she'd overcome her moral scruples to become The Godmother, striding around in a long black coat and a pashmina, being generally fierce. There was little opportunity for interplay between the principals in this first (of two) episodes, but when they did meet (usually during visiting time) it was magical. Imagine a post-watershed Angie and Den. "Fuck you, Terry Green, fuck you and the horse you rode in on," she spat. Terry was imperturbable. "You kiss our kids with that mouth?" he asked, with those infuriating hooded eyes and half-smile that used to enliven Albert Square.

Most of Sunday's episode belonged to Dobson, and she grabbed the opportunity with both hands. Confronting her daughter's wife-beating husband, she stripped the varnish off the office panelling with a stream of red-hot invective. Toying with the corrupt police officer who seems to have framed Terry, she went all breathy and girly before delivering a verbal kick in the nuts. Occasionally she huddled, fragile but brave, in the back of a chauffeured car, staring out over bleak London landscapes like a lonely monarch. She even got to sing a song (Sam Green was, we discovered, "the former dancer and 70s singer") to welcome Terry home from prison. This took place in the nightclub in which Terry had shares, the sort of place that always features in crime dramas, replete with pole dancers. Pole dancers are getting a lot of TV work these days, as a cipher for criminality. In The Stretch, they even featured in the title sequence.

Apart from Grantham and Dobson, there were some tasty cameos and supporting performances. Luke Goss (yes, that Luke Goss) played a nasty modelling agent, all moisturiser and hair gel, who tried to intimidate our Sam in a posh restaurant. Nicholas Day was all jowly threat as dodgy DCI Frank "Raquel" Welch, groping Sam with one hand and faking forensics with the other. Next week, Grantham gets a bigger bite of the cherry; we can only hope that there's a future for Terry and Sam Green thereafter.

Cold Feet returned for its third series as lively and as original as ever. At the beginning, it was all looking a bit too much like a life insurance advert, with healthy young couples and obliging toddlers running around in sunny parks. But reality kicked in soon enough, with poor old Pete (John Thomson) discovered naked on Rachel's sofa ("I hope that's not a skidmark") and protecting his modesty with an empty Shredded Wheat packet.

TV producers are always apt to claim: "It's an ensemble piece" - usually when all the performances are of an equal blandness, but for once it's really true. It's impossible to single any of the Cold Feet crew out for special praise, although last night Fay Ripley (as Jenny) and Hermione Norris (Karen) almost stole the show. One of the children wore a horrid wig and seemed to be auditioning for a remake of The Omen, only to be shorn in a rare scene of child hair mutilation towards the end of the first half.

It says much for the pulling power of Cold Feet that it sustained momentum across two hours - for this was the obligatory feature-length double episode. By 11pm there were so many plot lines up and running that it will be hard not to keep coming back week after week; unusually, for TV characters, these are people that it's easy to care about.

Toying with the corrupt police officer who seems to have framed Terry, she went all breathy and girly before delivering a verbal kick in the nuts. Occasionally she huddled, fragile but brave, in the back of a chauffeured car, staring out over bleak London landscapes like a lonely monarch. She even got to sing a song (Sam Green was, we discovered, "the former dancer and 70s singer") to welcome Terry home from prison. This took place in the nightclub in which Terry had shares, the sort of place that always features in crime dramas, replete with pole dancers. Pole dancers are getting a lot of TV work these days, as a cipher for criminality. In The Stretch, they even featured in the title sequence. Apart from Grantham and Dobson, there were some tasty cameos and supporting performances. Luke Goss (yes, that Luke Goss) played a nasty modelling agent, all moisturiser and hair gel, who tried to intimidate our Sam in a posh restaurant. Nicholas Day was all jowly threat as dodgy DCI Frank "Raquel" Welch, groping Sam with one hand and faking forensics with the other. Next week, Grantham gets a bigger bite of the cherry; we can only hope that there's a future for Terry and Sam Green thereafter. Cold Feet returned for its third series as lively and as original as ever. At the beginning, it was all looking a bit too much like a life insurance advert, with healthy young couples and obliging toddlers running around in sunny parks. But reality kicked in soon enough, with poor old Pete (John Thomson) discovered naked on Rachel's sofa ("I hope that's not a skidmark") and protecting his modesty with an empty Shredded Wheat packet. TV producers are always apt to claim: "It's an ensemble piece" - usually when all the performances are of an equal blandness, but for once it's really true. It's impossible to single any of the Cold Feet crew out for special praise, although last night Fay Ripley (as Jenny) and Hermione Norris (Karen) almost stole the show. One of the children wore a horrid wig and seemed to be auditioning for a remake of The Omen, only to be shorn in a rare scene of child hair mutilation towards the end of the first half. It says much for the pulling power of Cold Feet that it sustained momentum across two hours - for this was the obligatory feature-length double episode. By 11pm there were so many plot lines up and running that it will be hard not to keep coming back week after week; unusually, for TV characters, these are people that it's easy to care about.

webTitle: Security forces foil Real IRA bomb plot

fields.headline: Security forces foil Real IRA bomb plot
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Fear of a Real IRA Christmas bombing campaign on the mainland was raised yesterday when a plot to detonate a 500lb bomb was revealed by security service sources.
fields.body:
Fear of a Real IRA Christmas bombing campaign on the mainland was raised yesterday when a plot to detonate a 500lb bomb was revealed by security service sources.

The homemade bomb, nuts and bolts round a core of fertiliser explosive, might have been destined for London. It was twice as powerful as that used by the Real IRA in the 1998 Omagh bombing that killed 29, and would have been the largest on the mainland since the Provisional IRA's Docklands bomb in 1996. The device was discovered by RUC officers concealed in a motorised horse box at a disused racecourse at Hannahstown, west Belfast, two weeks ago.

Dissident Republican terrorists were believed to be intending to travel to the mainland via Scotland, taking the Larne-Stranraer ferry, the route used in 1996 to Docklands. Though there was no specific intelligence about the target, police sources indicated that London would be the "logical" target.

Yesterday police said they had intercepted a van with a "barrack buster" mortar in Co Fermanagh on Saturday night. Two shots were fired by police and four men were arrested.

Last week the anti-terrorist branch in London warned of a possible terrorist offensive in the run-up to Christmas, and urged public greater vigilance. However, Scotland Yard has not changed its level of alert in response to the latest discovery. It has been on amber for more than a year, meaning high concern over a terrorist threat, but no intelligence indicating one is imminent.

The size of the bomb and the intended target may indicate a change in tactics from the Real IRA. Since the outrage caused by Omagh, a tactical catastrophe, the dissident group has used "nuisance" or propaganda attacks.

Earlier this year the London rail network was halted; last month in an audacious attack a missile was fired at MI6 headquarters in London.

The horsebox bomb may indicate a return to a policy of taking lives to hammer home opposition to the peace process. Police believe Real IRA may still try other means to explode a large device before Christmas.

Security sources believe the group has 100-150 active supporters, armed with explosives and rocket launchers, with membership rising.

webTitle: Leader: Labour has lost its way over the FoI bill

fields.headline: The freedom trail
fields.standfirst:
Labour has lost its way over the FoI bill
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The puzzle about Labour's capture by the machine - if that is what explains the great retreat from its own 1997 white paper on freedom of information to the Gruyère-like bill that reaches its report stage in the House of Lords tomorrow - is just why ministers think official knowledge has become "theirs" to cherish and protect.
fields.body:
The puzzle about Labour's capture by the machine - if that is what explains the great retreat from its own 1997 white paper on freedom of information to the Gruyère-like bill that reaches its report stage in the House of Lords tomorrow - is just why ministers think official knowledge has become "theirs" to cherish and protect. Jack Straw and Tony Blair could yet be out at the next election. Then, their faces pressed against the smoked glass of Whitehall, they might once again, as they did before May 2 1997, see virtue in letting the rest of us look in.

What is especially hard to explain is why they think the present bill's anal-retentiveness is in Labour's political interest. Defence, foreign affairs and such classes of information are one thing. We might not agree with Mr Straw on the height or opaqueness of the barriers around them but they are recognised by even the best of the world's FoI regimes. The problem lies with domestic information that, freed up, might make Labour's own objectives easier to realise - for example, improving public safety.

Take data gathered by the health and safety executive, say about a site where employer negligence may have been responsible for an accident. Labour's bill would exclude it from public view whether or not the data was relevant to a prosecution - in other words, the state does not have to show any "harm" would be done by disclosure. Even in its let's-be-matey with business mood, Labour surely must want to align itself with better protection of the public. Instead its yen for secrecy puts it on the side of the coverers up - visibility or at least the threat of transparency are surely preconditions of safer operations, by road, rail or in corporate life at large.

This bill, which had its second reading in the Commons as long ago as April, came late to the Lords and is now in the thick of the traffic jam holding up the transport bill, the right to roam, the end of fur farming, etc. Perhaps because even Mr Straw sees that a failure to legislate would be a catastrophe, towards the end of last week the Home Office semaphored concessions in the direction of the Liberal Democrats. The amendments the government may now accept sound substantial and might even turn the bill into a half loaf. But in the light of past evidence of Labour ministers' attitude towards an issue at once so emblematic and so substantial, no one should hold their breath.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Peter Snow, having replaced the gaskets blown while reporting the US election results, can build up a whole new head of steam for the fifth series of Random Edition (11.0am, Radio 4).
fields.body:
Peter Snow, having replaced the gaskets blown while reporting the US election results, can build up a whole new head of steam for the fifth series of Random Edition (11.0am, Radio 4). It starts with Charles ll's triumphant return to London, as recorded by The Parliamentary Intelligencer for May 1660. The programme tracks the King's Restoration progress, from his overnight stay with Colonel Gibbon in Rochester to the Banqueting House in Whitehall.

Brian Humphrey had one knee replaced on the NHS. But, when the other needed replacement 18 months later, he was sent to a nearby private clinic to avoid blotting Southampton General's waiting list return. He had the same surgeon but vastly different surroundings, as Jenny Cuffe discovers in Saving The Patient (8.0pm, Radio 4). In the first of four programmes about the new public-private health concordat, Cuffe explores the health service's often mad culture of constant penny-pinching, occasionally interrupted by random extravagance.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Edward Scissorhands
fields.body:
Edward Scissorhands

(Tim Burton, 1990)

6pm, Sky Premier

Funny-peculiar fantasy from Tim Burton's fertile mind. This is in the fairy-tale style of Beetlejuice, with Johnny Depp as the strange, black-clad Edward, created by barmy Vincent Price and left with large scissors where his hands should be. For a time he's sheer delight for suburban Dianne Wiest and daughter Winona Ryder - but he's finally obliged to cut up rough.

Payback

(Brian Helgeland,1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Mel Gibson had a serious falling out with director Helgeland, replacing him to reshoot and add new scenes to a thriller that isn't as hardboiled as it would like to be. It's a rerun of Point Blank, John Boorman's version of Richard Stark's novel The Hunter, with Gibson trying to fill the considerable Lee Marvin role as Porter, a-hard-as-coffin-nails hood double-crossed and left for dead, and now returning to get even with the Outfit. Punchy entertainment, with veterans James Coburn and Kris Kristofferson are among the heavies.

Once Upon A Time In America (Part I)

(Sergio Leone, 1983)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Leone's homage to America and its movies is a sprawling gangster saga spanning nearly 50 years in the lives of five Jewish hoods - the full four-hour version, not the mutilated 140-minute one. Like his Westerns, it's a potent mix of grand vista, intense violence, and reflection. Robert De Niro is compelling as Noodles, a powerful man eaten up by the guilt of a betrayed friendship; James Woods highly charged as a manic crook. Plus an august, swirling Morricone score. It continues tomorrow night.

The Internecine Project

(Ken Hughes, 1974)

11pm, Carlton Cinema

Gangly James Coburn carries this flashy thriller. Landing a big job at the White House he has to cover up a murky secret service past in Britain, so arranges for the likes of Harry Andrews, Ian Hendry and Julian Glover to murder each other.

webTitle: Mark Lawson salutes Inspector Morse

fields.headline: Watching the detective
fields.standfirst: Back in 1987, TV executives were adamant - British audiences would never get Inspector Morse. Now, as it takes its final bow,  Mark Lawson salutes the show which changed the face of mainstream drama
fields.trailText: Back in 1987, TV executives were adamant - British audiences would never get Inspector Morse. Now, as it takes its final bow, Mark Lawson salutes the show which changed the face of mainstream drama.
fields.body:
Television is a dynastic form: most programmes are descended in some way from previous series. The bastard progeny of the first successful docu-soaps - Driving School and Airport - still litter the schedules. If the BBC's new hit quiz show The Weakest Link were a person, then the Child Support Agency would be contacting ITV's Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? for maintenance payments.

This programming DNA, though, generally only lasts for a couple of generations of schedules before being replaced by stronger new seeds. There are very few shows which make a permanent impact on the television gene pool, their characteristics visible elsewhere for decades. At some level, every Controller or director embarking on a classic serial is trying to remake ITV's Brideshead Revisited, while Channel 4's Brookside permanently changed the way in which soap opera is filmed and written.

And Inspector Morse (Wednesday, 8.30pm, ITV) - this week screening its final episode, The Remorseful Day, 13 years after the first - invented a genre of drama. From Dalziel And Pascoe through The Wexford Mysteries to The Midsomer Murders, the two-hour television pseudo-movie based on a paperback by an English crime-writer has become like the postman in the Father Brown mystery, quite unnoticed as it goes about its work. The brief establishing scenes divided by white-on-black opening credits as classy instrumental music plays are now as familiar as a newsreader's crisp "Good evening."

But it's an important lesson for television - especially at a time when new formats are nervously pre-tested with focus groups - that the length, pace and tone of Inspector Morse were initially rejected by executives as a ridiculous imposition on the patience of viewers.

Some of the objection was to content - Morse's opera habit and Oxford home seemed to some a little BBC - but it was the shape which brought most disdain. It was firmly believed that you could only hold viewers on their sofas for two hours with a Hollywood hit. Detective fiction at the time, led by Anglia's adaptations of PD James's Dalgliesh novels, divided books into six one-hour episodes, although, at the time Morse was born, the BBC had just begun to experiment with movie-hybrid films of Agatha Christie's Miss Marple stories.

Now that a format which appalled has become the television norm, the factors in the success of Inspector Morse can be understood. The first was the instinct that a large mainstream audience might respond to being flattered by the look and sound of a show. The best adjective for the series has always been the American word "toney": the opera and Oxford colleges were the kind of glamorous trappings often used in adverts. Morse's scripts were written by distinguished theatre writers (Anthony Minghella, Julian Mitchell, Peter Nichols, Charles Wood) and directed by people (Herbert Wise, Peter Duffell, Danny Boyle, Antonia Bird) with serious movie form before or afterwards.

It's also notable that a surprising number of the landmark pieces of TV drama - Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy; One Foot In The Grave; The Singing Detective and Inspector Morse - have centered on morose middle-aged men. Perhaps this is because so many of the core television audience either are grumpy fiftysomethings or have easy access to one.

And Morse was played by the performer who, apart from Alec Guinness, best understood small-screen acting. The inspector is a coarser character in the novels by Colin Dexter, verging sometimes on dirty old man. Thaw refined him, making Morse a moral conscience in a vintage car. The trick of characterisation on television is the ability to convey thought through an expression. The producer of Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy tells a story about Guinness going through the script crossing out his lines. Most actors ask for more but Sir Alec would rather say it with his face.

It's easy to imagine Thaw also swapping a speech for a creasing of his eyes or cheeks. In this week's The Remorseful Day (written by Stephen Churchett, directed by Jack Gold), the detective is suffering from stomach ulcers, but Thaw's grimaces are merely exaggerated by these symptoms. What he always conveyed in the long, pained looks of Morse was a constant moral indigestion. Revealingly, there are two false moments in the final film and both result from that frequent moment of unease in TV drama when a person alone speaks aloud. Kevin Whately's Sergeant Lewis, for example, is forced to exclaim "damn and blast!" after losing a suspect he's trailing. Thaw would have been trusted to speak it with his features.

Morse's maker (in a televisual sense) died 11 years ago. Kenny McBain, the producer who forced Morse through a sceptical ITV system, was killed by cancer horribly young, shortly after the series received a Queen's Export Award for its overseas sales. He never even had a chance for his name to become as famous as the others associated with the series, but his memorial is a form of television fiction which has become the goal of all channel controllers.

webTitle: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Harrison Ford in Dead Heat On A Merry-Go-Round
fields.body:
Harrison Ford in Dead Heat On A Merry-Go-Round (Bernard Girard, 1966)

Who? Renowned former carpenter, whose big break came with George Lucas's American Graffiti (1973) - the pair later worked together again on a little art project called Star Wars. Ford became the king of franchises, appearing in the two further Star Wars movies, and starring three times as whip-wielding archaeologist Indiana Jones. Despite the fact he's pushing 60, Ford's now set to play Indie again, although he might have to replace the whip with a walking stick. Regrettably, he tried his hand at romantic comedies in the 90s (no sequels planned for Six Days, Seven Nights or Random Hearts), before playing the decidedly un-heroic professor in the career-saving thriller What Lies Beneath. And don't say "midlife crisis", but last week he split with his wife of 17 years, and was then pictured in the National Enquirer with 30-year-old actress/walking rake Lara Flynn Boyle.

The role: Uncredited Bell Hop. He works in a hotel where con artist Eli Kotch (played by world's coolest man James Coburn) is attempting to pull a scam.

Best line: It's not strictly best, as there's nothing to compare it to. He simply walks around the foyer shouting "Paging Mr Ellis."

Cringe factor: Low (other than looking like a pubescent).

Other wannabes: Rose Marie - who plays Margaret Kirby here - re-invented herself playing sassy Sally on the Dick Van Dyke Show in the 60s.

Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin calls it an "involved but entertaining crime drama".

Also not starring in: Luv, a 1967 Jack Lemmon comedy, as an uncredited hippy. He also appeared as an airport worker in 1970's Zabriskie Point.

Dead Heat On A Merry-Go-Round, 6pm, today, Sky Cinema

webTitle: Jacques Chaban-Delmas

fields.headline: Jacques Chaban-Delmas
fields.standfirst: Reforming French prime minister and Bordeaux city boss frustrated in his presidential ambitions
fields.trailText: Reforming French prime minister and Bordeaux city boss frustrated in his presidential ambitions
fields.body:
Jacques Chaban-Delmas, who has died aged 85, was prime minister of France between 1969 and 1972, and played a high-profile role in his country's politics for more than 40 years. He was a leading figure in the Gaullist movements of the fourth and fifth republics and sat in the national assembly almost continuously from 1951 until his death. He was also one of France's most celebrated regional political bosses, using his position as mayor of Bordeaux to build up a network of alliances and clients, which transcended party barriers and led to him becoming known as the Duke of Aquitaine.

A man of liberal views, ingratiating charm and inexhaustible energy - he played tennis at international level - Chaban-Delmas possessed driving ambition, and yearned to scale the summits of the state. Yet his 1974 candidature in the presidential election that followed the death of Georges Pompidou failed disastrously, and he never quite overcame the suspicion of his colleagues that he lacked the political substance, and perhaps even the integrity, to be president.

Chaban-Delmas was born into a relatively modest Parisian family. He also decided to make Bordeaux the basis for his political operations, and became its deputy-mayor. This was an astute choice in that the Bordeaux bourgeoisie needed an authentically patriotic, yet modernising, leader to help it overcome its notably unheroic record during the occupation.

Chaban-Delmas quickly demonstrated an ability to ride the two horses of liberal reformism and Gaullist nationalism that became the hallmark of his appeal. On the one hand, he served in several fourth republic governments, including one formed in 1954 by the liberals' hero, Pierre Mendes France; on the other, he was a member of de Gaulle's court in exile, which was happy to ignore constitutional proprieties in order to bring their champion back to power. Thus, as defence minister in the Gaillard government, he participated in the plots and plans which, in 1958, took advantage of the worsening Algerian crisis to bring down the hated fourth republic.

With de Gaulle back in power, Chaban-Delmas showed his drive, and his talent to please, by getting himself elected president of the national assembly against the general's own candidate. The truncated role of the assembly in the new republic was not to stop government governing, and he proved a diligent agent of Gaullist power. But he also took care to flatter the susceptibilities of his parliamentary colleagues and develop his reputation as a progressive reformer. In a regime whose characteristic style was repressive authoritarianism, these were substantial assets, especially when allied to a lounge lizard style that led him to be nicknamed Charming Delmas.

Surrounded by bright, young civil servants, and even some trade unionists, Chaban-Delmas developed a programme of achievable social reform, which could transcend the rigid absolutes of Gaullism and communism. Although the national assembly was utterly irrelevant to the drama that exploded on to the streets of Paris in May 1968, its president, who used the crisis to launch his Kennedyesque vision of a new society, began to look increasingly attractive to a right, which badly needed to demonstrate that it, too, had a social conscience. Thus he was an obvious choice for prime minister once Pompidou had won the presidential election which followed de Gaulle's resignation in 1969.

As prime minister, Chaban-Delmas tried to turn his new-society theories into concrete policies aimed at softening the harshnesses of France's system of social relations. With the help of a reformist socialist, Jacques Delors, he introduced measures to liberalise an authoritarian broadcasting network and improve industrial relations, which were characterised on both sides by sullen ill-will.

Unlike any of his predecessors, he visited the downside of France's much trumpeted economic miracle, the dreadful slums around Paris, in which many immigrants had to live. Even Mitterrand acknowledged his sincerity.

Yet good fortune soon deserted him. He lacked the personal authority to impose his views on his colleagues; on the parliamentary Gaullist party, which, once the 1968 panic was over, was all for cracking down on lefty subversion; and, above all, on President Pompidou. Urged on by political advisers who detested Chaban- Delmas as an irresponsible reformer and a frivolous politician, Pompidou rarely concealed his scepticism for what he contempt- uously referred to as the "so-called new society", and was irritated by what he saw as its creator's failure to recognise presidential supremacy.

By 1972, Chaban-Delmas's government was in trouble, and he, himself, was under attack. After the poor result of the referendum on British membership of the EEC, Pompidou demonstrated his displeasure by depriving him of all responsibility for broadcasting. In May, Chaban-Delmas tried to consolidate his position by asking for, and getting, a massive vote of confidence from the national assembly. But he failed to obtain presidential approval for this act of independence, and, six weeks later, Pompidou sacked him. It was a brutal demonstration of where real power lay in the fifth republic.

Out of office, Chaban-Delmas sought to establish himself as heir apparent to the Gaullist legacy - or, to put it more bluntly, as the natural successor to the dying Pompidou. Once again, however, things went wrong. While he was still prime minister, the Canard Enchainé newspaper had revealed that he had used tax breaks to pay no tax for several years, an omission which, though perfectly legal, cast a shadow over his claims to desire a socially more united France, and came on top of a series of corruption scandals which damaged the credibility of the Gaullist governing class.

His innumerable sexual conquests, another point in common with Mitterrand, went uncriticised, but the messy circumstances surrounding the end of his second marriage accorded ill with the conserv-ative morality to which ordinary Gaullists clung.

Things unravelled rapidly after Pompidou died in April 1974. Chaban-Delmas was never convincing on television, and the speed with which he announced his presidential candidacy, even before Pompidou was in his grave, offended many. He also came up against the implacable enmity of the dead president's advisers, and, in particular, of Jacques Chirac, who held the key post of interior minister. Chirac has some claim to be regarded as his political assassin since he ruthlessly used his office to discredit Chaban-Delmas's electoral credibility, and to advance the cause of the rival conservative candidate, Valery Giscard d'Estaing.

By the end of the first-round campaign, the former prophet of the new society looked as archaic as the Gaullist old guard, whose prisoner he appeared to be. In a phrase that became famous, the journalist Francoise Giroud observed that to criticise his campaign was like firing at an ambulance. In the first ballot, he obtained only 15% of the vote, and was eliminated from the contest.

It was the end of Chaban-Delmas's presidential ambitions, but not of his career. He was still the boss of Bordeaux, and remained an avid player in the political game. He kept on preaching the virtues of the new society, in the hope that that their reasonableness, and his ability to transcend party lines, might yet bring him office.

To an extent, his hopes were realised. In 1978, he regained the national assembly presidency as the candidate of his erstwhile rival, Giscard, against that of his irreconcilable enemy, Chirac; and, in 1986, his name was again cited as a possible prime minister in the new climate produced by the need for cooperation between a socialist president and a rightwing assembly. Nothing came of it, but he returned, for the last time, to the national assembly presidency.

By the 1990s, Chaban-Delmas's control over Aquitaine was weakening. Ill health forced him to give up Bordeaux town hall in 1995, after a period in which he had cut a faintly ridiculous figure, endlessly running up stairs when the television cameras were present to prove that his youthful dynamism was intact. There were also signs that his management would not be spared its share of corruption scandals.

If Chaban-Delmas's national policy achievement was slender, his record in Bordeaux shows how much boss politics can achieve in big-city France. For a time, he had managed to present a more attractive face of Gaullism than that offered by many of his rivals, and the pragmatic reformism of the new society has lasted better than the grandiloquent alternatives with which it was unfavourably compared in the early 1970s.

Although he lacked the ruthlessness of Mitterrand, there were some similarities between their personal and political styles. This may help to explain why Chaban-Delmas was never fully acceptable to the hard men of power who turned Gaullism from a heroic myth into a conservative party.

He is survived by the last of his three wives and by his four children.

Jacques Pierre Michel Chaban-Delmas, politician, born March 7 1915; died November 10 2000

webTitle: Hugh Paddick

fields.headline: Hugh Paddick
fields.standfirst: Versatile actor with a repertory from radio comedy to Brecht
fields.trailText: Versatile actor with a repertory from radio comedy to Brecht
fields.body:
Each week in Round The Horne, one of BBC radio's most sublime comedies of the mid-1960s, Kenneth Horne would go in search of new trends. A famous example: "Today, many of the best films are made by the small independent film units. Recently, I visited the office of one such company. The sign on the door said Bona Prods, so I prodded and entered. Hello, anybody there?"

The response, given by actor Hugh Paddick, who has died, aged 85, became an immortal catchphrase: "Oh, hello. I'm Julian, and this is my friend, Sandy."

Julian and Sandy, played by Kenneth Williams, spoke in Polari, a bizarre mixture of the Romany language and homosexual streetcode. Here is Julian explaining Bona Prods' version of Samson and Delilah: "Well, I see Samson as huge and butch, with great bulging thews and whopping great lallies, with a long blonde riah hanging right down his Jim and Jack.

"The film opens with him lying spark out in his paliasse. Suddenly, there's a movement behind the arras, and who comes trolling in but this palone, Delilah. She vadas his sleeping eek, and she pulls out this pair of scissors and lops off his riah. Then they drag him up the king's lattie and chain his lallies to a pillar."

Scripted by Barry Took and Marty Feldman, it was daring and radical material for the time, especially in a popular radio series. Homosexual acts were only decriminalised in 1967, two years after Round The Horne was first broadcast, as a revamped version of an earlier show, Beyond Our Ken.

The urbane Horne was essentially straight man to a troupe of gifted character comedians, including Paddick, and, while Julian may have been Paddick's most famous role, he also scored as ageing juvenile Binkie Huckaback in Noel Cowardish parody sketches with Betty Marsden's Dame Celia Molestrangler.

The waspish Williams, never slow to condemn a fellow actor, especially if he thought he was being upstaged, thought the world of his "Julian" and, in his diaries, spoke warmly of Paddick's kindness as a man, and of his "subtlety and brilliance" as a performer.

Paddick was a farmer's son who failed his bar exams and disappointed his family by then enrolling at a drama school. Tall and handsome, as a young man he played conventional leading roles, working for Liverpool repertory theatre for many years.

His big break came when he landed the role of Percival Browne, in the West End production of Sandy Wilson's 1920s' musical pastiche, The Boy Friend, in 1954. Coincidentally, Took and Feldman named Julian and Sandy after Wilson and Salad Days writer, Julian Slade.

More West End parts followed, often in revue, and, after his success in Beyond Our Ken and Round The Horne, Paddick became a regular fixture on radio and television. As a performer, he was far less camp than Williams, and was thus able to take on a greater variety of parts, often playing exasperated officials, or acting as straight man on television to comedians such as Tommy Cooper, Jimmy Tarbuck and Morecambe and Wise.

He starred in two series, Pardon My Genie, for Thames in 1972, and Can We Get On Now, Please?, a legal sitcom with Sheila Steafel, for Granada in 1980. Much earlier, he had supported Elsie and Doris Waters in their own ITV series, Gert And Daisy, in 1959. He also appeared in the third series of Blackadder in 1987.

Paddick's first love was the theatre, and he scored notable successes. He took over as Colonel Pickering in My Fair Lady, at Drury Lane in 1959, and, in 1966, he co-starred with Fenella Fielding in Let's Get A Divorce. In Robert Patrick's Play By Play, he starred opposite Sheila Hancock. He acted with Paul Schofield and Ben Kingsley in the National theatre production of Volpone in 1977, and his last stage appearances were in Michael Frayn's Noises Off (1985) and Brecht's The Resistible Rise Of Arturo Ui, in 1987. From 1960, he appeared in supporting film parts, most notably in The Killing Of Sister George (1968) and the broad farces, Up Pompeii (1970) and Up The Chastity Belt (1971).

Paddick, who described himself as "a straight actor gone wrong", was an unassuming person, who was embarrassed to be recognised in the street. He never quite escaped Julian, though and, in 1987, he and Williams recreated the fey duo for a Terry Wogan Christmas television show.

In his introduction to a book of Round The Horne scripts, Barry Took described Paddick as "one of the finest comic actors in the profession," adding: "His work on Round The Horne was immaculate, and if he ever failed to get a laugh, it was the fault of the script and not him. Hugh is the sort of man who lightens the lives of those around him, a joy to work with and invaluable to Round The Horne."

Paddick is survived by his partner Francis, who had been with him for more than 30 years.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Philip Purser writes: The passionate love affair between the Czechoslovak film star Lida Baarová (Obituary, November 9) and the Nazi regime's propaganda minister, Dr Josef Goebbels, may not have ended when Adolf Hitler angrily ordered them to part, after entreaties to the führer from Goebbels's wife, Magda.
fields.body:
Philip Purser writes: The passionate love affair between the Czechoslovak film star Lida Baarová (Obituary, November 9) and the Nazi regime's propaganda minister, Dr Josef Goebbels, may not have ended when Adolf Hitler angrily ordered them to part, after entreaties to the führer from Goebbels's wife, Magda.

According to one well-placed witness, the lovers continued to meet. The assignations took place at the Berlin home of Baarová's fellow-actress Hilde Koerber, who was also a native of Czechoslovakia.

Koerber was then the wife of Joseph Goebbels's most-trusted film director, Veit Harlan, who made the notorious 1940, anti-semitic feature film, Jew Süss. Their son, Thomas, told me a few years ago how, as a schoolboy, he would peep through his bedroom window and watch the elaborate precautions to ensure that the coast was clear when the propaganda minister's car drew up.

Certainly Lida Baarová was still in Berlin in 1938, when her last German movie, Liebeslegende, or Preussische Liebesgeschichte (Prussian Love Story), was completed. Thanks to the scandal which by then attached to her name, it was not shown.

webTitle: New waves

fields.headline: New waves
fields.trailText: American Cousin is in a panic about the plague of mobiles. She dreads the Circle Line. Yesterday she sat on it opposite a young woman who was yelling into a lilac mobile, writes Michele Hanson.
fields.body:
American Cousin is in a panic about the plague of mobiles. She dreads the Circle Line. Yesterday she sat on it opposite a young woman who was yelling into a lilac mobile. As she babbled, the other passengers grew restless. They wanted to be chatting and blipping as well. A Mexican wave of mobile usage started up. The chap next to her got out a grey one, the businessman opposite grabbed for a black one, another fellow fished out a red one. Soon they were all at it, fiddling and poking and saying nothing in particular.

No wonder Cousin is going round the bend. Everywhere she goes there are crowds of users, shoulders and necks squidged together, gripping the mobile, yattering away in a hundred languages, so that the world must be just a great frizz of radio waves, zipping about between the millions of mobiles.

Where are these waves going? Through Cousin's body, perhaps. They can go through anything: earth, sky, sea, houses. Surely they must be jiggling us about in some way, thinks Cousin, disturbing things, brewing up secret tumours and causing the floods. She can't for the life of her understand how it all works and neither can I. I have barely got to grips with the two tin cans and a length of string.

Luckily, our house is mobile free, unless the Daughter is here. For years, she and her mobile have been conjoined. As we drove along the stinky Holloway Road yesterday, she was staring and poking at it in the usual way. Bip, bip, pokety-poke. What was she doing? "Text messages," she snapped, concentrating fiercely. The messages told her to phone people, so she blabbed all the way to the shops. And in the shops. The phone rang repeatedly. Diddly widdly, yap yap, ring, twiddly diddly.

What a worrying world. And now, as I write, Dubya is nearly president. We are all done for. American Cousin is suicidal, but it all fits her theory. W Bush's sentences seem rather scrambled. Has something been jiggling his brain about? Does he have a mobile?

Everywhere she goes there are crowds of users, shoulders and necks squidged together, gripping the mobile, yattering away in a hundred languages, so that the world must be just a great frizz of radio waves, zipping about between the millions of mobiles. Where are these waves going? Through Cousin's body, perhaps. They can go through anything: earth, sky, sea, houses. Surely they must be jiggling us about in some way, thinks Cousin, disturbing things, brewing up secret tumours and causing the floods. She can't for the life of her understand how it all works and neither can I. I have barely got to grips with the two tin cans and a length of string. Luckily, our house is mobile free, unless the Daughter is here. For years, she and her mobile have been conjoined. As we drove along the stinky Holloway Road yesterday, she was staring and poking at it in the usual way. Bip, bip, pokety-poke. What was she doing? "Text messages," she snapped, concentrating fiercely. The messages told her to phone people, so she blabbed all the way to the shops. And in the shops. The phone rang repeatedly. Diddly widdly, yap yap, ring, twiddly diddly. What a worrying world. And now, as I write, Dubya is nearly president. We are all done for. American Cousin is suicidal, but it all fits her theory. W Bush's sentences seem rather scrambled. Has something been jiggling his brain about? Does he have a mobile?

webTitle: It's official: girls hate PE

fields.headline: Down with sport!
fields.standfirst: It's official: girls hate PE.  Anna Davis remembers why
fields.trailText: It's official: girls hate PE. Anna Davis remembers why.
fields.body:
There's a particular scent-cocktail in girls' changing rooms. Sweat, feet, cheap body spray. The overall stench is like ancient cheese doused in vinegar. And when the showers are switched on, the stink gets worse. You have to shower even if you aren't sweaty or muddy. Even when you've been freezing your tits off on an icy hockey field while Mrs Rees showed off her expertise ("This is how you dribble, girls"). She's issuing orders: "Leave your towels on your benches and no running. If I see you haven't washed properly, I'll make you shower again."

When you're 13 and your body is going weird, the last thing you want is to take your clothes off and form a queue while Mrs Rees ticks your names off on her register. If you forget your towel, you drip-dry. And you can't help but stare at Tracy's boobs because they're, well, enormous. Tracy catches you looking and you turn purple. There's a whisper going round about Mrs Rees, too: "She's a lesbo. She likes it when we're naked."

Mrs Rees should have joined the army. My first lesson, Kit Inspection, ended in detention. We sat cross-legged with our kit folded in front of us while she marched up and down. We were supposed to have our names embroidered on the outside of the Aertex shirt, gym skirt, shorts and lurid yellow hockey socks - as well as name tags inside. My mother had refused to do this or allow me to: "What a waste of time. They just can't be bothered to learn your names." Try telling that to Mrs Rees.

Having your period didn't get you off Games unless you had a note from your mum. And even then Mrs Rees took some convincing - she kept another register with everyone's dates on it. Verrucas would get you out of showering but you needed something impressive to avoid the lesson. Bronchial asthma would do, or broken bones or sudden vomiting.

A government report released last week found that girls hate PE and drop out early because of the archaic attitudes of teachers, the skimpy old-fashioned kit and the physical fascism that often goes with the teaching of team sports. "But team games are the best training for life," Mrs Rees would say. So I learned that hockey was all ankle-clobbering and netball was about running back and forth pointlessly. Then there was rounders. You chose to field far away from the action - nobody could hit the ball all the way out there, could they? "Anna - catch! Catch! . . . What is wrong with you?"

Yup, great training, particularly the excruciating choosing of teams. I'd stand there as the number of girls around me dwindled, transmitting a message telepathically to the swaggering captains: "Choose me next. Me. I'm one of you, not one of them. Can't you see that?"

As a result of last week's report, the Youth Sport Trust and Nike have launched a government-backed initiative to encourage more girls to do sport. It recommends schools allow modern kit such as baggy tracksuits and sweatshirts - which must be an improvement on the embroidered hockey socks. It also advises greater choice of activity - dancing, aerobics, gymnastics.

Wait a minute, though. Isn't this all rather familiar? I could have sworn they said this last year and the year before that. And anyway, we did gymnastics at school - trouble was, the only activity we covered was vaulting, leapfrog-style, over a box. "Don't be such a wimp, Anna. You're a tall girl with long legs - it should be a doddle." And I'd bounce half-heartedly off the springboard and land - thud - on the top, straddled on my tender bits.

I'd like to think this initiative will result in more than a few bright posters of smiling faces on the walls in the stinky changing rooms. I hope it does. But I suspect they'll have to get rid of Mrs Rees if anything is really going to change.

Anna Davis's latest novel, Melting, is published by Sceptre.

webTitle: Day in the life

fields.headline: Day in the life
fields.standfirst: Last week, parliament voted to call it a day at 10pm - a move driven by women MPs. But if they struggle to juggle their days, how do other women manage their time? Interviews by  Diane Taylor
fields.trailText: Last week, parliament voted to call it a day at 10pm - a move driven by women MPs. But if they struggle to juggle their days, how do other women manage their time? Interviews by Diane Taylor.
fields.body:
Felicity Gainsborough lives in Bristol with her two children, Sebastian, 11, and Tippi, seven. She works as a staff nurse.

6.30am I get up and start getting everything ready for the children. This is the quietest time of the whole day for me. I separated from my partner two years ago and at the same time Sebastian became ill with ME.

6.45am I wake Sebastian up. He is making progress and has gone back to school but I never know how he'll be in the morning. Sometimes he has aches and pains but today he doesn't seem too bad. This is the time of day when the children are most likely to tell me things - it also happens to be the most inconvenient time to listen.

7.30am To the bus stop to drop Sebastian off, then it's back home and Tippi gets ready for school and I get ready for work. Drop Tippi off, park my car nearby and walk one and a half miles to the hospital - there's never any parking there.

9.30am I start work on the colo-rectal surgical ward. It's physically demanding and emotionally draining because a lot of the patients have cancer, so they need lots of support.

3pm Grabbed a 15-minute break and a sandwich a couple of hours ago, but by now I'm on my knees. It's an extremely busy ward and a lot of the care is very technical: pumps, drips, drains and epidurals. The patients really appreciate the little things you do for them. I washed one's feet and cleaned her teeth, and managed to arrange a wheelchair so a man who's been here since September can have a day out with his family.

3.30pm Pick up Tippi, then Sebastian, then go home for half an hour's quiet time. I'm lucky because my ward manager has been wonderful about allowing me to work flexible hours to fit around school.

4.30pm Supervise homework, prepare food and get the children ready for bed. It all takes a long time.

9.30pm I've read a story and now the children are in bed. I try not to let the day's tasks drag on much longer. I feel tired most of the time.

Claire Curtis-Thomas, Labour MP for Crosby, lives in Liverpool with husband Michael, niece Angel, 17, and children Georgina, 12, Carla, 10, and Lewis, two.

1am Carla has got food poisoning and is projectile vomiting. I clean her up and change her sheets.

6.30am Eight changes of sheets later, I emerge from Carla's room to see to the other children, making sure they're bathed and dressed and ready for school and nursery. Meanwhile Michael deals with the night's washing and looks after Carla.

8.30am The children go to school. I have to delay travelling to Westminster to take Carla to the doctor while Michael collects the others from school. He's given up work so he can stay at home and look after the children while I commute to parliament. I phone Westminster to say I'll be later than expected.

4.30pm I finally leave for London. On a normal day, I'm in the office first thing and spend the first two or three hours going through all the correspondence that has arrived. No time to grab any food.

11.30pm It takes me seven hours to travel down today, but I do answer 60 constituents' letters on the train. The kids call me on the mobile, asking me to arbitrate on a row over who has possession of the TV remote control. I've missed the meetings, debates and committees I'd normally attend during the day, but I'm still in time for a late sitting which doesn't finish until after 2am. We usually get one night a week when the debate ends at 10pm but then there can be eight votes that take you up to midnight. The other nights, business can go on until 2am, 3am or even 4am. I don't think keeping these hours does anything for the quality of the debate - and it takes me a month during recess to get over it. I'm looking forward to the concession on hours which means we'll finish at 10pm. This situation is very wearing for everyone and my children can't escape the stress. It's said finishing at 10pm is family-friendly but it's pretty strange families that work until 10 every night. I don't see why we can't work 9-5.

Mya Elmalem is a single parent who lives in London with four-year-old Jake. She has a full-time job as a youth worker and is also studying for a distance learning degree in informal and community education.

7.30am The mornings are the part of the day I find hardest with Jake because he always says he doesn't want to go to school and refuses to get dressed. Today I go through the usual performance with him. He just sits on the sofa and refuses to get ready. I shout at him because we're going to be late.

9.30am Back home from school and time to study for my degree. I have to be very disciplined about getting my work done. It's a nightmare combining this with the youth work job, which is 35 hours a week, and looking after Jake, but I know it will be worth it in the end. I'm 21 now but when I'm 25 and Jake is eight, I will have my degree and will be able to walk into a well-paid job in youth work which could mean much more civilised hours than the ones I work now - usually afternoons, some evenings and some weekends.

3pm I go to work and Jake goes to an after-school club. Then he is picked up by his childminder. She collects him two days a week, I collect him two days a week and my mum collects him one day a week. I do get support from my family but I also pay out a fortune in childcare and it takes army precision to make sure that everything is sorted out for Jake and I get my work done. Work is very busy. Today I'm doing cooking with a group of boys. Many of them have never even picked up a can opener before and nobody's tried to teach them because they can be quite wild.

10pm I finally get home. Jake won't go to sleep until he's seen me and his bedtime is the best part of the day because everything is more relaxed. I read him lots of stories: his favourite is Guess How Much I Love You.

11pm The day finally ends. I try to study for a little while, but I'm exhausted. I know my life won't always be this stressed but this is the way I have to live for the next four years if I want to improve things for Jake and myself.

Alison Dishington lives in London with husband Neil, who works with computers in a city bank, and Izzy, six, James, five, and Matthew, two. She does not go out to work.

7am Matthew comes into our bedroom to wake us up. I go downstairs with him because I don't want him to wake the other two children up yet.

7.30am Izzy and James come down for breakfast, then disappear back upstairs and I have to hound them to get dressed while I do their lunchboxes. We finally leave for school and just make it for the 8.50 bell.

9am I do something with Matthew most mornings, take him to a music group or mother and toddler group. I think it's important for him to socialise with children his own age, so it's back to horrible-coffee-and-disgusting-biscuit mornings.

2pm Matthew goes to sleep. This is an oasis in the day and it's nice just to have the silence. I can shower, make calls and cook without having the children round my ankles . Before I had them, I worked for a company that makes wedding dresses. I kept on a bit of work for them after Izzy was born, but once James arrived I simply didn't have the time.

3.20pm Matthew wakes up and we collect Izzy and James from school. James has one of his friends over and I help them make chocolate crispie cakes, which they love. I'm getting lots of questions from all of them about when Christmas is - they don't have any real sense of time, so don't realise it's a way off yet.

6.45pm Bathtime. I find the hours after school go so quickly, especially now they have things to do at home. I listen to Izzy read and try to have them in bed by 7.30pm. This is about the time Neil gets home, so he doesn't always see them before bedtime.

8pm Neil and I have a meal, then listen to music or watch TV, and before we know it, it's bedtime. The time just flies by. When Izzy and James were little, we used to take life as it came and it didn't matter if we were still in our pyjamas at noon but now school is a factor we can't take things that casually any more.

webTitle: Leader: Bush should rein in his lawyers in Florida

fields.headline: Keep up the fight
fields.standfirst:
Bush should rein in his lawyers in Florida
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Fight the Florida fix. Its latest manifestation is Bush buddy James Baker's outrageous bid to persuade Miami's federal court to block a full manual recount in Palm Beach county today. Mr Baker, openly suggesting that local poll officials may fiddle the outcome, also wants a halt to recounts elsewhere. This is a blatant attempt to thwart an accurate return in a state election awash with irregularities. What are the Republicans scared of?
fields.body:
Fight the Florida fix. Its latest manifestation is Bush buddy James Baker's outrageous bid to persuade Miami's federal court to block a full manual recount in Palm Beach county today. Mr Baker, openly suggesting that local poll officials may fiddle the outcome, also wants a halt to recounts elsewhere. This is a blatant attempt to thwart an accurate return in a state election awash with irregularities. What are the Republicans scared of? Judging by a partial manual recount in Palm Beach that showed Democrat Al Gore gaining votes, and given that the nationally decisive, state-wide margin between him and George W Bush is down to about 283, the answer is plain.

What has happened to the Republicans' oft-repeated argument that voters, not lawyers, should decide last Tuesday's presidential election? By becoming the first of the two parties to take federal court action, George W Bush and his advisers perform a complete volte-face after claiming to be guided by lofty, altruistic principles. They are terrified that the final, official, certified Florida result, whenever it comes, may go against them. Hence Mr Baker's desire for a quick, unrevised verdict and his sudden concern about "human error". Mr Baker should know all about the latter. It was his hapless campaign strategy that cost George Bush Snr his re-election bid in 1992 and ushered in eight years of Clinton-Gore.

Fight the Florida fix. Palm Beach aside, evidence of malpractice grows in poor, urban, Democratic-inclined Miami-Dade, an area with a history of fraud, and two other counties. These are not wild claims. In all, 6,000 individual complaints have been lodged in the state capital. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has collected hundreds of sworn affidavits from angry voters. They allege that one "lost" Miami ballot box, number 501, was found in a church four days after the poll. Three other boxes also went missing. The affidavits claim that many queuing to vote were turned away (which is illegal); that despite holding voting cards, others were not allowed to vote because the electoral rolls were faulty; and that a lot of voters were given invalid, pre-punched ballots. Local Democrats say 17,000 ballots cast in Miami-Dade's black and immigrant precincts are being treated as "suspicious"; and they, too, will rightly push for recounts. If they are denied by local courts and there is prima facie evidence of malpractice and racial discrimination, the US justice department and the FBI are legally obliged to step in.

Fight the Florida fix. Despite the now proven inaccuracy of the first state-wide count, Mr Gore remains under intense pressure to concede the presidency. Newspaper editorials, here and in the US, urge him to act in his country's "best interest" and dive on his sword. Let us explode some of the half-truths peddled by the wine bar wafflers. There is as yet no US "constitutional crisis": the Clinton administration is in office until January 20. There is no rush: the Electoral College can convene any time between now and then. The delay is not "dividing the nation": it is already divided, right down the middle, as the election showed. Nor will there be a country-wide recounts epidemic (unless panicking Republicans start one). Mr Bush is not "acting presidential": a real, unifying leader would support the Florida investigations.

Americans want a clean result, not any old result. An opinion poll today shows that 72% back the Florida recounts, despite the time they take up. They want what Mr Gore, but apparently not Mr Bush, wants: a fair contest, scrupulously assessed, according to the rules.

The delay is not "dividing the nation": it is already divided, right down the middle, as the election showed. Nor will there be a country-wide recounts epidemic (unless panicking Republicans start one). Mr Bush is not "acting presidential": a real, unifying leader would support the Florida investigations. Americans want a clean result, not any old result. An opinion poll today shows that 72% back the Florida recounts, despite the time they take up. They want what Mr Gore, but apparently not Mr Bush, wants: a fair contest, scrupulously assessed, according to the rules.

webTitle: Warning as 'Good Samaritans' die on motorway

fields.headline: Warning as 'Good Samaritans' die on motorway
fields.trailText: Police yesterday warned motorists to be cautious when stopping on the motorway, after three Good Samaritans were killed as they tried to help the victims of an overturned car.
fields.body:
Police yesterday warned motorists to be cautious when stopping on the motorway, after three Good Samaritans were killed as they tried to help the victims of an overturned car.

A removal van driver and a couple in a Range Rover died when an articulated lorry ploughed into the scene of the accident at Dishforth on the A1M in North Yorkshire.

Three passengers in the overturned car, two women and a man, all from Leeds, were killed and their driver is in intensive care in Harrogate district hospital. The driver of the articulated Sainsbury delivery lorry, 54-year-old Brian France from Barnsley, South Yorkshire, was arrested after being treated in hospital for minor injuries and he was bailed pending further inquiries.

Officers dealing with the accident on Saturday afternoon praised the humanity of the would-be rescuers, but said that the dangers of stopping on motorways could not be over-emphasised.

Sergeant Steve Burns of North Yorkshire police said: "The whole tragedy is that three people have become victims themselves because they did what you or I would have done and went to help. I would say to others who find themselves in a similar position: take as much care as you can."

The six victims are expected to be named today, after relatives have been informed. The overturned car, a Vauxhall Carlton, struck the central reservation in clear weather while travelling south, rolled over and slid on to the hard shoulder.

The driver of the removal van, from Cheshire, pulled up behind the Carlton to offer help while his mate ran to the back of the van to warn approaching traffic. The couple in the Range Rover, from Thirsk in North Yorkshire, stopped in front of the wrecked car and went to comfort its occupants until help arrived.

Police believe part of the removal van may have been jutting out into the motorway lane when the Sainsbury's lorry struck it from behind. The collision forced the lorry on top of the Carlton. A 100 tonne crane and firemen with acetylene cutting equipment were needed to reach the crushed car.

Yorkshire's helicopter ambulance, which has only been in service for a fortnight, took the two casualties to hospital while the removal van driver's mate was treated at the scene for shock.

webTitle: UK 'jeopardising' chance to create forecasting hub

fields.headline: UK 'jeopardising' chance to create forecasting hub
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: There could be storm clouds brewing - or at the very least a deep depression settling over the Met Office. A former chief has challenged the defence department's decision to move Britain's forecasters from Bracknell in Berkshire, their home for 40 years, to Exeter in 2003.
fields.body:
There could be storm clouds brewing - or at the very least a deep depression settling over the Met Office. A former chief has challenged the defence department's decision to move Britain's forecasters from Bracknell in Berkshire, their home for 40 years, to Exeter in 2003.

Lord Hunt of Chesterton, formerly Professor Sir Julian Hunt, and once a director of the Met Office, argues that the move would take the forecasters further away from their best customers, and from colleagues at Reading University and a European Centre for medium range weather forecasting nearby.

The Met Office staff are civil servants, but they must operate as a business, selling information to the armed forces and other government agencies. They also sell forecasts to armed forces across Europe and to airlines. Suddenly, says Lord Hunt, the outlook has become less bright.

"The Met Office has a strong European position," he said. "It has a very strong link with the European Centre and one of the possible locations is the field at the Met Office college next to the European Centre, which is an extraordinary possibility of finally bringing the British Met and the European Met together in a sort of European campus. It is also one mile away from a five-star meteorology department in Reading. It's a godsent opportunity."

Last week Lewis Moonie, the defence under-secretary, announced that the Met Office, with its 1,000 staff and the most powerful supercomputers outside America, would set up its new home in Exeter. "It has all the necessary links and local facilities for a world-leading weather centre," he said.

Alternatives were to move to Reading or Norwich or to stay in Bracknell. The first has built up a powerful meteorology department, the second is the home of a world-class centre for climate research. The Met Office at Bracknell is also home to the Hadley centre for climate prediction and research, at the heart of debate about global warming.

Lord Hunt said: "Other government agencies moved to Taunton and elsewhere and they had difficulty recruiting high level staff. To be blunt about it, there are probably 30 people in the Met Office who are absolutely crucial, they are the highest level computing and scientific people. You can find new managers and probably chief executives, but you can't find these people and they want to be where the action is."

The Met Office started under the Board of Trade, providing information for seamen in 1854. It joined the air ministry in 1920, and during the second world war employed almost 7,000 people.

Peter Ewins, chief executive of the Met Office, said: "Moving to Exeter will allow us to offer our customers improved services at a price they can afford."

webTitle: Epicures blanch at vegetarian caviar

fields.headline: Epicures blanch at vegetarian caviar
fields.trailText: It is black, comes in a jar, and one whiff is enough to send food purists into a dead faint.
fields.body:
It is black, comes in a jar, and one whiff is enough to send food purists into a dead faint.

After two years of secret development, Cavi*Art, the first vegetarian caviar, has been unveiled, to derision and applause in equal measures.

Its maker, Finlay's Foods, based at a retail park in Manchester, is not a concern you might identify with the luxury market for roe of sturgeon.

The product (approved by the Vegetarian Society and London's kosher council, Beth Din) comes from seaweed, deriving its caviar texture from alginic acid, a plant extract.

To the untrained eye, it looks like the real thing. Incontrovertibly, it is cheap. While a 50g jar of Beluga costs £95, a 100g jar of the veggie version costs £4.99."We are assured by experts it tastes exactly the same as Beluga," said Kevin Webb, a consultant for Fin lay's. "With the sturgeon nearing extinction, it is great news for caviar lovers."

Harrods' food hall was more cautious. "I would have to taste it first," said Charles Ribeyro, its caviar buyer, adding: "I don't understand why somebody would want a vegetarian caviar."

At a specialist shop, Caviar House in London's Piccadilly, the manager, Jean Pierre Esmilaire, was indignant. "They should look in the dictionary," he said. "Caviar can only be defined as eggs from fishes. The only taste a product like this can replicate is the saltiness. Bad caviar is very salty. Top quality, fresh Iranian caviar is not salty at all."

If it replicated anything, he said, it was not Sevruga, Osetra or Beluga, but black market caviar heavily salted to travel hidden in unrefrigerated containers. Since this is what most of us are familiar with, Finlay's is unlikely to complain.

webTitle: Police called in over Hawking injuries

fields.headline: Police called in over Hawking injuries
fields.trailText: Police have investigated an allegation that the scientist Stephen Hawking had mysteriously received a number of injuries.
fields.body:
Police have investigated an allegation that the scientist Stephen Hawking had mysteriously received a number of injuries.

The inquiry was opened when a "third party" told police that the Cambridge physicist and author of the best-selling A Brief History of Time had visible injuries. Staff at a hospital are reported to have been interviewed, but the inquiry is now closed.

Prof Hawking, 58, known for guarding his privacy, made no formal complaint to police. The Lucasian professor of mathematics is paralysed by motor neurone disease, confined to a wheelchair, and speaks with the aid of a computer voice box.

A spokesman for Cambridgeshire police said: "Allegations that a 58-year-old Cambridge man has suffered injuries were made, the cause of which were and remain unknown to us.

"We have found no evidence to support these allegations. Given the individual has not made a complaint to police, we do not wish to discuss the details of the allegations. And given the inquiry is effectively shelved, it's not fair to talk about the nature of that inquiry." However, added the spokesman, if anyone had any evidence, they should come forward.

Prof Hawking is reported to have visited the accident and emergency department at Cambridge's Addenbrooke's hospital on several occasions with various injuries but declined to explain how he got them. A hospital spokeswoman said: "He is not an in-patient at the moment."

Sir Martin Rees, astronomer royal and a colleague, said yesterday that Prof Hawking appeared to be well a week ago, and showed no sign of injuries.

He is looked after at his Cambridge home by private nurses. In 1990 he left Jane, his wife of 25 years and mother of their three children, to live with his nurse, Elaine Mason, the wife of the computer engineer who designed his voice synthesiser. They married in 1995.
