webTitle: Pumps bail out coal mines as river levels start to fall

fields.headline: Pumps bail out coal mines as river levels start to fall
fields.standfirst:
Return to normality begins, but agency warns waterlogging may bring new alerts until April
 Storm over Met Office removal
Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Production at Britain's biggest coalfield has virtually ceased since floods swamped power supplies to all but emergency and safety systems 900ft below ground.
fields.body:
Production at Britain's biggest coalfield has virtually ceased since floods swamped power supplies to all but emergency and safety systems 900ft below ground.

With flooded areas in Yorkshire reaching the size of Windermere, more than 100,000 tonnes of production has been lost at the three "superpits" near Selby, which lie directly below inundated areas around the swollen Ouse. The mines are dug far below the water-bearing strata and in no danger of flooding, but their power sub-station at Osgodby was overwhelmed a week ago. Rapid flooding saw 4ft of water enter the building within half an hour, cutting supplies to the coal faces.

The operator, RJB Mining, plans to restart coal-cutting this morning, after importing two large generators from the Netherlands and installing them yesterday. In the meantime, 100 miners a day plus sandbags and equipment have been diverted to help the huge emergency operation around Selby and York.

Elsewhere in Britain, rivers began to fall yesterday, in spite of patches of heavy rain and brief alerts - at Brighton in East Sussex, a huge storm drain was almost overwhelmed, and in Havant in Hampshire culverts were blocked by debris.

But the environment agency warned that, overall, the ground was so waterlogged over hundreds of square miles that flood alerts might continue to be given until April. A spokesman, Ray Kemp, said: "Springs which have been dormant for more than 100 years are coming back to life. Unless we have an exceptionally dry winter, every time there is rain of any considerable quantity, people can expect flooding, until growing vegetation in the spring soaks the water up."

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, acknowledged the long-term effects, saying he would hold talks with the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, about helping farmers. "We have to be aware that these are unique floods. They are causing a huge amount of damage and the government stands ready to help," he said.

Eleven severe flood warnings remained in place last night, from the Lavant in Sussex, which remains a serious threat to central Chichester, to the Ouse and Derwent in Yorkshire. Troops ferried thousands of compressed car tyres to shore up 250,000 sandbags along the Derwent, where breaches in dykes had threatened the town of Howden over the weekend.

Three great pumps ferried from the Netherlands have started draining two tonnes of water a second from Selby and two neighbouring villages. Pumps were also credited with saving parts of Chichester yesterday, when the local fire service diverted floodwater into a disused pit.

Anita Hudson, 26, meanwhile was married in style thanks to an army amphibious lorry, decked out in white bunting, that ferried her between her home in Selby and York register office. Troops also laid on a cream tarpaulin to protect the wedding outfits of Ms Hudson, her bridesmaids and her parents, before her wedding to Steve Alger, 41.

The rail network is showing signs of more normal working, but floods and the post-Hatfield repair programme continue to make nonsense of timetables. The Great Western line from Exeter and Plymouth to London ran for the first time for a week yesterday. The east coast main line to Scotland reopened, diverted round a landslip near Doncaster, and the York-Leeds line also reopened. But the Brighton to London line was closed and Railtrack warned of possible disruption in the south-east.

webTitle: Poppy day marches into a new century

fields.headline: Poppy day marches into a new century
fields.standfirst: Cenotaph remembrance service opens ranks to civilians and other faiths in wider tribute to the many
fields.trailText: Their medals flashing in the rare bursts of sunlight, thousands of veterans marched solemnly past the Cenotaph to the strains of Rule Britannia, as they had done for decades.
fields.body:
Their medals flashing in the rare bursts of sunlight, thousands of veterans marched solemnly past the Cenotaph to the strains of Rule Britannia, as they had done for decades.

But yesterday's service of Remembrance in London was a new ceremony for a new millennium, combining the best of its traditions with a fresh spirit of inclusivity.

As a poll suggested that a quarter of children have no idea what Remembrance Day is about, the organisers, the Royal British Legion, strove to guarantee its future by increasing its relevance to the community as a whole.

The wording of the brief service was amended to include overseas servicemen and women, representatives from more faiths took part and for the first time a contingent of civilians - "2,000 for 2000" - followed the 6,000 veterans in their procession.

Relatives of men shot for cowardice or desertion marched alongside evacuees, the Women's Land Army and the Ex-Services Mental Welfare Society. Even representatives of the long-disbanded Army Pigeon Service, which used the birds for vital wartime messages, were present.

For the most part, the ceremony ran according to its time-honoured rituals. As Big Ben struck eleven, the crowds hushed to observe the two minute silence, before Royal Marines' buglers sounded the Last Post.

The Queen and other royals led the laying of poppy wreaths, including one on behalf of the Queen Mother, who is still recovering after breaking her collar bone.

Tony Blair, William Hague, Charles Kennedy and David Trimble also laid tributes, watched by dignitaries including the former prime ministers Lady Thatcher and Sir Edward Heath and the mayor of London, Ken Livingstone. Representatives of the Sikh, Buddhist, Hindu, Muslim and Greek Orthodox faiths joined Jewish and Christian leaders for the first time.

But no participant was prouder than Gertrude Harris, 87, from the campaign Shot At Dawn. The group is determined to vindicate the 305 men executed during the first world war - far more than the German tally of 18, but far less than the French - whom it describes as brave soldiers who cracked under the strain.

Mrs Harris was three when her father, Private Harry Farr, was shot for cowardice near the Somme in 1916. The 26-year-old regular had spent five months in hospital suffering from shell shock and could not cope when sent back to the frontline. His court martial lasted 20 minutes and he defended himself. Despite his previous good conduct he was sentenced to execution.

Mrs Harris was 40 before she found out how her father had died. An aunt let the secret slip; the rest of his family refused to talk about him and her mother was so ashamed of the stigma that she only spoke about it in the last years before her death at 99. The execution brought financial hardship as well as disgrace, as the government stopped pensions to both widow and child. "It was dreadful, dreadful. We were thrown onto the streets because we couldn't afford the rent," said Mrs Harris, from Harrow, north-west London.

"Today is for my mother. When she saw the veterans on Armistice Day she used to say: 'Harry should have been among them. He was a brave man. He was no coward.'

"I'm proud of my father. It's been a wonderful day and it's an honour to represent not just him but all the other men."

She added: "I used to say my father was killed by Germans. But he was shot by his own people - which was murder.

"They're beginning to accept that these men weren't cowards and I hope I'm still alive when they exonerate them."

But the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, yesterday said pardons would "not be appropriate in this retrospective way".

"The question of a pardon is a very technical issue and a legal issue ... there are ways in which those who died in these particularly unfortunate circumstances can be remembered," he said on GMTV's Sunday programme.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: A jeweller was beaten up in his garage in Chigwell, Essex, before thieves drove off in his car containing £100,000 worth of jewellery. The 53-year-old man suffered facial injuries.
fields.body:
Raiders attack jeweller's home

A jeweller was beaten up in his garage in Chigwell, Essex, before thieves drove off in his car containing £100,000 worth of jewellery. The 53-year-old man suffered facial injuries.

Beatles' record goes on sale

The Beatles will today release 1, their first collection of greatest hits. It features their number one singles in Britain and the US.

One Fat Lady attacked

Two people were arrested after celebrity cook Clarissa Dickson Wright was sprayed with red paint as she signed copies of her new book, Clarissa and the Countryman, on Saturday in Norwich. Dickson Wright - the surviving half of TV's Two Fat Ladies duo - was unhurt.

webTitle: Letters: Further religious wars...

fields.headline: Further religious wars...
fields.trailText: Hywel Williams, like many Christians on the defensive, distorts the opposition's case (In defence of the Christian religion, November 10).
fields.body:
Hywel Williams, like many Christians on the defensive, distorts the opposition's case (In defence of the Christian religion, November 10).

He says, "The Christians demythologised Jupiter and his gang". So they did - by substituting another mythology derived from Mithraism, Judaism and other sources.

In contrast to Williams's assertions, it was not universally believed in the ancient world that slavery was natural. You would search the Bible in vain for texts condemning it, however, and there are plenty that support it (see Romans 13).

While many progressives were Christians, they were effective to the extent that they ignored or rejected Christian doctrine or the entrenched position of the Church. Wilberforce's campaign against the slave trade, for example, was not supported by the Church. Today there are still too many Mother Teresa types who adhere to the traditional Christian views about poverty being the will of God.

Finally, the early Christians and Jesus himself were convinced that the "last times" were at hand, that the world was about to end, many still are. Hardly a sign of belief in progress.
Barry Thorpe
Stockport barrythorpehg@beeb.net

 Hywel Williams deludes himself that "the very idea of progress is a Christian invention". It took over a millennium and a half of Christianity before any return to the Greeks' supremacy in science, literature and democracy.

As to human rights, while some Christians have obviously supported them, all too often their institutions have opposed them - and still do. Such institutions still treat women as inferior, and tell gays they should have no sex life.

Some, perhaps most, Anglican bishops want Christian values to override human rights and voted (unsuccessfully) against the churches being subject to the Human Rights Act in the House of Lords.
Keith Porteous Wood General secretary, National Secular Society

 Modern international human rights law is no more "a Christian gift", as Hywel Williams puts it, than it is a threat to Christian values, as some bishops would have it. The 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights was a response to the descent into barbarism which culminated in the second world war. Its profound moral vision reflected the diverse influences of its drafters, including all the main religions, Confucianism, liberalism, communitarianism, socialism and social democracy. It is partly for this reason that human rights values can be embraced by those of any religion and of none.
Francesca Klug
Academic director, Human Rights Act Research Unit, King's College, London

 So that's what the Inquisition was doing - defending human rights! And I thought they were just persecuting subversives. Hywel Williams's partial and comforting view of the history of Christianity misses out all of the appalling suffering inflicted in its name and fails to engage with the central argument of Joan Smith's piece (So the British have become atheists, October 30) which is that all religions deal in fairy tales.

The fact that Christianity may or may not have incidentally contributed some ideas that, in their time, were socially progressive, doesn't make the principal tenets of its belief system any less nonsensical for most people today than any other religion.
Jeff Wells
London

 If Christianity were true, it wouldn't be so easy to make fun of.
David McKeegan
Coventry dave@mckeegan.u-net.com

webTitle: Letter: Saying sorry

fields.headline: Saying sorry
fields.trailText: My talk at the CBI conference seems to have attracted some "off track" headlines (Rail chaos blamed on 'wrong trains', November 8). The truth about gauge corner cracking is that no one knows how it is caused nor the speed of propagation.
fields.body:
My talk at the CBI conference seems to have attracted some "off track" headlines (Rail chaos blamed on 'wrong trains', November 8). The truth about gauge corner cracking is that no one knows how it is caused nor the speed of propagation. This is why we have set up a task force of academics, cross-industry experts and overseas railways to guide our search. Until the task force reports it is wrong for anyone to believe that I feel heavier freight trains may be to blame. All trains impose stress on the rails. The experts will seek to determine what causes gauge corner cracking and what part, if any, freight trains play.

I realise that sorry is not enough for the major disruption, but we have embarked upon the biggest safety programme ever and this will take time.
Gerald Corbett
Chief executive, Railtrack

webTitle: Letters: Why every vote counts for the lady in blue trousers

fields.headline: Why every vote counts for the lady in blue trousers
fields.trailText: Darren Johnston of the London assembly intends to explain the benefits of the London voting system in New York in January (Letters, November 11). Perhaps he should first visit Belfast, to see an even better system. My constituents are able to number preferences for all candidates, not just two.
fields.body:
Darren Johnston of the London assembly intends to explain the benefits of the London voting system in New York in January (Letters, November 11). Perhaps he should first visit Belfast, to see an even better system. My constituents are able to number preferences for all candidates, not just two.

The US could elect a president by the single transferable vote system just as easily as Ireland does.
David Ford MLA
Alliance Whip, Stormont

 Maybe the Americans are attempting to vote for the third way. The House of Representatives, the senate and the presidency are all about as evenly balanced as you can get with such a vast electorate. Why not consensus instead of the winner takes it all system?
Matt Cooper
London me@matthewcooper.screaming.net

 We should not sneer about the inability of some Americans to accurately complete ballot papers (Letters, November 11). Any returning officer could tell you of the mess some voters over here can make with just three choices and the complex technical mechanism of putting a cross in the box next to the sole candidate of one's choice.
Sue Rumfitt
Kempston, Bedford
SueRumfitt@compuserve.com

 In Florida about 15,000 votes were disallowed because voters punched holes for two candidates. It is difficult to ascertain the exact intentions of these voters.

When I was a candidate in the 1983 UK general election, I was allowed one vote on the basis of a ballot paper which read: "I vote for the lady in the blue trousers". Since I was the only female candidate in Milton Keynes, the voting intention was clear though the method not!
Janet Nightingale
Rowley Regis, West Midlands
janet.nightingale@which.net

 Remember when Bush failed to name various world leaders? Well, we shouldn't have mocked: can any of us name the US president?
Tom Freeman
London
tomafreeman@hotmail.com

 To the experienced actor's eye, the transformation of George W Bush over the past few days has been astounding. The dilated pupils, the uncertain stares, the hammy display of false confidence, all indicate a man who is moving and behaving as he is told.

The symptoms are familiar to anyone who has been on a first-night stage with a fellow performer who is either miscast, technically out of his depth, or lazily and inadequately prepared. This is someone who no longer knows his lines, his moves, his part, or even his characterisation.

These symptoms are terrifying when multiplied to what they would become in a president under stress.
Ian Flintoff
London
tomafreeman@hotmail.com

webTitle: Letter: Racism behind bars

fields.headline: Racism behind bars
fields.trailText: Your report on the Commission for Racial Equality's investigation into racism in the prison system following the murder of Zahid Mubarek (Failings at Feltham that ended in racist murder, November 11), raises a fundamental issue that should be central to the inquiry. This relates to medical screening at the point of reception.
fields.body:
Your report on the Commission for Racial Equality's investigation into racism in the prison system following the murder of Zahid Mubarek (Failings at Feltham that ended in racist murder, November 11), raises a fundamental issue that should be central to the inquiry. This relates to medical screening at the point of reception.

This process needs to be completely overhauled as do the reception procedures in general. For many prisoners, reception remains a brutalising and alienating experience. This can be compounded by a cursory medical examination which often takes place in conditions which, as a number of prison staff pointed out to me, do not come anywhere near to conforming to the health care standards for prisons in England and Wales, which call for an average of 10 minutes per individual screening.

The insidious pressure on those staff who want to do a good job but who have to be seen not to be "weak" by taking too much time with the prisoners, the slavish adherence to the prison timetable and staff shift system, and the sheer pressure of numbers coming through from the courts can all contribute to a situation whereby those with psychological problems, such as Robert Stewart, will be missed.

It is therefore very important that the CRE investigates the impact of these processes on the reception procedures rather than concentrating solely on the formal world of performance indicators and paper goals, which often hide more than they reveal about the true nature of power in our prisons.
Prof Joe Sim
John Moores University, Liverpool LSWJSIM@livim.ac.uk

webTitle: James Bulger's killers' right to privacy

fields.headline: Vanishing act
fields.standfirst: James Bulger's killers go to the high court today, seeking an injunction that will prevent their new identities from being revealed.  Clare Dyer  looks at the repercussions if they win
fields.trailText: James Bulger's killers go to the high court today, seeking an injunction that will prevent their new identities from being revealed. Clare Dyer looks at the repercussions if they win.
fields.body:
In just a few months, the two young men who killed the toddler James Bulger will slip out of the secure units in the north of England which have been their homes for the past eight years. They will begin new lives in different parts of the country with new identities and carefully manufactured histories designed to obliterate all traces of the past.

The photographs of their 10-year-old selves, endlessly recycled in the media's iconography of evil, bear little resemblance to the stocky 18-year-olds they have become. But will the edifice built to protect them from exposure to the mob hold up? Ralph Bulger, James's father, has vowed to hunt them down, and the tabloids which called for them to be locked up for life are not going to forget them. "Recent experience tells us that if they were to be named and shamed by the media it would put them, and anyone else who resembles them, at grave risk of vigilante attacks," said Rob Allen, director of research at Nacro, the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders.

Today, lawyers for Robert Thompson and Jon Venables will ask the high court to impose a "Mary Bell" order - a permanent injunction banning the media from revealing the slightest detail of their new lives, names or whereabouts.

The pair could be released as early as February, and the construction of their new life stories has already begun. If they succeed, they will live out the rest of their lives under a shroud of secrecy, their true identities hidden from all but a handful of people. "If Thompson and Venables win, the effect will be to prohibit anyone from naming them or photographing them,"says Martin Partington, a solicitor for Trinity Mirror, one of the newspaper groups fighting the injunction. "They will effectively become non-people."

No criminal leaving custody has had such protection before. The blanket ban protecting Mary Bell, jailed aged 11 in 1968 for the murder of two small children and released 12 years later, was actually granted to safeguard her daughter, who was made a ward of court and is still under 18. There is no precedent in English law for a court to grant such a ban to protect an adult. Indeed, it seemed questionable whether there was any mechanism for doing it - at least until last month, when the Human Rights Act came into force.

The act made the European Convention on Human Rights part of English law, creating for the first time a right of privacy enforceable in our courts. But the convention also enshrines a right to freedom of expression. Lawyers have been keenly awaiting the first big test case to see how the English courts would deal with the clash between the right of privacy and the media's right to inform the public. Few foresaw that the first beneficiaries would be not pop stars or politicians but child killers.

Since their trial in 1993, Thompson and Venables have been protected by an injunction imposed by the trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, banning the media from publishing their whereabouts or any details of their daily lives. Last July, as their 18th birthdays loomed, four newspaper groups went to the high court to clarify what would happen to that injunction when the pair came of age. Would it automatically lapse? The president of the high court's family division, Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, ruled that the injunction should stay in place until today's three-day hearing. The case is seen as so important for the penal system and the protection of young offenders that separate legal teams will represent the Home Office, the attorney-general and the official solicitor, as well as Thompson, Venables and the newspapers.

In deciding cases that raise human rights issues, our courts have to take account of case law from the European court of human rights in Strasbourg, though they need not follow it slavishly. Judgments from Strasbourg show that the court rates privacy as an important right, but puts the right to free speech higher, as an essential safeguard in a democratic society.

Our senior judges, however, have been keen to carve out a right of privacy since the case of Gorden Kaye, the 'Allo 'Allo actor who was ambushed in his hospital bed by a Sunday Sport reporter and photographer while still heavily sedated after an accident. In that case, the judges reluctantly decided there was nothing they could do. Now there is something they can do and Thompson and Venables may be the first to reap the benefit.

Apart from the right to privacy, the European convention on human rights expressly allows limits on freedom of expression to prevent "the disclosure of information received in confidence". The English courts have in recent years begun to impose a duty of confidence on snoopers who obtain information by unethical means, such as trespass, listening devices or long-lens cameras.

In addition to these arguments, Venables' QC, Edward Fitzgerald - who also represents Myra Hindley - produced a novel suggestion at the July hearing that the injunction could be justified to protect the statutory right of offenders to rehabilitation. Dame Elizabeth, who will preside over this week's hearing, described that as "a most interesting question which has not yet been addressed by any court to my knowledge".

Should Thompson and Venables win, the way could be open for those other icons of evil, Myra Hindley and Rosemary West, if they ever regain their freedom, to disappear from our sight. Partington says: "The Thompson and Venables case could make new law because there has never been a situation where people have effectively asked a court to sanction them not to be people any more. It's quite a dangerous precedent. If juveniles who commit serious crimes and are not released till they are adults are given anonymity, why shouldn't everyone have it?"

The Strasbourg court has not had to rule on many clashes between the rights of privacy and freedom of expression. The closest to Thompson and Venables' case may be Z v Finland, in which the court held that the right to privacy of a woman with HIV was violated when her name, linked with the infection, was mentioned in a court judgment passed to the press. Her lawyers had argued that the revelation had dramatically affected her private and family life by exposing her to opprobrium and the risk of ostracism.

In Thompson and Venables' case, exposure could not only endanger their chances of rehabilitation and a normal life; it could put their lives at risk from revenge attacks. But protecting them may not be so simple. What about the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act, which will oblige them to reveal their murder conviction to any prospective employer?

And in the internet age, is it even possible to become a non-person? A high court injunction would ban the media in England and Wales from blowing their cover. Separate injunctions could cover Scotland and Northern Ireland. But there would be nothing to stop anonymous postings on foreign websites, or stories in any of the thousands of foreign newspapers whose online editions are freely accessible to readers here. Judges in the case of the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary allowed the press to reveal that their parents came from Gozo after learning that the information was freely available on the internet.

Whatever the outcome, the Thompson and Venables case could go all the way to the House of Lords. Lord Bingham, now the senior law lord, revealed his views in a lecture four years ago. He believed the law should protect personal privacy, but "the right must be narrowly drawn, to give full effect to the right of free speech and the public's right to know". He concluded, however: "I think it almost inevitable that cases will arise in which the need to give relief is obvious and pressing; and when such cases do arise, I do not think the courts will be found wanting."

It's quite a dangerous precedent. If juveniles who commit serious crimes and are not released till they are adults are given anonymity, why shouldn't everyone have it?" The Strasbourg court has not had to rule on many clashes between the rights of privacy and freedom of expression. The closest to Thompson and Venables' case may be Z v Finland, in which the court held that the right to privacy of a woman with HIV was violated when her name, linked with the infection, was mentioned in a court judgment passed to the press. Her lawyers had argued that the revelation had dramatically affected her private and family life by exposing her to opprobrium and the risk of ostracism. In Thompson and Venables' case, exposure could not only endanger their chances of rehabilitation and a normal life; it could put their lives at risk from revenge attacks. But protecting them may not be so simple. What about the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act, which will oblige them to reveal their murder conviction to any prospective employer? And in the internet age, is it even possible to become a non-person? A high court injunction would ban the media in England and Wales from blowing their cover. Separate injunctions could cover Scotland and Northern Ireland. But there would be nothing to stop anonymous postings on foreign websites, or stories in any of the thousands of foreign newspapers whose online editions are freely accessible to readers here. Judges in the case of the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary allowed the press to reveal that their parents came from Gozo after learning that the information was freely available on the internet. Whatever the outcome, the Thompson and Venables case could go all the way to the House of Lords. Lord Bingham, now the senior law lord, revealed his views in a lecture four years ago. He believed the law should protect personal privacy, but "the right must be narrowly drawn, to give full effect to the right of free speech and the public's right to know". He concluded, however: "I think it almost inevitable that cases will arise in which the need to give relief is obvious and pressing; and when such cases do arise, I do not think the courts will be found wanting."

webTitle: Why can't  we  elect a dead MP?

fields.headline: Why can't  we  elect a dead MP?
fields.trailText: The second most entertaining result of the American elections was the victory of a much-loved but undoubtedly dead man to the senate seat for Missouri. Mel Carnahan had died in a plane crash, but his widow announced that she would take the seat if he won; the voters duly elected the deceased. I rushed to find out if this could happen here. Alas, no. Parker's Law and Conduct of Elections says that if a candidate dies, the returning officer "countermands" the poll, which means that it is postponed to allow the political party to find another, live, candidate. The last time this happened here was 1951. How boring.
fields.body:
The second most entertaining result of the American elections was the victory of a much-loved but undoubtedly dead man to the senate seat for Missouri. Mel Carnahan had died in a plane crash, but his widow announced that she would take the seat if he won; the voters duly elected the deceased. I rushed to find out if this could happen here. Alas, no. Parker's Law and Conduct of Elections says that if a candidate dies, the returning officer "countermands" the poll, which means that it is postponed to allow the political party to find another, live, candidate. The last time this happened here was 1951. How boring.

 A pre-trial procedural hearing in the case of Barry George, aka Bulsara, charged with the murder of Jill Dando, was postponed because it was due to fall on Dando's birthday. I suppose it demonstrates the court authorities to be sympathetic to the victim's family, although it's not as if any of them was going to have to give, or listen to, upsetting evidence. In itself it doesn't matter much, but I wonder whether such extreme consideration would have been extended to families of less high-profile victims.

 An extraordinary event took place recently in one of the appeal courts in the Royal Courts of Justice. Three members of a jury gave evidence, in open court, about a case they were in. The law is strict about protecting the secrets of the jury-room. Jurors are forbidden from revealing how and why they have reached their verdicts.

The defendants had appealed because they had been told that one of the jurors claimed that a fellow juror was "bent". The appeal judges took statements from the 12 and decided to hear three of them in person. Had they decided that the juror in question was indeed tainted, they would have considered delving into the jury's deliberations, to assess whether its verdict had been affected. That, in turn, would have led to a crucial argument over whether jury secrecy breaches the right to a fair trial under the Human Rights Act. How can an accused know if the jury has given him a fair hearing if he is not allowed to ask how it reached its verdict? That discussion was averted this time, but it's only a matter of time before it comes up again.

 We journalists are accustomed to getting sued for libel from time to time by various politicos, celebs and men in dodgy suits, but we don't often have civil servants at the other end of a defamation action. In that, we differ sharply from Marc Thoma, a broadcaster from Luxembourg, who had no fewer than 63 - yes, 63 - civil servants from the Water and Forests Department after his hide. In quoting accusations against them which had appeared in a local paper, he had, they claimed - I translate - emitted commentaries both calumnious and offensive.

Anyway, Thoma lost (to all 63) because, the court ruled, he had not distanced himself sufficiently from the accusations he was quoting. Needless to say, he has gone to the European court of human rights claiming 63 breaches of his freedom of expression.

 My intention was to write a paragraph apologising for not having reminded you to invest your life savings on a racehorse called Legal Right, winner of the Thomas Pink Gold Cup at Cheltenham on Saturday. It would not have been easy, because this column is sent to the printers on a Friday, and, though confident, I could not have been 100% certain of the result. My apology would have admitted that, just possibly, another horse might have won - in which case there would have been no need to apologise.

My plans are now in confusion. Legal Right did not run on Saturday because of injury. But watch for him in future, in spite of a few negative signs. He is often lame (not good for a racehorse), and temperamental. "He drives you potty from day to day," his own trainer admits. "You can't make sense of a horse like this." Come to think of it, does he not resemble the principle he is named after?

webTitle: Letters: and other hostilities

fields.headline: and other hostilities
fields.trailText: Like other readers (Letters, November 11), I was delighted and moved to see your homage to the members of the International Brigade who fought against fascism in the Spanish civil war (G2, November 10). I was disappointed, however, that of all the testimonies included, only one, that of Penny Feiwel, recounted the part played by the British women who went to Spain.
fields.body:
Like other readers (Letters, November 11), I was delighted and moved to see your homage to the members of the International Brigade who fought against fascism in the Spanish civil war (G2, November 10). I was disappointed, however, that of all the testimonies included, only one, that of Penny Feiwel, recounted the part played by the British women who went to Spain.

The first British victim of the war was Felicia Browne, an artist who was painting athletes at the workers' Olympiad in Barcelona when the war began. She joined a republican militia and was shot on the Aragon front.

After December 1936, foreign volunteers were warned that women could not join the militias. Nevertheless, many British women participated in the fight against fascism in Spain - as nurses, doctors, journalists, secretaries and refugee workers. Like the men, they made individual decisions to join the international fight against fascism, and homage is due to them too.

Julia Johnson
Swansea

 To Sir Alfred Sherman's list of situations that echo Spain (G2, November 10), let's add Nicaragua. In Hackney a decade ago I heard a representative of the International Brigaders from the US talk about the parallels, introducing a filmed account of his comrades' moral and practical support for the Sandinistas.

Idealistic left-minded people young and old from the UK and elsewhere went out to Nicaragua in the 1980s, not to fight, but to work so that the Nicaraguans could fight and build. And to bring back word of the struggles and achievements of a small people who overthrew fascism and poured their meagre resources into building a humane and progressive society.

Brigades still go out to Nicaragua, working with fair trade co-ops and environmental and community building projects. I hope the veterans of Spain feel a fellowship with these modern counterparts.

Tim Evans
London

 G Gil (Letters, November 11) is exaggerating. I would refer him and readers to Hugh Thomas's definitive The Spanish Civil War, which states clearly that no more than a dozen Britons fought for Franco, even giving most of their names. The remarkable Peter Kemp was the only one to write his memoirs - although there might have been Britons in the Spanish Foreign Legion, which was also on his side.

Mark Taylor
London

• This page was amended on 26 November 2009. The original included email addresses for some signatories, now removed in response to a request.

webTitle: Greening our electricity

fields.headline: Greening our electricity
fields.standfirst: On the eve of the Climate Change Summit in the Hague, many consumers have still only a vague idea as to what they can do to reduce their own impacts on the earth's atmosphere.  Dr Mark Avery, Director of Conservation for the RSPB, explains what consumers can do - and why the RSPB has become an energy producer
fields.trailText: On the eve of the Climate Change Summit in the Hague, many consumers have still only a vague idea as to what they can do to reduce their own impacts on the earth's atmosphere. Dr Mark Avery, Director of Conservation for the RSPB, explains what consumers can do - and why the RSPB has become an energy producer.
fields.body:
Britain's climate is undoubtedly changing. Although the current disastrous floods cannot definitely be laid at the door of climate change they illustrate the type of extreme event which may become more common as climate change proceeds. They show that a changing world climate won't just mean nice warm summer days for UK - but maybe floods, storms and unpredictable weather.

Moreover, sea levels are rising worldwide in response to global warming. Our coasts are being eroded and threatened - particularly in south east England. Here we will have to realign the coast in order to protect it. This will involve giving back to the sea some of the land which we have claimed from it over the last few centuries. But elsewhere, millions of people's lives are threatened - low lying Pacific states and countries such as Bangladesh will be severely affected by sea level rise.

In anticipation of this week's world climate summit, the RSPB surveyed the British public's awareness of climate change. 96% of people had heard of climate change, and more than nine out of ten said they would take action if they knew it would help minimise it. However, most people simply weren't sure what they could do.

They were even less clear that almost everything we do has an impact. At home, our cookers, TV sets, computers, washing machines and boilers are responsible for a quarter of our greenhouse emissions. And over the last quarter century domestic electricity consumption has more than doubled.

It's clear that we're all going to have to work a lot harder to get the message across to people that the choices we all make are both part of the problem and can be part of the solution to these global problems.

Investing in more energy efficient goods and services will help reduce emissions and save money. Manufacturers now label domestic appliances to show how much energy each product uses - from the most efficient to the least.

Changing to environmentally friendly electricity - green electricity - will help decrease our dependency on fossil fuels.

As Europe's largest wildlife conservation organisation with over a million members, the RSPB decided to do our bit and launched our own "green energy" scheme. This scheme, in conjunction with Scottish and Southern Energy, supplies electricity from 100% renewable sources. Half of the "green electricity" comes from existing hydro plants and the rest from existing wind, sewage and gas landfill.

We are actively looking for opportunities for our own nature reserves to produce green electricity - particularly through solar and wind power.

Everyone wants to live in a cleaner, healthier world. Most people want to help the environment. But it isn't easy - it requires genuine lifestyle changes - the way we live, work and behave. Let no one doubt the power of the consumer to change things. Because climate change is largely man made, we can all do our bit to limit it. One of the simplest options is to switch to using energy from renewable sources. These will be big steps towards helping the environment and our wildlife.

webTitle: Leah Rabin

fields.headline: Leah Rabin
fields.standfirst: Israeli leader's widow, devoted to Middle East peace
fields.trailText: Israeli leader's widow, devoted to Middle East peace
fields.body:
"Where were you before, when the right were calling Yitzhak a traitor?" demanded Leah Rabin of a 250,000-strong crowd a week after the assassination of her husband, the Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin, in 1995. It was vintage Leah - feisty and direct, passionate yet unsentimental. Now, five years after his murder, she, too, has died, of lung cancer.

To many, it might seem like the end of an era. Ehud Barak, Yitzhak's putative heir, is trading insults with Yasser Arafat, and the Oslo peace process, the crowning achievement of the Israeli leader's premiership, seems to be in tatters.

Leah Rabin would probably not see it that way. Both before and (even more vigorously) after Yitzhak's death, she travelled the world campaigning for Middle East peace. Like her husband, she saw peace as an unstoppable train. When naysayers doubted that Arafat was "a real partner", she would remind them that one has to make peace with enemies, not friends.

She never forgave the Likud leader Benjamin Netanyahu for her husband's death; in her view, his violent invective led directly to it. And when Netanyahu won the election of June 1996, ousting Rabin's successor, Shimon Peres, many saw her as Margaret to his Richard III, reminding the new premier of past crimes. Detractors interpreted her fierce loyalty in a different light, and cast her as a Lady Macbeth figure.

Even on the left, some never forgave her for holding a $2,000 bank account in New York, where her husband was ambassador from 1968 to 1973. A trivial affair, maybe - a little nest-egg to help indulge her passion for Chanel suits and jewellery - but the account was illegal under Israeli foreign currency regulations, and it led to Rabin's downfall as prime minister in 1977.

Leah's weakness for fashion became the stuff of Israeli folklore. During the 1994 peace negotiations with Jordan, she lost a brooch, and reputedly ordered an entire regiment to recover it. To poorer and more hawkish Israelis, such vanity smacked of the Ashkenazi elite, and they heckled her in the old Jerusalem market.

Certainly, in terms of personality, Leah and Yitzhak were poles apart. He could be gruff and contemplative, decisive in battle but almost shy in public. By contrast, she was strident and outspoken. What they shared was a mutual admiration that lasted a lifetime, and a commitment to what they considered to be Israel's best interests.

Born Leah Schlossberg in the German seaport of Königsberg (now Kaliningrad in Russia), she came from a cultured, well-to-do family and arrived in Palestine, aged five, in 1933 - the year that Hitler took power in Germany.

A t 16, she abandoned a teacher training course to join the crack zionist regiment, the Palmach, and fell instantly in love with its deputy commander, the dashing young Yitzhak Rabin - "he seemed to me like a King David," she once recalled. They married four years later, during Israel's war of independence, when she worked as editor of the Palmach's newspaper.

She taught briefly in 1958. For most of their first 27 years, however, she commanded the home front, while Yitzhak pursued a military, diplomatic and political career. Yet she was much more than a housewife, and was infinitely more subtle and perceptive than many Israelis gave her credit for. A month ago, she criticised Barak for being prepared to sacrifice so much of Jeru- salem to the Palestinians. As she told the Pope last February, the city had a double role: it was "the political capital of Israel and capital of the three religious confessions".

Israel's right felt vindicated by those comments. But what they missed was the codicil - what Leah's husband would have done was to keep on talking to Arafat, not to treat him as an irritant. Indeed, her opinion of Arafat was probably pivotal to the initial success of the Oslo process. When Yitzhak expressed reservations about shaking Arafat's hand on the White House lawn in 1993, it was apparently she who insisted that he had to do so to attain peace.

It was the start of an unusual, and unexpectedly close, relationship. After Yitzhak's death, Arafat broke a rule of a lifetime to enter Israel and pay his condolences at Leah's Tel Aviv flat. In 1996, she told a German magazine that he was like "part of my family" - an extended gathering that also included Bill and Hillary Clinton, King Hussein of Jordan and his wife, Noor. Leah Rabin often represented Israel at forums and charities which politicians felt wary of attending.

Her dignity at Yitzhak's funeral did much to bind national wounds, as did the moving eulogy of her granddaughter, Noa Rabin-Philosoff. Yet personally, she admitted that the moment of assassination recurred endlessly in her mind, like "a repeating videotape".

Leah Rabin maintained influence to the very end. She prevailed upon a reluctant Barak to allow Peres to meet Arafat, in a bid to end the current violence. And her daughter, Dahlia, and son, Yuval, continue to bear the torch of peace.

Leah Rabin, peace campaigner, born April 8 1928; died November 12 2000

webTitle: Railtrack to deliver profits warning

fields.headline: Railtrack to deliver profits warning
fields.trailText: Railtrack is today expected to issue a profit warning when it delivers its first set of figures since the the Hatfield rail disaster in which four people died.
fields.body:
Railtrack is today expected to issue a profit warning when it delivers its first set of figures since the the Hatfield rail disaster in which four people died.

The company, which owns and operates Britain's rail network, is set to announce a fall in half-year profits from £241m to around £150m. At the same time it is expected to warn that its full-year results will be lower than forecast be cause of the huge amount of emergency repairs it has been forced to carry out in the wake of the tragedy.

However Railtrack is unlikely to make any comment on the amount of compensation it will have to pay the train operating companies (Tocs) for the massive disruption to services the repairs have caused.

According to reports this weekend the train operators, which are losing around £2m a day in revenues because of Railtrack's decision to close track and enforce go-slow areas, are demanding up to £200m in compensation. It is believed that some are even considering withholding their track access payments, worth around £2.2bn each year, until Railtrack pays.

City analysts expect Railtrack to take a special provision in the first half of the year to cover the costs of the repair work. They expect the company to make clear the work will lead to a £50m slump in profits over the year. "Given all the operational problems this year - in the shape of the worsening delays and the Hatfield crash - it seems likely that substantial provisions will be made to cover short-term maintenance expenses. Consequently we expect the current year's results to be significantly below last year's," Deutsche Bank transport analyst Richard Hannah said.

webTitle: The five degrees: the new qualifications system for universities

fields.headline: The five degrees: the new qualifications system for universities
fields.trailText: The Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education today publishes detailed academic requirements which universities will in future need to meet to offer degree courses. These apply to universities and colleges in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and define five distinct academic levels.
fields.body:
The Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education today publishes detailed academic requirements which universities will in future need to meet to offer degree courses. These apply to universities and colleges in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and define five distinct academic levels.

The five levels correspond to Certificate, Intermediate, Honours, Masters and Doctoral degrees. Here we list the five definitions published by the agency.

Certificate level

The holder of a Certificate of Higher Education will have a sound knowledge of the basic concepts of a subject, and will have learned how to take different approaches to solving problems. He or she will be able to communicate accurately, and will have the qualities needed for employment requiring the exercise of some personal responsibility. A Certificate may be a first step towards obtaining higher level qualifications.

Intermediate level

Holders of qualifications at this level will have developed a sound understanding of the principles in their field of study, and will have learned to apply those principles more widely. Through this, they will have learned to evaluate the appropriateness of different approaches to solving problems. Their studies may well have had a vocational orientation, enabling them to perform effectively in their chosen field. They will have the qualities necessary for employment in situations requiring the exercise of personal responsibility and decision making. The intermediate level includes higher diplomas, ordinary (non-honours) degrees, and the Foundation Degree.

Honours level

An honours graduate will have developed an understanding of a complex body of knowledge, some of it at the current boundaries of an academic discipline. Through this, the graduate will have developed analytical techniques and problem solving skills that can be applied in many types of employment. The graduate will be able to evaluate evidence, arguments and assumptions, to reach sound judgements, and to communicate effectively. An honours graduate should have the qualities needed for employment in situations requiring the exercise of personal responsibility, and decision making in complex and unpredictable circumstances. Honours degrees form the largest group of higher education qualifications. Typical courses last for three years (if taken full time) and lead to a Bachelors degree with honours, having a title such as Bachelor of Arts (BA) or Bachelor of Science (BSc). Also at this level are short courses and professional 'conversion' courses, based largely on undergraduate material, and taken usually by those who are already graduates in another discipline, leading to Graduate Certificates or Diplomas.

Masters level

Much of the study undertaken at Masters level will have been at, or informed by, the forefront of an academic or professional discipline. Students will have shown originality in the application of knowledge, and they will understand how the boundaries of knowledge are advanced through research. They will be able to deal with complex issues both systematically and creatively, and they will show originality in tackling and solving problems. They will have the qualities needed for employment in circumstances requiring sound judgement, personal responsibility and initiative in complex and unpredictable professional environments. Masters degrees are awarded after completion of taught courses, programmes of research, or a mixture of both. Longer, research based programmes often lead to the degree of MPhil. Most Masters courses are taken by honours graduates, but some Masters degrees in science and engineering are awarded after extended undergraduate programmes that last, typically, a year longer than honours degree programmes. Also at this level are advanced short courses, often forming parts of Continuing Professional Development programmes, leading to Postgraduate Certificates and Diplomas. (NB The MAs granted by the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge are not academic qualifications.)

Doctoral level

Doctorates are awarded for the creation and interpretation of knowledge, which extends the forefront of a discipline, usually through original research. Holders of doctorates will be able to conceptualise, design and implement projects for the generation of significant new knowledge and/or understanding. Holders of doctorates will have the qualities needed for employment requiring the ability to make informed judgements on complex issues in specialist fields, and innovation in tackling and solving problems. The titles PhD and DPhil are commonly used for doctorates awarded on the basis of original research. Doctoral programmes with a substantial taught element lead usually to degrees that include the name of the discipline in their title (eg EdD for Doctor of Education).

Full details of the new qualifications framework can be found on the QAA's website at: http://www.qaa.ac.uk

webTitle: Udinese knocked off the top after Malesani cheats death

fields.headline: Udinese knocked off the top after Malesani cheats death
fields.trailText: Two weeks ago, Alberto Malesani was a dead man walking. His big-name Parma side - Buffon, Thuram, Cannavaro et al - were clamped to the lower half of Serie A, without a win in their opening three games, and Malesani's bloodshot eyes betrayed the pressure he was facing. "In the last days I haven't slept very well," he wearily explained. "But this doesn't mean that I'm going to surrender. I want to stay here."
fields.body:
Two weeks ago, Alberto Malesani was a dead man walking. His big-name Parma side - Buffon, Thuram, Cannavaro et al - were clamped to the lower half of Serie A, without a win in their opening three games, and Malesani's bloodshot eyes betrayed the pressure he was facing. "In the last days I haven't slept very well," he wearily explained. "But this doesn't mean that I'm going to surrender. I want to stay here."

But after successive wins against Milan and Bari, Malesani was entitled to feel more relaxed about his situation. The vultures had stopped circling. He was safe. And then on Saturday he nearly died. The Parma coach was on the way back from training when he lost control of his car on the motorway. In the resulting crash, he fractured his collar bone and had to be airlifted to hospital. But not even a close encounter with the grim reaper could stop the indefatigable Malesani. "I stared death in the face but tomorrow I'll be back on the bench," he defiantly told reporters from hospital. And so he was.

And Parma were able to display the same stubborn qualities as their coach, as they edged past Serie A leaders Udinese with two goals in the last six minutes.

Malesani's side, inspired by Portuguese winger Sergio Conceicao, was dominant throughout. The only problem was they couldn't score. Inform Patrick Mbomba missed chance after chance, as did - perhaps less surprisingly - Savo Milosevic. But just as in their previous two games, Parma found a way to win right at the death.

Sabri Lamouchi broke the stalemate six minutes from time, driving his shot home off the inside of the post. And then in injury time, French playmaker Johan Micoud capped an excellent display with a 25-yard curler, leaving Malesani ecstatic at the 2-0 victory. "When we play like this I think we can win against every team," he claimed. "We dominated the whole game and I knew that sooner or later we were going to score, it was just a matter of time."

Udinese's defeat opened up the way for Roma to return to the top of Serie A, and Fabio Capello's side took full advantage with a 2-1 win against lowly Reggina.

Roma were without Gabriel Batistuta, and found Reggina keeper Massimo Tiabi in inspired form (no, really) but even so, the result was never really in doubt, even when Erjohn Bogdani equalised Francesco Totti's opener early in the second half. The Lupi were simply too strong, and despite Tiabi's best efforts they scored the winner through Montella after 72 minutes.

Afterwards, Reggina's Franco Colomba had nothing but praise for Roma. "I think we lost to a good team," was his gracious assessment. Meanwhile Capello was typically coy, praising Montella as a "good penalty box player," but refusing to say why he has preferred playing Marco Delvecchio alongside Batistuta. "I try to play the best elements available at any given time," he stated, his poker-face giving nothing away.

On Saturday the big game between Juventus and Lazio at the Stadio Delle Alpi fizzled out to a 1-1 draw, after Marcello Salas's 25-yard scorcher cancelled out Igor Tudor's opener for Juve. But unfortunately the match will be remembered more for events off the pitch.

Sadly, the Lazio fans are at it again - this time directing their racist abuse at Edgar Davids. And then, after the taunting came the violence. During the game TV cameras showed a man being kicked unconscious for several minutes, before the police finally decided to act. An ominous forerunner for England's friendly against Italy - also at the Stadio Delle Alpi - on Wednesday night, perhaps? Elsewhere, lowly Lecce - famous for the garishness of their MCC tie-esque shirts as much as the quality of their football - displayed gladiatorial levels of courage to beat Internazionale in the San Siro for the first time in their history.

Things started badly for Lecce when they conceded a penalty after ten minutes, but keeper Antonio Chimenti made a brilliant save to thwart Laurent Blanc. And so the pattern of the match was established: Inter shots, Chimenti saves - and the only time it was broken was in the 21st minute when Davor Vugrinec put Lecce ahead.

Incredibly the scored stayed at 1-0, even though Lecce were reduced to ten men just before half-time when Alberto Malusci was sent off for hacking down Sukur. In the second half Inter even tried a four pronged attack of Vieri, Keane - reportedly about to go on loan to Reggina for a year - Sukur and Recoba but they still couldn't find a way through.

"Today I stopped everything. It was my day," explained Lecce keeper Chimenti afterwards. "But it's all the team that won. We were down to ten men and we gave our best shot. Let's enjoy this result."

And no doubt they will. But one man that won't be around to enjoy Napoli's 1-1 draw at Perugia is their chain-smoking coach Zdenek Zeman, who was today sacked after five months in charge of the Azzurri. But if he's feeling too down maybe he should remember the words of death-dodging Parma coach Malesani, who yesterday admitted that the car crash had altered his priorities. "Now I've this kind of lease of life like, isn't it good to be alive?" he chirped. And then he broke out into a smile.

webTitle: Pick of the week

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: A foul-mouthed Scottish leprechaun, a reluctant Presidential candidate, tortillas, and the Bard in the Big Apple
fields.trailText: A foul-mouthed Scottish leprechaun, a reluctant Presidential candidate, tortillas, and the Bard in the Big Apple
fields.body:
The Paula Principle
(icebox.com)
"I'm scared. I'm a moron - and if I'm elected President there'll be CHAOS!" No, that's not George W. Bush speaking but reluctant Presidential candidate Senator Chester Foster, hero of a new animated series from 'Seinfeld' supremo Larry David. If you've been pining for caustic 'comedy about nothing' since Jerry and Co. went off the air, here's your quick fix. Besides the Bush-baiting, there's more than a hint of George Costanza in the self-hating, girl-chasing Foster, who threatens to bail out of the race for the White House in this pilot episode. We're hooked already. (KS)

 View the film

The Man Who Couldn't Open Doors
(in-movies.com)
Paul Arden's spare, good-looking film is that website rarity, a genuinely original piece of work. It does just what it says on the tin - recounts the story of a man whose life is blighted by his door phobia - but employs a wry, stylised elegance which rewards anyone ready to spend 14 minutes on something more sophisticated than Flash juvenilia or movie spoofs. Selected for the Un Certain Regard strand at Cannes in 1998, it's a prime example of how the internet can extend both the life and the audience of a classy short film after a spin round the festival circuit. (KS)

 View the film

The Storm
(zucasa.com)
Copenhagen-based Thomas Eikrem looks at man, machine, and industry in a brief but evocative trawl through Danish building sites. Storm was filmed on Super 8, but with a bleached-out look makes it look much older than that. Makes contemporary Copenhagen look like post-war East Berlin. (SD)

 View the film

Welcome to Mundo Tortilla
(www.bigmagazine.com)
A wonderfully interactive flash animation that traces the history of the humble tortilla. Or, everything you wanted to know about tortilla but were afraid to ask. Highlights include the history of the tortilla through time and man's struggle to understand its true nature. Or the dos and don'ts of cooking one. Or tortilla-related FAQs. Witty, with a lively design, great sound and an unashamedly cheesy take on food, it's very tasty. (SD)

 View the film

The Ugly Little Doll: The Golden Teeth
(dreamspan.com)
When you read that this is the tale of an unworldly toy, co-opted into a grave-robbing spree by a foul-mouthed Scottish leprechaun, you'll probably stop paying attention round about the word 'by'. Which would be a shame, since you'll miss out on this enjoyably crass little animation. Creators Mischo McKay and Mike Chapman have a rude, rough-edged style which makes Tim Burton look as demure as Uncle Walt Disney by comparison. Undoubtedly the weirdest thing you'll see this week, or any other. (KS)

 View the film

Merchant/Venice
(Ifilm.com)
Kathy Acker's radical reworking of Merchant of Venice is a condensed, episodic version of the play that lasts a little over 20 minutes. The film transposes Italy for New York and mixes the Bard's prose with bits of Big Apple slang. It's an intense and claustrophobic experience: the only relief coming from some wonderful camp performances and quite possibly the longest homosexual kiss ever seen on screen. Undeniably difficult, but not unrewarding. (SD)

webTitle: Abbey National launches service for 'new affluents'

fields.headline: Abbey National launches service for 'new affluents'
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Abbey National launches its new wealth management business, to be called Inscape, tomorrow.
fields.body:
Abbey National launches its new wealth management business, to be called Inscape, tomorrow.

The business will be officially introduced by the bank at the venture's new central London advice centre. Its arrival comes five months after Abbey launched an internet bank called Cahoot.

The venture is described as a comprehensive wealth management service aimed at the one in 12 people who have £50,000 or more to invest. It will have a presence on the internet but will also offer a face-to-face service via branches.

There are more than 4m people with this level of assets and several banks apart from Abbey are pouring resources into tapping into this lucrative market. Credit Suisse, Switzerland's second biggest bank, last week launched a new online investment and banking service targeting the 7m people it has dubbed Britain's "new affluents" - those with £30,000-plus to invest.

Credit Suisse's Global Investor Portfolio account allows people to trade shares on 15 stock markets including London, New York and Frankfurt, hold cash in up to four currencies and buy unit trusts from leading name companies. Personal financial advice will be available to customers from next year.

Meanwhile earlier this year HSBC and stockbroker Merrill Lynch joined forces on a similar online banking and investment services company aimed at those with between £60,000 and £300,000 to invest.

Abbey National's new business had been codenamed "Project Prosper" - it has attempted to keep the real name a closely-guarded secret. Last night the bank refused to comment on the details of the launch.

There are more than 4m people with this level of assets and several banks apart from Abbey are pouring resources into tapping into this lucrative market. Credit Suisse, Switzerland's second biggest bank, last week launched a new online investment and banking service targeting the 7m people it has dubbed Britain's "new affluents" - those with £30,000-plus to invest. Credit Suisse's Global Investor Portfolio account allows people to trade shares on 15 stock markets including London, New York and Frankfurt, hold cash in up to four currencies and buy unit trusts from leading name companies. Personal financial advice will be available to customers from next year. Meanwhile earlier this year HSBC and stockbroker Merrill Lynch joined forces on a similar online banking and investment services company aimed at those with between £60,000 and £300,000 to invest. Abbey National's new business had been codenamed "Project Prosper" - it has attempted to keep the real name a closely-guarded secret. Last night the bank refused to comment on the details of the launch.

webTitle: Opera review: An end to histrionics at the Royal Opera House

fields.headline: An end to histrionics at the Royal Opera House
fields.standfirst:
Katya Kabanova
Royal Opera House, London ****
fields.trailText: Whoever ends up with what has been described as "the worst job in opera" - the directorship of the Royal Opera House - can at least take some heart from this revival of Trevor Nunn's bold, effective staging of Janacek's great tragedy. Although not an unqualified success musically, the production boasts several impressive singers and, happily for a company that recently has not been able to rely on the performances of its stars, a heroine of the highest calibre.
fields.body:
Whoever ends up with what has been described as "the worst job in opera" - the directorship of the Royal Opera House - can at least take some heart from this revival of Trevor Nunn's bold, effective staging of Janacek's great tragedy. Although not an unqualified success musically, the production boasts several impressive singers and, happily for a company that recently has not been able to rely on the performances of its stars, a heroine of the highest calibre.

Amanda Roocroft's return to the title role was much anticipated, following her success earlier this year at Glyndebourne as Janacek's other haunted young heroine, Jenufa. She didn't disappoint. Vocally she was on glorious form, every note beautifully placed, each inflection expressive, her phrases seamless. Her Katya was a human being rather than a tragic heroine - even in her final scene there were no histrionics. Her interpretation allowed the audience to see to the depths of Katya's vulnerability, and the audience warmed to both character and singer as a result.

In this staging, directed by David Edwards, it's not strictly up to the singers to conjure feelings of impending meltdown - Maria Björnson's designs do that adequately enough. The action takes place in a cold, glistening whirlpool, ready to suck Katya down even before her fate is sealed. A huge, sweeping net curtain hangs in front; at its root this opera is a tragedy of family relationships. David Harvey's wan, chilly lighting only warms around Katya herself. For some reason, amid all this stark abstraction, real horses pull Tikhon's carriage. It's all rather discomforting, and doesn't leave much room for intimacy - but then, in this work all the truly passionate exchanges are left unseen.

Katya's nemesis is her mother-in-law, Kabanicha. Josephine Barstow was herself a renowned Katya in her day; her Kabanicha, a clipped, sour-faced old harridan, treads the line between being seriously unpleasant and comically so, staying just on the right side. Occasionally her look and tone hint at the bitter disappointments and regrets that have made the woman what she is.

There were several other notable performances on stage: Marianna Tarasova as Varvara, Robert Dean Smith as Boris, Timothy Robinson as Kudrjas. Yet the production didn't quite achieve the opera's full sense of latent passion and violence. This was down to those in the orchestra pit. Janacek's music is economic in its expression, but it needs more light and shade, much more space than conductor Simone Young was prepared to yield. Like Katya, the players seemed constrained, unable to let themselves go, and so the score, like the obviously mimed beating received by Boris, ultimately lacked punch.

 In repertory until November 29. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Copland weekend

fields.headline: Copland weekend
fields.standfirst: Barbican, London ****
fields.body:
When, with the benefit of 21st- century hindsight, the history of 20th-century music comes to be written, it may well be that Aaron Copland assumes a more central position than he has usually been accorded.

Copland never tried, or even wanted, to create the wholly new language that characterised the music of the post-war European generation. Yet Copland grappled with ways to synthesise his creative ideals with mass-audience appeal, and attempted to define a truly American music.

As Leonard Slatkin's weekend with the BBC Symphony and Concert Orchestras demonstrated, celebrating what would have been the composer's 100th birthday, Copland's music has an enormous expressive range: from abstract orchestral pieces in his most complex idiom, to the irresistible confidence of Billy the Kid, and music written for radio, film and stage.

And yet, as revealed by the first half of Friday's programme, it's still possible to talk of one, instantly recognisable, Copland voice, whatever the surface differences of form and function of his music.

Inscape, written in 1967, was Copland's last large-scale piece. Although the work uses Schoenberg's serial technique, Copland's spacing of chords and distinctive melodic writing make Inscape rather a distant reflection of the open spaces of Appalachian Spring than a homage to European modernism. Slatkin's beautifully controlled account was perfectly attuned to Inscape's translucent world.

Copland's Piano Variations, composed in 1930, is regarded as one of his most austere works. Yet in Marc-André Hamelin's spellbinding performance, the music's references to jazz were as memorable as its modernist histrionics. In this use of other music, the Variations develop the ideas of the Piano Concerto, composed in 1926.

Billy the Kid, one of Copland's three ballet scores, is also one of his most famously populist works. Slatkin and the BBC Symphony Orchestra performed the complete score, adding picturesque depth to the better-known suite.

With the BBC Concert Orchestra, Slatkin introduced an unfamiliar programme of Copland's film and radio music. There is the same vivid directness in the 1937 Prairie Journal and the suite of Music from the Movies, compiled by Copland in 1942, as there is in his concert music of the period.

Copland's dramatic music may be his most underrated. With soloists and singers from the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, Slatkin and the Concert Orchestra performed The Second Hurricane - originally written "for high school performance" in 1936 - with moving naivety. A semi-staged performance with the BBCSO of Copland's only full-scale opera, The Tender Land, was the final instalment of this fascinatingly rich investigation of his work.

webTitle: Theatre review: The taming of the Duchess of Malfi

fields.headline: The taming of the Duchess of Malfi
fields.standfirst:
The Duchess of Malfi
Barbican, London **
fields.trailText: After superb productions for the Royal Shakespeare Company of Don Carlos and The White Devil, Gale Edwards comes up with a somewhat tame version of Webster's grisly classic. A modern-dress affair, with echoes of La Dolce Vita and Pulp Fiction, it fails to create a coherent world that can contain Webster's dark nihilism, oppositional faith and astonishing aphoristic poetry.
fields.body:
After superb productions for the Royal Shakespeare Company of Don Carlos and The White Devil, Gale Edwards comes up with a somewhat tame version of Webster's grisly classic. A modern-dress affair, with echoes of La Dolce Vita and Pulp Fiction, it fails to create a coherent world that can contain Webster's dark nihilism, oppositional faith and astonishing aphoristic poetry.

Part of the problem lies in Peter J Davison's design, dominated by a towering, glass-walled rectangular cage. It's fine for spectacular inserts such as the masque of madmen or an abattoir-like exhibition of human carcasses. But it cramps the action and its inner depths remain hidden from the side-stalls. Sue Willmington's costumes also obscure the play's crucial differences of rank. It's the Duchess's passion for her steward that precipitates events but here the sharp-suited Antonio seems as fashion-conscious as his silk-gowned employer. Even the surly spy, Bosola, appears to buy his black-leather macs at the same emporium as the crazily incestuous Duke Ferdinand.

What the production lacks is a convincing ambience or any real contest between corruption and virtue. The programme intriguingly suggests that Webster's Duchess is a Protestant martyr assailed by a wicked papistry. But although Aisling O'Sullivan's tall, red-haired Duchess is tender, loving and visually striking in her seductive lingerie, she misses the character's defiance. She is not helped by the inexplicable decision to cut Bosola's magnificent bellman's dirge. I am not asking for old-fashioned, boom-and-bust rhetoric, but a line such as "I am Duchess of Malfi still" cries out for something more than plaintiveness. The Duchess is not just a harassed widow: she is someone who greets violent death with the do-your-worst assurance of a true believer.

Having discovered a note of feminist resistance in The White Devil, Edwards strangely misses it here; even the device, once used by Philip Prowse, of bringing the Duchess back to haunt the final scenes puts pathos before tragedy. In fact, the actors who come off best are Colin Tierney as a crisply demonic, wolfish Ferdinand, Ken Bones as a Cardinal who has no compunction about copulating with his mistress against a cross, and Tom Mannion, who stepped into Bosola's bloody shoes at short notice. Mannion not only uses his Scottish accent to suggest an aggrieved outsider at a corrupt court but even makes the character's fits of conscience convincing. On a grander level, however, the production misses the vital Websterian contradiction in which destructive evil is countered by resilient goodness.

 Until November 18. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

webTitle: Pires/Dumay/Wang Trio

fields.headline: Pires/Dumay/Wang Trio
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Chamber music, as its very name suggests, was originally intended to be played in intimate circumstances - with friends, lovers or one's family. The great Portuguese pianist Maria Joao Pires has, it would seem, consciously striven to enact its inherent privacy in public. Her violinist, Augustin Dumay, is her partner; the cellist, Jian Wang, her son-in-law. The light of a standard lamp transforms the Wigmore platform into a drawing room, as the audience effectively eavesdrops on a family get-together.

Schumann and Schubert (both Pires specialities) formed the programme, which started with the latter's E Flat Piano Trio. This is one of the greatest chamber works, passing slowly from melancholy calm to extremes of despair, before hauling itself from the emotional depths to end on a note of uncertain, jittery optimism. The performance finds the Trio infinitely responsive to its gradations of mood, though not quite consistent in style. The Andante's accumulation of density, which turns beauty into horror, had chilling inexorability.

Pires played with her matchless limpidity, alternately teasing and coaxing a flawlessly coloured lyricism from Wang. Dumay adopted a broader approach. His tone is dark, sometimes shot through with acidic sharpness and he occasionally lets rip with a sweeping heft more appropriate to Brahms. He's happier with Schumann, when the Trio were joined for the E Flat Piano Quintet by Gordan Nikolitch (leader of the LSO) and French viola player Gérard Chausée.

The Quintet's manic-depressive combination of austerity and jolting emotion are better suited to Dumay's style. It's a fiddly work to get right, largely because Schumann doesn't give equal weight to the five performers. It is piano-driven, forcing Pires to set pace and tone, which she does to perfection. The string writing largely focuses on a sequence of dialogues for first violin and cello, allowing Dumay and Wang to duet and duel. Chausée has little to do until the tragic slow movement, where he comes into his own with force. Of the excellent Nikolitch we hear little (Schumann's fault, not his).

Throughout, the work's sudden swirls into manic excitement induced elation in the audience. There can't be many family get-togethers that bring the house down, as this one did.
